div1.p: The editors are very grateful to the National Endowment for the Humanities, which has generously awarded the project a three-year grant (2018–21) under the auspices of its Scholarly Editions program, and to the Research Libraries Program of the Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation, which has provided invaluable grant support for the Carlyle Letters Online. We are also grateful to the Binks Trust for its continuing financial contributions to the funding of the Edinburgh editorial team and office. The editors again express their gratitude to the British Academy, which made the Carlyle Letters a British Academy Research Project and continues to support us with an annual grant, and to the members of its Committee on Academy Research Projects and its assistant secretary, Ken Emond. The editors also express their gratitude to those private individuals who have made donations for the support of the Edinburgh Carlyle Letters office, to the University of Edinburgh Development Trust, and to Joyce Caplan and the Friends of Edinburgh University Library.

We remain extremely grateful for the advice of Paolo Mangiafico, Scholarly Communications Strategist and Co-Director, ScholarWorks Center for Scholarly Publishing, Duke University Library; and we continue to extend our thanks for early critiques of the electronic edition to David Chesnutt, formerly of the Model Editions Partnership at the University of South Carolina, and to Natalia Smith of the DocSouth project at the University of North Carolina. Brent E. Kinser serves as coordinating editor of The Carlyle Letters Online in addition to his editorial service to the print edition. DNC Data Systems of Mumbai, India, has electronically encoded volumes 1 through 46 of the Carlyle Letters. Colin Wilder and staff at University of South Carolina host the online edition at the Center for Digital Humanities.

The letters in this volume cover the two-year span from October 1871 to September 1873. During this period, TC lamented his lack of purpose even as he persistently sought ways to extend his influence upon his times. These efforts were colored by mercurial swings in his mood, ranging from mordant humor at the prospect of his demise, to nostalgia for his earlier days as a struggling writer. Inevitably, his sentimental forays into the past were undercut by his realization of the myriad sacrifices that JWC had made to secure his success, and by his unwitting neglect of her. TC was also haunted by the need to clarify his legacy, particularly in circumstances where he was surrounded by followers such as William Allingham, Moncure Daniel Conway, Charles Gavan Duffy, John Forster, James Anthony Froude, William Edward Hartpole Lecky, David Masson, Charles Eliot Norton, James Fitzjames Stephen, John Ruskin, and John Tyndall, all of whom were eager to interpret his wisdom for posterity. Referring to Conway’s assiduous attempts to befriend him, TC quipped to Emerson that “I will not employ [him], should I need a Boswell (which I never shall)” (TC to RWE, 2 April 1872). Yet TC’s anxieties about the ephemerality of his fame and authority were sharpened by the loss of relatives and friends.

The sudden accidental death of TC’s nephew James Aitken on 25 September 1871 reinforced his proclivities towards silence. To his sister, Jean C. Aitken, he wrote: “‘It is Gods holy will’ is all that any of us can say or think upon it;—and to think it so with our whole heart is far better than any speaking of it; and the sole assuagement that exists for any of us” (TC to JCA, 13 Oct. 1871). On 9 October, he received a request from Thomas Erskine’s nephew James to write a brief tribute to his father for a “pleasant & useful memorial.” TC commented to his sister Jean that “I cannot for my life think what to say about Erskine that could be suitable for the public it is meant for; but yet I suppose there will be no avoiding of an attempt to say something! I much dislike this kind of demand upon me (which comes far oftener than I could expect); but on reflecting, too, I should perhaps admit that in a case like Erskine’s especially, it has its value to me and its uses” (TC to JCA, 13 Oct. 1871). But TC could not bring himself to comment on “Saint Thomas” (Wilson, Carlyle 6:207), whose “rose-pink” Christian piety was antithetical to his more “Rhadamanthine” (Frederick the Great, Works 12:429) perspective. He sent James Erskine “about 20 … Letters” retrieved by his niece and assistant, Mary Aitken, but refused to contribute to the proposed volume (see TC to JCA, 13 Oct.).

With less reserve, TC thanked John Forster profusely for sending him the first volume of The Life of Dickens (1872–74): “I am already deep in it, sat reading there, in fact, till 2 this morng. I need not tell you, what you already guess privately and all the world will confirm, that it is of the liveliest interest, and dextrously and exactly done: easy to prophesy that it will go round the globe, and be eagerly read by thousands on thousands of men” (TC to JF, 29 Nov. 1871). Yet Carlyle was “privately” also startled by the book’s reception. He informed his brother John that “there are already subscribed for about four thousand copies” (TC to JAC, 7 Dec. 1871). In a letter to Gavan Duffy, he described the “perfect rage or public famine (Copies not to be supplied fast enough)” (TC to CGD, 12 Dec. 1871). Perhaps recalling earlier invitations issued to him by Emerson to visit the U.S., which he had considered but never acted upon, TC took particular interest in Forster’s account of Dickens’s tumultuous first North American tour in 1842. The novelist’s frank criticism of the American “bores”—a judgment that TC echoed in Latter-Day Pamphlets (1850)—and their crude manners and morals, as well as his attacks against their piratical copyright laws, had generated widespread controversy. TC confided to Duffy: “Me nothing in [the volume] so surprises as these … American explosions round poor Dickens, all Yankee-doodle-dodom blazing up like one universal Soda-water Bottle round so very measurable a Phenomenon, this and the way the Phenomenon takes it was curiously and even genially interesting to me” (TC to CGD, 12 Dec. 1871).

But TC, to whom Forster had been sending advance drafts of the book, already knew that the “comical” conclusion to the first volume contrasted sharply with the “dark” finish to the second, where Forster described the novelist’s grief at the loss of his infant daughter Dora. Dickens’s reaction to her death, quoted by Forster, resonated deeply with TC: “[H]ow often it is with all of us, that in our several spheres we have to do violence to our feelings, and to hide our hearts in carrying on in this fight of life, if we would bravely discharge in it our duties and responsibilities” (Forster, Life of Dickens 2:460). These “very tragic and very mournful” (TC to CGD, 12 Dec. 1871) words seemed to summarize TC’s own predicament as he turned seventy-six. Lionized by the public and besieged by admirers, he disliked having to keep up a posture of gratitude and seized any chance he could to escape from the commotion. With his niece, he began translating the Faereyinga Saga from a German translation and writing a brief history of the early Norse kings. It offered a respite from the tiresome “celebrity hunters” who tormented him with mundane requests. To his brother he complained, “A full week ago you were promised to have that poor ‘Preface’ to the Saga … alas, it is not yet finished, nor dare I promise it in another week. Nothing can excel or equal the interruptions & paltry obstacles that have continually come in the way of ending it: but end it I will, if spared alive;—nay, in the meanwhile, it is better
to me, with all its chaotic adjuncts, than if I had in my mind nothing at all to regard as ‘Work’” (TC to JAC, 20 Jan. 1872).

Yet “work” could not prevent TC from periodically being overwhelmed by memories of JWC and their remote Scottish past. A letter from Colonel David Davidson, childhood friend of JWC, received by TC, 12 February 1872, “with much emotn,” jolted him into a renewed bout of introspection. Davidson had recently visited JWC’s nurse and companion Betty Braid at her home in Greenend, South Edinburgh. During their conversation, she recalled JWC’s father, Dr. John Welsh, and “the circumstances of his illness & death” (Davidson, Memories 325; see AppendixBetty Braid’s Narrative). In her laconic manner, which for TC evoked “fine old Scotch practicality, and simple wisdom” (TC to DD, 22 Feb. 1872), Braid conveyed JWC’s agonized response to her father’s demise: “She was sitting on the chair, when she got up wi’ a scream, an’ cried, ‘I maun see my father!’ an’ rushed to the locked door o’ his room; but, before she could open it, Dr. Howden gat her in his airms, an’ she fainted clean awa’. He carried her through the drawing-room, ye ken, to the little bedroom aff it, an’ laid her on the bed beside her puir mother that was lying there in deid swoon; an’ there they were, like twa deid corpses!” (see AppendixBetty Braid’s Narrative). For TC, who had struggled awkwardly but persistently to live up to the heroic ideals that Dr. Welsh had embodied for JWC, this narrative recaptured a bitter-sweet phase of his existence. Betty Braid herself constituted “the last living link of scenes and places now all departed, but dear and sacred to me as no others are” (TC to DD, 22 Feb. 1872). Across the front of the envelope containing Davidson’s letter, TC wrote, “what a unique of Histories it has been to me! To be reposited in my safest place—Here.”

The death of Giuseppe Mazzini on 30 March elicited more ambivalent feelings. TC commended the Italian patriot’s steadfast devotion to the nationalist cause, which he grudgingly conceded to Conway had been successful: “He died receiving the homage of the people, and seeing Italy united, with Rome for its capital. … We wait to see whether Italy will make anything great out of what she has got” (Moncure D. Conway, Autobiography, Memories and Experiences, 2 vols. [Boston and New York, 1904] 2:67). Uneasy about Mazzini’s close friendship with JWC, particularly in the darkest stages of their marriage in the 1850s, TC preferred to distance himself from the Italian on political rather than personal grounds. But the line separating the two spheres was never clear, as TC acknowledged. On 1 February, he exclaimed to William Allingham: “Poor Mazzini! lying dead there—all done, all over. What a bright young man when he came in here in 1836 and sat on that sofa! He got into ‘solidarity’ and all manner of absurdities. He used to trouble himself about every wretched Italian who was in any way political. There was one Italian who fell in love with a danseuse and stabbed himself; Mazzini took care of him, recovered him, and persuaded the girl to marry him” (Allingham Diary 208;
see TC to JAC, 30 March 1872). TC was ignorant of the extent to which he himself had benefitted from such selfless and “absurd” behavior. It had been Mazzini who had striven to console JWC in her misery, and to counsel her to remain faithful to her husband, despite her loneliness and wretchedness (see 20:222JWC to TC, 6 July 1846, and 23TC to JWC, 7 July 1846).

As an antidote to these often painful reminders of the receding past, TC tried to keep focused on the evolving “Condition of England,” which he described in a phrase borrowed from T. H. Huxley as “administrative nihilism.” His summary of democratic culture suggested that he had lost none of his corrosive powers of analysis: “[A] Government carried on by Parliamentary palaver and Universal Suffrage, with penny newspapers presiding, must necessarily be a Do-nothingism, and neglect [not] only its Colonies, but every other interest, temporal and eternal, except that of getting majorities itself by hook or by crook” (TC to CGD, 12 Dec. 1871). At some point in spring or early summer 1872, TC began composing a pamphlet, later published by William Paterson in 1882 as Last Words of Thomas Carlyle On Trades-Unions Promoterism and The Signs of the Times. TC gave the piece, dated 12 July 1872, to his nephew John Aitken, who was helping him with business matters. In the preface to the published version, Aitken referred to it as a “Latter-Day Pamphlet,” serving as an “outline or index to [Carlyle’s] Literary Will and Testimony” (see TC to Lady A, 13 July 1872). TC covered familiar topics with biting acumen and originality: the corruption of Trades Unions (whose aims he broadly supported) from the older Guild ideal of the nobility of labor to the more recent “Mammonite” conception of an organization “avowedly for increase of wages alone” (8–9); the shoddiness and mediocrity of manufactured goods; and the continued ascendance of “Feudalism and Preservation of the Game” over “Industrialism and Government by the Wisest” (15). But in a fresh excursion, he highlighted the rise of “Promoters,” a “new-sprung Sect of people … well known in the City region just now, and spreading there like a Tropical Hemlock-Forest” (16–17) whose “trade is to devise seductive projects of companies for industrial Enterprise … of every conceivable sort, in any quarter of the terraqueous globe” (17–18). For TC, this latest scourge, sanctioned by Government deregulation of banks and financial markets, was the “Avatar or fated coming-in upon us of General Commercial Gambling.” “Promoterism,” he predicted, would transform the “sober arithmetical Counting-house of Trade” into “a Rouge et Noir Table, presided over, not by Merchant Princes but by Hungry Scoundrels” (32). Ironically, his Miltonic vision of a world in thrall to “Beelzebub & Co.” would soon be rendered in fictional form by TC’s nemesis Anthony Trollope, who began writing his very Carlylean attack against “Promoterism,” The Way We Live Now (1875), in May 1873.

TC occasionally attended public functions, though never without a faint sense of the ludicrousness of his renown as “the Chelsea Sage.” On 10 May 1872, he agreed to attend a reception hosted by Count Albrecht von Bernstorff,
the German imperial ambassador in London, in order to meet with Princess Augusta of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach, empress of Germany, and wife of Wilhelm Friedrich Ludwig, emperor of Germany from 1871. The Princess had wanted to convey her appreciation to the author of Frederick the Great for his deep understanding of Prussian history and culture, but as TC recounted to Mary, “Her English was not fluent, though correct enough … she did not seem to wish me to speak at all—and indeed, I now guess, must have had her speech probably all by heart (but don’t whisper this to any soul!),—which gives a slightly ridiculous character to the whole affair,—and entirely secures one’s head against being turned with it!” (TC to MA, 11 May 1872).

TC’s facetious tone here—reminiscent of JWC’s humor—indicated his trust and confidence in Mary, both as a companion and intellectual stimulus to him. Yet he was also faintly aware that she harbored ambitions that went beyond serving as his personal secretary, which may have been inspired by JWC’s own example. During the time in which she had helped TC to organize and edit JWC’s letters, Mary was exposed to the prodigious wit and sarcasm of a woman who had scorned the role of being a subordinate “wife of genius.” Mary was proud of her free-thinking aunt and closer to her in spirit than TC possibly cared to contemplate. Like JWC, Mary came to resent the ubiquitous barriers in Victorian society that prevented women from fulfilling their personal and professional aspirations. In a statement she added to a letter she had copied for TC to the poet and teacher Meta Wellmer, Mary held out the expectation that “the next generation of women will have a much better position than those of this one have, when trades & professions are thrown open to them. A boy has every thing open to him at present whereas a girl or young woman who does not marry has to fight a … battle for a livelihood” (TC to MW, 29 May 1872). Her own eclectic interests—women’s rights, Scottish ballads and folklore, and housing and education for the poor—reflected her independent instincts. Though fiercely loyal to her uncle, she was resolved to pursue an autonomous course. In March 1872, Mary failed in her attempt to obtain a position as adjunct to the housing reformer and activist Octavia Hill, who had been renovating properties (purchased by Ruskin) for the poor. TC encouraged her to continue searching for “an Honest livelihood and occupatn” (TC to JAC, 30 March 1872), but others in his circle were less tolerant of these endeavors. John A. Carlyle wrote to TC on 31 March, “I was extremely shocked to find that the dear little Mary had left you, & gone to face the difficulties of London life, leaving you in solitude. You & I have both of us money enough—more than we know how to make a right use of—& I cannot see why she should go out to find a Livelihood” (see TC to JAC, 30 March 1872). Long accustomed to his brother’s curmudgeonliness, TC quietly ignored his comments.

But in September, Mary’s outspokenness produced a conflict that her uncle
could not overlook. Though the precise nature of their quarrel is unknown, Mary had apparently offended Lady Louisa Ashburton by voicing suspicions to Carlyle family members that she had schemed to marry TC. Involved since the spring of 1868 in a serious (and secret) lesbian relationship with the American sculptress Harriet Hosmer (see Kate Culkin, Harriet Hosmer: A Cultural Biography, [2010] 117–18), Lady Ashburton responded angrily. She wrote to Mary’s mother, Jean C. Aitken, and asked TC to forward “the letter to Dr Carlyle, if you will to Mrs Aitken much better—as it is quite clear the poisoned tongue of calumny, added to the natural inclination to believe her own child, has made your sister take a jaundiced view of the matter” (13 Sept. 1872; see TC to Lady A, 12 Sept. 1872). In the same letter Lady Ashburton may also have implied that Mary was being disloyal to her uncle by giving priority to her own career. Desperate to mend fences, TC tried to appease Lady Ashburton while encouraging Mary to accept a position offered to her by the feminist activist Clementia Taylor and her husband, the Liberal politician and radical Peter Taylor. TC took no chances with his prickly brother, exhorting him not to “say a word agt the Peter Taylor’s; they are really very good honest-hearted people, and their ‘Philanthropy[’] &c &c won’t infect her clear little head or heart. Encourage in everything; and say, wht I really believe, that all this sorrow be for her good, and will lead to far better employt for her here than she ever cd have from poor old dreary Me and the fag-end of my days” (TC to JAC, 5 Sept. 1872). On 25 September, Mary wrote to her Uncle, announcing to him that “all my arrangements with Mrs Taylor are made—only the day of my going not fixed.” Assured that relative harmony had been restored, TC invited her to stay with him at Cheyne Row, until she was ready to assume her new position. Mary herself was evidently relieved to be returning: “I need not say, dear Uncle, that I look forward with much pleasure to seeing you again” (25 Sept.; see TC to Lady A, 28 Sept. 1872). She arrived back on 2 October, and immediately resumed her former position as TC’s assistant.

Over the next six weeks they began revising the Life of Schiller, which was being prepared for “The People’s Edition” of TC’s collected works. Edward Twisleton had given TC a copy of Ernst Julius Saupe’s Schiller und sein väterliches Haus [Schiller and His Father’s Household] (1851), which, together with excerpts from three other German books, TC intended to make into a supplement to the biography. On 26 October 1872, he mentioned to John A. Carlyle that “Mary and I are faithfully standing to our poor bit of work; the translation [of Saupe] fairly ended & mostly recopied & put right. … On the whole it keeps my hands and my head pretty full through the few working hours of the day;—and in that respect may be counted a kind of blessing to me; Saupe’s botchings and my own bother with them being better than the poor gloomy meditations which I should otherwise awake to every morning”
(TC to JAC, 26 Oct. 1872) Yet even in these modest “Dryasdust” labors, TC experienced moments of high emotion. On 2 November 1872, he told John, “Poor Schiller, the account of his death, which I read yesternight the last thing (vividly described by one Voss, who sat up with him 12 nights, and saw him the day before he died, look at his last little Baby with inexpressible love and Wehmuth [sadness], and then bury his head among the pillows in a flood of tears) brought me also to the edge of weeping, or even over the edge” (TC to JAC, 2 Nov. 1872).

On 7 November 1872 TC received a visit from Emerson, who was touring Europe and Egypt with his daughter Ellen Tucker Emerson. The American was touched by TC’s warm greeting: “He opened his arms & embraced me,” he told his wife, “and we sat down & had a steady outpouring for two hours & more on persons, events, & opinions” (see TC to JAC, 13 Nov. 1872). Two days later Emerson regaled William Allingham with instances of TC’s exuberance: “His humour runs into everything, hearty laugh, excellent company—has always something memorable to say in choice language” (Allingham Diary 216). But TC was more restrained writing to John: “Emerson was here yesterday and we had a long talk, and do muddy walk: very gentle; clear and pure on his part; but less of real heart interest coming out of it than one expected” (TC to JAC, 13 Nov. 1872). He may have been aware that the press referred to Emerson as “the American Carlyle” (see, for example, Shetland Times, 5 May 1873), and made determined efforts in his letters and conversation to repudiate the comparison.

Since the Rectorial address of 1866, and JWC’s subsequent death, TC had consciously projected a public image that contradicted the popular notion of him as a mellowed prophet. Though his respect and affection for Emerson were undiminished, he felt compelled to emphasize the temperamental and philosophical chasm dividing them. He explained in April 1873 to his new American acquaintance, the Harvard professor Charles Eliot Norton: “There’s a great contrast between Emerson and myself. He seems verra content with life, and takes much satisfaction in the world, especially in your country. … But the warld is verra black to me; and I see nothin’ to be content with in this brand new, patent society of ours” (Norton Letters 1:484–85). TC sought to distinguish himself from Emerson at the same time that he wanted to stress his intellectual compatibility with his two most prominent British protégés, Ruskin and Froude.

In his letter to Emerson of 2 April 1872, TC trumpeted their merits as committed lieutenants, though he realized that neither man was temperamentally suited to the proselytizing role that he demanded from them. In “Munera Pulveris, Oxford-Lectures on Art, and whatever else he is now writing,” TC declared, “Ruskin is copiously and desperately, pouring [fierce lightening-bolts] into the black world of Anarchy all round him. No other man in England that
I meet has in him the divine rage against iniquity, falsity, and baseness … that every man ought to have.” But TC, who knew about his disciple’s fragile mental state and his tormented relationship with Rose LaTouche, the 24–year old daughter of a wealthy Irish banker, could not conceal from Emerson that Ruskin was “not a strong man; one might say a weak man rather; and has not the least prudence of management; though, if he can hold out for another 15 years or so, he may produce, even in this way, a great effect” (TC to RWE, 2 April 1872). Froude, who planned to conduct a lecture tour on Irish history and the Anglo-Irish relationship of the U. S., October 1872, was a “most clear, friendly ingenious solid and excellent man,” and TC was delighted to hear that Emerson would be one of his hosts in the “New Country.” Froude was “the valuablest Friend I now have in England, nearly tho’ not quite altogether the one man in talking with whom I can get any real profit or comfort” (TC to RWE, 2 April 1872).

Throughout November and December, Froude’s American visit dominated TC’s correspondence. Given the antagonistic role that he had played in Anglo-Irish relations in the 1840s and 1850s, TC found it difficult to disengage himself from the controversy that Froude was stirring in the U.S. He savored the outrage that Froude met with from Irish nationalists and supporters of Home Rule, and fondly recalled the role that he had adopted as a provocateur, taunting his opponents with satire and invective. At the core of TC’s Swiftian vision of Ireland were two contradictory assumptions, which revealed a peculiar combination of radical and reactionary impulses. On the one hand, he believed that Britain was guilty of a world-historical injustice. He asserted to Forster, 22 November 1872: “In no province of human affairs at any time or in any place did I find so despicable and even ignominious and hideous an attempt at governing by any Nation. Lord help the People’s William [Gladstone] and us all!” (TC to JF, 22 Nov. 1872). On the other, he was convinced that the Irish “canaille” (TC to Lady A, 14 Dec. 1872) deserved their fate, and he shared Froude’s opinion that this feckless population was incapable of governing itself.

It was a position that TC had always held in the manner of the author of Gulliver’s Travels, employing satire and paradox to bewilder, aggravate, and disarm his opponents. Somewhat naïvely, the earnest and painstaking Froude had underestimated the impact that his hostile Carlylean rhetoric would have on Irish-American opinion. He lacked his mentor’s raucous sense of the absurd, and in the U.S. he found himself frequently outflanked by nationalists and priests who understandably endorsed his condemnation of British cruelty and hypocrisy at the same time as they excoriated him for his anti-Catholic prejudice. As he had done earlier with the beleaguered Ruskin in the Governor Eyre episode, TC dismissed Froude’s misgivings and exhorted him to persevere. In a letter to Henrietta Froude, 5 December 1872, TC lauded
her husband’s mission and instructed him to take no more regard of his critics than “the barking of dogs or the braying of asses. He may depend on it, what he is saying about Ireland is the genuine truth, or the nearest to it that has ever been said by any person whatever.” Betraying his own longing to re-enter the arena of political combat, TC hypothesized: “were I in his place, I would make next to no apologies or explanations, but quietly and firmly read my lectures in the pre-appointed places; and that done walk silently about my own business,—especially not to be too long in walking home again to my own hearth and known friends” (TC to HF, 5 Dec. 1872). Though pleased that Froude had produced such a disturbance, TC missed his company and looked forward to his return. As he admitted to John Forster on 20 December, “I wish we saw him back again safe and sound after this tremendous raid across the Border!” (TC to JF, 20 Dec. 1872). To TC’s relief and surprise, Froude returned sooner than expected. Unnerved and exhausted by the hostility that his lectures had generated, he cut short his visit and sailed from New York, 18 December 1872, arriving back in England a month later.

TC found considerable compensation for Froude’s absence in the company of Charles Eliot Norton, who had been living in London since the autumn of 1872. Recovering from the death of his wife, Susan Ridley Norton, February 1872, Norton immediately warmed to TC. He informed a friend, 27 December 1872: “I think the chief pleasure of my stay in London this year has been the frequent walks and talks I have had with Carlyle. I see him often enough to have grown familiar in some sort with him, and sincerely attached to him. … He is the most striking figure in London,—and when he dies there will be a bigger gap than the death of any other man could make” (Norton Letters 1:420). TC was equally impressed by Norton. He commended him to his brother John as a “fine, gentle, intelligent & affectionate creature, with whom I have always a pleasant, soothing & interesting dialogue when we meet” (TC to JAC, 22 March 1873). Yet tensions were already building between Froude and Norton that would have profound implications for TC’s future literary reputation. In an entry to his diary, 25 January 1873, Norton confessed: “I have never taken to Froude, and his late performance in America is not calculated to raise one’s opinion of him. His face exhibits the cynical insincerity of his disposition. Carlyle is fond of him, and assures me I should like him better, if I knew him better. But he is an out and out disciple of Carlyle, in thought and in literary form, … and Carlyle is not insensible to the flattery of being accepted as master by a man of Froude’s capacity” (Norton Letters 1:461–62). TC tried to assure Norton of Froude’s integrity, and at least temporarily, an uneasy accord was established.

In the new year, TC arranged to revise his will, the most recent version of which he had written on 6 April 1871. He asked Forster to undertake the task of drafting it, despite the latter’s poor health. He reported to his brother John:
“Poor F[orster is] still in great distress; not dangerously ill … but really in a bad fit, he admits,—incessantly coughing & with very little sleep. … During the whole of this misery Forster has been strenuously busy for me, upon a matter which you will much approve when I tell you of it on our first meeting again” (TC to JAC, 5 Feb. 1873). TC was moved by Forster’s generosity, toiling amidst considerable pain to compose his will. On 30 January 1873, TC sent him a letter of thanks: “God bless you, dear Forster;—I can never forget what you are now doing for me & have before this done” (TC to JF, 30 Jan. 1873).

In spring 1873, TC was forced, by the death of John Stuart Mill, to remember an earlier acolyte who had served him with similar fidelity. He wrote, 10 May, “Yesterday I got a great shock when Norton told [me] when we were stepping out into the street that John Mill was dead! I had heard no whisper of such a thing before; & a great black sheet of mournful more or less tragic memories, not about Mill alone, rushed down upon me: Poor Mill, he too has worked out his Life Drama in sight of me; & that scene too has closed before my old eyes, though he was so much my junior!” (TC to JAC, 10 May 1873). Carlyle’s anguish was aggravated by a letter he received a week later from Harriet Isabella Mill, Mill’s sister, who was upset by an article published in the Daily Telegraph that repeated the story of the burnt manuscript of The French Revolution. In a tender reply, TC gently advised her to forget the “babbling newspapers,” and to “dismiss [the incident] wholly from your thoughts as a thing, which to me is now grown a No-thing,—nay has even risen (by the sacred memories connected with it) to be a real possession, which it is blessed for me, & as it were sacred, to look back upon! This is truly the character of it to all that are concerned—both to me, who still linger on this Earth, & to your dear Brother whose memory alone now remains to us” (TC to HM, 17 May 1873). In forcing himself to relive the episode once more, TC exhibited the same nobility of character in the present that he had long ago demonstrated in the past. Notwithstanding the profound political and philosophical differences between them, TC could recognize the “sacred” ties that bound him in solidarity with John Stuart Mill, a fellow toiler in the Babylon of literary pursuits.
David Sorensen

div1.p: October 1871–September 1873

October. TC writes to comfort his sister Jean Aitken about her son James’s death; Mary is arranging her late brother’s affairs (13). TC is translating the Icelandic saga, Faereyinga Saga, from German, with Mary’s help. John Forster is in very poor health. Lady Ashburton arrives in London (10) on her way to Melchet to oversee repairs there.
November. TC writes his sister Jean to thank her for the new clothes sent for Mary and himself (1). He thanks Forster for the first vol. of The Life of Dickens (29).

December. TC receives many letters and messages marking his seventy-sixth birthday on 4 December. He visits Lord Houghton (4), who is unwell, in a hotel (5). He sends (6) condolences to John Ruskin on the death of his mother (5). TC sends vol. one of Forster’s Dickens for John A. Carlyle to share with the family (7). He writes to Charles Gavan Duffy (12). Brother Alick writes from Canada; TC sends the letter on to the family in Dumfriesshire (14). He sends money to his half-brother, John, in Canada. He replies to Alick in Canada (16), telling him of his pleasure at the visit in August of Alick’s two sons Alexander and James. He thanks J. H. Balfour-Browne for his dedication of a new book (20) and James Marshall for finding a cast of Goethe’s hand for Lady Ashburton (23).

January 1872. He thanks John A. Carlyle for Dumfriesshire news, sending a book by Bret Harte (20). He and Mary are making slow progress on their translation of the Faereyinga Saga (25). He agrees with John’s view of Browning’s latest book as “worth nothing at all.” TC and Mary dine at Caroline Davenport Bromley’s (24) and at the Forsters’ (28).

February. Jean has sent collars from Scotland (3). TC writes to a young lady poet, suggesting she would do better with “well written prose” (4). He tells Lady Ashburton he sleeps badly (10); he dines with Forster (11). He acknowledges payment from Chapman & Hall of royalties of £511 .. 17 .. 6 (13). He thanks David Davidson of Haddington for visiting Betty Braid (22). John A. Carlyle sends a copy of Goethe’s Symbolum for John Tyndall. TC bemoans “that monster of a Norse preface, or sketch of the Early Kings of Norway,” a “totally worthless thing” (24). He is reading Ruskin; both James Anthony Froude and John Forster are suffering from bad coughs.

March. TC complains to Smith, Elder & Co. about the late arrival of Ruskin’s Fors Clavigera numbers (12). He discusses family affairs with John A. Carlyle and is in low spirits (23). Mary is looking for work in London, so far with little success; she has apparently moved out of Cheyne Row but still comes to take dictation twice a week (30).

April. TC writes warmly to Ralph Waldo Emerson apologizing for his long silence. Emerson had advised against allowing Moncure Daniel Conway to write a life of TC. TC encourages Emerson to read Ruskin. He signals the intended arrival in the U.S. of Froude, “a most clear, friendly ingenious solid and excellent man” (2). He describes his short holiday at Belton to John A. Carlyle who is also suffering from dyspepsia (13). Forster takes TC for a country drive (14) since TC refuses dinner invitations. TC declines becoming involved with a political meeting (18) and the presidency of a new Temperance organization (22), having been invited by John Pearce. TC tells his brother John, who is expected 2 May, to bring “a bottle or two of genuine whisky” since all he can find in London is “dirty Irish” (27).

May. TC sends someone an autograph, while grumbling about it (5). He has an audience with Augusta, empress of Germany (10). He acknowledges royalty payments of £471 .. 17 .. 6 from Chapman & Hall (21), and describes Walt Whitman (in a letter to Thomas Dixon) as “the loudest-roaring blockhead in all America” (23). He thanks Clara Thomson for a pamphlet on the roles of men and women in society (26). He writes encouragingly to Charles Gavan Duffy in Australia (28). John A. Carlyle has gone to Vichy; TC reports to him an “[a]bundance and super-do of intrusive Callers” (29).

June. TC gives permission to Edward Walford to translate some of his work into Latin or Greek (14), and he congratulates Edward FitzGerald on progress in providing a monument at Naseby (15). He thanks Mary Aitken for her dealings with Elliott & Fry over their use of family photographs; she is busy and learning German (18). TC asks Jean to send a straw hat (20). He writes her again with money for various gifts; her son John visited TC on 21 June and wrote at dictation a long letter to John A. Carlyle (22).

July. TC stays at Melchet for a few days, swiftly returning to London when he cannot sleep. He thanks Lady Ashburton for a hamper of produce from Addiscombe, and encourages her to take a “Cottage at Strathpeffer” rather than go to Marienbad (4). He regrets Jean Aitken’s decision not to accompany him and John A. Carlyle on a seaside holiday to Seaforth Lodge (9); he thanks Lady Ashburton who had proposed the holiday (13). He sends a gift to Betty Braid to mark JWC’s birthday on the 14th (13). He warmly seconds Margaret Oliphant’s support of a Mr. Virtue (15). He writes to Lady Ashburton about her ill health (19), and again to confirm the date for his and John’s
arrival (25) at Seaforth (22). He acknowledges receipt of £546 .. 13 .. 4 from Chapman & Hall.

August. TC writes to John Forster about being at Seaforth Lodge (2) and to Lady Ashburton about the fire at Melchet Court (4); she joins them, then leaves (20) to stay at Broadlands while overseeing builders at Melchet; Emerson’s son visits; TC tells Forster that he and his brother John are enjoying “the brightest weather, & the deepest silence” (21). TC and John postpone their departure for London on hearing of a heat wave there, staying at the seaside where a long-standing problem with the water supply is cured (24); they return to London (26) when the temperature drops.

September. “I am completely solitary here” in Chelsea (4). He tells Maggie Welsh he will not come to Scotland this year, but would be glad to see her in Chelsea (4). In Dumfries John A. Carlyle is giving Mary Aitken a daily German lesson; TC tells John: “what a light she was in this dim scene” (5). There is a misunderstanding between Mary and Lady Ashburton; Lady Ashburton and Jean Aitken have been in correspondence about Mary, and TC is not pleased (12); he defends Mary from any possible accusation of mendacity in a letter to Lady Ashburton (16). TC begins work on a supplement to a reprint of his Life of Schiller. Froude and Tyndall both leave for the U.S. to lecture (28).

October. Mary Aitken returns temporarily to Chelsea to provide writing help for TC (2). TC sends John A. Carlyle various magazines, and discusses the possibility of his coming to stay in London to avoid spending the winter in Dumfriesshire (2). He invites Harriet Hosmer for an afternoon visit (17). The Schiller work keeps TC and Mary busy for this month; Forster has been unwell, but has completed the second volume of his life of Dickens; Froude and Tyndall enjoy varied success in the U.S. (26).

November TC is depressed during a spell of bad weather, and his writing is progressing slowly. He dines at the Forsters’ with William Allingham and Emerson’s son, sees a good deal of James Fitzjames Stephen, and hears of Emerson’s expected arrival in London (2). Emerson visits (12). He expects to finish the Schiller supplement on 23 November (22). Emerson and daughter leave for Paris. TC praises warmly both Forster’s Dickens and Froude’s The English in Ireland (22). He tells John A. Carlyle of Mary’s plans to take up a teaching and assistant’s post with the Taylors, and Maggie Welsh’s plans to come to visit in the New Year (29).

December. TC sends greetings to Henrietta Froude and thanks her for news of her husband’s tour in the U.S. (5). He comments to John A. Carlyle about his visit to Edinburgh; tells him about Robson the printer’s bankruptcy, and sends on several letters from family and friends (7). He sends FitzGerald
books (7), and acknowledges receipt of £594 .. 15 .. 10 from Chapman & Hall (9). Mary is preparing to leave for her new post, while Maggie Welsh is at Liverpool on her way to take over writing duties in Chelsea (14). Mary writes to Meta Wellmer and expresses her support of women’s education (14). TC confirms he will not spend Christmas with Forster, who is ill, gives news of Froude’s controversial lectures on Ireland in the U.S., and passes on news of the Nortons where he met Ruskin after a long absence. “James Fitz Stephen on a long walk each Sunday” is his main company (20). He complains to John A. Carlyle about exceptionally wet weather (23). Maggie Welsh is due, 31 Dec., from Liverpool. Organizers of the John Knox monument committee try to engage TC’s interest; he is unwilling to be involved but considers various Knox portraits (27). News arrives from Canada about family matters, and TC is asked to help Francis Child pursue his collection of popular ballads. Many visitors continue to call (30).

January 1873. TC sends a New Year gift to his sister Janet Hanning (2); James Baillie is dying, and Maggie Welsh tries to help him (4). TC writes his brother Alick in Canada thanking him for news, and also for news from Alick’s son Tom (7). He writes John A. Carlyle asking to see Mrs. Stirling’s letters from JWC, and telling him of Froude’s imminent return from America (8). Mary Aitken departs for her new employment (8). TC is impatient for news of Lady Ashburton, to whom he writes of Mary’s “magnanimity and clear stoicism” (10). Maggie now writes his letters for him (10). After unusually wet weather, the Forsters return to London, and TC and Maggie are invited to a belated Christmas meal on the 13th. Froude will be back “next week” (10). Mary has gone to Brighton with the Taylors and “seems to like them well,” TC tells his brother John. The Chelsea Embankment is being built, “the infinite of mud & pother” (14). He would, he tells brother John, be glad to do anything to help family in Canada (16). He writes to Forster about a draft of his will (30).

February. TC writes to brother John of bitterly cold weatherand the deserted streets of London; Forster suffers badly from a cough (5). Complaining to Lady Ashburton about the weather, TC admits to feeling “weaker, blinder too.” Caroline Davenport Bromley has visited, also Froude; Mary is coming to dine (16). He declines an invitation from Lady Taylor (11). He sends spiritual advice, recommending Kant, to a correspondent (16), and discusses with his brother John their niece Mary Holden’s difficulties (19). He urges John to accept Edinburgh’s offer of an LL.D. (26).

March. TC writes Lord Napier contradicting a false story about Frederick the Great (3). He discusses investments and Irish affairs with brother John (7) and passes on to Lady Ashburton news of Forster’s improved health (8). He tells John he is happy to invest in railway stock if the price is good, and
would like to help his sister Mary Austin in renewing the lease of The Gill if he can (12). With Maggie’s help, TC is clearing “a great heap of rubbish”; Mary Aitken is doing well at the Taylors’ (20). TC sends £4,050 for brother John to put on deposit in the bank for him; he and Caroline Davenport Bromley visit Charles Eliot Norton (21), who is recovering from illness (22). TC discusses with John the possibility of financing a farm in Canada for their brother Alick’s son James; he walks with Froude and with Norton, “an extremely amiable man” (29).

April. He tells Lady Ashburton “Maggie & I go on here with the utmost composure,” in quiet reading mostly. Lady Ashburton’s new house in Kensington Gore is still being worked on (1). He declines another invitation from Lady Stanley (7). He writes to John A. Carlyle about correspondence received, about John’s forthcoming doctorate, and with news of Emerson’s return from Egypt a week ago (12). He writes a very friendly introduction to Edward FitzGerald on behalf of Charles Eliot Norton (14), and sends FitzGerald’s reply to Norton, calling him a “peaceable, affectionate, & ultra modest man” (18). He visits the Forsters (21). Emerson visits (24). Mary visits (25), “seemed well-doing & cheerful.” Thanking John for a postcard from Edinburgh, TC expresses dislike of the lack of privacy in their use (26).

May. TC invites his brother John to consider a visit to Chelsea (7). He parts from Norton (9), who is returning to the U.S. (16). He learns from Norton of the death of John Stuart Mill (7), which affects him strongly. He dismisses Browning’s new poem as “the despicablest, most conceited & utterly worthless performance I ever met with from the hand of a man of talent!” (10). Mary visits regularly and seems to flourish in her new life (10). He writes Harriet Mill a magnanimous letter on the story of the burning of the French Revolution manuscript (17). He congratulates Sir Henry Cole on his photographic copy of the Bayeux Tapestry (20).

June. TC writes William Dougal Christie on the London Library, declining to be involved in questions of the librarian’s salary or the financial state of the Library: “I am totally hors de combat” (18). He tells Forster of his pleasure in the summer warmth, and the prospect of a sea-bathing holiday with Mary Aitken and her mother, Jean (24).

July. He writes to Lady Ashburton in Marienbad with his concerns about her daughter Mary’s health and wishes she were back in England with its summer sunshine; he has been in touch with Thomas Woolner about a sculpture commissioned by Lady Ashburton, “really a meritorious bit of sculpture” but requiring some kind of explanation to the viewer (6). Maggie Welsh has left for Liverpool, and TC is considering a month’s sea-bathing with Mary and her mother in the Isle of Bute. TC sends Betty Braid a gift in memory of
JWC’s birthday (12), along with news of the death of James Baillie at the end of March. He thanks Froude for an invitation, but tends to prefer a week in Blickling with Lady Lothian and Lady Gertrude Chetwynd-Talbot before heading for Scotland (30).

August. Instead of Isle of Bute, TC and Mary leave for Blickling, Norfolk (2), from where TC writes to Forster about the beauty of the place and his enjoyment of it (8). They leave Blickling for Yarmouth, to Newcastle (by sea) then to Dumfries (by rail) (12).

September. TC stays at Auchtertool, Fife (1–5), then goes to Haddington to visit JWC’s grave with Mary Aitken and Maggie Welsh, staying overnight in Edinburgh (5); TC and Mary return to Dumfries. TC writes FitzGerald from Dumfries about their Naseby monument plan, which has failed (13). He tells brother John that he “has suffered a great deal of misery in this confused … seven weeks”; he and Mary return to Chelsea (15). London seems empty and TC rather enjoys the experience. He denounces autograph hunters (20). He complains to John that his digestion is seriously upset, his “wretched stomach dragging me down all day.” Forster’s health seems improved. TC urges John to go back to translating: “nothing cd be more medicinal to the weary wandering mind” (27).

As volume 48 enters the final stages of editing, we received the news of the death of one of its senior editors, Aileen Christianson, who has been with the edition since 1967, a backbone of its regular and scrupulously edited appearance. While she devoted years of her life to this, Aileen was also a charismatic tutor and lecturer, in both Scottish literature and women’s studies. Forthright, confident, and cheerful, Aileen was a conspicuous member of Edinburgh University, of the Carlyle Society, and of the world of Carlyle studies. She has left a legacy of published work on Jane Welsh Carlyle, on Scottish women writers, and on the onward march of the Duke–Edinburgh edition of the Letters. She will be much missed.

bibl.sourceNote: MA-JHB-B [JHBB], [10 Oct.]. MS: Balfour-Browne inc. Hitherto unpbd. Text taken from a partial transcript of MS. John Hutton Balfour-Browne (1845–1921), lawyer, legal writer, poet, essayist, and diarist, b. Dumfries. He had been at school with one of Jean Aitken’s sons (J. H. Balfour-Browne, Forty Years at the Bar [1916] 134), presumably John (the nearest in age). He wrote legal works under his own name, and novels and poems under various pseudonyms, eg., Marshall Hamilton, Max Hillary, and Guy Fleming.
bibl.head: MARY AITKEN TO JOHN HUTTON BALFOUR-BROWNE

docBody.p: Mr Carlyle, my Uncle, desires me to say that, after many delays, he has received and read the NovelMarshall Hamilton, For Very Life, 2 vols. (1871), apparently his first novel. and Letter you have been so kind as send him. In the Novel, of which you ask his opinion, he says he finds considerable talent— But his idea is that in a novel one expects Action rather than reflections; in which latter my Uncle thinks yours abounds almost too exclusively. The plot also he considers extravagant and wild. In short he thinks the talent and ingenuity you are evidently possessed of might be more suitably expended in some real work, of history or other, than in Novel writing; and he would bid you not stop, but proceed in your Literary labours, though in a different direction.Balfour-Browne later wrote: “In 1870 I published a book—a novel. It was accepted by Messrs Chapman and Hall … on the ‘half-profit principle.’ … I sent a copy of the book to Carlyle, and he wrote me by the hand of his niece Mary Carlyle Aitken a very nice letter, and told me that he had found a good deal of talent in the book and would willingly accept the dedication of my next novel, but he advised me to devote myself to real work. Well, I have, although reluctantly, taken his advice” (Forty Years at the Bar 137). For his second novel, see TC to JHB-B, 20 Dec. The next work pbd. under his own name was Handbook of Lunacy (1872).

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 13 Oct. MS: NLS 527.54B. Quot: A. Carlyle, NL 2:279–281. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
I intended writing to you yesterday, but was invincibly prevented; indeed I have various days intended, but always some pitiful invincible trifle has prevented me. One poor word, however, you shall have today; tho’, alas, what good can it do! All words are in effect idle; the stroke has fallen, our loss is irrevocable and unalterable. “It is Gods holy will” is all that any of us can say or think upon it;—and to think it so with our whole heart is far better than any speaking of it; and the sole assuagement that exists for any of us. I am much
struck by the universal sympathy poor Jim’s death awakens and the great love of all his friends for him.— A faithful useful clear and loving hearted man; and felt to be such, apparently without exception by all who knew him. There is a mournful but deep and true comfort in knowing that this was verily the fact; a human being at any stage of his existence cannot end on better terms. You cannot but weep for him, dear Sister; but surely this is not the worst kind of sorrow; by degrees I trust you will find it has been blessed to you.

Mary is very diligent and active doing all she can to unravel the unpleasant mystery about His worldly effects; which we hope will one day come to clearness;John A. Carlyle wrote, 6 Oct.: “Jean … feels rather anxious to know the state in which poor Jim’s affairs were left. His luggage & papers arrived two days ago, but they throw no light on the subject. Perhaps Mary might write to Dilberoglue & clear up the matter, as he will most probably know what Jim had to enter the partnership with. John looked through all the papers in vain. He … spoke of starting for London tomorrow or Friday.” Stauros Dilberoglue (1818–78; see 40:22740:biographical notes), Greek businessman, philanthropist, art collector, and partner in the merchant shipping firm Cavafy & Co.; Jean Aitken’s son James Aitken Jr. worked in their Liverpool office from 1867 or 1868 (see 45:1TC to JAC, 1 July 1867, and 22145:biographical notes); apparently he had become a partner; he d. in London, 20 Sept.; see 47:226TC to JAF, 26 Sep. 1871. it is for the present an unwelcome mean ingredient in your sorrow; but perhaps it is no evil either,—give you all something to do outwardly while in the endless inward sorrow there is nothing to be done at all. God be with you, dear Sister; and sanctify to you (as our Fathers used to say) this heaviest of griefs that He has sent you.
I will say no more at this time.

My own affairs here are still in a so-so way; but I reckon myself gradually coming round. For the first week I had considerable difficulties about
sleep; and felt myself weak, shivery and nervous to an unusual degree; but I do rather feel as if this were abating; and we try in all ways to manage as discreetly as we can with it. You can tell John we have actually begun translating that Icelandic Story from the GermanTC and Mary Aitken were translating the Faereyinga Saga from the German translation in C. C. Rafn and G. C. F. Mohnike, Færeyínga saga oder Geschichte der Bewohner der Färöer im isländischen Grundtext mit färöischer, dänischer unter deutscher Übersetzung (Copenhagen, 1833); see TC to JAC, 20 Jan. 1872, and Chris Vanden Bossche, “Carlyle’s Færeyinga Saga Translation,” CA 10:64–65, 78 n. 7. For TC’s preface (which became “Early Kings of Norway” [Carlyle, Works 30:201–310]), he was to use J. G. Dahlmann’s history, Geschichte von Dännemark, 3 vols. (Hamburg, 1840–43) for background, and the English translation by Samuel Laing (1780–1868; ODNB), Heimskringla, 3 vols. (1840), of the sagas written in Old Norse in Iceland by Snorro Sturleson (ca. 1179–1241), poet and historian. and daily insist, what we can, on getting more or less (less for most part!) of it put to paper. The labour I know well enough to be worth in itself nothing; but to poor me able only for nothing, it has a perceptable, though infinitely small, value; and I mean to stick to it, if possible to the end— Froude is coming today, of which I am glad a little; AllinghamJames Anthony Froude and William Allingham. turned up above a week ago and has been a diligent attendant every second day or so; he also is rather better than nothing. The rest of my visitors and affairs in this place are nearly absolute intrusions; and are reckoned in my impatience as minus quantities; though perhaps they are not altogether so either. One’s gloom from within would perhaps get still gloomier were there no interruption from without. Poor Forster and poor Mrs F. are both of them again reported very poorly. Forster obliged to run the country for a little while yet; and work as if he were well. In a week or two he is to have two months of entire rest:John Forster wrote to TC, 24 Sept., with condolences on the death of James Aitken Jr. He continued: “I should have written to you long ere this but for my illness. I had hardly left town … when I broke down, and ever since have been making such fight as I could! I left London the 6th and have not had two days freedom from painful incessant wearing cough. … I am obliged at last to confess myself vanquished—and as early as possible (for one day’s more work I must do) I go back. I think of Bournemouth for a few weeks rest.” we hope this, at the seaside or here quiet at home may do something for him. He speaks of Miss Cunningham’s affair one day to me; he will be ready for your letter at Xmas nextWilhelmina Cunningham; TC, John A. Carlyle, and Forster had agreed, Nov. 1869, to send her £20 a year between them, the money being sent through Jean; see 46:109TC to JCA, 16 Nov. 1869; 10TC to RWE, 18 Nov 1869; and 114–15TC to JAC, 22 Nov. 1869. if we be all spared till then. Lady Ashburton came suddenly up on Tuesday last “for one week”; had ridden all the way from Dingwall (600 miles) at a stretch; to stay one week at Melchet upon manifold business mostly of a provoking nature (about her grand new house which lets in the water and refuses to be heated as it ought),TC meant Melchet Court, built 1862–68. —I have seldom known an innocent human creature more tormented
with incessant provocations of that kind. She was full of generous sympathy for you for Mary and all of us. She staid here two days; but, owing to a Yankee Sculptress, a gabbing little Miss Hossmer who had hold of her,Lady Ashburton first met Harriet Hosmer in Rome, 1867 (see Surtees, Ludovisi 130–31). we saw the less of her here. On Wednesday evening she dashed off for Melchet; from which, in another four days, she dashes off to Dingwall again,—1200 miles of new railwaying for another month at Loch Luichart. Oh me, Oh me!—

You may give the enclosed to John; and encourage him to write again though clearly I am his debtor at present. The Charles Stewart PamphletCharles Stewart (b. ca. 1791), of Hillside, nr. Lockerbie, Dumfriesshire, landowner, land-agent, and factor. John A. Carlyle wrote, 9 Oct.: “Yesterday I got a letter & some pamphlets from Charles Stewart containing letters of his about Moffat & its neighbourhood. In one of them he mentions that your ‘John Waugh minister of Borrostowness’ in Cromwell’s time was a native of Moffat & had a small estate there called ‘Heatheryhaugh’ little more than a mile from Moffat. … And it happens … that this very land is to be sold by roup [public auction] on Friday first, & will give in price nearly 50 times what John Waugh would have got in 1660.” John Waugh (ca. 1619–74), minister of Borrowstouness (now Bo’ness); for TC’s comments on him in Cromwell, see Carlyle, Works 7:278–79. John continued: “I could send Mr S’s letter & two of the pamphlets of wh I have duplicates. … The pamphlets are old, but all the rules of the one about Cottages on the Hope Johnstone Estate [presumably of John James Hope Johnstone (1796–1876), of Raehills, Lockerbie, and Hook House, Dumfriesshire; see 36:181TC to JAC, 15 Aug. 1860] are still in force & working well.” never arrived till last night about nine, though the Letter had arrived 48 hours before. I read the Pamphlet and adjuncts before going to bed, with considerable approval of both; and will write about them before long. The Linlathen message also came; and Mary on search, has found about 20 Erskine Letters;—I cannot for my life think what to say about Erksine that could be suitable for the public it is meant for;James Erskine (previously Paterson) wrote, 9 Oct.: “I hesitate in asking you to do anything you might find a burden. … But knowing the kindly remembrance you have of my Uncle & the pleasure you had in each others society—I hope you wd find it agreable to write whatever comes into your mind about him, & allow it to take its place with similar contributions from 3 or 4 friends—in a little volume—which along with the few letters we can now obtain wd, I think, make a pleasant & useful memorial.” He also asked if TC would allow him to publish any of Erskine’s letters that he had. John A. Carlyle wrote, 22 Oct.: “In regard to that request of Erskine’s (young Paterson’s) you surely might refuse to undertake any writing.” TC apparently wrote telling him that he had decided against it, as John replied, 26 Oct.: “We are all glad to hear that you have dismissed the question about Erskine by sending the Letters only to his nephew.” Erskine wrote, 27 Oct.: “My wife & I have read all the letters you kindly sent—with great interest & pleasure. … I still hope that a time may come—when you will find it good & pleasant medecine to write a few words of your Friend. It wd be a further tie between you, & wd be a very valuable stone in this small memorial to him.” but yet I suppose there will be no avoiding of an attempt to say something! I much dislike this kind of demand upon me (which comes far oftener than I could expect); but on reflecting, too, I should perhaps
admit that in a case like Erskine’s especially, it has its value to me and its uses.TC did not write anything.

This is all, dear Sister, or almost more than all, the greater part of it worth almost nothing to you. I add only my poor heart’s blessing upon you and all you have still left to you. God be with you all.

closer.note: After James Aitken’s death, TC’s regular gift to James and Anna-Maria Baillie was channeled via the Rev. Wodehouse Raven (1806–90), vicar of Christchurch, Streatham; see also 47:187TC to WILL, 11 April 1871; TC’s first check to him, for £10 (the check stub: “for Baillies”; the returned check: “for Mrs Baillie”), was dated 16 Oct. 1871; see 2.

figure.p:
Thomas Carlyle’s check to the Rev. Wodehouse Raven, 16 October 1871
Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JR, 21 Oct. MS: Helen Viljoen Collection. Pbd: Ruskin’s Works, 22:xix–xx; Cate 161–62.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p:
Dear Ruskin,—I cannot explain to myself the strange, and indeed lamentable fact that I have not seen you, or heard a distinct word from you for, I think, seven or eight months.For TC’s last recorded contact with John Ruskin, April 1871, see 47:199–200TC to JRU, 30 April 1871. It is a fact that has become not only surprising to me, but distressing, and the source latterly of continual anxieties both about myself and you. For three months I had no Amanuensis (I in the Highlands, Mary in Dumfriesshire far away), and without a hand could not write to you myself: about the middle of that period, too, there came the most alarming rumours of your illness at Matlock;Ruskin caught a chill in July while staying at the New Bath Hotel in Matlock, Derbyshire; this led to an attack of internal inflammation. He recovered gradually under the care of his friend Henry Wentworth Acland (1815–1900; ODNB), physician. and both Lady AshburtonTC inserted “Ashburton” where Mary wrote “A.” and myself (especially the latter party for whom I can answer best) were in a state really deserving pity on your account, till the very Newspapers took compassion on us, and announced the immediate danger to be past. All this is wrong; and not as it should be. I beg earnestly that, wherever this may find you, you would at onceTC inserted “at once.” devote one serious half-hour to me; and write a few words of authentic news concerning yourself, and especially a word of prediction as to when I may expect to see you again, if ever.Ruskin replied, 23 Oct.: “Your loving letter greets me returning today from Oxford. My illness indeed very nearly ended me; and left me heavy in limb and otherwise helpless for some weeks— Gradually … my strength came back—but I cannot yet run or climb as I could before. … I … send this miserably written letter to you with my love, and will come, if I may to see you, at ½ past 8, tomorrow evening.” The Fors Clavigera sufficiently assures
me, from time to time, that it is not want of the old goodwill towards me which keeps you silent;Ruskin’s Fors Clavigera appeared monthly; see 47:199–200TC to JRU, 30 April 1871. Ruskin apparently arranged for them to be sent to TC; see TC to SE&Co., 12 March 1872. but the Fors Clavigera itself (which very few can get hold of, though many are seeking it) awakens anxieties in me instead of satisfying them all. In short a deliberate bit of letter is indispensable to me for all manner of reasons.

It is four weeks today since I returned hither; said by sanguine friends to be visibly “improved in health,” felt by myself to be only invisibly so, if at all: now as formerly I have my daily (especially my nightly) battle to fight with the innumerable Beasts at Ephesus,Cf. 1 Cor. 15:32. human diabolical and also of the inanimate sort, which never quit a poor fellow till they have brought him to the ground altogether, against which I faintly but really sometimes with an earnest wish, endeavour to make fight, though of course with weaker and weaker effect. Froude has returned, and is often asking about you; as indeed are many others, to whom the radiant qualities which the gods have given you, and set you to work with in such an element, are not unknown. Write me a word at once, dear Ruskin. Mary sends her love to you. The most mournful tragedy has happened in her and my circle,—the death of her eldest Brother by the accident of leaping down from a coach here, probably with too much trust in his nimbleness of limb;—an excellent completely faithful and valiant young man whose loss has thrown a gloom over us all.— No more today. Do swiftly what have begged of you: I remain ever and always

bibl.sourceNote: TC-WB [WBAT], 28 Oct. Pbd: “The Rev. William Bathgate, D.D.,” The Worthies of the Evangelical Union (1883) 436. William Bathgate (1820–79), liberal theologian, minister of Winton Place Church, Kilmarnock, Scotland, 1860–79; see TC to WBAT, 1 Dec. 1870.
bibl.head: TC TO WILLIAM BATHGATE

docBody.p:
Dear Sir,—Mr. Carlyle, my uncle, desires me to thank you cordially for the letter he received from you yesterday. To my uncle, your plan seems very feasible and good; I send your letter by this post to Mr. Chapman; if he sees good, and you have the necessary leisure and willingness for the task,Bathgate wrote, 26 Oct.: “I believe that a carefully selected volume of extracts from your writings might be singularly serviceable to many thoughtful men. I would have the book compiled by some loving, filial, reverent hand, with ample skill and leisure, so that the arrangement of the selections might, as a building, be a piece of art, approximately worthy of the material. … There might also be a Golden Treasury of Aphorisms. I believe that many persons, tolerably acquainted with your works as a whole, would greatly prize such a volume. Others who have not the opportunity of becoming acquainted with your writings generally, would derive stimulation, courage for the battle of life.” Bathgate himself did not produce the volume of extracts; his next work was The Deep Things of God (Glasgow, 1876); nor did he apparently find anyone else to do so. my uncle
knows nobody more likely than yourself to succeed in the undertaking. With my uncle’s best wishes and thanks.
docBody.closer:
Yours very truly,
Mary Carlyle Aitken.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 1 Nov. MS: NLS 531.9. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: I enclose you today the small settlement of Mary’s dressing-gown and my own warm shoes.Mary Aitken recorded in TC’s checkbook: “31 October 1871 / Mrs Aitken (for Dressing Gown Cloth Shoes &c / £2 .. 1 .. 2” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). Mary will mark on the margin what the particulars are; which she says are all right. She is sitting in her dressing gown at this moment,—a comfortable looking garment; I too am in my new shoes;—the first day they rather hurt my lame toe, though seeming roomy enough and very warm and snug otherwise. I laid them aside for a week; and for the last day or two they are unexceptionable and promise to be a valuable possession through the winter months.John A. Carlyle wrote, 26 Oct.: “Glad to hear you get some good of the buckskin shoes.” TC previously had problems with his toes; see 46:130TC to JAC, 18 Dec. 1869.

This little tatter of a thing is therefore off my hands. About it indeed there need have been no hurry; but I suppose I wished to tempt you to another Letter; for I am truly anxious to hear definitely from you; and am often enough thinking about you in the sad time that now is. I am myself so so, not entitled to complain much but still less to brag. My sleep is almost uniformly broken and indifferently bad; but I never except once since you last heard of me have lost a whole night Patience, patience; we must endeavour to be patient and to do daily the poor duties of the day,—certain one thing that the end (under God’s good pleasure and in God’s hand) is not far.

Tomorrow I intend to send you Macmillan’s Magazine where possibly you
may find something to read. Tell me how you get on with Ziethen.Hans Joachim von Zieten (1699–1786), Prussian general; possibly Luise Johanne von Blumenthal, The Life of Gen. de Zieten, trans. from German by B. Beresford (Berlin, 1808); TC’s copy: HCC. I enclose a bit of Paris talk about the state of Trade &c, which wears an authentic look,—if you have not seen it already, it came from Lady Ashburton this morning, who is at length in the Highlands again; but I suppose not for long.
Adieu, dear Sister, I am ever

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 8 Nov. MS: NLS 527.55. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Forster has been here taking leave of us before going to the sea side, where it is uncertain how long he may continue. He is still very far from well; cannot sleep for coughing &c &c and does not know but he may be driven home again in a few days.Forster wrote from the Bath Hotel, Bournemouth, 19 Nov.: “The Small One [Eliza Forster] is, I hope, getting a little stronger; and, though I have not had good nights, my cough has spared me very much. … [T]he place decidedly is a success thus far, and I am extremely glad that we have come to it.” His errand here seemed to be all on our behalf; on my Chapman affairs, on John’s ditto and prospects towards Harding &c &c:John Aitken was currently employed by Chapman & Hall (see TC to JCA, 18 Nov.), but was perhaps still hoping to get employment with Robert Palmer Harding, head of a prominent London accounting firm, Harding, Pullein, Whinney, & Gibbons; see 47:208TC to JAC, 29 May 1871, and 225TC to JAF, 26 Sep. 1871. in short nothing could exceed the kindness of Forster as usual. Among other things he produced the enclosed cheque to be sent to you for behoof of Miss Cunningham;See TC to JCA, 13 Oct. I said it was not due or suitable till Xmas; he approved much of your delay and silence till then; but insisted on my sending it you at once & having done with it. Keep it therefore on those terms, dear Sister or have it changed when you like into ten Notes for behoof of Miss C. when the time comes. A single word of receipt either to Forster or to us will finish the matter.

I received the Dr’s big Packet on Monday; and am glad to see the worthy old Gentleman of HillsideIn connection with John A. Carlyle’s letter of 9 Oct. about Charles Stewart of Hillside; see TC to JCA, 13 Oct. was evidently a little gratified by what had taken
place. We dispatched, Mary and I, to Leighton his oblique MessageTC apparently sent John some information about Sir Baldwyn Leighton, living at Loton Park, Shrewsbury, as John wrote, 22 Oct.: “I have another copy of Stewarts pamphlet on Cottages, & could send it at once to Sir B. Leighton or yourself.” TC then apparently sent John a newspaper containing an article by Leighton, as John wrote, 26 Oct.: “The newspaper I will send on to Mr Stewart with a few words of explanation.” He then wrote, 5 Nov.: “Two days after forwarding the Shrewsbury newspaper to Mr Stewart, I wrote a few words telling how Sir Baldwin Leighton & his father [Sir Baldwin Leighton (1805–71), 7th bart.] before him had attended to the Cottages on their estate with success & how their plan seemed much the same as his own on the Annandale estates. And he seems to have been stirred up very pleasantly, & sends the two enclosed letters, & the package of pamphlets. … The letters will not be altogether uninteresting to you, I think, from so old a man; & you can shew them both, or the last of them alone, to Sir B. & give it to him along with the pamphlets … if you think it desirable. It is a pity that more landlords don’t attend to such important matters.” Charles Stewart wrote to John, 1 Nov., thanking him for sending “Sir Baldwin Leighton’s excellent Lecture” (MS: NLS 1770.88). This was probably the second of two papers delivered by Leighton at the Social Science Congress in Leeds, Oct. 1871, “Poor Law Out-Relief” and “Landlords and Labourers”; they were pbd. as Pauperization: Cause and Cure (Shrewsbury, 1871). or what we judged to be such;— and expect with confidence enough that it will have the due reception. I deeply feel that I am in John’s debt and mean to pay him very soon.

My blessings on you all.John wrote, 5 Nov.: “Jean bears her great sorrow calmly & bravely, & there is this addition to it that no search or enquiry enables her to find out what Jem had done with the two or three hundred pounds he had saved & spoke of both to herself & John. She has given up seeking to ascertain, & made up her mind to seek no farther.”

closer.note: From “Ever” to end in TC’s hand.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-TH, 12 Nov. MS: Illinois Univ. Pbd: Daniel Clark, M.D., Pen Photographs of Celebrated Men and Noted Places (Toronto, 1873) 185. Text: Clark. Thomas Hughes (1822–96; ODNB), social reformer and author.
bibl.head: TC TO THOMAS HUGHES

docBody.dateline:
No. 5 CheyeneThus in text. Row, Chelsea,
Nov. 12, 1871
docBody.p:
Forgive me that I have not sooner answered your friendly, cheery, and altogether pleasant little note.Hughes had apparently written to TC to ask him to contribute a copy of his works to a new library for Chicago. The Chicago Public Library, with over 20,000 volumes, had been destroyed in the Great Chicago Fire, 8–10 Oct. Hughes had visited Chicago, 1870, and been impressed by its energy and industry. I suppose BurgessAndrew Hutton Burgess (see 47:135TC to THH, 5 Jan. 1871), also involved in the project. would have told you my objections to
the project; that it seemed to me superfluous, not practicablyFor “practicable.” by the methods he proposed (for the gifts of all the books of living authors will go for very little in such an enterprise) and, third and worst, that it wore on the face of it a visible pick-thank kind of character—a thing greatly to be avoided, both in Chicago and here!

These objections do not vanish on reflection, but on the contrary gather weight. Nevertheless, if you and the literary world feel nothing of the like and the project does take fire and go on,The appeal for contributions was led by Hughes and headed by Queen Victoria; it included many prominent authors, politicians, and cultural institutions; more than 8,000 books were eventually sent. it continues certain that my poor contribution of a copy of my books shall not by any means be wanting.
docBody.closer:
Believe me alway, yours, with many regards
T. CARLYLE.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 18 Nov. MS: NLS 531.10. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
Though there is very little time left, I must write you one word before the week end. The shirts came on Tuesday; excellent warm, roomy shirts, and very warm here in the frostThe Times reported, 16 Nov.: “In centigrade degrees, the mean temperature of the air last week at Greenwich was 4.0 deg., or 3.2 below the mean temperature of the corresponding week in 50 years.” that there was;—the buttonless sleeves I knew beforehand would be intolerable; and had wrist bands put on in the course of the day. All is right under that head ever since; and I am very much obliged for this new bit of service done me. You ask if there is anything farther you can do in the way of warm clothing; to which my answer is, Almost nothing, except perhaps it were possible for you at Dumfries to find me a proper pair of winter gloves. A thick effectual pair of woolen gloves well lined with flannel not too big and that will fairly fit the human hand. Mary searched all London for me; and could find no such things, “Knitted lined gloves not made now, Miss”; at the long last she did find in some big Shop one pair left as relic not the right kind either (for they seemed to be woven not knit and otherwise of unpleasant colour); but they seem to be very “feel” lined with plush and I thought they would do. Yesterday, however, on putting them on, I found
they were decidedly too big and that the lining was too small for the outside of them; so that I would gladly have a better pair if they are to be had. But I much doubt there is no such thing attainable. What a singular feature it often seems to me that all mortals in this country seem to aim, not at making things better and better, but at making them, every new season, different: singular though extremely explicable; and undoubtedly the work of the Evil Genius, if that were any comfort. Dont, you, much bother about this of the gloves. I really can manage quite supportably as I am.

My sleep continues obstinately bad and broken; I can hardly remember three nights of sleep anything like regular since I returned hither. There is often a feeling in me, too, as if, at bottom, in spite of all this, I had a kind of clearness and interior health superior to that of last year (which Heaven knows is not saying much for it, though a little is always something!).— Meanwhile I am often rather sick of the thing; but of course can do no good by that. And in fact had better be silent about it till we see if it mend at all.

HereTC inserted “n.l.” before “Here,” indicating a new paragraph. is a knock, I hope it may be Froude;—but no it seems to be nobody. Mary however is due outside to walk with JohnMary Aitken’s brother John was now living in London. Mary wrote to Ann Welsh, 5 Dec.: “My brother lives about 20 minutes walk from us; and often comes down to us in the evenings. He and I go for very long walks together on Saturdays—when he has a half holiday; and he comes here to dinner every Sunday. He seems to like London and his work very well; but he had a bad start poor fellow; he was only here about a fortnight till that dreadful accident happened. He is now our only Brother that is left to us” (MS: EUL). John Aitken was now working for Chapman & Hall; Forster had written, 21 Aug., that Frederic Chapman was about to go away on holiday, but would write to John Aitken to discuss whether John would start work immediately, or would wait for Chapman’s return from holiday. and I must end.

Give many thanks from me to the Doctor for his little Note, and Stewart DocumentsJohn wrote, 14 Nov.: “I sent Sir B. Leighton’s letter on to Mr Stewart … & have received the enclosed from him together with that letter.” which latter I keep for Leighton against his next appearance here.Sir Baldwyn Leighton’s London home was 52 Park St., Gloucester Sq. I have a (stupidish) Prussian BookUnidentified further. which I intended for him; along with a little letter;—both of which can easily wait till Monday Accept, dear Sister, my hasty farewell.
docBody.closer:
Your affectionate Brother,
T. Carlyle.Edward FitzGerald wrote his annual letter to TC, 17 Nov., and sent him a brace of pheasant. TC apparently replied as FitzGerald acknowledged the letter in his reply to TC, 20 Dec., and mentioned to a friend, 23 Dec., TC’s “very kind and long letter dictated … in reply” (FitzGerald’s Letters 3:305–6, 313–14, 315).

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JF, 29 Nov. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd. Written partly in TC’s hand in blue pencil and partly by Mary Aitken, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Thanks for all the pains you take with me. The bright new Volume came punctually (by Nephew John)Forster wrote from Bournemouth, 27 Nov.: “Day by day I have been expecting the promised book. … I have written by this post … to cause the volume to be sent to you tomorrow without fail. It is to be published early next week. … [Y]ou will kindly let no one see it (except Mary) until after next Monday [4 Dec.].” John Aitken delivered the first vol. of Forster’s The Life of Charles Dickens (1872–74) from Chapman & Hall. yesternight abt 9;—and in spite of an unwelcome interruptn, I am already deep in it,—sat reading there, in fact, till 2 this morng. I need not tell you, what you already guess privately and all the world will confirm, that it is of the liveliest interest, and dextrously and exactly done: easy to prophecy that it will go round the globe,Up to here the letter is in TC’s hand; the rest is in Mary Aitken’s hand. and be eagerly read by thousands on thousands of men. Euge, euge [Well done, well done]!—
