We want a new Note about health matters; the first was a great favour and solace to one’s mind; the account given fairly beyond what one had reckoned on. This time you say nothing on the subject; but from various signs I flatter myself things are not worse than they were but probably better.Forster wrote: “[T]he Small One [Eliza] is lying on the sofa, quite tired out with her walk. We indeed do almost nothing, she and I here, except in the health-hunting way, which is really very hard work after all.” Confirm these fine surmises to us; at all events let us know how the truth stands. No time was better spent than your rustication now in gathering a little strength to front the storms that are coming in the next two months.TC probably referred to the fact that four months (not two) away (2 April 1872), Forster would be 60 and could then retire from work; see TC to CDG, 12 Dec. Courage, Courage I hope we shall not only see XmasForster wrote: “We shall be back in good time for our Xmas Day meeting—please God.” on better terms than were expected, but also the Ides of March,—the Ides of March both come and gone!The Ides of March (15 March) was the date in the Roman calendar of the settling of debts; it was also the date of the murder of Julius Caesar, and so seen as a day of reckoning. God grant it; that is often a prayer of mine.

I am myself not worse than when you parted with me; nor much better, though sometimes almost inclined to think myself half-imperceptibly so;—I believe the first fall of snow, however, will teach me the reverse. Glazed streets in London, which are the second stage of snow, prohibit me from walking, and are the enemy I dread most, especially with that beautiful bit of
civic legislation, “Throw out ashes before your door, and you are fined;” one of the most astonishing laws ever passed by mankindIt was against London bylaws to throw ashes into the streets to prevent accidents, even in times of frost and icy pavements; see 44:151TC to JAF, 10 Feb. 1867; see also 47:137–38TC to JAC, 13 Jan. 1871. Local authorities in London had the power to enforce “the prevention of nuisances arising from snow, filth, dust, ashes, and rubbish within the district” (W. Cunningham Glen, The Laws Relating to Public Health and Local Government [1872] 151). It was to prevent congealed ashes clogging drains and causing flooding after the snow melted. in or out of bedlam;—and very characteristic of an English people at this time, who have got a Talking Parliament and a People’s WilliamWilliam Gladstone, prime minister; the nickname, “people’s William,” had been given to him by the Daily Telegraph; see 46:194TC to JAC, 13 April 1870. to “govern” them.
Write a little Note soon, dear Forster, or encourage Mrs F. to do; taking in both your cases, her own as well as yours. God bless you both, dear and helpful Friends.
docBody.closer:
Yours ever / T. CarlyleIn his letter of 19 Nov., Forster wrote: “I heard not a bad story of a Frenchman the other day, during the siege of Paris and the famine. He had a favourite dog called Fox—and in the extremity of hunger he killed and eat him. After a hearty meal on the roast favourite—pushing away the platefull of bones—his eyes filled with tears—and . . [ellipsis in MS] ‘Ah! poor Fox! how he would have enjoyed those bones!’—Swift could not have objected to this bones of a story.” For an illustration of the Paris market for dogs’ and cats’ flesh, see 13.
The market for dogs’ and cats’ flesh
Illustrated London News, 28 January 1871

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, [1 Dec.]. MS: EUL inc. Text taken from John A. Carlyle to Dr. John Brown, 2 Dec. Hitherto unpbd. John Brown (1810–82; ODNB), physician and author, old friend of John’s, who had attended Erskine in his last illness; see TC to JAC, [4] March 1870.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: An American Gentleman knocked at the door the other day, wishing to see you, while Mary & I were busy upstairs. She sent down your Dumfries address; but the man courageously lingered, said his business here was with me for three minutes, during which time—such my message down stairs to him—I was at his service. A thick-set, loud, Theological personageJoseph Cook (1838–1901), New England Congregational pastor. John A. Carlyle wrote to John Brown, 2 Dec.: “Today I have received a letter from my brother in which he encloses yours of 29th Octr; & I am glad to see your hand again. … You will be amused by what he says of the Revd Joseph Cook” (MS: EUL). John replied to TC, 4 Dec.: “I was much amused by your account of the loud American, who had such perseverance in getting sight of you.” came up accordingly; & had five minutes of me—not uncomfortable, tho’ to myself loud & useless—after which I dismissed him to the University of Göttingen with what little of blessing I could.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JF, 5 Dec. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p:
My poor Birthday yesterday brought an unexpected crowd of letters and congratulations from far and near; a thing wonderful to me and I may say sad
rather than joyful. At least sixty of the seventy-six times that poor anniversary has now come round have been unmarked by any notice of it at all,—except indeed by OneJWC. who can now notice it no more:—and here, when we have got to the 77th,TC meant his 77th year, not his 77th birthday. He wrote in his journal, 8 Dec.: “Monday last [4 Dec.], my 76th Birthday, then came a quite unexpected, unexampled heap of recognitn, whh surprised me, if they did not interest. Once there was only One that remembered my Birthday; mournful and nichtig [trivial] was the whole world’s remembrance, now that Hers is wanting: ah me!— I said to myself, however, ‘Does this strange influx of Anniversary Benevolence mean that I am what the Scotch call fey; that this is perhaps to be my last Birthday?’ Small matter, I shd think; unless I cd learn to work agn a little! But this, and all things, shall be as it pleases God. Five days of my 77th year are already fled” (TC’s journal; privately owned). and are looking forward over the grand Brink, not back upon the sordid scramble we are just about to leave, comes such a jingle of bob-majorsA term used in bell ringing. from so many bells! I almost asked myself, Does this signify (Scottice) [th]at I am fey, that this is the last of the times? Small matter if it be; very small, had we any right to choose in the matter.

But certainly of all the Gifts and Good Wishes that came, none was practically half so good as your silently symbolical one which arrived soon after mid-day in the shape of three substantial cases of white Spanish “Gondomar,”Gondomar wine, from the Duero / Douro Valley that runs through Spain and Portugal. —the wine I like best of all other; and of which, for sometime past, seen myself reduced almost to zero. Thanks, Thanks, dear practical Forster; here is now as much of the fine medicinal article as I shall probably ever drink; the difficulties, at which I weakly shuddered, of tracking out its obscure City locality, and all bother about it, is permanently overcome, and I have nothing to do henceforth but drink and be grateful! This latter double duty you may depend upon it I shall certainly do, and find no difficulty in the same!— Well, well; I will say no more about it. I find my words very ill expressive of the thing I mean by them, which, therefore, we will mainly leave to silence.

I finished off the Dickens the second night after I wrote; it was a reading with what I used to call voracity such as is now rare to me in Books. The interest goes on increasing; that universal blazing up of Yankee-doodle-doodom around poor Dickens, as if it had been one huge bottle of Soda-water, is presented in the liveliest manner by help of Dickens’s own Letters; and was wonderful, and in a sense tragic to me. It fitly closes Vol I;The last six chapters of vol. 1 of Forster’s Life of Dickens covered Charles Dickens’s visit to North America, 22 Jan.–7 June 1842; much of the narrative was from the letters he sent home. It is not clear to what TC referred; Dickens was wildly feted in America, and wrote of the exhausting life he was leading; he raised the question of copyright which enraged many of the people and made two speeches on it, one at Boston (1:291) and one at Hartford (1:299–301); TC was one of the authors who wrote to him at the time supporting his position (1:304–5), and Forster printed this letter, and also remarked on TC’s and Dickens’s friendship (1:313–15; also CL 14:92–94). and, alas, there will be,
as brother to it, at the end of Vol II, another still higher evervescenceThus in MS, for effervescence. there, which to my own poor thought, is still more tragical!TC refers to the deaths at the end of vol. 2 of Dickens’s father (1785–51), and then two weeks later his infant da., Dora (1850–51). The Book I have no doubt, nor can anybody have, will circulate far and wide among the kindreds of mankind to which we belong. The wonder to me is, how, in those miserable circumstances of health, you have got it written, with such an air of calmness, perfect clearness, as if you had nothing else to care about or do. Pause wisely awhile before beginning Vol II;The Athenæum advertised, 5 Oct. 1872, that vol. 2 of Forster’s Life of Dickens (1873), covering 1842–52, would be come out early Nov. 1872, and that vol. 3(1874) would complete the work. and let us hope to see that come out in as perfect a form.

Yesterday afternoon I walked through the Park; and, shortly after sun-set, got into Clifford St, Bond Street, and there, after some searching found, in a Family Hotel (meaning a place altogether solitary except for one Valet),Almond’s Hotel, 6 Clifford St., London. the renowned Lord Houghton, ci-devant Richard Milnes,Richard Monckton Milnes, 1st Baron Houghton. down very deep in gout and other ailments, whom, though I hurt his hand in shaking it, my visit seemed to please a little. He did not seem in bad heart, though he has been hunted by continual illnesses since Autumn last; again and again reported to be quite recovered, and then straightway falling ill again:—I was really touched to see poor Milnes, how he too has to pay his Tax to Time, like all of us in this world that is made of Time. My private dread was that his health might be in a worse way than I understood, and that this “recovery” too might prove of short duration.Lord Houghton survived TC, living until 1885. — Before quitting home I had had a loud visit from Dr Blakiston, who is now settled here, having lifted anchor altogether from St. Leonards,Dr. Peyton Blakiston (1801–78); he and his wife, Bessy, b. Barnet (ca. 1810–91), had looked after JWC in St. Leonards, March–July 1864. They were now living with Charles Bally (b. ca. 1846) at 75 Margaret St., London. Charles was a relative of Blakiston’s da.-in-law Annie, b. Bally (1843–97); see 43:73–74JWC to BBL, [10 Dec. 1865], and 26743:biographical notes. and, medically “struck his flag,”A naval term meaning to lower a ship’s flag to show surrender; Blakiston’s son Peyton (1831–66), had been a commander in the Royal Navy. as he terms it:—he loudly, and with much jolly emphasis, enquired after Forster, and threatened him with a call.

I will be ready for Xmas with you unless Fate forbid. Send us a few words
as to your continued rustication (gathering of health as to both of you, I hope it still proves). Blessings be with you both.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JR [JRU], 6 Dec. MS: Luis Gordon of Luis Gordon and Sons, London. Pbd: Ruskin’s Works 36:xxiii; Sir Edward T. Cook, Life of John Ruskin, 2 vols. (1911) 2:223; Cate 165. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p: My heart is sore for you in these dreary moments. A great change has befallen; irrevocable, inexorable,—the lot of all the world since it was first made, and yet so strangely original, as it were miraculous, to each of us, when it comes home to himself. The Wearied One has gone to her welcome Rest;Ruskin’s mother, Margaret, died at Denmark Hill, 5 Dec.; TC noted in his journal, 8 Dec.; “Ruskin’s aged Mother (90 or so) died last Tuesday (just while I last wrote here); a small-Note from him that night, every word of whh was like a tear” (TC’s journal; privately owned). Ruskin wrote to Mary Aitken, 3 Jan. 1872: “I’ve sent you a little Venetian chain, which my Mother used to wear— She liked it best of all her chains. The gold is very pure, and if you will be at the pretty pains of washing it, will I hope gleam out with Venetian light” (MS: NLS 555.58). and to you there is a strange, regretful, mournful desolation, in looking before and back;—to all of us the loss of our Mother is a new epoch in our Life-pilgrimage, now fallen lon[e]lier and sterner than it ever seemed before.— — I cannot come to you; nor would it be proper or permissible, for reasons evident. But I beg you very much to come to me at any hour, and let me see you for a little, after those sad and solemn duties now fallen to you are performed. Believe always that my hearts sympathies are with you, and that I love you well.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-MW [MEW], 7 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 9207. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO META WELLMER

docBody.p:
Punctually three days ago your Letter reached me, a sad but very kind and welcome arrival here.Meta Wellmer apparently wrote TC a birthday letter; now untraced. She had done so in previous years; see 45:207MAI to MEW, 3 Dec. 1868, and 47:116–17MAI to MEW, 3 Dec. 1870. Often enough you have been in my thoughts since that
stern calamityThe death of her mother; see 47:171MAI to MEW, 12 March 1871. came upon you on a sudden,—like the whirlwind striking the four corners of Job’s House,Cf. Job 1:19. and sweeping it to wreck, leaving his existence, which a moment before had been so happy and loving sheltered, for the future all desolate bare and silent! Alas, I can too well conceive it, and see too well how sternly irremediable it seems to you, and how poor the small something is that can be done to remedy it.— Being ignorant of your address, certain only that you had shifted elsewhither,Wellmer was now living in Zurich; she wrote to TC from there, 18 Dec. we could not write; and this new Letter, sad as it is, came like good news in comparison. The very day before, without the least remembrance of “December 4,” or of any chance there was for us that day, I was anxiously thinking of you and trying to contrive some expedient. Thanks for what you have done; this Letter is a real relief and favour.

Many thanks too for the Photograph,Possibly one of the unidentified women’s photographs found in the later vols. which brings you so much nearer to us than words could: this is an excellent German physiognomy, comely to the eye and mind; strong, yet gentle, delicate, full of resolution, affection veracity of soul and word;—sufficiently expressive to me of the qualities and talents I had otherwise already recognised in you.

Dear Miss Wellmer, you must not sit down in indolent despair over this misery that has naturally so shattered you. You are yet in the flower of your years and have much good work lying in you, which it is much a duty and obligation for you still to do. This is a truth that I tell you not an idle figure of speech; and in fact it is the sum of all the advice and encouragement I have to give. Other remedy in sorrow and affliction except strenuous labour I could never find;TC was apparently working on his preface to the Færeyinga Saga (TC to JCA, 13 Oct.) as he commented in his journal, 8 Dec., on Dahlmann’s “Denmark Histy, read for the sake of that old Saga” (TC’s journal; privately owned); Dahlmann’s Geschichte von Dännemark did not discuss the sagas and only mentioned Snorro Sturleson in a footnote (1:110–11); TC was to describe it as “accurate, learned and unwearied” (Carlyle, “Early Kings,” Works 30:201). but in that there is gradual remedy, and a solacement from the very first. Lay this to heart and practically consider it I beg of you. I know not whether you could again think of undertaking tuition, even of a gifted young soul and in the favourablest circumstances; but that if you did like it, is still clearly within your scope. In literature too you may believe me when I speak it, there are useful things, far beyond what reviewers call useful that are still possible to you. Not everybody, you may depend on it has as clear a recognition, and as genial and piously wise a judgement of the many things she has
experienced and looked at itThus in MS. this world. I liked very much, for instance, those Nürnberg Sketches you sent me years ago;Wellmer had sent TC a letter from Nürnberg sometime in 1868; see 45:207MAI to MEW, 3 Dec. 1868. still better perhaps those traceries of personal experience in France:See 47:116MAI to MEW, 3 Dec. 1870. —in fact a little Picture of yourself and what you have seen and lived through in this world, would not even that be a thing to prize? Work I bid you, Work while it is still called today.Cf. John 9:4 and Carlyle, Sartor 146.

I had but little more to say, if anything; and the paper is done. Mary herself is writing to you; and I doubt not will furnish abundant details.Mary wrote to Wellmer, 6 Dec., telling her about the death of her brother James Aitken; she sent Wellmer a photograph of herself, although she did not like it, as TC insisted; she concluded: “My Uncle writes to you today; so this will go with his letter” (MS: NLS Acc. 9207).
God bless you, dear Miss Wellmer,

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 7 Dec. MS: NLS 527.56. Quot: Cate 165–66. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand; TC’s signature cut away.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
I expected you would like the Dickens; no doubt Jean also will be curious about it;John A. Carlyle wrote, 4 Dec.: “I have read most of Forster, & will give it to Jean. … The first part of the volume is very interesting, & perhaps the too abundant details of the rest of it are unavoidable from Forster’s point of view.” by all means let her see it. By all means too let the RussellsDr. James and Mary Russell, JWC’s old friends. John had asked if he could send it to them “when Jean gets done with it?” have it;—after which here is poor Mary waiting who has never yet seen it except on the outside and ought to have a leisurely chance. By a dodge of Frederick Chapman’s, which I find considerably amuses John, the publication is delayed till Friday (tomorrow); by which means there has risen a quasi-famine for the Book; and I am told there are already subscribed for about four thousand copies. Inclosed are a pack of letters which signalized Monday last:TC’s birthday letters; John replied, 10 Dec.: “All the letters & notes … were interesting to us here; were read by me first of all, & then downstairs partially in the morning, & completely in the evening.” I hardly expect you will yourself have patience for them; but my Sister I know will
like to read such of them as are fairly legible. None of them, so far as I care, need to be returned.

The Shropshire BaronetSir Baldwyn Leighton. brought me 2 days ago a Pamphlet Report (extremely dull and unreadable) of the Grand “Poor Law Conference”; one Copy of it I advised that he should send to Charles Stewart; which no doubt he has already done.See TC to JCA, 8 Nov.

Poor Ruskin has lost his Mother; she died Tuesday about 2 p.m. A note from him of three short lines came that night; mournful as if every word were a tear.— Lady Ashburton did at last arrive on Tuesday evening; self and child (the latter recovered from bronchitus by the way) seemed both well and were making due enquiries for you. Forster is coming home almost straight way; himself seemingly rather better, but Mrs F. has taken sorethroat. N.b. she wants a little oatmeal for baking Perkin’s with!Ginger flavored biscuit made with oatmeal and treacle, known as “parkin” or “Scotch Perkins.” Mary thinks two stones should be sent, I decidedly one. Let Jean herself consider and decide.— And so good bye to you all, dear Brother,

postscript.p: Gloves came safely, and are all right (thank Jean, and say).The phrase in parentheses was written by TC; for the gloves, see TC to JCA, 18 Nov.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-CGD, 12 Dec. MS: NLI. Pbd: Charles Gavan Duffy, Conversations with Carlyle (1892) 242–46. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO C. G. DUFFY

docBody.p:
A good many weeks ago, I had your friendly and cheerful little Note, which was very welcome to me after the long silence. It has lain on my table ever since; daily soliciting some answer, and strange to say daily in vain. Truth is, my own right hand having grown entirely useless to me for writing, the business is altogether disagreeable and even, in the old sense, impossible (for “dictation,” do what I will, never rightly prospers); and the indolence and torpor, now grown habitual, especially in these heavy, dark November and December days, with their fogs and fitful frosts, deter me altogether from answering any letter, except under actual compulsion of the hour. Tantùm mutatus ab illo [how changed from what he once was]!Cf. Virgil, Aeneid 2.274. — I also had safely delivered by
the Postman your copy of Homes in the Land of Plenty; recognisable as yours by the handwriting outside, which also was kindly welcome to me: I already had a copy from the Author;Rev. James Ballantyne, Homes and Homesteads in the Land of Plenty: A Handbook of Victoria as a Field for Emigration (Melbourne, 1871). Rev. James Ballantyne (1818–96), b. Galashiels, educ. Glasgow and Edinburgh Univs., ordained United Presbyterian minister, 1848; minister at Earlston, 1848–50, Arthur Street Church, Edinburgh, 1850–54; he was involved in the temperance society and the anti-slavery society; he emigrated to Australia and became a minister in Melbourne, 1855–76. No other contact with TC has been traced. and had read most part of it; but this I sent to the Chelsea Library for behoof of my Fellow-Citizens, and have put yours, as naturally worthier, in its stead. Another paper, excellently written and conceived, concerning the Association of all your Australian Colonies into one,Duffy was prominent in promoting the federation of the Australian states from 1857; he chaired a Royal Commission on the subject that pbd. the report, 3 Oct. 1870, “Federal Union: First Report of the Royal Commission” (Parliamentary Papers 1870 II: 2nd Session, No. 10), in which Duffy emphasized the advantage of federation as a means of common defense against foreign aggression, and demanded the right to remain neutral if Britain was at war. An intercolonial conference was held in Melbourne, Sept. 1871; Duffy’s plan was rejected. I also received and read with approval and good wishes at the time you intended;—for all these things accept my hearty thanks in the lump; and pardon me for loitering so long with that poor return.

It gives me real pleasure to find you again in Office;Duffy was appointed premier and chief secretary of Victoria, June 1871. He wrote to TC, 6 Sept.: “For the last few months I have been employed in steering the ship of the state, and find it a toilsome and exhausting task. But labour never proved so pleasant as carrying long cherished projects into effect, it is the flesh therefore that wearies, not the spirit” (MS: NLS 1770.75). and ruling, so far as any rule is possible, what geographically we may call one of the largest Empires (for your Colony is clearly the presiding one) that is to be found on the face of the earth! I rejoice also to hear that your Ministry succeeds, or was succeeding when we last heard: the ideas you had upon it, so far as I could gather, were sound and good, and deserved success. One thing I always earnestly wish, in reference to Australia and its progress, That you and Mother-Country could contrive some way to have ten times as much emigration. For fifty years the possibility of this, and the immensely beneficial effects of it (especially for us) have hung before my mind as certainties, even as axioms, evident like those of Euclid; the total neglect of which, in the face of such circumstances as ours are now plainly becoming, has often filled me, and yet fills, whenever I think of it (which is now seldomer), with astonishment, impatience and even indignation. “Administrative Nihilism,” as Huxley calls it,“Administrative Nihilism,” Thomas Henry Huxley’s address to the members of the Midland Institute, 9 Oct. 1871; pbd. Fortnightly Review, Nov. 1871. that is the explanation; and, alas, what Huxley does not say or quite see,
Nihilism of that kind is precisely the apple that grows and must grow upon every Parliamentary tree in our day. This I at last perceive; and it quiets me on many a grievance a Government carried on by Parliamentary palaver and Universal Suffrage, with penny newspapers presiding, must necessarily be a Do-nothingism, and neglect [not]Word omitted in MS. only its Colonies, but every other interest, temporal and eternal, except that of getting majorities for itself by hook or by crook. If on these terms we can consider it the best of all kinds of Government, we are free to do so; but the consequences are, have been, and will ever be Nihilism, as above said by Huxley,—nay minusism (as I could say) to an ever more frightful, ruinious, detestable and even damnable extent; the ultimatum of which is Petrolium and what we have seen in Paris not so long ago!— — In spite of all this, I still privately hope there is patriot honesty and probity enough on both sides of the Ocean Not to let this immense and noble interest sink to the seabottom, but to save it as probably the very greatest that ever was entrusted to the guidance of a nation. Enough, Oh far too much of this; what have I to do with it more?

Your friend Forster has been here since I began this letter. He is still busy and unwearied; though laden with a great burden of almost perpetual ill-health, especially in Wintertime. He has just been some weeks on the Southern Coast taking his holiday there; he looks really a little stronger, and will front under better omens the three months’ service that still remain to him. Were April the 5th once here, F. can claim his pension;See TC to JF, 29 Nov. and will without a day’s delay give the matter up. I do hope, and indeed expect, he will be able to achieve this without farther permanent damage; and then there is plain sailing, so far as one can see, and nothing worse.— The whole world is, in these very days and weeks, full of F. and his Life of Dickens, for which there is a perfect rage or public famine (Copies not to be supplied fast enough):Forster’s Life of Dickens sold out before publication; the Athenaeum recorded its progress: “The whole of the first edition of the first volume of Mr. Forster’s ‘Life of Charles Dickens’ has been subscribed for by the trade, and the second edition is at press” (Athenaeum 2 Dec.); “Third edition is nearly ready” (Athenaeum 9 Dec.); “A fifth edition of Mr. Forster’s ‘Life of Dickens’ will appear shortly. Over 2,000 copies have been subscribed for by the trade” (Athenaeum 16 Dec.); “The sixth edition is now ready” (Athenaeum 23 Dec.); “The ninth edition now ready” (Athenaeum 30 Dec.). —I should [think]Word omitted in MS. it likely there is a Copy on the Sea for you too; and that you will read it with interest and satisfaction two or three months hence, in some holiday you may have. It itThus in MS. curious, and in part surprising; yields a true view of Dickens (great part of it being even of his own writing); only one Vol. of it,
the Second not to be begun till after the above-mentioned April 5. Me nothing in it so surprises as these two American explosions round poor Dickens,—all Yankee-doodle-dodom blazing up like one universal Soda-water Bottle round so very measurable a Phenomenon, this and the way the Phenomenon takes it was curiously and even genially interesting to me, and significant of Yankee-doodle-doodom. Vol. First ends with a Soda-Water explosion which we may reckon genially comic; Vol. Second will end with a ditto which has a dark Death’s head in it; and has always seemed to me very tragic and very mournful.The six last chapters of vol. 1 covered Dickens’s visit to North America; it is not clear exactly to which incidents TC referred; see TC to JF, 5 Dec.

With regard to myself, there is almost nothing to be said that you do not already know. A week ago yesterday I entered on my 77th year; I am not worse in health than that means, nor can I brag of being much better; I do retain nearly complete soundness of organs, but the strength of everything is inevitably lessening every day; the Son of Adam has to do,Thus in MS, for “die.” and, if like a tree, it is to be by aid of time alone, one knows not whether that is not perhaps, within certain limits, the less desirable way. But we have no choice left in the matter, and are surely bound to be thankful to be left on any tolerable terms in the Land of the Living and the Place of Hope.See Carlyle, Sartor 121. You ask what I am doing, dear Duffy, I am verily doing nothing,Duffy wrote: “I cannot believe it possible that you are idle and I am watching for the fruit of your labour. You have no choice any more than the river has a choice to flow on till it reaches the sea or the swamp; I do not ask therefore whether you are working, but on what are you working?” (MS: NLS 1770.75). knotting up some thrums of my life’s Web; gazing, with more and more earnestness and generally with love and tenderness rather than any worse feeling into the Eternity which can now only be a few steps ahead: I avoid all company except that of one or two close friends. Last winter I read most of my Goethe over again; reading a good Book is in fact my most favourite employment; even an intelligent book, by an honest-hearted man is tolerable to me, and my best way of spending the evening—Adieu, dear Friend; you see there is not a speck more of room.
docBody.closer:
Ever trulyFrom “Ever truly” in TC’s hand. Yrs,
T. Carlyle.TC made no comment on Duffy’s opinion about Bismarck’s responsibility for the Franco-Prussian War: “I cannot manage to love your Bismark. He seems to me half attorney, half dragon, and I do not know which half of him is least pleasant. He planned that War, and managed to throw the discredit of beginning upon the other side; and he bought success at a price which few of the flesh and blood of man would be willing to pay for it I think” (MS: NLS 1770.75).

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 14 Dec. MS: NLS 527.57. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:281–82 inc. The letter is written in ink in TC’s hand; his signature is cut away.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,—Here is a Letter that came from Alick last night: all is in the usual way there, as you will be thankful to see;—especially poor old Brother John’s readjustment of his housekeeping,For their half-brother, John Carlyle, in Canada, see 47:11TC to JAC, 26 May 1870, and 46:23446:biographical notes; he had apparently moved house recently, probably to live with his da., Janet Ellis; see TC to AC, 16 Dec.; his wife, Peggy, d. 1867. whh is a novelty, was welcome to me! I don’t want the Letter back; do you put it by, somewhere, when done with.— I will also request you to get this £25 changed into a Canada set of dollars in the form of Draught to poor old Brother John;Mary Aitken noted in TC’s checkbook: “14 Decr 1871 / Dr Carlyle / £25 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). in his new quarters, it will be privately a kind of anchor to the poor old heart or imaginatn. Please send it me hither at yr earliest convenience, and his Address along with it, if you know that. Or one might address it to Alick’s care, perhaps most fitly of all.

I have had a miserable 48 hours with half a grouse I dined on, day before yesterday. Catch me eating any more of that kind of bird.TC apparently sent the grouse on to Charles Augustus Ward; Ward wrote, 15 Dec.: “A brace of feathered heather bipeds children of the mists of Morven have sought & found me out, & to my delight their superscription showed that they were angels from the Row of Cheyne. … Very many thanks for the kind thought.” TC wrote on the letter: “Ward (1 specimen).” Ward regularly sent TC presents of autumn fruit (see 47:83TC to CAW, 20 Oct. 1870) and Ward wrote, 4 Dec.: “Bearer will leave herewith the annual fruit of a summer land, which … pray accept with customary kindness.” Morven, hill in the Scottish highlands. Thank Heaven I can still get down a little bit of mutton or beef, to keep the old wheel still creaking and turning at the cistern, till it finally stop, and have done.

A proper artist in St James’s StreetPossibly Pierpont Robert, Leather Merchants, 97 St. James St. is making me a laced Mitten (or Muffetee reaching to the knuckles,—whh is to steady my poor right hand to a wonderful degree,—if it can! I wish it cd, don’t I! One of the cruellest items of my outward lot is this of having lost the power of writing. I cd still work a little now and then, but for that. “Dictatn” brings mere diluted moonshine; ah me!— — Yesterday, Lady Ashburton’s brougham (she is here for a week past, so far towds Melchet at last, and is kept in the house by a slight sore-throat of her Mary’s).Her da., Mary Florence. I drove out to DenmarkWord repeated with a line over it on new page. Hill; a strangely misty, mournful, silently meaning-ful, lonesome and beautiful drive to and from: Ruskin was
not there; gone to Town with his CousinPresumably Joan Severn, b. Agnew. on busss,”—whh probably was just as well, in the mood and state I was in. Rn, I believe, is abt quitting Dk Hill altogr; going to OxfordRuskin was appointed Slade Prof. of Fine Art at Oxford, 1869, and regularly lectured there from Feb. 1870; see TC to JRU, 21 Oct. and Coniston Water:During the summer Ruskin had purchased a small house, Brantwood (which he was to enlarge substantially), Coniston Water, Cumberland; following the death of his mother, 5 Dec., he began planning to move there. I am very wae and anxs, abt him

Needn’t return any of these Letters; give Jean whatr use of them she likes,—with my love to her, and you and every one. Adieu, dear Brother.TC wrote: “Dr Carlyle / The Hill / Dumfries” on the reverse of the final page, presumably for someone else to write the envelope.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-AC, 16 Dec. MS: MUL. Pbd: Marrs 774–77. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO ALEXANDER CARLYLE

docBody.p: The night before last your welcome Letter came to hand; I am very glad to hear of you again, with nothing but good news, after so long a silence. Neither of us can now write much; to myself the inability to write with my own poor right hand is, on all sides, a severe affliction, and announcement that my work is properly speaking done: but not the less, nay all the more, perhaps, one’s thoughts go free; and I doubt not there is fully as much communication between Canada and me in that way as there ever was by any other. Many thanks for the trouble you have taken to give me some shadow of your doings and various fortunes there.

One bit of news gratified me specially: that of poor old Sandbed JohnTheir half-brother, John, was known as Sandbed John because he was raised by his grandfather John Carlyle (ca. 1742–1835; see 8:102TC to JAC, 30 April 1835), farmer at Sandbed, Middlebie parish. getting out of his lonesome Shanty into a better circle of surroundings;—I do hope and trust his DaughterJohn Carlyle’s surviving da. was Janet Ellis, b. Carlyle. will be daughter-like, and faithfully good to him; she must be much unlike what I can suppose her if this be not an altogether favourable change for the poor old man. That of the Kist-lid bed and heap of duds, where you had last seen him, was a most grim and rugged picture; totally unsuitable to the most stoical old man within a step or two of his 80th year!— Directly on reading your Letter, the wish rose in me to send the
good old man a little Gift and Memorial of kinship and days that are gone; I wrote, accordingly, at once to John at Dumfries, and he at once returns me the enclosed Bank Document,See TC to JAC, 14 Dec. which you are to get translated into a Draft of Canada Dollars for him and to present inclosed in the letter, bearing his address, which goes along with this. I know well you will not grudge the trouble, and will do the thing with punctuality and convenient speed. The Dr from Dumfries suggests that New-Year’s Day would be a fit time for your making your appearance with the little message: “at Old New-Year’s Day,”“Old New-Year’s Day” under the Julian Calendar was 12 Jan. and was still traditionally celebrated as New Year in parts of Scotland. if not at New, there will be time enough to have the thing ready,—we here for our part waste no time, but write by the very first post. I also enclose the Dr’s Letter of this morning, which contains the freshest news from our kindred in Scotland,—and at least tells you the state of the weather!

Our poor Sister at Dumfries bears up valiantly under what is doubtless the heaviest stroke that ever befel her:The death of Jean’s son James Aitken Jr.; see TC to JCA, 13 Oct. I was at Dumfries sitting at breakfast with her when the Telegram came, summoning Mary and her to London; I have seldom seen a more pathetic scene than that of her rising instantly from the half done meal and starting on the tragic journey, and with a world of wild sorrow carefully repressed, or struggling nobly to repress itself, getting down to the railway in little less than half an hour. The whole occurrence was of cruelly tragic nature; and has deeply grieved us all. There is only one Son now left to poor Jean; John, the youngest of the three; whom I think you never saw; he is now in London, getting settled as a Clerk favourably beside us here;—it was on rapid visit to him that poor James found his death in that tragic manner. This John also is an honest, ingenious and kindly creature, of whom we all hope good, now that he has got delivered out of his long dormantcy (as Clerk at Dumfries in some Branch Bank, under one they called Leein’ Jamie)James Gordon (1809–84); John Aitken was previously employed as a bank clerk at the Commercial Bank, Dumfries; see 47:82TC to WM, 17 Oct. 1870. into a wider and freer field.

Your own two Boys made a memorable day for me last Autumn;Alick and James Carlyle, who visited Britain in the summer; see 47:222TC to SWA, 9 Aug. 1871. and I may tell you, their Father, that I really liked them both well, as indeed we all did in the Old Country; I have seldom seen a pair of young men, whose modest rational and affectionate ways were more agreeable to me. You may tell Alick in particular—or even not tell him, if you so think fitter—that I expect considerable things from him, in the Scholarly or otherwise intellectual way, though I by no means urge that on him, No, No. let him try to be a faithful
man in whatever station he alights; that is all I require of him. To your good Jimmie also, whose sensible discreet and kindly way, and even whose Yankee accent (or even imagined resemblance of such) was singular and agreeable to me, I send my affectionate regards and best wishes,—do not forget this. Goodluck be with them all, poor Fellows. There is something mournfully beautiful to see the hearty Young Ones starting on the race, when one is quitting it oneself. Right good speed to them, and honest speed above all!

Our Brother Jamie of Scotsbrig we hear is at Birmingham, with his Daughter and Son in law,Jenny and William Scott. whither he often goes of late years in the Winter season; I suppose he feels better there; his Daughter is naturally very good to him. I believe her Husband too is a worthy and friendly sort of man, and that they are well enough off in their financial affairs. Poor Jamie has generally a good deal to do with ill-health, want of sleep &c, want of power to eat, poor Fellow;—and I can well believe that a skilful Nurse and Cook who takes pains with him must be of great benefit and comfort in his case. At home he usually alternates between Scotsbrig and Craigenputtock; liking the latter rather more (they can observe) the HousewifeCatherine, wife of James Carlyle Jr., at Craigenputtoch. there being rather the skilfuller. John’s WifeMargaret, wife of John Carlyle, at Scotsbrig. at Scotsbrig is a very amiable honest creature, whom I have seen just twice, for a little while each time, but I can believe the general opinion entertained, that in housewifery she is below the level rather than above. Jamie is prosperous otherwise, and I believe has plenty to live upon, and latterly finds all his enterprises prosper reasonably well.

Be so good as send me one word, dear Brother, when you have received this enclosure, and undertaken this message: one word to this effect (or even a Newspaper addressed to me with three strokes) will suffice so far: so soon as you have delivered the thing, please report in another word;—but this you can make TomAlexander’s eldest son, Thomas. do. That will be the method: Newspaper first, then Letter by Tom or Jimmie.
God bless you all, young and old, dear dear Brother. I ever am,

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JHB-B [JHBB], 20 Dec. MS: Balfour-Browne. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO J. H. BALFOUR-BROWNE

docBody.p: You are welcome to dedicate your new Book to me,Marshall Hamilton, Men Were Deceivers Ever (1872), pbd. under one of Balfour-Browne’s pseudonyms, was dedicated “(by permission) / to / THOMAS CARLYLE, ESQ., / with the profound respect / and / grateful admiration of the / author.” if you incline to do me that honour. I found a good deal of unripe talent in the former Book;Marshall Hamilton, For Very Life (1871); see MA to JHBB, 10 Oct. and hope, and expect, this new one will shew features of improvement;—which is a process that should never end with a man, and cannot too soon begin. I could much recommend conciseness and the rigorous exclusion of all that does not bear upon the goal you aim at. This precept, you will gradually find, contains an infinitude of others, and indeed will lead, if loyally followed out, to almost every other.
Heartily wishing you good speed in the best sense of that word,—I remain

closer.note: John A. Carlyle, 25 Dec., enclosed a clipping from the Scotsman, 25 Dec., “containing a letter from Professor Masson about the Edinr University & its relation to the Ladies Educational Association.” The Edinburgh Ladies Educational Assoc. was founded (15 Oct. 1868) to encourage women’s education at a univ. level through programs of lectures. Masson also supported the separate campaign for women medical students’ admission to Edinburgh Univ.; see 47:152TC to JAC, 10 Feb. 1871.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JM [JMA], 23 Dec. MS: British Museum. Hitherto unpbd. James Marshall, secretary to the grand duke and duchess of Weimar (see below). Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JAMES MARSHALL

docBody.p:
You were very good very diligent and successful in that matter of Goethe’s Hand;Mary Aitken had written to Marshall earlier in the year at TC’s request (letter untraced), asking if he knew if there were a cast of Goethe’s hands. Marshall replied, 20 June, that as he was not in Weimar at the time, he had asked his son to enquire and had since heard that there was such a cast, currently untraced; he, Marshall, would be returning to Weimar very soon, and would continue the search. He had apparently been successful. and gave the “great lady”Lady Ashburton; Mary Aitken wrote to her, 23 June: “I have here copied the part of a Letter wh. came to my Uncle this morning (in answer to one I wrote to Mr Marshall at Weimar) which refers to the possibilities of getting a Cast of Goethe’s Hands. We hope he will be able to find them” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). much satisfaction in regard to it. I have not
myself seen the plaster Cast; but it is safe at Melchet within a hundred miles of me; and I hope to admire it attentively with much interest one day. Though it seemed a singular fact that Madame von GoetheOttilie von Goethe (1796–1872), Goethe’s da.-in-law; she had cared for Goethe until his death in 1832. could not recognize it either to be or else not to be the great Man’s hand, I thought and think there could be no reasonable doubt but that it was veritably his; at all event there was evidently no clearer evidence anywhere to be obtained on the subject.

I owe you many thanks for your prompt kind, and indeed troublesome endeavours in this matter; and in short for the expeditious felicity with which you accomplished and finished it. The Lady herself I believe wrote you a word of receipt and acknowledgment; I had myself undertaken to pay you the small money-expense (which indeed, so far as I could guess your German Coins into English, was singularly small, not a half or a third of what it might have been): but now, in this long delay, I have both lost the papers and quite forgotten the sum;—so that unless my good Marshall will again have the kindness to tell me what it was, and how to send it from England to Weimar, I absolutely cannot pay him! From this small downbreak into Bankruptcy let him again relieve me, if his goodness will again go so far!—

Meanwhile I have, what has for some months been my intention, had a copy of Oliver Cromwell (“people’s edition”),Oliver Cromwell’s Letters and Speeches, vols. 15–19 of the people’s edn. (1871–72). Marshall replied, 1 Feb. 1872, apologizing for the delay, explaining that it was caused by the death of his oldest son, 6 Jan. He continued: “Your Cromwell has proved a real god-send to me in these dreary days—so much so indeed, that I cannot help thinking that it was a higher power than mere chance, which prompted you to send it me at the time you did. The high, unworldly tone of thinking which pervades both the text and the commentary has been a support and comfort to me during many a long sleepless night.” Marshall had four sons, another of whom had d. 1854 (see 29:268TC to JMA, 25 Feb. 1855), and one da. the latest of the things they have been printing for me here, packed up for you, to be dispatched for Weimar day after tomorrow, by such conveyance as there is; and I hope it may arrive sometime about New-Year’s Day; and be a kind of friendly salutation to you though otherwise of little or no use. If it say symbolically that I look back with pleasure and affection on all the passages that have been between us, and wish you cordially, you and yours, all manner of good in this world or elsewhere, it will certainly tell you no lie nor shadow of a lie! and so give it welcome, dear Marshall.

I have grown very old, and am naturally growing weaker year by year and day by day: but except weakness, I have no special complaint, no bodily organ zone diseased at all; & am faring along slowly steadily the “way of all the Earth,” under the fairest kind of circumstances granted to those that are doomed to live so long. Mournfully tender, very solemn, very strange it often seems to me; but I try to “live in Islam,” as Goethe tells us we should all do;Goethe, “Book of Maxims” verse 39, West-östlicher Divan (1819): “If Islam means submission to God, we all live and die in Islam’s dominion.” See also Carlyle, Works 5:56. and indeed know no other precept or recipe that will fit all worlds. Very hateful to me are the Anarchies, the platitudes and basenesses of these poor times that are come. Detestable, contemptible, altogether damnable seem to me the Darwinisms, and other Philosophic Balderdashes (Poltertaschen) that have risen; but I hold my peace upon them, know they can be temporary only; and peaceably hold on my way. Why quarrel now with any ugliest jackass one may find upon the road, which is so near done?

I have not heard of WilsonMarshall wrote: “Mr Wilson and Wife are very well, and have both been very kind to me on the late trying occasion.” Thomas Wilson; their last recorded contact was Oct. 1870; see 47:73–74TC to [TWI], [early Oct. 1870]. for a long while; but hope he and his household are well. If you or he, or both of you, or any body, would send me some news of Weimar, it would be very welcome. Do not fail, when opportunity arises to offer my humble services and loyal homages to the High and Noble LadyMarshall’s current employers were Karl Alexander (1818–1901), grand duke of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach 1853–1901, and his wife, Princess Sophie of the Netherlands (1824–97); TC was probably thinking of the duke’s mother, grand duchess Maria Paulowna (1786–1859), whom he had met in 1852; see 27:301–2TC to JWC, 25 Sep. 1852. whom you have the happiness to serve, whom I always think of with true respect, gratitude and devotion. Adieu, dear Marshall; I remain ever

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 20 Jan. MS: NLS 527.58. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:282–83 inc. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:245. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Here is another day of miscellaneous wet puddle that, out of its interruptions and confusion, will yield nothing for me but a glaury walk in Mackintosh to Hyde Park and back;—preceeded by this little word to you in such circumstances as there are.

I duly received your two letters about the beginning of the week; and was much obliged for the trouble you had taken. Thornhill, especially Holm Hill and its memories remain with me always, upon what basis you well know; I am very glad to hear that poor Mrs Russell is rather in an improving state at least not worse, or visibly growing so; and the honest old Dr and she are not to have their household gods, and innocent life-partnership swallowed in dark clouds, as all earthly households have to be, till a yet unknown time. Give my best regards to both of them by your next opportunity.Dr. James and Mary Russell of Holmhill; John A. Carlyle wrote, 11 Jan.: “Yesterday I went to see Dr & Mrs Russell. … I found Mrs Russell looking better than when I saw her in October. She has had less of headaches, generally sleeps tolerably well, & looks cheerful & resigned. The Dr also looked better. … [They] desired me to send their affectionate regards to you.” For Mary Russell’s illness, see 47:12–13TC to JAC, 26 May 1870. This book, Brett Harte,Bret Harte (1836–1902), American writer, poet, and journalist; he wrote stories set in the western U.S. (including the California gold rush following 1849), tales of native Americans, and Spanish legends. His recent works included The Luck of Roaring Camp: And Other Sketches (Boston, 1870), That Heathen Chinee and Other Poems Mostly Humorous (1871), and Lothaw or the Adventures of a Young Gentleman in Search of a Religion (1871). a recent American Celebrity, may perhaps suit them for reading, or perhaps even you or Jean at Dumfries in the first place. It belongs intrinsically to Mary to whom I made gift of it some time ago, but she is willing to surrender it awhile on this errand, having herself read it before. Brett Harte himself is a notable kind of object, a man altogether modelled upon Dickens, like Dickens, seeking his Heroes in the region of b[l]ackguardism and the gutters, where heroic magnanimities and benevolences, I believe, were never found; and delineating them like him by ell-deep mimicry instead of penetration to the real root of them and their affairs,—which indeed lies much farther down! Like Dickens, however he does the feat generally rather well; and I suppose will continue at the same mode of workmanship, though a man of more weight of metal than Dickens was. I heard first that he was still young, which made me think he might mend; but by the last accounts he is towards 40; and I consider shaped for life. Read him, if you can at Dumfries, then at Holmhill;John replied, 22 Jan., thanking TC for his letter and the books: “Jean has already read most of the American, & she thinks it will be interesting to Dr & Mrs Russell.” John wrote, 28 Jan. “I did read Harte’s Californian stories one evening & found them amusing, & here & there very clever, but one could not stand much continuance of such reading.” and let him fight his own battle. Last night there came some messages newspapers &c from Canada: one Letter, insignificant enough, I think from near Niagara,Unidentified further. which I enclose today; and another vastly superior Note from Emerson;Ralph Waldo Emerson wrote, 5 Jan., that “the last rich instalment of your Library Edition” had arrived: “& now my stately collection is perfect. … Happy man you should be, to whom the Heaven has allowed such masterly completion.” which I keep here for a day or two, not having yet got it properly read,
but will send to you in a day or two. My other Canada communication was a Newspaper from Alick Junior at Bield; Newspaper with nothing in it, but with three strokes on the cover of it, which perhaps was meant as an indication that the Money order for poor old JohnJohn Carlyle, their half-brother; see TC to JAC, 14 Dec. 1871. had come to hand. Or perhaps not? For there came from Alick Junr, withal, a Letter for Mary,Mary Aitken and Alick Carlyle met the previous summer; see 47:222TC to SWA, 9 Aug. 1871. which, it seems, said nothing of it. One word on the subject I shall hope to get by and by; but may do without it tow, like the gomeril at Scotsbrig in reference to the moon.Unidentified.

A full week ago you were promised to have that poor “Preface” to the Saga, touching upon the Norse Kings it is concerned with; alas, it is not yet finished,See TC to JCA, 13 Oct. 1871. TC and Mary completed their translation of the Færeyinga Saga mid-Dec. 1871, but TC had not yet finished the preface that was to form the basis of “Early Kings of Norway” (1875). William Allingham recorded in his diary, 24 Jan.: “C. dictating to his niece introduction to the Saga—Heimskringla, Norse Chiefs” (Allingham Diary 208). nor dare I yet promise it in another week. Nothing can excel or equal the interruptions & paltry obstacles that have continually come in the way of ending it: but end it I will, if spared alive;—nay, in the meanwhile, it is better to me, with all its chaotic adjuncts, than if I had in my mind nothing at all to regard as “Work.” As I grope about, read SnorroSnorro Sturleson; see TC to JCA, 13 Oct. 1871. again &c &c, I find a great many meanings attach themselves to those old Tryggvesons, Hakons, Olafs,Olaf Tryggavson (ca. 960–1000), king of Norway 995–1000, Haakon Haraldsson, or Haakon the Good (ca. 920–61), king of Norway 934–61, Olaf the Thick-set, and Olaf II, or Olaf the Saint (995–1030), king of Norway 1015–28; see Carlyle, Works 30:201–310. and their work in this world; and if I knew Icelandic, like you,John A. Carlyle had used his knowledge of Icelandic to criticize TC’s trans.; he wrote, 25 Dec. 1871: “It is on the whole very readable, though incorrect in several places so far as I can see. I have gone through it all. It is from the German of Mohnike [see TC to JCA, 13 Oct. 1871], which I have not here & therefore cannot judge how far he has deviated from the original.” He then listed some specific corrections: “I have marked errors in pencil as I went thro’ the Saga; but if there is to be any detailed correction, I shd require to have the vol. you translate from beside me. The Saga is not without merits, though one of the poorest I have read.” He continued with further corrections of Icelandic word meanings. (and, alas, if I had my own right hand but not otherwise), I feel as if I could still write a rather bright and useful little Book about them! which reminds me of the old rough proverb in Annandale dialect— If Ifs and ands were pots & pans!Proverbial. In brief you shall have that Preface, if I be spared a little while.

Adieu, dear Brother, for this day; it is full time I were addressing myself to my muddy walk, since that is to be the sole achievement, as appears. This tepid, dark and glaury weather I think with you, is unfavourable to health;
as, certainly, it is depressing and distressing. Nevertheless, except continual trouble with the grinder teeth, or the gums there about, I dont feel worse than usual, rather the reverse; and have reason to be thankful. Give my love to Jean and everybody; my Blessings on you all.
docBody.closer:
Ever your affectionate Brother,
T. Carlyle.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 25 Jan. MS: NLS 527.59. Hitherto unpbd. Written by TC in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: You will not see the Norse Book of KingsJohn wanted to see Rafn and Mohnike’s Færeyínga saga (see TC to JCA, 13 Oct. 1871) to judge how different it was from the original; see TC to JAC, 20 Jan. whh we are busy with (Heaven help us!) not till “the end of still another week” at soonest. Too weak is the poor champion grown; too diligt, extensive and incessant the enemy and crowd of enemies and anarchies here! All I can say is, the battle continues, and shall continue: what more can one do. The element externally is one of continl muddy darkness, latterly with deluges of rain;—nor, alas, is the internal element much better; perhaps in essentials it is even worse;—nor can one much mend it either; oftenest all one can do is but to take besoms & umbrellas & defend oneself a little (here too), and for the rest never to give in!— Today, after puddle of sevl ineffectual kinds, I can at least send you Emerson’s Letter whh I promised; where to I will another from a certn good Norfolk ParsonWhitwell Elwin, an old friend of Forster’s, was rector of Booton, Norfolk. Elwin “appreciated [TC] personally; visited him at Chelsea, and enjoyed several evenings with him at Forster’s, where they were the only two persons who were allowed to smoke” (Some XVIII Century Men of Letters, Biographical Essays by the Rev. Whitwell Elwin, with a Memoir, ed. Warwick Elwin [1902] 1:251). whom I sometimes see at Forsters, & who has been talking with me abt his writing or trying to write some Sketch of Lockhart’s Life by and by.Elwin succeeded John Gibson Lockhart (1794–1854; ODNB), writer and literary editor, as editor of the Quarterly Review, 1853. In 1871 “Carlyle begged Elwin to write the Life of his old chief, but, though he continued to urge it on him, it was without avail. The subject would have been congenial, and doubtless it was materials that were lacking” (Some XVIII Century Men of Letters, Biographical Essays by the Rev. Whitwell Elwin, with a Memoir, ed. Warwick Elwin [1902] 1:94). You can return me both the Letters (as well as Boxall’s;Sir William Boxall (1800–1879; ODNB), portrait painter, director of the National Gallery 1866–74. He had asked TC for some historical information about a recent acquisition, and wrote thanking him, 23 Jan.: “I thank you heartily for the ready fulfilment of your kind promise … a valuable memorial of your kindness to me as well as a document full of information and giving increased interest to the subject represented in the picture.” TC wrote on his letter: “Had sent Boxall (by request) something abt Dutch-Spanish Treaty of Münster,—illustrative of Terborch’s Picture concerng it. jany 1872.” Gerard ter Borch, “Ratification of the Treaty of Münster” (1648). The painting was donated to the National Gallery by Richard Wallace (1818–90; ODNB), art collector and philanthropist, 1871. whom I think you know) by any opportunity there is.

Browning’s
Book came duly, and lies here: I had already seen and read it,—and nobody else will consent to! Yr own acct of it is perfectly exact, “worth nothing at all.”John wrote, 22 Jan.: “By yesterday’s post I sent you Browning’s new work. It was much praised in the Daily News, Scotsman &c & I got a copy. … I disliked it much, & think it worth nothing, except one could take delight in mere dexterity of versification”; presumably one of the two new long poems by Robert Browning, 1871, Balaustion’s Adventure: Including a Transcript from Euripides (Aug. 1871), and Prince Hohenstiel-Schwangau, Saviour of Society (Dec. 1871). Brg has been growing steadily worse for some good while; & this is his worst hitherto.TC had been more appreciative of Browning’s The Ring and the Book (1868–69); see 46:2TC to JAC, 11 Jan 1869. Allingham reported TC’s views of that poem during a walk in Hyde Park, 2 Jan.: “C. praised parts of The Ring and the Book very highly—‘showing a most intimate acquaintance with Italian life—better, I think, than anything else of Browning. … But the whole is on a most absurd basis. The real story is plain enough on looking into it; the girl and the handsome young priest were lovers’” (Allingham Diary 207). But we know not for how long.

LastWord repeated at turn of page. night we dined at Miss Brley’s;Caroline Davenport Bromley. a miserable business; but it was not to be avoided: Brookfield,William Henry Brookfield. Lady Eastlake (terrific giantess)Lady Elizabeth Eastlake (1809–93; ODNB; see 37:152–53TC to JAC, [2 April] 1861); “a strikingly handsome, imperial-looking woman, of commanding figure (she was 5 ft. 11 in. in height)” (Journals and Correspondence of Lady Eastlake, ed. Charles Eastlake Smith [1895] 1:30). and some strangers. Ach Himmel.— On Sunday night we are to go to Forster’s; no denial wd he take—oh dear, oh dear! Fr seems rather better; & has the fair prospect of holding out for his “2 months” (till April next), the rather as he is not to be sent travelling, but to stay at home and in “the Office” now.
Take care of yrselves all of you, & wish me well, as I know you always do. My love to Jean in partr.—
docBody.closer: Ever yr wh[olly] Affecte Brr / T. Carlyle

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 3 Feb. MS: NLS 527.60. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
My dear Brother,—Many thanks for your Letter; it is longer more deliberate than usual & contains various details & observations that were interesting to
read.John A. Carlyle replied, 28 Jan., commenting on letters TC had enclosed in TC to JAC, 25 Jan., including one of Emerson’s. He wrote about J. G. Lockhart being partly blamed for the duel between Jonathan Henry Christie (1792–1876), lawyer, and Dr. John Scott (1783–1821), resulting in Scott’s death; see 1:302TC to JAC, 9 Jan. 1821, and Leonidas M. Jones, “The Scott-Christie Duel,” Texas Studies in Literature and Language, vol. 12 no. 4 (Winter 1971) 605–29. John then commented on the working life of Lockhart: “One can hardly imagine a more unwholesome occupation than he had in working for the early numbers of Blackwoods Magazine in such a place as Edinr then was. … He had much more talent than he gets credit for, had a real feeling for all that is highest & noblest in literature, & supreme hatred & disdain for every kind of meanness & imposture.” I intended you a long letter today; but am driven by stress of time &c to put you off with a mere word, to the effect that all is in the usual way here.— You may tell Jean also that her beautiful collarsJean C. Aitken wrote, 30 Jan.: “I last night sent off … a dozen of shirt collars for you—having noticed that the old ones were a little frayed when you were here. … Will you kindly accept them as the smallest of gifts.” She ended her letter: “I wd be so glad if you could send me a single line sometimes. But do not if it bothers you as I much fear it does.” have arrived within the last ½ hour all safe, 4d to pay (Mary says they wd have come by post altogether for 4d! consider another time). Thank Jean very much; say I find her very mindful & the collars seem first rate.

You will get yr Fraser on Tuesday morning. I might almost have sent it today but do not quite. There are several articles worth looking into, especially one by Owen upon—“Longevity” (of the old Hebrew Patriarchs particularly!),Richard Owen’s “On Longevity,” Fraser’s Magazine (Feb. 1872): 218–233, refuted the assumption that “the longevity specified in Genesis v. might be possible in the sense of compatibility with the physiologically ascertained laws of human life” (219). that contains curious observations & physiognomic Owenisms also, not a few. Of course you can have our following Frasers forwarded, without ill done to me or to poor Walter at AuchtertoolRev. Walter Welsh, minister, Auchtertool, Fife. in any means or degree upon the terms offered by you. All right that.

Today there has come an interesting letter from MarshallJames Marshall; see TC to JM, 23 Dec. 1871. of Weimar, with a thrice interesting enclosure (wh. might really be a kind of indiscretion on Marshalls part, did not one take heed!).— I send the whole to you read it to Jean only, pray, after you have made it out yrself & send it back at yr convenience.Marshall wrote, 1 Feb.: “I did [give] your messages to the Grand-Duchess—or, rather … I sent her your letter to read. … She returned me the letter accompanied with a brief note, which so exactly expresses my own appreciation of it, that, at the risk of committing a very great indiscretion, I venture to enclose it along with this.” John sent it back quickly as TC wrote in his journal, 15 Feb.: “Pretty little Note abt me from the Grand-Duchess of Weimar;—whh I will stick on here, unless it be already lost … ‘Grand-Duchess of Weimar, to her Secy Marshall (jany 1872)’”; the letter (in French) was about Marshall’s letter from TC. TC wrote on the reverse: “inclosed in Letter from Marshall,—now lying somewhere among my Brother’s big packages here” (TC’s journal; privately owned). For the grand duchess Maria Paulowna, see TC to JM, 23 Dec. 1871. I will not add another word, Mary withal being very eager to get out
to keep her appointment with John.John and Mary Aitken went for walks together on Saturdays; see TC to JCA, 18 Nov. 1871. My blessing on you all.
docBody.closer: EverFrom “Ever” in TC’s hand. affectly / T. Carlyle

bibl.sourceNote: TC-UC, 4 Feb. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd. The letter and postscript is in Mary Aitken’s hand, with several insertions and signature by TC; recipient unidentified.
bibl.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p: Your VersesUnidentified; probably unpbd. which I return by this post are very amiable and pretty; I trace in them clear evidence of natural ingenuity, sensibility and a gracious enthusiastic and most willing mind. But, in very love to you, I am bound to add, that, in my opinion, you do not yet seem fit to be a “Worker” in this vocal way; and that a long course of good reading (wise books, I mean, and avoiding of the foolish kind like poison!) of good reading, earnest study, observation, self-examination and reflection will be the indispensable preliminary to any really useful, wise or important Working in that department. This is not said to discourage you; but only to admonish and exhort.

Another, probably still more severe-looking, thing I must say or hint. That, when you have amassed any stock of thoughts that seem to you new, and justly imperative for utterance, you should rather try to utter them by the direct and clearest method,—namely, in well written prose; verse, or “poetry” as it is called, except when you absolutely cannot express your thought by speaking, but are compelled to singing of it, I have for many years regarded as a melancholy waste of human faculty in those times. This is all I had to say; and you are to accept it as a friend’s word, not an enemy’s,—for that would be a great mistake indeed.
Believe me to be with many thanks for your true, tho’ wildly exaggerated kindness towards me, and with many wishes for your true success and happiness in this world,

postscript.p: P.S. Of course, there will be no needless communication of this scrap of writing, least of all any printing of it in the Newspapers;—far be that from us both, especially from you!

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 10 Feb. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I have had two bad nights, not sleepless altogether, but my worst for several months; and am very low today;—not safe for me to undertake any party or excitation in the evening; the penalties being such, and close ahead! Tomorrow, too, I am to dine with Forster; “a Son of Dickens’sProbably Francis Jeffrey Dickens (1844–86), who immigrated to Canada and joined the North-West Mounted Police in 1874. just going abroad” &c &c; and the impetuous F., though himself very ill, would take no denial.
Adieu, dear Lady; if, as I suppose is likely, I find you flown for today, I intend to call tomorrow between 3 & 4. Ever yours affectionately

closer.note: TC wrote a letter of condolence about this time to Dr. Hogg, one of the elders of Ranelagh Presbyterian Church, Chelsea, on the death, 6 Feb., of Rev. Thomas Alexander (1817–72), minister, ca. 1850–65 (see 39:75TC to JODO, 2 March 1863); subsequently minister of Halkin Street Chapel, Belgrave Sq., he had lived at 18 St. Leonard’s Ter., Chelsea. W. H. Wylie wrote: “Though Mr Alexander was a Presbyterian of the most antique type, advocating stern adherence to the well-trod paths in which the Covenanting fathers travelled, he was on excellent terms with his neighbour in Cheyne Row” (Wylie 344). TC’s letter was read at the funeral (Wylie 344). See also 46:154TC to TAL, 3 Feb. 1870.

bibl.sourceNote: TC’s receipt-C&H [CAH], 13 Feb. MS: Morgan. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with date line and signature in TC’s hand.
bibl.head: TC’s RECEIPT TO CHAPMAN & HALL

docBody.p: Received from Messrs Chapman & Hall Three Bills, payable in Six months from their respective dates, viz:
Half year’s a/c (July 1871 to Nov 30); One hundred and ninety seven pounds, five shillings & 10d
Royalty on Cromwell, vol IV (People’s Editn), One hundred & fifty seven pounds, five shillings & 10d
Royalty on Cromwell, Vol V (People’s Editn), One hundred and fifty seven pounds, five shillings & 10d.

closer.note: TC finished his preface to the Færeyinga Saga 14 Feb.; he wrote in his journal: “Thursday 15 feby. 1872.— Finished yesterday that long rigmarole upon the Norse Kings:—uncertn now what to do with it, if not at once throw it into the fire? It will otherwise need correcting and copying fully;—and in the end is worth nothing at all! Has taught me at least how impossible the problem is to me of writing anything in the least like myself by dictatn; how the presence of a third party betn my thot and me is fatal to any process of clear thot;—how (to summarise all kinds of failure) everythg I write by that kind of method becomes thrice as long as it shd be! But I had taken a Thought to finish this thing thro’ whatr chaos of impedimts; and it has been a kind of daily task to me, useful tho’ ugly, for many months past. Have it copied fair, therefore, and sent to Dumfries (for Brother John and Sister Jean there);—but everybody is forbidden hereby to think of printg any part of it, now or henceforth in its prest state of mere waste instead of drained and culturated field! Ah me; if I had but still my own right Hand;—and is it quite lost forever, then? Today I do write the above; legible, tho’ very slow: try it further; why not?” TC continued his journal, 17 Feb.: “Still idle, or merely endeavourg to annihilate rubbish a little, a very little! The 3d day of that poor functn. Heart sad as can be,—full of mournful memories, and cloudy unspeakable anticipatns and reflexions;—hath grown a most poor place to me, nothing precious, dear or beautiful now for the lonesome old pilgrim!” (TC’s journal; privately owned; pbd: Froude, Carlyle 4:417 inc). Mary Aitken made the fair copy and TC worked on the corrections; see TC to JAC, 24 Feb.

postscript.p: Chelsea, 13 Feby 1872

bibl.sourceNote: TC-DD, 22 Feb. MS: Montague Collection, New York Public Lib. Pbd: David Davidson, Memories of a Long Life (Edinburgh, 1890) 325. Text: Davidson, Memories 325. TC had Davidson’s letter copied by John Aitken (MS: NLS 1770.122); quotations from his letter are taken from that copy; the original, MS: Wilder Books, Elmhurst, Illinois, catalog 70 item 45, is now untraced.
bibl.head: TC TO DAVID DAVIDSON

docBody.p:
Dear Sir,—I am very much obliged indeed by the letter I received from you yesterday morning, right thankful that you were prompted to make that visit, and to write to me such an account of it.Davidson wrote, 19 Feb., describing his visit, 17 Feb., to Betty Braid. He found she had moved two doors further down the street in Greenend, Liberton: “Her new abode is small but neat & comfortable, & in the nice carpeted room we went into I found her husband [Alexander] sitting by the fire.” Not for many a long day have I read any letter so interesting and affecting to me;—a letter which I shall carefully keep among my valuable records! Good old Betty is at this time the most venerable woman that I know in the world. So much of loyalty, of piety, of patient endeavor—in a word, of noble human worth, and fine old Scotch practicality, and simple wisdom to be found there. She belongs to me also, as the last living link of scenes and places now all departed, but dear and sacred to me as no others are. She once told me something, volunteered to tell me, of that sad tragedy which happened in your eighth year;Davidson continued: “On the wall were photographs of her two kind friends, a coloured print of the old Church at Haddington & a photograph of the tomb. The latter led to our speaking of the death of Dr Welsh in 1819, when I was a boy of 8. Vivid were my own recollections of that solemn Sabbath morning when it was whispered that he was dead. … Betty told me most feelingly and with no common graphic power, the circumstances of his illness & death.” Davidson later recorded: “When I got home from this striking interview, I wrote down the substance as nearly as possible in the foregoing words, and sent it off to Mr. Carlyle” (Davidson, Memories 325); for his narrative, see Appendix. a strange and solemn
narrative on her part, and on mine, to which I listened speechlessly attentive: but it was nothing like so minute as yours. Thank you, thank you for this true favour done me! I hope you will again, as you propose, go out and visit poor Betty; and keep me acquainted with anything that befalls her,Davidson wrote: “When I told her I was going to write you she bid me say she was wonderfully well but frail her legs bowing just as they liked, like two willow wands. … Greenside [Greenend] is not so near as I could wish or I should see Betty oftener. But her minister Mr Guthrie, has promised to keep me acquainted with her state of health that I may be ready to see her if unwell.” Betty’s minister was the Rev. David Guthrie, Free Church minister, Liberton; he was one of the sons of Dr. Thomas Guthrie (1803–73; ODNB; see 31:25331:biographical notes), preacher and philanthropist; JWC attended one of his sermons, 1856; see 31:200JWC to TC, [29 Aug. 1856]. so long as she and I are spared alive. The late Mr. ErskineThomas Erskine, d. March 1870, regularly visited Betty Braid; see 47:43TC to BB, 13 July 1870. was a regular link between Betty and me, as long as he lived, but since his death this is wanting to me; and a bright element in poor Betty’s reverential life as well.TC wrote on the front of the MS copy: “addressed, T. Carlyle Esqr, Chelsea; recd 20 feby, with much emotn. T.C.” and on the back: “Copy of Coll Davidson’s Letter to me (of 19 feby 1872) T.C.” On the letter itself he wrote: “19 Feb. (1872) Col. David Davidson abt good old Betty at the death scene at Haddington in 1819; ah me! D’s the questionable, study, … what a unique of Histories it has been to me! To be reposited in my safest place—Here. T.C.” (MS: Wilder Books, Elmhurst, Illinois, catalog 70 item 45). —
docBody.closer:
Believe me, dear sir, yours always with many thanks and regards,
T. Carlyle.Davidson also commented on the death of Rev. Thomas Alexander (see TC to LLA, 10 Feb.): “I was grieved to see the death of Mr Alexander. He was a good man, & kind to my boy now in India when in London. I was struck with the coincidence, driven unconscious to an hospital.” W. H. Wylie wrote that “[Alexander] died very suddenly, and under most distressing circumstances” (Wylie 344). Davidson had five sons (see 35:25535:biographical notes); he probably referred here to the eldest, Henry Chisholm (b. 1851).

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JT [JTY], 23 Feb. Typescript: Royal Institution RI TYP/1.206 (pbd. by courtesy of the Royal Institution). Hitherto unpbd.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN TYNDALL

docBody.p:
My brother answers punctually by return of post; and here is a copy of the
poem itself, as well as perfect indication of its place in Goethe’s Werke.John A. Carlyle wrote, 22 Feb.: “I have received your note this morning, & at once send you the poem of Goethe which you want. Your edition of his works is the same as mine, & you will find it vol. 3d p. 69.” Goethe’s poem “Symbolum” (“Des Maurers Wandeln” or “The Mason’s Ways”), Werke I: Gedichte und Epen (Munich, 1996): 340–41. The edn. John refers to is Goethe’s Werke, 54 vols. (Stuttgart, 1828–33). TC quoted the poem at the conclusion of his inaugural address as rector of Edinburgh University; see 43:185. See also TC to JAC, 24 Feb. It appears we had it in our hands that night; but in our hurry did not know.Tyndall later recalled: “[Carlyle] was intimately acquainted with every nook and corner of Goethe’s work—sometimes more intimately than the poet’s own countrymen. I once had occasion to quote the poem ‘Mason Lodge,’ translated and published in Past and Present [Carlyle, Works 10:237–38]. The article in which it was quoted was afterwards translated into German; the original poem, therefore, required hunting up. None of my friends in Berlin knew anything about it. On learning this I went down to Chelsea, where, in answer to my inquiry, Carlyle promptly crossed his sitting-room and took from a shelf the required volume” (Tyndall, “Personal Recollections” 11).

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 24 Feb. MS: NLS 527.61. Quot: A. Carlyle, NL 2:83–84; Wilson, Carlyle 6:245. TC began the letter, writing in blue pencil until “dictated”; Mary Aitken wrote the rest, with TC signing it.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Punctual to its moment, and complete in every point and portion, came yr ansr of yesterday morning during break. I took yr Copy of the “Symbolum,” and while still drinking my Coffee, Mary’s being done,—dictated to her three words for Tyndall, packed these and Symbolum into an envelope;See TC to JTY, 23 Feb. and so had completely washed my hands of my engagement. A neat little job altogether: thank you much for enabling me to do it so compendiously. Nay I think it was you who first led me to this beautiful little Goethe Poem, and that without you I should probably never have discovered it, certainly not so soon, if ever! which is another perhaps still more considerable favour.

We are working dreadfully, poor Mary & I, at that monster of a Norse preface, or sketch of the Early Kings of Norway; seldom did I undertake a more totally worthless thing, never anything at all which so bothered me in getting executed, or cause so near the impossible in this my fatal want of a right hand. Alas, alas, who could have thought that a shaking right hand would prove such a calamity, and as good as condemn me to silence for the rest of my earthly existence! I persist in this beggarly Norse monster; and will finish it, purely on
one ground, Not to be beaten with it altogether. Mary talks of being actually done with the copying (as I will with the corrections) about the end of next week: you shall then see it, if it could do the least good to you or anybody. If I ever try dictating again I must try it by some new scheme.
