But I begin to see no scheme will ever avail me; and that I am in all essential respects as good as done for;—my right hand having lost its cunning.Cf. Ps. 137:5.

I have no London news to send you, except what you will find in the Newspapers; or indeed might as well not find at all. Upon the Tichborne Trial,Sir Roger Charles Tichborne (1829–1854?), elder son of Sir James Tichborne (1784–1862), 10th bart. and Harriette-Felicité, b. Seymour (1808/9–68), disappeared at sea in 1854. In 1865 a man came forward, later assumed to have been Arthur Orton (1834–98; ODNB) although his identity was never clearly established, and claimed to be Sir Roger; recognized as such by Sir Roger’s mother, the rest of the family disputed this; after her death, 1868, the case went to court; it was not finally resolved until 1874. TC had commented in his journal, 8 Dec. 1871: “‘Tichbourn Trial’ (beastliest of human businesses, into whh I looked one day, and never more) occupies seemingly all Engld these many months,—as if there was nothing else worthy of study or care in this Engld, all anarchic, and now evidently on the eve of declaring itself so by boundless upbreak and downbreak!— The aspect of these matters is too sad for me; it is only by compulsion that I think of them at all” (TC’s journal; privately owned). See also William J. Kinsley, “The Tichborne Case,” Yale Law Journal, vol. 20, no. 7 (May 1911): 563–69. occupying almost all England for above a year, I spent exactly one hour,—convinced in that space that here was the ugliest brute & scoundrel I had ever fallen in with, and utterly a liar; not worth anybody’s notice farther in this serious world. The Gladstone Ministry & its contraversiesThus in MS. against a DizzyBenjamin Disraeli. do; its Alabama Claims,The Alabama, a ship built in Britain for the Confederate States, 1862, was the subject of a compensation claim; see 47:126TC to KVF, 10 Dec. 1870. An arbitration board met in Geneva 1871–72, and awarded the U.S. $15,500,000. The British issued an apology for the destruction caused by British-built Confederate ships, but admitted no guilt. its Ballot BillsIn spring 1872 Gladstone’s Liberal govt. introduced a bill proposing secret ballots for elections, vigorously opposed by Disraeli. After a series of amendments by the House of Lords, the Ballot Act was passed, 18 July. and other imbecilities are a thing painful to look at even from afar. People’s WilliamWilliam Gladstone. himself wishes to be out of it, and certainly will be out soon, if that were of the least importance, which I do not think it is. Enough, enough of all that brutish rubbish, that lies round one as an ugly chaos, saddening one’s poor existence, not cheering it in any way.

I am reading Ruskin’s books, in these evenings; the first 2 voll. of a new edition of them, which he has sent me (voll ii & iii properly, for the 1st has not yet
come:The Works of John Ruskin, 11 vols. (1871–80); the first three volumes are Sesame and Lilies (1871), Munera Pulveris (1872), and Aratra Pentelici (1872). Ruskin wrote to Mary Aitken, 3 Jan.: “I’ve sent him some books. Get him to look at the preface to Munera Pulveris” (MS: NLS 555.58). Ruskin wrote in the preface: “Let me inscribe the second [volume] to the friend and guide who has urged me to all chief labour, Thomas Carlyle” (Munera Pulveris xxvi). I find a real spiritual comfort in the noble fire wrath & inexorability with which he smites upon all base things and wide spread public delusions; and insists relentlessly on having the ideal aimed at everywhere; for the rest, I do not find him wise, headlong rather, and I might even say weak. But there is nothing like him in England in these other respects.— Froude has caught a bad cough (kind of nervous thing) the other day; I am going to him so soon as this is done. Poor Forster also is coughing horribly; thank Heaven he has now nothing more than a month of his public bondage to struggle with; and will then have freer field as well as better weather.

Your Dale-Park Letter is very kind; but also sad, recording so much distress by sickness there— I have no doubt they truly wish to seeThe name is missing, probably because it would have been the first word on a new page. John A. Carlyle’s friends Elizabeth (b. Church) and John Charles Fletcher (1798–1875), lived at Dale Park, Arundel; see 41:61TC to JAC, 6 Oct. 1864. John wrote, 21 March, that he had had a letter from Dale Park “announcing the death of Charles Church [presumably related to Elizabeth Fletcher], who I think was the youngest of the family. He had made what is called a large fortune in Peru, & has had little or no enjoyment from it. Mr. Fletcher has had another threatening of apoplexy, which however has turned out to be severe gout, to which he has long been liable.” on his feet again.— — This morning there came a letter from Gordon.Probably John Gordon. It represents him as getting better but is otherwise of no meaning whatever. Much more singular there came to me, by way of valentine, a pair of warm looking furry bits of slippers, which would not look upon my feet but on my asking Mary if her Mother cd or cd be expected to wear them she answered rather affirmatively; & accordingly by this post I dispatch that miserable item out of my way. The maker & sender is a Mrs Cameron,Probably Julia Margaret Cameron (1815–79; ODNB), photographer; she had a reputation for benevolence and generosity; for a previous gift to TC, see 34:258TC to JMC, 31 Dec. 1858. defined to me sometimes as one of the foolishest, kindest & fondest of the human species,—whom happily I have not seen for years.For Cameron’s photographing of TC, June 1867, see 44:210TC to TMC, 9 June 1867, and 12TC to JRU, 13 June 1867. Mary tells me there is not a scrap of paper more. With my blessings to one & all of you.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-SE&Co., 12 March. MS: untraced; text from typescript. Hitherto unpbd. George Murray Smith (1824–1901; ODNB) and Alexander Elder (1790–1876), publishers, 15 Waterloo Pl., London.
bibl.head: TC TO SMITH, ELDER & CO

docBody.p: If the fact be, as I think it is, that Mr Ruskin has instructed your people to send me the Nos of Fors Clavigera on their publication,Ruskin’s Fors Clavigera was pbd. monthly, 1871–84; “Every Man his Due,” letter 13 (Jan. 1872), “On the Dordogne,” letter 14 (Feb. 1872), and “The Four Funerals,” letter 15 (March 1872. I find it necessary to say that the last two Nos have not reached me till about three weeks after the due time; and that the No for this current month, also, has not yet arrived.

p.closer: I am, Gentlemen, / Yours truly, / T. Carlyle.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 23 March. Addr: The Hill / Dumfries / N.B. PM: London, 23 March 1872. MS: NLS 527.62. Hitherto unpbd. Written by TC in blue pencil; envelope in Mary’s hand.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Yr Letters came, many thanks for them and for the news they brot. I am glad the good Dr R. is on foot agn;John A. Carlyle wrote, 10 March, that he had visited Dr. Russell, who had a very sore toe: “He had been three or four days in bed, & was still in bed when I went yesterday, but the toe looked much better, & was less painful.” He wrote, 21 March: “The enclosed came last night from Dr Russell, & I send it on to relieve you from all anxiety about him & Mrs Russell.” still more that poor John of Scotsbrig is not to have to go to Edinr on that sad errand!John Carlyle at Scotsbrig had been unwell; John wrote, 18 March, that he was recovering; presumably there was another letter, now untraced, explaining the “sad errand.” The £50 you paid for me I inclose here: better to pay off what one owes at once,John A. Carlyle wrote, 18 March, that he had received a “warrant for £2, dividend of six per cent for ⅔ of the year ending in Decr last, on your £50 of Shares. … I ordered 5 additional Shares of £10 for you, & also for myself. … Don’t bother yourself in repaying the £50 wh I can get as soon as I see you again.” Mary noted in TC’s checkbook: “23 March 1872 / Dr Carlyle (for Shares in Artisan Dwellings) / £50 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). —and with thanks for the trouble our creditor had! That “artisan House” Funds seems to be one of the best “investts” not to speak of the really useful purpose it has.TC and John had invested in the Artizans, Labourers & General Dwellings Company, a philanthropic property company managed by J. Royle Martin; see 47:139TC to JAC, 13 Jan. 1871. John wrote, 10 March: “Mr Martin invites us to take each five Shares more … & perhaps we might do so.” If you cared
now or at any time to go deeper into it, I shd be willing to accompany pari passu [on equal footing]!

John’s ClerkshipTheir nephew John Aitken; see TC to JCA, 8 Nov. 1871., and the Harding questn, have been agn (secret, for by John’s advice and wish I delayed any interference) in agitatn for a week past,—till yesty when all was settled, on what I think a good footing, as John himself doubtless has told you, or will tell. Harding, I guess, had been staggered by John’s low-voiced, slow, rustic appearance, and knew nothing of the worth that is in him. John himself seems to really prefer Chapn’s employt,—and thinks to learn and prepare there for the one Life-scheme he has ever formed, that of becoming a Dealer in old Books!— He is a very honest fellow, John; does his work, I believe, in a thorough & really superior manner,—& likes London, to all appearance, perfectly well. He is ill-lodged, I fear, no fireplace of his own &c &c; but this you will be able to overhaul when you come up.

I shd be glad (but am not altogr) to con-TC wrote “con-” at the end of a line, presumably intending to write “confirm.” that the weary Norse Ms. is actually now copied fair; and ready to be sent for yr careful criticism & perusal,—if you like and when you like. No such insignift Nothing of a Piece ever cost me the hundredth part of the time, trouble and intolerably paltry botheratn this has done,—principally from the want of a right-hand that cd write! And somehow cd not witht finishing fling it away.For TC’s thoughts on finishing the preface, 14 Feb., see TC’s receipt to CAH, 13 Feb. He spent the following weeks correcting it while Mary made the fair copy. Mary wrote to Ann Welsh, 1 March, about their translating of “an Icelandic Saga from the German—I did the merely mechanical part, that of writing at dictation. We got it finished some time since; but we are as busy as ever writing a little account of the Early Norse Kings. It too is at last finished and we are re-revising it. Neither of them is to be published; but Uncle thinks it is good for him to keep up the habit of working; and to work as long as he can” (MS: EUL).

Our weather is very blusterous and bad for a week past; and one’s own poor life-course, spirits and world are not above the average pitch at prest, nor can well be!— — I had many other things & more importt too, to write here; but must not try at this time. With my best blessing to you all—

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 30 March. MS: NLS 527.63. Hitherto unpbd. Written by TC in blue pencil. The letter is difficult to read and some words are missing or may be incorrectly transcribed.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: The Letter and the Post-CardPostcards, first produced in 1861 by John P. Charlton (1841–98), printer and stationer of Philadelphia, were first issued (complete with a stamp) by the post office in Britain, 1870. were lying both togethr to welcome me this morng: Thanks, Thanks; all is right now—and, in fact, perhaps I needed not have been so impatt!

Mary, for the prest, comes to me only twice a week,Mary had moved into lodgings; possibly she had taken a room near to or in the same house as her brother John. She was looking for work (see below) and returning to take dictation twice a week from TC. to wipe up the bits of scribble that may be needed;—in the way of “Compositn” writing (save the mark!)Cf; “Bless the mark,” coterie speech; see Othello 1.1. I have fairly ascertained that dictatn never will do for me. Everythg grows twice or even thrice as long by that method; a sign of every kind of fault; sign, that, after endless bother, the thing is still not done, nor can be! And so, as a next shift, I have got me two Slates; and do my “Literature” there (to wait quietly for Mary, and be really mine, done from nature as of old, only ten times slower. Wish me well in it! The Laced-wristikinSee TC to JAC, 14 Dec. 1871. was not worth a doit; this of the Slate (Heaven help me!) is I all I have left.

Yesterday I sent the Fraser; There is little in it worth reading. Today I send Jean the Macmillan; the last Article, Masson on MazziniGiuseppe Mazzini d. 10 March. David Masson, “A Memoir of Mazzini,” Macmillan’s Magazine 20 (April 1872: 509–20. Masson wrote first about his own friendship with Mazzini; he had first met him 25 years ago, and continued to meet him regularly “in the house of one or another of the very few English families that enjoyed his intimacy, till at length I came to know him well, and what hardly promised to be an acquaintanceship became for me one of the friendships of my life” (Macmillan 509). He continued with the history of Mazzini’s political work: “[H]e was the most tenacious man I ever met. … As an Idealist in Italian politics, as the spiritual torch-bearer of a great cause, he was unsurpassable. He ran with the torch, the same torch, for forty years. … The Unity of Italy! who does not remember how that idea was derided in all our newspapers, attacked, written down, treated as a wild chimera? … Mazzini … was more than the Italian Patriot. … His patriotism was the main outcome of a very powerful, original, and various mind” (Macmillan 517). Allingham recorded in his diary, 13 March: “Carlyle’s at 3—friendly. ‘Poor Mazzini! lying dead there—all done, all over. What a bright young man when he came in here in 1836 and sat on that sofa! He got into “solidarity” and all manner of absurdities. He used to trouble himself about every wretched Italian who was in any way political. There was one Italian who fell in love with a danseuse and stabbed himself; Mazzini took care of him, recovered him, and persuaded the girl to marry him. Mazzini was indolent, rose late, and smoked a good many cigars. His mother watched over him and sent him £200 a year, which he never took care of’” (Allingham Diary 208). John wrote, 18 March: “The news of Mazzini’s rather sudden death was solemn to all of us here. On the whole he was one of the very best men that one ever knew.” is the only Piece I
took to, or even fairly read;—except indeed that by the German, on Turner & Mulready;Richard Liebreich, “Turner and Mulready. On the Effect of Certain Faults of Vision on Painting, with Especial Reference to their Works,” Macmillan’s Magazine 25 (April 1872: 499–508. Richard Liebreich (1830–1917), German ophthalmic surgeon, born in Königsberg, currently lecturer at St. Thomas’s Hospital, London. J. M. W. Turner (1775–1851; ODNB), William Mulready (1786–1863; ODNB), artists. don’t omit that!— By the bye, I wish you wd read carefully, and then give Jean to read, that Norse-King puddle, and then tell me both with your severest candour, what you really think if it,—in case you happen to think anything at all! Whh I take to be likeliest result, and (singular to say) not the unwelcomest in my prest position of affairs.

Mary, I hear, is gone to Ruskin today; purposing to consult him earnestly, as to Employt and Miss Hill (whom probably you know abt)—one of Miss Hill’sOctavia Hill (1838–1912; ODNB), housing and social reformer; she had worked with Ruskin since 1855 as a copyist and then as a teacher; after his father’s death, 1864, Ruskin bought previously run-down and ill-managed properties for her to renovate and then administer for the poor. She was assisted by female “lieutenants” such as Henrietta Barnett (1851–1936; ODNB), Catherine Courtney (1847–1929; ODNB), and Emma Cons (1838–1912; ODNB). lieutenants, managing by force of eye, and imperative discretion mostly silent, the poor tenants of Ruskn: it is a thing Mary, and I think cd learn to do well. She has been trying and inquiring for some months back, as to teaching,Mary had worked as a pupil teacher in Peebles before coming to London; see 44:163TC to JCA, 24 Feb 1867. and has had the kindest receptn from certn Inspectors &c; but I think has wisely given up that, as “dangerous for diseases in the back” (so the [word illegible] testimony went) a thing doubly dangerous for her. Failing Ruskin, I think she will try for some place of Private Secretary; whh also she is very fit for, [words illegible]— In fact she has made up her mind (in whh I have warmly seconded and applauded) to try London to the uttermost for an Honest Livelihood and occupatnTC noted in his journal, [26 March]: “Mary went to Madam Venturi’s—my good, true and clever little Mary; resolute to knock at the door of this big British Chaos, and ask, ‘Have you any honest place for me?’” (TC’s journal; privately owned). Presumably Mary was asking for work, not lodging. John wrote, 31 March: “I was extremely shocked to find that the dear little Mary had left you, & gone to face the difficulties of London life, leaving you in solitude. You & I have both of us money enough—more than we know how to make a right use of—& I cannot see why she should go out to find a livelihood.” —& she now has free avenue (whh she had not here) and the top of the morning, “breakfast over by 8½ a.m.” An honourable, kind, clever and valiant little soul,—whose honest independt determinatn in this her little “challenge
of the world” I much approve. — — Oh what a bit of writing work!John A. Carlyle, wrote, 31 March: “I found it very difficult to read, the writing being so small on both sides & the paper so thin.”

closer.salute: Pity me all of you,—and accept my love & blessings.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-RWE, 2 April. MS: RWEMA. Pbd: Slater, CEC 587–89. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO RALPH WALDO EMERSON

docBody.p: Dear Emerson,—I am covered with confusion, astonishment and shame to think of my long silence. You wrote me two beautiful letters;Since TC’s last recorded letter to Emerson (4 June 1871), Emerson had written at least five letters, three of them as introductions to family or friends visiting Britain. none friendlier, brighter, wiser could come to me from any quarter of the world; and I have not answered even by a sign. Promptly and punctually my poor heart did answer; but to do it outwardly as if there had lain some enchantment on me,—was beyond my power. The one thing I can say in excuse or explanation is, that ever since Summer last, I have been in an unusually dispeptic, peeking, pining and dispirited condition; and have no right hand of my own for writing, nor, for several months, had any other that was altogether agreeable to me. But in fine I don’t believe you lay any blame or anger on me at all and I will say no more about it, but only try to repent and do better next time.

Your letter from the far West was charmingly vivid and free; one seemed to attend you personally and see with one’s own eyes the notabilia, human and other, of those huge regions,Emerson had traveled for six weeks through the western parts of the U.S., April–May 1871; there is no trace of a letter written from the “far West,” but in his letter of 30 June 1871 he gave TC some descriptions of the country, the animals, and the people (Slater, CEC 581–83). in your swift flight through them to and from. I retain your little etching of Brigham Young as a bit of real likeness;Brigham Young (1801–77), Mormon religious leader and politician, president of the Mormon Church 1847–77; for Emerson’s comments on him, see 47:211TC to RWE, 4 June 1871. I have often thought of your transit through Chicago since poor Chicago itself vanished out of the world on wings of fire.Emerson’s letter of 10 and 13 April 1871 (Slater, CEC 577–79) was posted from Chicago, although he gives no details of the place. For the Chicago fire, see TC to TH, 12 Nov. 1871. There is something huge, painful and almost appalling to me in that wild Western world of yours;—and especially
I wonder at the gold-nuggetingThere is no mention of “gold-nuggeting” in any of Emerson’s surviving letters. there while plainly every gold-nuggeter is no other than a criminal to Human Society, and has to steal the exact value of his gold nugget from the pockets of all the posterity of Adam, now—and for some time to come, in this world. I conclude it is a bait used by All-wise Providence to attract your people out thither, there to build towns, make roads, fell forests (or plant forests), and make ready a Dwelling-place for new nations, who will find themselves called to quite other than nugget-hunting. In the hideous stew of Anarchy in which all English Populations present themselves to my dismal contemplation at this day, it is solid consolation that there will verily, in another fifty years, be above a hundred million men and women on ths Planet who can all read Shakespeare and the English Bible and the (also for a long time biblical and noble) history of their Mother country,—and proceed again to do, unless the Devil be in them, as their Forbeers did, or better, if they have the heart!—

Except that you are a thousand times too kind to me, your second Letter also was altogether charming. You may depend on it, I will not employ Conway,Emerson wrote, 5 Jan., that he wished someone would write down conversations with TC: “[someone] competent to report your opinions,—for you can speak as well as you can write … & let it not be Conway, who (this in your private ear), cannot, in my experience, report a fact or speech as it fell. It suffers a strange distortion in his mind. But he is a good fellow, & bright, & I owe him only good will.” Moncure Daniel Conway, U.S. Unitarian minister. should I need a BoswellJames Boswell (1740–95; ODNB), companion and biographer of Samuel Johnson (1709–84: ODNB), lexicographer. (which I never shall): my opinion of him is completely your own, and indeed I see less and less of him, though never absolutely nothing, as the years roll on. He has one merit, that of a great deep and as if almost exclusive admiration for you; I think there is nothing so fixed in his mind as that. For the rest a windy, easy-going, fluff of a creature; content with crudities everywhere, as if they were purities and talking a great deal of stuff that has only half meaning in it: but he is very sociable, good-natured, guileless, and is a general favourite I think among the people he frequents. Peace be with him, poor soul; only not too much of him; and let his visits be more and more like those of angels, short and far between!—

Do you read Ruskin’s Fors Clavigera, which he cheerily tells me gets itself reprinted in America? If you don’t, do, I advise you. Also his Munera Pulveris, Oxford-Lectures on Art, and whatever else he is now writing,—if you can manage to get them (which is difficult here, owing to the ways he has towards the bibliopolic world!). There is nothing going on among us as notable to me as those fierce lightning-bolts Ruskin is copiously and desperately, pouring into the black world of Anarchy all round him. No other man in England that I meet has in him the divine rage against iniquity, falsity and baseness that
Ruskin has and that every man ought to have. Unhappily he is not a strong man; one might say a weak man rather; and has not the least prudence of management; though, if he can hold out for another 15 years or so, he may produce, even in this way, a great effect. God grant it, say I. Froude is coming to you in October.Froude went on a lecture tour of the U.S., Sept.–Dec., tracing the course of Irish history from the 12th century to the present, based on The English in Ireland in the Eighteenth Century (3 vols. [1872–74]), that he was in the process of publishing. You will find him a most clear, friendly ingenious solid and excellent man; and I am very glad to find you among those who are to take care of him when he comes to your New Country. Do your best and wisest towards him for my sake withal. He is the valuablest Friend I now have in England, nearly tho’ not quite altogether the one man in talking with whom I can get any real profit or comfort. AlasWord repeated with a line over it at the turn of the page. here is the end of the paper, dear Emerson; and I had still a whole wilderness of things to say. Write to me, or even do not write, and I will surely write again.
docBody.closer:
I remain as ever Your Affectionate Friend,
T. Carlyle.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 13 April. MS: NLS 527.64. Hitherto unpbd. Written by TC in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Yr three Letters have all come, the last of them, inclosing Alick’s, this morning. The yesterday’s one arrived soon after 2 p.m.; I meant to ansr that once, but people came in, Forster, Brookfield &c, and I could not get it done.

I took no hurt by my little Belton visit,TC visited, 5–8 April, Belton House, Lincolnshire, home of Lady Marian Alford and her son, Lord Brownlow; his wife, Lady Adelaide Brownlow, wrote, 25 March: “We do so hope to be able to persuade you to come to us here some time soon—Brownlow says you have been here once—& so I know that what has been done once can be done again—& I shall feel dreadfully offended if you will never come here in my time!! You would find no party here—only ourselves, Lady Marian & my sister Gertrude Talbot, who would both join with me in the warmest way to beg you to come.” Her sister was Lady Gertrude Frances Chetwynd-Talbot. or none worth mentn; and I gained no benefit, except two days of the purest country air, spent in mournful, not miserable, solitary musing, or rational & not quite useless conversatn, chiefly with that beautiful ingenuous & graceful young Countess & her do Sister “Gertrude” (Gartrudis), both of whom seemed heartily kind to me, much gratified with my visit, and are bright sylphlike eagerly-inquiring young souls, worth making acquaintance with,—if to me, at this date, anybody were certainly worth that; whh, in sad fact almost nobody is! I got an illustrious sleep
that night yr Letter was sent off (Saty last);John wrote, 7 April: “We are all glad to hear that you did accept the kind invitation … & had got through the first night tolerably well. It might do you much good to stay some time longer than you speak of at Belton House which seems to be a quiet place, out of the reach of railways.” but the next night, had next to none; and so made for home on Monday by express, instead of jaunting to LincolnCounty town of Lincolnshire, 23 mi. (36.5 km.) N of Belton. as had been in part proposed. Heigho heigho! I ought to stay at home, and hold my peace, as much as possible, in the years now come!—

I am very sorry indeed, dear Brother, to hear of yr dyspeptic ailments; whh are dismally well-known to myself, as among the heaviest and ugliest inevitables one’s old age has. Vichy,John wrote, 11 April: “my flatulent dyspepsia has been more severe for the last few weeks. I often think I shall have to go back & try Vichy again during the summer, though reluctant to go.” For John’s previous trip to Vichy, 1868, see 45:132TC to JAC, 20 May 1868. if you can stand it, is probably altogr advisable. At any rate, I have been looking for some pleast transit of you (to Dale-Park or somewhither)See TC to JAC, 24 Feb. this good while; and I think you shd at once gird yrself together, and let me see you agn for a ten days, till you decide what farther? The weather is as beautiful as possible; and of quiet room, or of brotherly welcome to you, there is certainly no lack.

I myself don’t design any “expeditioning” this summer, or any that I can possibly help. Nothing but bother and misery attend me on such occasns;—the insolent intrusive importunity and gaping and gazing of my stupid fellow-creatures is itself quite a considerable nuisance over and above.

Lady Ashbn is to leave Town abt a week hence,—the kindest of all my friends here; but who can do me, as it were, no good at all! She goes to Melchet for some “2 months,”—after that quite uncertn whitherwd.— Forster’s dinner I absolutely refused; but he comes tomorrow, at 3½ p.m. “to drive me out, for a country walk”; & I judge, will try to smuggle me home with him all the same.

Mary I saw two days ago, and expect today: I fear her “employt” adventure is not prospering (Ruskin “gone to Italy”Ruskin left England at the end of March, visiting France and Switzerland before arriving in Italy, 17 May. on the sudden): but she seems intent to see that out.For Mary’s search for work, see TC to JAC, 30 March. My lovingest regards to Jean. Ever yr

postscript.p: What a strange tragicomedy that of Blackie is with his unruly boy-mutineers!There was a report in the Edinburgh Courant, 10 April, describing disruptions at the prize-giving, 9 April, of John Stuart Blackie’s Senior Greek Class at Edinburgh Univ. Evidently some of his students had been troublesome throughout the year, and continued to be disruptive during the event. Why didn’t he expel these 2 or 3 imps long since?——

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JP [JPEA], 18 April. MS copy: Trevelyan Papers, Robinson Lib., Univ. of Newcastle. Hitherto unpbd. John Pearce (1847–1930), temperance reformer, philanthropist, businessman.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN PEARCE

docBody.p: Dear Sir,—I cannot attend yr Meeting;The United Kingdom Alliance held their annual meeting at Exeter Hall, The Strand, London, 18 April; the main topic of discussion was the government’s Spirituous Liquors (Retail) Bill, currently going through Parliament along with the other, more radical, temperance bills. The Times reporting the meeting, 19 April, commented that something might actually be achieved if only all the various people and organizations could work together to propose a realistic bill, rather than separately proposing bills often too radical to achieve much support. but my complete convictn goes, and for long years has gone, with yours in regard to that matter; & it is one of my most earnest and urgent Public Wishes that some such Bill do become law.

postscript.p: Chelsea, 18 April, 1872

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 20 April. MS: NLS 527.65. Hitherto unpbd. Written by TC in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear Brr,—There never seemed to me to be anything but a small old Volksmährchen [folk tale] in that Todtentanz [Dance of Death]—only I was uncertn abt the final part of the meaning: Does the Warder die in that way withn the Steeple, while the Gerippe [skeleton] smashes to shards witht? Also why is Spinnen [spider] (langbeinigen [long-legged]) in the plural?TC refers to Goethe’s poem “Totentanz”; John replied, 21 April: “In that Todtentanz Spinnen plural may be put for Spirne to avoid the indefinite article wh wd have made the line too long. The jetzt hat er am langsten gelebt [now can nothing help to save him] one would say must mean that he had got to the end of his life, but the phrase is not very clear.”

I hoped yesterday to have heard something farther abt Vichy, and especially abt preliminary Chelsea. So soon as you fix abt anything, let me know.John wrote, 21 April: “I think of starting for the South either at the end of this week or early next week.” He then wrote, 25 April: “I have been rather worse than usual this week with the dyspepsia, & have put off starting for London till next week. If I resolve on going to Vichy again, which is still doubtful, it would not answer to go before the middle of May.”
 The inclosed bits of letters will indicate what is going on around. None of them do I want back but Emerson’s:—I have seen his Daughter twice, and like her very much; I am trying all I can to be of some use to her Husband & her,Edith and William Hathaway Forbes; Emerson wrote, 19 Jan.: “I send my son-in-law, Col. William H. Forbes, & my daughter, Edith … to see your face, & crave your blessing. … They are on their way to France & Germany, & Italy, and I have charged them to see you, and if not now, then on their return to London. They will appreciate any counsel you shall give them as to places & things in London, or out of it, which they ought to see.”
 while 
they stay here; but see not well of what, so utterly feckless am I grown of late weeks, nothing in me but perpetl nausea, “flatult dyspepsia,” and a steady canopy of sorrow (not always sacred, tho’ sometimes such if well let alone!)

Today I send Jean a Quarterly Review, whh came to me yesterday; I didn’t find it much worth reading; nor I doubt will you.— Forster is better since the “faint,” or kind of fit, he had this day week; it is the second such there has been within the last 2 years;For Forster’s previous “faint,” see 47:207TC to JAC, 29 May 1871. & naturally he does not like it at all.— Froude’s eldest daughterGeorgina Margaret Froude. is ill of lungs, & he is evidly anxious abt her.— Poor old Murray, he too ends!Thomas Murray (1792–1872), printer and misc. writer, d. 15 April; TC’s friend at Edinburgh Univ.; see 1:3–TC to TM, 24 June 18135TC to TM, 24 June 1813. TC had possibly seen Murray in Edinburgh when he went for the rectorial inauguration; see 43:39. All end.
With my blessings to Jean & every one of you,

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JP [JPEA], 22 April. MS copy: Trevelyan Papers, Robinson Lib., Univ. of Newcastle. Hitherto unpbd. For John Pearce, see TC to JPEA, 18 April.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN PEARCE

docBody.p: Dear Sir,—Many thanks for yr attentions, for the honour you do me.Apparently a proposal to nominate TC as president of the United Kingdom Alliance. The PamphtsPresumably temperance pamphlets, otherwise unidentified. shall be turned to acct,—tho’ I myself require no argumt or evidence farther on that disgraceful subject.
With many acknowledgts I must decline the honour of Presidency. From the bottom of my heart I wish you success complete & speedy.

closer.note: TC wrote his second check for the Baillies to the Rev. Wodehouse Raven, 21 April 1872; see oppabove. From then on, TC wrote one annually in April for “£20” until 1876 when they ceased.

figure.p:
Thomas Carlyle’s check to the Rev. Wodehouse Raven, 21 April 1872
Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

postscript.p:
Chelsea, 22 April
1872—

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 27 April. MS: NLS 527.66. Quot: A. Carlyle, NL 2:285. Written by TC in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,—Abt Thursday, then, I will expect you,John A. Carlyle replied, 28 April, that he would spend a night with a friend, Wed. 1 May, on his way to London, and would reach Chelsea Thurs. evening, 2 May. —with many “wishes” (“good journey” &c &c), not needing expressn here!— Don’t forget to tell us whh room you will prefer: the front room upstairs, contiguous to me, is what I had settled (perfectly quiet by day or night, clean, airy, and well known to you); but Mrs W. recollects yr once preferring the back room on this (drawing-room) floor: say whh.John replied: “In regard to the rooms, I think the old one in front upstairs, to which I have been most used, would suit me best. It is, as you say, always quiet, & the only objection I ever had to it was the fear of disturbing you in the adjoining room.” The plan of the second (third, U.S.) floor names the front room as “Spare Bedroom & Dr. Carlyle’s Room” and the adjoining back room as “Mr. Carlyle’s Bedroom”; see 45:173TC to JSK, 21 Sep. 1868. The “back room” of the first (second, U.S.) floor is described as “Mrs. Carlyle’s Bedroom”; see “Mrs. Warren, TC’s housekeeper,” 47:172. Item, let me recommend you to bring for yrself (if you still go upon that article) a bottle or two of genuine whisky: sound brandy is abundt here; as are wines, of truly multifarious sort; but no whisky except dirty Irish.

Please do bring down that Norse Kings Ms. & the Saga withal may as well come, tho’ abt the latter I care little or nothing. The former cost me, poor Mary & me, a deal of trouble; and I cd like well to have it put right in all details
by such an opportunity.John wrote, 25 April: “Shall I bring with me the translation of Faröer Saga & the Essay on the Norse Kings? … The translation is in general accurate enough, but some errors occur which I have marked; & I find that the German translation wh you followed is not quite so good as I thought it. The ‘Norse Kings’ is too long. Many passages are true & valuable, but the minute details are often inaccurate & imperfect. One might perhaps leave out a good many of them with advantage. At present the Essay is some thirty pages longer than the poor Saga & could hardly be given as an Introduction to it. Much has been done since Dahlmann’s time, by Munch, Keyser &c. I have Munch’s 8 large volumes of Norse History … and they quote authorities throughout, & have a pretty good index, & detailed genealogical tables from Harold Fairhair downwards.” For Dahlmann, see TC to JCA, 13 Oct. 1871; Peter Andreas Munch (1810–63), Norwegian historian and philologist, Det Norske Folks Historie, 8 vols. (Christiana, 1852–63); Rudolph Keyser (1803–64), Norwegian historian. Indeed it strikes [me]TC omitted “me.” you cd not better fill yr forenoons, while waitg on the questn, “Vichy” than by a thorough revisal of this Piece,—in the light of yr new Norse Histy (whh also bring).John replied, 28 April: “As to bringing with me Munch’s History, I feel doubtful whether it would be of any use as you don’t know Danish well, & I could not be of much assistance to you. The ‘Norse Kings’ MS I read most carefully immediately after it came, & have read it again twice. And three or four times already I have vehemently tried correcting the errors, & could not satisfy even myself; so that I think there could be no hope of my being able to do any good in the matter. Indeed I think it would make me ill again with vexation as it has done.” He ended the letter: “Perhaps it may be as well after all to bring Munch & Snorro with me; & I will do so unless you forbid me, though I fear you would be too impatient, & I myself also too thin-skinned & too unwell.” He wrote again, 29 April: “I was not very well when I wrote to you last night. Today I have again read your sketch of the Norse Kings, & think it excellent. And I find that with a little patience all the errors in it may be easily corrected. I will bring with me Munch (pronounced Moonk) & also Snorro; & it will be a very good occupation for me, in the forenoon’s I have to stay with you, to shew what errors need correction.” John presumably meant C. C. Rafn and G. C. F. Mohnike’s edn. of Snorro’s Færeyínga saga (see TC to JCA, 13 Oct. 1871). I don’t think I shd like to part with many (or perhaps with almost any) of the anecdotic insignificances, the whole Norse “Histy” being nothing to me save Anecdotes;—but I shd be very desirous to have everything correct, instead of disgracefully not.John wrote, 28 April: “What one would like to accomplish would be to keep all the good passages in due coherence, without any errors in additional details which might be dispensed with. I failed in the attempt, & that was the reason why I kept silent so long after receipt of the MS; & then in my last letter suggested leaving many details out altogether. I need hardly say that it is not for want of will that I have failed. To one who knows nothing about Norse History the MS is excellent reading, but it would be unsuitable for you to send forth anything unauthentic after having gone to the bottom of so many matters of History, & some of the errors are great.” A tolerable (or even a fairly legible) Map of Norway wd be a great acquisitn; but I suppose, that is impossible in these latitudes & these habitudes!— Think of all this; & let us do our best.

Forster is up to par agn; his “faint” nothing but a Stomachic affair (thinks
Quain): F. called here, Thursday last, while I was out for the Emerson Photohg business.Emerson wrote, 19 Jan.: “I believe I shall give Edith a secret counsel, which, if she obeys, I hope you will be good, & permit her to carry out.” The National Portrait Gallery’s copy of the photograph of TC taken with Edith Forbes’s eldest son, Ralph, has a handwritten note attached: “Mr Carlyle sat for this picture with the eldest grandson and namesake of Ralph Waldo Emerson by whose request the photograph was taken on April twenty fourth 1872”; see frontis. That latter was not at all so bad as I had figured it;—and was thot to have succeeded well. We shall see whether or not, abt the time. Lady Ashbn is still here, “busss” to the eyebrows; so that I see next to nothing of her: on Thursday week (for certn) she will have to quit London, house-lease being out then.Lady Ashburton had been renting houses in London, first in Stanhope St., then in Park Lane; she was currently negotiating with Mitchell Henry (1826–1910; ODNB), businessman and politician, to purchase a plot of land on the Kent House Estate on the edge of Hyde Park; her house was built there 1872–74; see Surtees, Ludovisi 151. — — Adieu, dear Brother, let us hope to meet agn, in peace, in this poor world, very soon! It is surely a mercy of Heaven to us both. Cd we but be rightly thankful!—

bibl.sourceNote: TC-UC, 5 May. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd.
bibl.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p: A very idle employt, that of gathering Autographs, especially from people who cannot any longer write!TC had been troubled for a long time with a shaking right hand, which hindered his writing; see 47:2TC to TCA, 4 May 1870. —

postscript.p:
Chelsea, 5 May
1872

bibl.sourceNote: TC-MA [MAI], 11 May. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:286–87 inc.
bibl.head: TC TO MARY AITKEN

docBody.p:
… The Imperial InterviewA. Carlyle’s ellipses. Princess Augusta of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach (1811–90), empress of Germany, wife (m. 1829) of Wilhelm Friedrich Ludwig (1797–1888), emperor of Germany 1871–88; she visited England, 2–14 May, and had expressed a wish to meet TC. passed yesterday without the least accident,—or, I think, the least real profit to either party. I was received with warm courtesy by the Count and Countess Bernstorff,Count Albrecht von Bernstorff (1809–73), German imperial ambassador in London, and his wife (m. 1839), Anna, b. von Könneritz (1821–93). who soon left me to myself in
a very grand room (which I knew of old);The interview, Fri. 10 May, took place in Prussia House, Carlton House Ter., the ambassador’s residence; TC had previously borrowed books from Bernstorff for research on Frederick; see 31:86TC to JAC, 7 May 1856. in about three minutes, BrandisJohannes Brandis (1830–73), Assyrian scholar, private sec. to Empress Augusta. entered for perhaps a minute and a half; and within another minute, entered (followed or escorted by Brandis, who flung the doors open) Imperial Majesty herself, with a blithe quick air and step, and a soft enough voice of welcome. She offered me her hand, which I kissed (according to rule); there were but two chairs in the room (set there on purpose no doubt); Majesty took one, I (not thinking, tho’ I apologised afterwards) took the other; Brandis stood to a side;—and there the High Lady at once launched into an official kind of declaration of the “reasons why she wished to thank me,”The Athenaeum reported, 18 May: “Mr. Carlyle received the other day, from the German Empress, the formal expression of the thanks of the Emperor, for his ‘Life of Frederick the Great.’” of the etc., etc., and in short, of the “greetness”A. Carlyle remarked that TC attached a note to a copy of this letter: “Cobbett reports, of one of his Displays or Harangues in some manufacturing Town, that a working man with a little son on his arm respectfully asked, If he would be so kind as shake hands with this little Boy? Cobbett readily did so. ‘Theare now,’ said the proud Father to his Boy, ‘Thou can say, a’ thy life, thou hast shooken hands wi’ the greetest man in England!’” (A. Carlyle, NL 2:286). William Cobbett (1763–1835; ODNB), political writer. of a certain man, and now “that Writer on Heroes was himself a Hero!” This was her last word on the chair. Rising to her feet she said cheerily, “It was Odo RussellOdo Leopold William Russell (1829–84; ODNB), diplomat, second son of the Carlyles’ friend Lady William Russell (1793–1874; see 39:27639:biographical notes), British ambassador at Berlin, 1871–84. who advised that I should see Carlyle, which I had often tried to do, but now I have done it!” and giving me her little hand, evidently to shake, this time, and kindly shaking mine with due expression of fare-you-well, graciously withdrew, and I saw her no more,—nor had had in the Interview, except listening, any active function whatever. Her English was not fluent, though correct enough; once or twice Brandis, once myself, helped her out with a word (—“temoin?” “witness,” was my stroke of help): all I said otherwise was by way of parenthetic interruption; she did not seem to wish me to speak at all;—and indeed, I now guess, must have had her speech probably all by heart (but don’t whisper this to any soul!),—which gives a slightly ridiculous character to the whole affair,—and entirely secures one’s head against being turned with it!The interview was not reported in the press at the time; following the death of Empress Augusta, 7 Jan. 1890, the Berlin correspondent of the London Evening Standard, 25 Jan. 1890, revealed details of the meeting; he quoted from Thomas Alfred Fischer (1844–1906), author and translator, who included an appendix about the interview in his trans. of Froude’s Life of Carlyle (Das Leben Thomas Carlyles. Aus dem Englishchen von. J. A. Froude), 2 vols. (Gotha, 1887) 1:400–401; TC did not mention the presence of other people but presumably they could have been in another room in the Embassy while the Empress spoke to them individually: “The following is all that I have been able to discover of Carlyle’s interview with her Majesty the Empress of Germany. During a stay of some duration in London, in 1872, the Empress Augusta wished to make the acquaintance of the most gifted men in England. About twelve or fourteen of the leaders of English Art and Science, including Carlyle and Froude, were therefore assembled one day in the house of the then German Ambassador. The Empress conversed in the most amiable manner with each of them, especially with Carlyle. The following extracts from a letter which I received from the Cabinet of the Empress in Koblenz show how great was her reverence for the English historian and philosopher:—/ “Koblenz, 3 Nov., 1886. / Her Majesty had long felt a special reverence for the famous English historian, and therefore wished, during a stay in England, to make the acquaintance of Thomas Carlyle. Her Majesty received him in the German Embassy, and discerned, from her conversation with him, not only how he judged of the historical events in Germany with rare sympathy and clear understanding, and felt a real affection for this country, but also how he did justice to the historical past of the Royal House of Prussia, and recognized its present task with a warmth of feeling astonishing in a foreigner.”

She is a fine old Lady to look upon; turned of sixty, and considerably older-looking than your Mother;Jean Aitken, Mary’s mother, was 62. a pair of uncommonly bright, large and kind grey eyes are now the striking feature; but when young she must have been fairly beautiful. She is not tall, but of good medium size, still slim of shape; and I recognised in her both her Mother and Father,Grand Duchess Maria Paulowna, see TC to JM, 23 Dec. 1871, and grand duke Karl Friedrich (1783–1853), of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach, whom TC had met 1852; see 27:301–2TC to TWC, 25 Sep. 1852. who were a smallish woman and a tall man. Her dress (of which I know not one particular, except that it had a brilliant small-speckly blue-and-gold look) seemed to me at once modest and magnificent.TC apparently asked Mary to copy this letter and the earlier letter to Jean Aitken about his interview with Queen Victoria, as she replied, 15 May: “I enclose a copy of the letter relating to the interview with the Empress but I have not yet found the one relating to that with the Queen; but will make a further search. We here have not spoken of your interview to any body at all.” She added a postscript: “I have just now found a copy by John of the letter relating to the other Interview and will copy and forward it tomorrow”; for TC’s letter about his interview with Victoria, 4 March 1869, see 46:21–27TC to JCA, 11 March 1869. —…A. Carlyle’s ellipses. William Allingham recorded a meeting with TC and Froude, 11 May: “C. talked against painting, said it was all worthless except portrait-painting: F. chimed in with him, and remarked in his sub-sarcastic manner, ‘The connoisseurs tell us a Portrait is no work of art.’—I said, ‘Oh no!’/ F.—‘Well, when I said to Ruskin that I cared for no pictures but portraits, he replied, “That proves you care nothing at all about art.”’ / W. A.—‘But that was not saying that a good portrait is not a work of art.’ I did not go on; it was merely tedious and vexatious” (Allingham Diary 209).

bibl.sourceNote: TC-TD [TDI], 23 May. MS: Harry Ransom Lib., Univ. of Texas. Hitherto unpbd. Written in TC’s hand.
bibl.head: TC TO THOMAS DIXON

docBody.p: Dear Sir,—I am right well pleased to see yr Life-buoy certified as genuine. Nothing did I ever hear of so worthy of the gallows in that swindling departt, as the scandal and horror you were the means of exposing in regard to “Life”-buoys, some years ago! It seems to me you shd really put yrself forward, push and proclaim, and let all the world know the distinctn betn Life-bs & Death-bsThomas Dixon (1831–80; see 45:89TC to [RAS], 25 Jan. 1868), cork cutter from Sunderland, working-class activist, and advocate of the cooperative movement, corresponded with TC from Aug. 1862; see 38:168JWC to TC, [27 Aug. 1862]. Dixon manufactured cork life-buoys, but the context of TC’s remarks is not further identified. (properly death with torture superadded) whh, it seems, the common-kind are. Are you too fond of quiet, and too careless abt much money, for going into this? I am quite serious in wishing it.

As to Walt Whitman, it seems to me he is probably the loudest-roaring blockhead in all America (not witht faculty either, but all gone into that fatal conditn). Some ten or more years ago, I had a thing of his, whh he called “Leaves of Grass”Walt Whitman (1819–92), American poet, essayist, and journalist. Dixon bought several copies of Whitman’s Leaves of Grass (New York, 1855), which he gave to various friends. and reckoned to be Poetry,—the like of whh I never saw in Nature, nor expect to see agn! My feeling was, “If god endowed the Parish Bull with the dismal gift of writing and rhyming, is not this somewhat the view
he wd give us of the Universe and its mysteries and glories!”— — For certn, I want to hear no more of Walt or his philosophies.
I counsel you to think seriously of the Life-buoy questn,—and of how many lives you might save by (successfuly) entering on it.
Greatly disinclined to write, but

bibl.sourceNote: TC-CT [CTH], 26 May. Addr: 3. Moray Place / Edinburgh. PM: London, 27 May 1872. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd. Written in TC’s hand. TC addressed the envelope to “Miss Clara H. Thomson” but she was probably Clara H. Thomson, b. Hertz (b. ca. 1837), wife of Robert William Thomson (1822–73; ODNB), engineer, inventor of the pneumatic tire, rather than his da.; they had three children, all under ten years of age, according to the 1871 census, none of them called Clara. It is likely that she signed her letter to TC “Clara H. Thomson,” leading TC to assume that she was a young woman. The “H” presumably stood for Hertz.
bibl.head: TC TO CLARA THOMSON

docBody.p: I have now read yr PamphletPamphlet untraced. attentively twice over,—having had a Copy several days ago, from a Yorkshire Lady“Yorkshire Lady” unidentified further. whose address I couldn’t quite make out, and yesterday a second Copy from yrself; for both of whh accept my thanks. I can assure you I have read with a great deal of satisfaction and approval,—and with considerable surprise, too; not expecting from a young Lady the clearest and soundest utterance I have yet heard on this miserable woman-versus-man Questn; surely the most tragic and anarchic that ever rose in any epoch, or (as you well wind up with saying) had need to rise!— Perhaps you may yet do much service on this sad matter; not alone by writing on it (high as yr possibility that way is), but by silently working, meditating and contriving how the roots of it might be cut away, the fatal need of it be made to lessen & at last cease. Two things surely are possible: 1° That all women shd endeavour (and be wisely aided and guided) more and more to qualify themselves for becoming useful and loveable wives of men; & 2° That if the men are not there, but driven abroad for a living, the women shd in some honourable & decorous way be emigrated to where they are! The difficulties, I well perceive, will be great, in both these directns, and the progress only gradual; but impossibility there is none in either of them. Courage, courage!—

In reference to yr Pamphlet I meant to have remarked farther, that you
seem to me to underrate greatly the quantity of Intellect that is in women, tho’ lucidly right as to its usual quality. An excess of beautiful candour, this. Also that you do not touch at all, or hardly touch, on the celestial (so we may call it) whh it lies with a noble wise and loyal wife to throw into the existence of her Husbd, irradiating by the beauty of her own dear soul, what were otherwise to the toilsome man, however valiant, a very dark and grim affair.
Adieu, dear young lady, Be wise, be humble, diligt, stedfast; and may a good Genius guide you,—as, in that case, he surely will!—

bibl.sourceNote: TC-CGD, 28 May. MS: NLI. Pbd: Charles Gavan Duffy, Conversations with Carlyle (1892) 247–49; Charles Gavan Duffy, My Life in Two Hemispheres (New York, 1898) 2:336–37. Written in TC’s hand.
bibl.head: TC TO CHARLES GAVAN DUFFY

docBody.p:
Abt ten days ago I recd the Report of Speech,Possibly the speech Duffy gave, 26 June 1871, at the Mechanic’s Institute Hall, Kyneton, after his appointment as premier of Victoria, 19 June 1871, Policy of the New Government: Speech of the Hon. Chas. Gavan Duffy, Chief Secretary of Victoria (Melbourne, 1871). In it he declared support for the reinvigoration of “industrial and commercial prosperity” (4); he promised a focus on land law (4) “while the present Administration remains in power, no man in this wide territory who desires to become a settler shall ask in vain” (5). He considered the country’s finances, pledging that “if a direct tax shall become necessary, it shall certainly not be a tax on industry” (6). He concluded with a commitment to an electoral system whereby every man would have a vote, which would be obtained “without inordinate effort,” and exercised “with as little sacrifice of time or money as may be.” the Newspr with yr Portrait and Sketch of Biography &c &c;Newspaper unidentified. all of whh, especially the first named Article, were very welcome and interesting. The Portrait is not very like, tho’ it has some honest likeness; but in the Speech I found a real image of yr best Self; and of the excellt Career you are upon; whh pleased and gratified me very much. Tho’ unable to write except with a pencil, and at a speed as of engraving (upon lead or the like), I cannot forbear sending you my hearty Euge, euge [well done, well done]!—and earnestly encouraging you to speed along, and “improve the shining hour,”Cf. Isaac Watts, Divine and Moral Songs for Children (1715). all you can, while it lasts. Few British men have such a bit of work on hand.The London Spectator commented on Duffy’s program, 9 Sept. 1871: “[W]e have not for years read a political manifesto so full of character and power. Mr. Duffy is an Irishman, a Catholic, and a rebel, a typical man of the class which we English say can neither govern nor be governed; but he speaks like the man for whom the Tories are sighing, the born administrator, utterly free of flummery buncombe, clear as to his ends, clearer still as to his means.” You seem to me to be, in some real degree,
modelling the first elements of mighty Nations over yonder; scattering beneficent seeds, whh may grow to do forests, and be green for a thousand years!The Melbourne correspondent of the London Standard wrote, 2 Feb.: “Now, under Mr. Duffy we certainly have not had stagnation; indeed, the only fear is that things are going too fast. Railways are to be opened, water works regenerated—this branch in a dry country is one of the most important of the public system—mining laws amended to some purpose, and many other things done which will be of great advantage and importance. The country, in short, appears to be waking up” (Standard, 21 March). Stand to yr work, hero-like the utmost you can; be wise, be diligt, patient, faithful: a man, in that case, has his reward. I can only send you my poor wishes; but then these veritably are, sorry only they are worth so little.

Nothing in yr list of projects raised any scruple in me; good, human & desirable, one felt them all to be,— except that of Gold-Mining only. And this too I felt at once was, if not human, or to All men’s profit yet clearly Colonial or to Victoria’s profit, & therefore inevitable in yr place & season. But I often reflect on this strange fact, as perhaps you yrself have done, That he who anywhere, in these ages, digs up a Gold-Nugget from the ground is far inferior in beneficence to him who digs up a Mealy Potatoe,—nay is, in strict language a Malefactor to all his brethren of mankind; having actually to pick the purse of every Son of Adam for whatr money he, the Digger, gets for his Nugget,For a similar expression of TC’s views on gold-mining, see TC to RWE, 2 April. and Be bothered to it! I do not insist on this: I only leave it with you,—and wonder silently at the ways of All-wise Providence with highly foolish Man in this poor course of his.

Adieu, dear Duffy; I have written more than enough: if I had a free pen, how many things cd I still write;—but perhaps it is better not!— — I am grown very old, and tho’ witht specific ailment of body, very weak (in comparison), and fitter to be silent abt what I am thinking of than to speak.

I send my kind and faithful remembrances to Mrs Callan.Margaret Callan, b. Hughes (ca. 1817–1883; ODNB), Irish nationalist, Duffy’s sister-in-law; see 45:101TC to JF, 2 March 1868; she and her husband, John B. Callan, had also immigrated to Victoria, 1856; see 32:46TC to MACA, 7 Dec. 1856 , 7TC to VL, 8 Dec. [1856]. — John my Brother is gone to Vichy agn (day before yesterday);See TC to JAC, 29 May. Forster is looking up agn, now that the collar is off his neck.John Forster retired from the Lunacy Commission around his 60th birthday, 2 April; see TC to JF, 29 Nov. 1871. Good be with you all.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 29 May. MS: NLS 527.67. Hitherto unpbd. Written by TC in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Yr Letter was punctually lying ready for me on Monday morng;John A. Carlyle had been staying in Chelsea since 2 May, and left, 25 May, for Vichy, spa town in the Auvergne, central France. I picked it from the others & their accompang trash, with intent to read it in walkg; but cdn’t quite manage that. I had been, in my solitary musings, almost morbidly anxious on the matter; and was truly thankful that, so far, nothing had gone ill with you, but that on the contrary you had slept and were feeling better. The same day, I forwarded the little half sheet to Dumfries (ordering it to be preserved, along with those that might follow): except a Newspr, in James’sProbably James Aitken, their brother-in-law; as newspapers were delivered free of charge the Carlyles put marks on them to indicate all was well. hand, this morning, I have got nothing from Dumfries since you went; nor had John,John Aitken who had just moved lodgings according to John A. Carlyle to Mary Aitken, 23 May: “[he] seemed to like his new lodging very well so far” (MS: NLS 1775E.152). when I saw him, night before last.

I hope by this time you are safe at Vichy in yr old quarters and environt,John A. Carlyle was staying at the Hôtel du Luxembourg, where he had he stayed on his previous visit to Vichy, May–June 1868; see 45:132TC to JAC, 20 May 1868. & plunging thro’ the preliminary quickset hedge of the affair,—i.e. getting accustomed to the ways of it. Courage; that will soon be done! After whh a real & considerable benefit is fairly to be anticipated,—I meant confidently to have written yesty and even Monday; but there was required a small deliberate Note (one of them to Duffy) on each of those days and, with disgust, I found, both times, that such a miserable vestige of a “task” had actually eaten up my day! The extent of one’s da’rkPossibly for “darg,” Scots word meaning task; otherwise unexplained. is not great in prest circs; and grows smaller, not bigger, withal. Essay, Essay.

At any rate, I had no news at all; nor has the English any to my knowledge,—if it be not that Today is Derby DayThe Epsom Derby horse race, Wed. 29 May. The Times reported, 30 May: “The great London holyday comes and goes, and year by year there is no diminution in the numbers of those who flock to Epsom to witness the most famous race the world knows of”; the Sheffield Independent reported, 30 May: “The weather was splendid, there being neither too much sun or shade. … Of course the exodus from London was greater than on any previous occasion, the four-in-hands more superb, and the toilets of the fair sex more lovely and charming than man or milliner could have conceived.” (multitude of mortals visibly rushing out upon it as towds a good thing, this morning while I walked); & that the day is not so sultry as perhaps a severe benevolence wd have wished!— Yesty came Forster; insisting, to no purpose, on my dining; is to come, on Sunday, and
give me a drive into the country. Froude, I think, was here once,—TaitRobert Scott Tait. came the day you went; as usual, rather minus quantity. Abundance and super-do of intrusive Callers, messagings not in my interest, and gifts of worthless new Books:—but, on the whole, I have been unusually silent, solitary since you went;—and called to reflexions whh I hope may be more profitable than they are joyful. “Einsam einsam, das bin ich ja: Doch die Geister meiner Geliebten sie umschweren mich,Cf. 24:7: “Lonesome, lonesome, that I am not; because the spirits of my beloved ones surround me”; lines tentatively attributed to TC in Rodger L. Tarr and Fleming McClelland, The Collected Poems of Thomas and Jane Welsh Carlyle (Greenwood, Fl., 1986) 194. —yea, that weel!—

Tell me what a Newspr to Vichy costs of stamp here; also whether ½ oz is the limit of weight for Letters.The London Post Office Directory (1873) stated that “The single rate on letters between the [U.K.] and places beyond the Sea, generally … is 6d. in whatever part of the [U.K.] the letter may be posted or delivered. … Newspapers … may be sent … at the following rates: Registered newspapers France and Belgium (not exceeding 4 oz.) 1d.”

Blackie wrote 3 days ago, “guggle-guggle,” abt petitng for a Govt Pension to the widow of some distingd Spiritualist!John Stuart Blackie visited London, April–May 1872, staying for some of the time with Lisett Barbara Gregory, b. Scott (d. 1885), known as Mrs. Makdougal Gregory, widow of William Gregory (1803–58; ODNB), chemist and psychic investigator. She had become a fashionable spiritualist, living at 21 Green St., Grosvenor Sq. It is not clear if it was Mrs. Gregory for whom Blackie was petitioning for a pension. He wrote to his wife, ca. 15 May: “I walked down to Chelsea and spent two agreeable hours with the grey old prophet and his brother. As usual, Thomas laid about him all round with a bland sweeping intolerance which appears to me the very reverse of wisdom. However, we managed to get on, as he was willing to take all the talk to himself. … On departure he gave me a nice present of the two big volumes of his ‘Wilhelm Meister,’ with an affectionate inscription” (The Letters of John Stuart Blackie to his Wife, ed. Archibald Stodart Walker [Edinburgh and London, 1909] 211–12). Actually so,—the blethering b——. Ansr (by halfpenny stamp & broken crumb of paper) at once only: “No, 1000 times No!”Anna M. Stoddart printed TC’s indignant response on a “scrap of paper” to an invitation to one of Mrs. Gregory’s spiritual evenings transmitted (probably at this time) by Blackie to TC: “No, a thousand times, no! Spiritualism = Ultra-Brutalism and Liturgy of Apes by the Dead Sea! Let not such things be once named among you!” (Anna M. Stoddart, John Stuart Blackie: A Biography [Edinburgh and London, 1896] 274). For an earlier similar response to spiritualism, see 46:5TC to [WDE], 19 Jan. 1869. — — Good be ever with you, dear Brr.

closer.note: Mary Aitken wrote from Dumfries, 22 May: “Something has at last turned up for me—better than anything I have heard of hitherto—when I was not exerting myself but merely going about idle here the offer as it were fell into my mouth. Mrs Peter Taylor has asked me to go to her (at Notting Hill) on the first of January or sooner. The duties are, to teach 4 nights a week for 2 hours in a school of hers (the “Aubrey Institute,” close to their house) for the poor children of the neighbourhood—the rest of my time to be at my own disposal—to live in Mrs Taylor’s house on the footing of a sister, and to receive £60 a year. I to try it for six months if I dont like it at the end of that time we to part friends. The offer is generous, and as Mrs Taylor is a very nice woman I do not like to fall between two stools and cast it aside on the bare chance of returning to you. If you are willing that I should go back to you at Chelsea, that would seem to me to be the right and proper thing for us both; but if not it seems to me it would be foolish to let this offer slip through my fingers and have nothing to fall back upon. If you would like me to go back to you, I will with pleasure and not look upon it as a ‘sacrifice’ to go. If you would rather not have me, then I will go to the Taylors, if I am spared, on New Year’s day.” Clementia and Peter Taylor lived in Kensington, at Aubrey House. TC’s reply is untraced, however John A. Carlyle wrote to Mary, 23 May: “Your uncle … had a letter from you, & meant to send an answer to you, but has been interrupted by some visitor. … He has been pretty well since I last wrote, sleeps better than usual & has better appetite. Yesterday we were at Addiscombe, & staid there for the afternoon & evening, getting back to Chelsea about eleven” (MS: NLS 1775E.152).

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JTD, 29 May. MS: Harry Ransom Lib., Univ. of Texas. Hitherto unpbd. John Thadeus Delane (1817–79; ODNB; see 38:165TC to JWC, 27 Aug. 1862), journalist, editor of the Times 1841–77. Written in TC’s hand.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN THADEUS DELANE

docBody.p: Wd you read the inclosed,—and beneficently deliver me from it, from me!—in what way you will at once see.
“to Shetland Fund” (or whatr it is

A.B.C. (by T.C.) £1.1s.0:TC had apparently been given £1 .. 1 .. 0 by “A.B.C.” for passing to the “Shetland Fund”; both unidentified further; possibly connected to The Shetland Times weekly newspaper, first pbd. 1 June 1872 (Dundee Courier and Argus, 31 May).
“from money is here inclosed; rect is there.

postscript.p: Chelsea 29 May

bibl.sourceNote: TC-MW [MEW], 29 May. MS: NLS Acc. 9207. Hitherto unpbd. TC sent this note of instruction to Mary Aitken as to what to say to Wellmer. Mary both enclosed and quoted it in her letter to Meta Wellmer, 2 June.
bibl.head: TC TO META WELLMER

docBody.p: 29 May (9½ p.m.). A braw silk quilt (all hexagon patches, red and black; black lining, do border):—Thank, for me, very cordially, with many wishes and regards.—I have also read sevl of the Poems,Mary Aitken wrote to Meta Wellmer, 2 June: “You will no doubt be surprised that I date from this place—my home [The Hill, Dumfries]—instead of from the, to you, familiar Cheyne Row. I came home for a holiday three weeks ago—another Uncle, Dr Carlyle, was then staying with the Uncle; but as the Dr has now gone off to Vichy my Uncle is now alone, however I hope in, at the latest, a week or two he will come here to spend part of the summer with us. / I got both your letters, Uncle’s and my own, forwarded this morning; & have read them with much pleasure. Many thanks also for the pretty little vol. of your Poems—which I hope to read tomorrow (Sunday). I got them amongst a number of little [notes] forwarded to me to answer for him. I enclose the envelope of your letter on which he has told me what to say to you” (MS: NLS Acc. 9207). The vol. of poetry is unidentified; Wellmer later pbd. Poems (Zurich, 1883). with satisfactn.Mary also mentioned her hope that “the next generation of women will have a much better position than those of this one have, when trades & professions are thrown open to them. A boy has every thing open to him at present whereas a girl or young woman who does not marry has to fight a [word/s missing; MS torn] battle for a livelihood”; she also commented that Tennyson was “a much overrated Poet,” and asked if Wellmer had ever read “our Burns? … He was a true Poet; but I don’t know whether Foreigners find it difficult to see the beauty of some pieces because of the Scotch dialect. He lived for many years in Dumfries and now lies buried about half a mile from our house” (MS: NLS Acc. 9207). Robert Burns (1759–96; ODNB) was buried in St. Michael’s Churchyard, Dumfries.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 11 June. MS: NLS 527.68. Hitherto unpbd. Written in TC’s hand.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,—Yesty morning (Monday), came that poor Note,Presumably a letter sent to Cheyne Row for John A. Carlyle. whh, I fear will be worth little to you; and along with it yours from Vichy, to myself, whh was very welcome and interestg. If you had given me, as supplement, the rudest pencil sketch, or outline of the azimuths, I shd have had a quite lively idea of the Vichy Old & New, and of the Localities where you are now wandering in search of a little renovatn of hea[l]th. In regard to that latter point (whh is the soul of the whole adventure), I am highly gratified with the acct you give! Yr weather, I fear, is not permanently mended, any more than ours; but surely it will & must soon mend; in the meantime, one has to be patt & to perse[ve]re.— I sent, yesty afternoon, yr Letter to John’s; he wd find it as a kind of welcome on his return from the day’s labour, and read it over a cup of tea. In my nine o’clock walk I partly thot I might meet him; but no, he didn’t,—so anxious “not to intrude”; poor good over-modest John!John Aitken’s London address is untraced; apparently near to Cheyne Row.

I ought to tell you another small thing: viz. that I fear my former Letter to you has never got to hand. I did certainly write, abt 2 days after yr first Vichy Letter came; I inclosed it punctually in the Cover you yrself had sent me, and I put 3 stamps upon it as you had directed: also, abt 3 days after, I addressed you a Shrewsbury Newspr (upon the Agricultural Strike or “Labourers’ Congress” at Leamington,A meeting of delegates from various laborers’ unions in the country at Leamington, Warwickshire, 29–30 May, to form a National Labourers’ Union; Shrewsbury newspaper unidentified; several papers reported the “Agricultural Labourers’ National Congress.” Allingham had noted a discussion with TC, 22 April: “We spoke of the Agricultural Labourers’ Strike, and I was somewhat surprised to find C. sympathising with the men. Speaking of Slavery he said ‘work by compulsion is little good’” (Allingham Diary 209). —whh had something in it from Leighton &
abt Charles Stewart);The Leamington Spa Courier, 7 June, published Sir Baldwyn Leighton’s paper, “Meadow and Garden Allotments for Labourers.” Leighton argued that in “some parts of England it is the custom to attach to every cottage a considerable and sufficient garden of say one-quarter or one-third of an acre. … Now it is in the power of every landlord and every farmer to remedy this state of things, at no perceptible loss to himself, by letting off in portions, of say one-quarter of an acre, some field or part of a field.” Later in the paper Leighton praised a system of “allowing only thrifty families to come on the land, and notably on the estate of Mr Hope Johnson in Dumfriesshire … under the direction of his agent, Mr. Charles Stewart.” TC and John A. Carlyle had already corresponded about Baldwyn Leighton and his papers given at the Leeds Social Science Congress, Oct. 1871; see TC to JCA, 8 Nov. 1871. upon this I put one Stamp, & despatched: but neither the Letter nor this seems to have reached you at all? Never mind: there was “nothing” in either,—except proof of my not having fallen negligt or forgetful of you; of whh there was little fear at any rate!—

We have no news worth a moment’s recital: “Alabama Question,”For the Alabama controversy, see TC to JAC, 24 Feb. &c, &c, of whh one abhors the sound of. I am in the kind of health you left me in, not worse, nor better. I am lonelier a good deal, at night especially, but am carefully reading—Shakspeare (till 1 a.m), & admire him more than ever. Intrusive interruptns do not fail, but are not worse than you saw. Yesty (e.g.) I had a really rather pleast dialogue with Lady Derby (only that she made me talk too much, & stay over Time). Walking up thither by appointt,Lady Derby wrote, 29 May: “I am very sorry indeed to have missed you twice when have been good enough to call upon me. … I was out of town the last time you came, & am still in the country. I shall return in about ten days & will venture to trouble you with another note when I arrive.” She lived at 23 St. James’s Square. I found London all streaming down in tumults floods, as if demented abt the Yankee “Boat-race,”The Times reported, 11 June, on the “International Boat Race,” held the evening of 10 June; it was a “four-oared race between the London Rowing Club and the Atalanta Boat Club of New York … rowed over the Metropolitan Course … down from Mortlake to Putney with the ebb tide.” It resulted “in the signal defeat of the Americans.” —very strange to me! “We have beat them agn,” howr: thank—whom, shall we say?— By a Note from Mary yesty, all is as usual in that region.—— Write if you get this. I intend to post it myself.
Good be evr with you, dr Brr.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-EW [EWAL], 14 June. MS: Walter Leuba Collection, Univ. of Pittsburgh. Pbd: Thomas Carlyle, Jocelin of Brakelond from Past and Present (New York, 1923). Written in TC’s hand. Edward Walford (1823–97; ODNB), classicist, writer, and compiler of reference works. The 1923 edn. of Jocelin of Brakelond was designed by Bruce Rogers (1870–1957), U.S. typographer and book designer, and pbd. by William Edwin Rudge (1876–1931), U.S. publisher; a copy of the holograph of this MS was included in its flyleaf; only 510 copies were printed; a copy is available in the Baylor Tarr Carlyle Collection; see “The Carlyle Collection of Rodger L. Tarr, Armstrong Browning Library, Baylor University,” Carlyle Studies Annual 25 (2009): 133.
bibl.head: TC TO Edward WALFORD

docBody.p: You are altogr welcome to the “one or two short pieces,” whh you mean to do the honr of “translating into Latin or Greek”;The translations are not further identified. —I only wish they deserved it better.

postscript.p: E. Walford Esqr

bibl.sourceNote: TC-EF, 15 June. MS: Trinity. Pbd: FitzGerald’s Letters 3:353–54. Written partly in TC’s hand and partly in J. A. Froude’s.
bibl.head: TC TO EDWARD FITZGERALD

docBody.p:
I am glad you are astir on the Naseby-Monument question;FitzGerald previously owned land at Naseby, site of the battle between the Royalist and Parliamentary armies, 14 June 1645; see 15:89TC to EF, 18 Sep. 1842, and 110TC to EF, 29 Sep. 1842. In 1855 he and TC had planned to erect a monument (see 30:40–42TC to EF, 23 Aug. 1855), but the plan was never implemented. TC apparently wrote to FitzGerald, late 1871, about the projected monument, as FitzGerald replied, 20 Dec. 1871: “I have not wholly neglected the wish you expressed in your last about the Naseby stone. / I was reading some months ago, your letters about our Naseby Exploits in 1842: as also one which you wrote in 1855 (I think) about that Stone, giving me an Inscription for it. … [W]hen you wrote in 1855, we had just sold Naseby to the trustees of Lord Clifden [Henry Agar-Ellis (1825–66) 3d Viscount Clifden].” He then wrote that Lord Clifden had since died, leaving a young son, Henry George Agar-Ellis [1863–95], 4th Viscount Clifden; on receiving TC’s letter, he wrote to Clifden’s lawyer to see what could be done; he continued: “If I get the Lawyer’s and Agent’s consent, I should be very glad indeed to have the stone cut, and lettered, as you wished. But whether I should pluck up spirit to go myself and set it up on the proper spot, I am not so sure. … You will think me very base to hesitate about such a little feat as a Journey into Northamptonshire. … But you know that one does not generally grow more active in Travel as one gets older.” FitzGerald then wrote, 12 June: “A fortnight ago I heard from the Brother of the Lawyer who is concerned for Naseby now, that if I wrote to the Agent, I might hear of something to the purpose. So I wrote to the Agent: and I enclose his Reply.” and that the
auspices are so favourable. This welcome “Agent,”The agent was Thomas Watts; unidentified further. so willing & beneficent, will contrive, I hope, to spare you a good deal of the trouble,—except indeed that of seeing with yr own eyes that the Stone is put in its right place, and the number of “yards rearward” is exactly given.

I think the Inscriptn will do;FitzGerald wrote: “I … enclose your own scheme of an Inscription for the stone, as you wrote it soon after your Visit down here in 1855”; see 30:41–42TC to EF, 23 Aug. 1855. TC returned the inscription, perhaps with alterations, as FitzGerald replied, [16 June]: “[Y]ou have returned me your Inscription maimed in the beginning of the second Paragraph. … And, as there may be some uncertainty … about the exact number of ‘Yards to rearward’ … may I substitute ‘Here, and for some Yards hereabout’?” and as to the shape &c of the Monument, I have nothing to advise,—except that I think it ought to be of the most perfect simplicity, and shdFrom here the letter is written in Froude’s hand. go direct to its object and punctually stop there. A small block of Portland Stone—(Portland excels all stones in the world for durability and capacity for taking an exact inscription)—block of Portland Stone of size to contain the words and allow itself to be sunk firmly in the ground; to me it could have no other good quality whatever; and I should not care if the stone on three sides of it were squared with the hammer merely, and only polished on its front or further side where the letters are to be.FitzGerald wrote, 12 June: “Now then: what size—and what Shape—is the Stone to be of? And where made? I know of no one in those parts now: and I suppose I could scarce trouble this Agent with it. As to seeing it set on the exact spot, I think I shall have to go there myself for that—which will be the hardest part of all, absurd and foolish as this may seem to you.” He then asked, [16 June]: “what height you think the Monument should be?” See also TC to EF, 7 Dec.
