In short I wish you my dear friend to take charge of this pious askThus in MS; possibly for “task.” in all its details; considering me to be loyally passive to whatever you decide on respecting it. If on those terms you will let me bear half the expense and flatter myself that in this easy way I have gone halves with you in this small altogether genuine piece of patriotism I shall be extremely obliged to you.

PollockWilliam Frederick Pollock (1815–88; ODNB), 2d bart., lawyer and author; FitzGerald wrote: “Pollock, who paid me a two Days’ Visit here three weeks ago, has since written to me that he had a walk with you—from Chelsea to Piccadilly … so that I gather you are well and strong.” has told you an altogether flattering tale about my strength &c. It is nearly impossible for any person still on his feet to be more completely useless.

postscript.p: J. A. Froude (just come to walk with me) scripsit [wrote this].Signature and postscript written in TC’s hand.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-MA [MAI], 18 June. MS: NLS 1763.313. Hitherto unpbd. Written in John Aitken’s hand, and signed by TC.
bibl.head: TC TO MARY AITKEN

docBody.p: Your little stinging address to Elliot & Fry seems to have “took an effect on them”John Joseph Elliott (1835–1903) & Clarence Edmund Fry (1840–97), photographers, 55 Baker St., London, photographed TC many times during the 1860s (for example, see 42:frontis. and 81); for their photographs, March 1868, of TC and one of Jean Aitken, see 45:120–22TC to JJE, [25 April 1868]. Apparently Mary Aitken had complained to Elliott & Fry that they had published photographs of TC for sale without authority; they were presumably either copies from these earlier photographs or they had taken extras of TC at the sitting with Emerson’s grandson, 24 April (see below). For JWC’s report of TC’s other regular photographer, John Watkins, printing TC’s and her photographs at a wholesaler and then displaying three of hers in a shop window, see 42:163JWC to TC, [30 July 1865]. (as the whiskey did on Dickey KevilRichard Keevil, “a wandering, innocent creature” who stayed with TC’s family for some months, 1826–27; see 4:179TC to AC, 1 Jan. 1827. long ago); for the fact is they have this day through Forster given a complete account of themselves; proved that they have printed for sale only 3 of the 4 photos allowed by your MotherWhy Jean Aitken would be involved in giving permission is not known; possibly they were negatives of photographs that had been promised to her. (the fourth not turning out well when they tried it);TC had recently sent photos to Mary Austin, as she wrote thanking him, 4 June: “I was glad of the two prints this morning, though I did not think you had forgotten me Still it was something more to see the T. C. and think of all the bother you would have in sending them They are very nice and will be well worth a place on some of our walls.” still more important: they have sent me down in a firm little box the two negatives of the Old Man & Emerson’s grandson:For Elliott & Fry’s photograph of TC with Ralph Emerson Forbes, 24 April, see TC to JAC, 27 April, and frontis. and have undertaken not to presume charging any money atall on Mrs Forbes.Edith Emerson Forbes, Emerson’s eldest da.; she, her husband, and their son visited TC in April; see TC to JAC, 20 April. So that whether they write to you or not we may consider their beggarly affair as completely settled, & wash our hands of it forever & aday. Thank you kindly for the trouble you took, which I know you did not grudge.Although Mary was in Dumfries, she was still helping TC with his correspondence; she wrote, 3 June, that she had sent off the letters he had asked her to, continuing: “The next things you get I shall be most happy to dispose of in the same way; and any copying will be ‘carefully attended to.’”

I liked your Letter very much; indeed it awakened in me many kindly emotions both joyful & the contrary which I do not speak of at present. It was very pretty to me the picture you gave of yourself conning your German lesson in
the woods of Dalscone,Dalscone Wood, about 2 mi. (3 km.) NE of Dumfries. amid the soughing of the trees and the singing of the birds—shut out from all other noises. It is an excellent use to put your time to just now, & I could really wish much that [you] should actually acquire a correct & effective knowledge of the German language after so long hovering on the outskirts of it.Mary wrote to Meta Wellmer, 2 June: “I am … working hard at German at present. I am going to try and learn to speak German & am to get lessons next week from a German teacher in the town” (MS: NLS Acc. 9207). I pray you apply diligently, & do your best towards this important result. The best of all methods; I believe would be that you took a good solid bit of printed German, a dictionary & a bit of paper & actually wrote down the best Translation you could make of it,—with the constant view of sending it to me to correct & criticise. Set about this I advise you the instant you get home. All Schiller, all Goethe and various other works (as you yourself know better than I) are to be found both among your uncles booksJohn A. Carlyle had a large collection of books in Dumfries. & mine here; I will with great pleasure overhaul your Translation, which will naturally be the very truest you can make, and you will find a feat or two of this kind to have a more condensing steadying & clearing effect on you than a great deal of reading would. Do it I advise you.

For the rest write at any time on all things you like, or have upon your heart, certain of an affectionate reception here. Of that there need not at any time be a doubt with you. Try to grow wise & wiser my dear little woman; there is nobody will more rejoice than I to see that result getting forward—, which indeed is the one result worth striving after by any of us in this world.

I am not in worse health than usual tho’ suffering a good deal from heat.The temperature in London in the shade was 77.5 degrees (Times, 18 June). The enclosed Letter came from Maggie Welsh today, you can read it and burn. Good be with you always, dear Mary
docBody.closer: Your Ever / affecte uncle / T. Carlyle

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 20 June. MS: NLS 1763.315. Hitherto unpbd. Written by TC in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: My dear Jean,—The sight of yr hand agn, yesterday morning, was right welcome to me. I know always yr unalterable feeling toward me, yr manifold affectionate anxiets,—and do, in silence “write” you many Letters: tho’, for valid enough reasons, I cannot do it vocally or visibly!For TC’s long-term problems with handwriting, see TC to UC, 5 May. Few days pass witht yr being part of my silent company here.

It is evidt I shall have to leave this dusty roaring roasting place, before long; but whitherward I cannot in the least settle. Dumfries occurs to me first, Dumfries or The Gill;Mary Austin wrote from The Gill, 4 June: “I have often wondered if you would come to Scotland this summer. None could be more pleased to see you, than us here.” but the railways, the fatal railways!TC was much disturbed by railway noises, both at The Gill (see 47:22TC to JCA, 8 June 1870), and at Dumfries (see 47:40TC to JMN, 4 July 1870). The one relief I have here is tolerable sleep;—and every night, I feel that one squeak of noise wd blow me up for the height of vigilance, and results too well known! Of that, therefore, I dare not think. Scotland, for a reason you will perhaps guess, Scotld especially Edinr and neighrhood,TC presumably was thinking of JWC’s grave in Haddington. I do wish to see yet one other time: Auchtertool Manse,Auchtertool Manse, Fife, home of JWC’s maternal cousins Rev. Walter Welsh and his sisters Maggie and Mary. accordingly, is a place I sometimes contemplate as possible,—tho’ not likely, or especially not for long. Lady Ashbn is ordered to the German Baths (Marienbad, in Bohemia);Marienbad, spa town in Bohemia, now the Czech Republic. omittg her grand palaces in Wiltshire &c, there is an admirable altogr silent Sea-Cottage, standg vacant for year’s past, where the Sea bathing solitude &c wd be complete (tho’ full of sad remembrances too!)Lady Ashburton had several homes, including Melchet Court, on the border of Hampshire and Wiltshire; the “Sea-Cottage” was Seaforth Lodge, Seaton, Devonshire, that TC and JWC had visited, March 1865 (see vol. 41); TC had not been there since. —of this I am latterly thinking oftener, tho’ nothing whatr is yet settled, nor perhaps will be, at the time of the Dr’s reappearance (if that were to have much influence on me, whh it isn’t).— So waste, so wae, so weary looks the world abt me, dear Jean;—no goal of any surety for me except one, whh I daily think of as an unfailing & eternal place of shelter; right sure and blessed that! In God’s good time.
I am weaker at walking than I ever was; but have not yet left off eating, as I did last year this time,—tho’ my “digestion” is something hideous to consider. No more of all that.

One thing I do definitely want, & have been much longing for these ten days past: a straw hat, any straw hat! Send me the old one,John A. Carlyle brought TC’s black straw hat, refurbished by Jean, to London, June 1871 (see 47:209TC to RWE, 4 June 1871); presumably TC then took it back to Scotland during the summer, leaving it at Dumfries on his return to London. I beg, by the first conveyance.— JohnJean’s son, John Aitken. was here night before last; nothing can exceed his loyalty to me at all times, & his modesty truly is in excess.
Don’t try reading the inclosed daft woman’s dud:Unidentified. give it to Mary to try and aftds burn!— God bless you all, dear Jean.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 22 June. MS: NLS 1763.316. Hitherto unpbd. Written in TC’s hand, mostly in blue pencil (see below).
bibl.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: My dear Sister,— Thanks for warning me of Miss Cunnm’s affair,TC, John A. Carlyle, and Forster agreed, Nov. 1869, to send Wilhelmina Cunningham £20 a year between them, the money to be sent through Jean; see TC to JCA, 13 Oct. 1871. Presumably TC had forgotten that it was his turn. John Aitken recorded in TC’s checkbook: “Chelsea / 21 June 1872 Miss Cunningham / £10 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). whh otherwise I might have overlooked for weeks, amid such hurry. Had I been master of a hand, you shd have had the inclosed in hand, and at this hour been paying it away; but as matters stand you cannot till Monday change it into currency, & pay down. Say everythg for me that is kind to the good old Lady; & tell me, when you next write, how she is.

Besides the £10, you find here a 10/-, whh latter is for yrself or my self. Price of the new straw hat, namely;Presumably Jean was buying TC a new hat; see TC to JCA, 20 June. and some trifle for or towards a certn poor Picture-frame whh I commissioned of you. Punctual to the last!— Give Mary charge of the inclosed Newspr Clipping, and bid her ask of Alick junr in Canada, Where there is any vestige of fact in it, or none whatr?Alexander Carlyle, their nephew in Canada; apparently TC knew that Mary and Alick were corresponding; the “clipping” not further identified. —

John was here last night; wrote a long Letter for me to the Dr,John Aitken was now writing some of TC’s letters. —who ought to receive it tomorrow morning, rather before the time you read this. He has said nothing yet of his movets after Monday.— I had an ugly “breach of sleep”; and was in sore misery all yesty; but now, thank Heaven, things are come round (or half-come round) agn, and I am muchTC wrote from “half” to the “m” of “much” in black ink and the rest in black lead pencil. better for the moment. My flitting and next whitherward are still unsettled,—constantly occupyg me. But happily the air is cooled to a beautiful degree by the much thunder & rain there has been (not here any of it, but widely over Engd 5 or 8 hours);There were severe thunderstorms over much of England, 18–19 June. so that possibly I may have some bit of respite respite of it.— I count on having you here this year, if I don’t go to you n.b. [note well]!—
What a disgusting work is this always to me;—slow as engraving, almost; and nothing like so satisfactory.
May blessings rest on you all, now and ever

bibl.sourceNote: TC-UC, 23 June. MS: sold at Christies’ Auction, NYC, 17–18 Oct. 1988. Pbd: Glasgow Evening News. 8 Aug. 1890; T. Carlyle, Letter to a Young Man, ed. Clement K. Shorter (privately printed, 1915); Christie’s sale catalog, NYC, 17–18 1988. Text: Shorter.
bibl.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.dateline:
5, Cheyne Row, / Chelsea, S. W.,
23rd June 1872
docBody.p: Your letter, so candid, so patient amid such dreary imprisonment, bespeaks my sympathy;Clement K. Shorter (1857–1926; ODNB), journalist and editor, wrote in his introduction to TC’s letter that it was prompted by a letter from a twenty-five year old man who wrote “laying bare the spiritual struggle that had come to him through his study of Spencer and Darwin on the one hand, and on the other the pain which his growing predisposition to agnosticism had given to his pious and puritan mother.” Herbert Spencer (1820–1903; ODNB), philosopher and social theorist; he and TC were not in agreement politically; he sent TC one of his books, 1844, and was surprised that TC acknowledged it; see 18:48–49TC to RB, 21 May 1844. Charles Darwin, proponent of the theory of natural selection; he was first taken to Cheyne Row, 18 Nov. 1838 (see 10:229TC to RWE, 2 Dec. 1838), by his brother, Erasmus Darwin, who had been friendly with the Carlyles since 1835. and surely my wish to help you, had I the power at all, would be very sincere. You seem to me to have been born with a naturally pious, just, and even devout turn of mind, but to have been swallowed into almost spiritual annihilation in the general deluge of what calls itself “Science,” and is, intrinsically mere trifling and baffling with the element external to us, issuing in what the Fool said in his heart long ago, and what no wise man or generation till our own ever said to itself, “That there is no God.”

One thing I can affirm to you which is very certain. That these miserable speculators about “Protoplasm,Thomas Henry Huxley (1825–95; ODNB), biologist and educational theorist, wrote “On the Physical Basis of Life,” Fortnightly Review 11 (Feb. 1869): 129–45, in which he argued that “Protoplasm,” the scientific name for the “physical basis of life,” was the “one kind of matter which is common to all living things,” binding life by a “physical, as well as an ideal, unity” (Fortnightly Review 129). For TC’s appalled reaction to this theory, see 46:16–17TC to JAC, 20 Feb. 1869, and 35–36TC to JTY, 20 March 1869. Origin of the Species, Man’s gradual descent from Apes or Oysters, &c., &c.,”Charles Darwin, On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection (1859) and The Descent of Man, and Selection in Relation to Sex (1871). For JWC’s reaction to the furor over Origin of Species, see 36:53JWC to MR, [28 Jan. 1860. are by no manner of means the first Thinkers of their epoch, but are, to a contemptible degree, the very reverse; and that it would be wise in you to quit such company, and consider well whether this were really “discourse of reason,” or discourse of “want of reason,” on the part of a self-conceited, low-minded, and, in consequence, essentially blinded generation, “Age of Progress,” “Aids of Science,” and whatever high names it may give itself.

I doubt not you have still in you a sense, which you had at Thirteen, of what a great man calls the “Infinite Nature of Duty”:A phrase TC used in many of his writings; e.g., Sartor 123, On Heroes 65, Past and Present (Carlyle, Works 10:109); the “great man” was presumably Goethe, who highly influenced TC’s ideas about duty. study to resuscitate, to acquire, to strengthen this as the grand object of every human being; this is of itself Godlike, and it is there only that the evidence of God can begin for a Man. Trying it by chemical decomposition, by logical discussions pro or contra, leads no-whither; a man must begin at the other end: namely, at the Fountain of Light from Eternity implanted in man himself by the Unknown Creator, or he will arrive at no certainty.

You say you cannot read much. Let me advise you, at least, to read nothing but good Books: what you yourself earnestly trying can feel to be good; in whatever Author, never so popular, philosophic clever, you detect a mean, impious soul, with him have nothing more to do. By being earnest and conscientious in this you get to judge better and be more justly discriminative day by day. As indeed one does in all things. Try faithfully, light will rise on you if so. “Knock and it shall be opened”See Matt. 7.7. is a true saying. The great source of disappointment is, men do not truly knock, they do not “try” in a noble and heroic manner, but in a mean and huckstering with an eye to their own happiness and the like; to such there is no answer from the Holy of Holies.

On the whole I bid you still hope for victory. Honour your excellent and pious Mother; and believe that her good prayers may verily, though in oblique ways and under unexpected forms, be answered in behalf of her loved son.
Adieu, dear Sir! I write unwillingly and under great obstruction. Consider all this as strictly private and for yourself only.

closer.salute: Wishing you heartily well, / Yours sincerely,

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 4 July. Addr: Melchet Court / Romsey / Hants. PM: London, 4 July 1872. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Written in TC’s hand, mostly in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Don’t fret yr kind heart, dear loving Lady that Melchet proved impossible!TC apparently stayed at Melchet Court for a few days; Allingham wrote to him there, 28 June: “It gave me a shock to find you were gone. I hope you will get good of the country.” We shd both of us recognise candidly the evidt inexorable Fact that, with so many reciprocal resources and with the most perfect will we can do each other little or no good, in this perverse practical world; and ought resolutely (with the minimum of vain regrets) to adjust ourselves to what will not and
cannot alter for our poor wishings and lamentings. This seems a cruel doctrine; but I clearly perceive it is a true one. More is the pity; more also be the patience, be the silent courage!

I have slept here, to my own surprise, these 3 nights; and am certainly not worse for what Melchet and its heavenlies and its earthlies did; nay, for the time, am as if in some degree better.— My Brother was not here on Monday Evg; he has been hovering & hanging abt Caen, Bayeux, HonfleurFollowing his visit to Vichy, John A. Carlyle had traveled to Caen, Bayeux, and Honfleur in Normandy, NW France. He wrote to John Aitken from Paris, 28 June: “Tomorrow morning I purpose starting for Caen & staying there till Monday next. … I was very glad to hear that [TC] had got out of London even for trial of Melchet” (MS: NLS 1775E.158). &c; & professes to be due here only this day (Thursday) abt 3 p.m. Apparently he never got the Melchet Letter Miss JerrardRebecca Jerrard (b. ca. 1799), housekeeper at Melchet Court. & I were at the pains to write him;—his own fault altogr. What his next plans are I know not at all;—if by good chance Seaforth Lodge,See TC to JCA, 20 June. and 3 weeks of the quietest sea-bathing, shd seem eligible, I cd well incline to try that withal,—and perhaps prove that somethg did “do me good”!—

Yesterday one of yr Addiscombe menUnidentified further. (very deaf as I heard from below) came hither, just on the heel of a Hamper for of his sending: found that all perfectly right;—& undertook, on Mrs W. ’sSarah Warren, TC’s housekeeper. urging by my order, Not to send us any more. I have now farther to beg & enjoin that Melchet also do cease altogr to send us any: the quantity of bother, trouble & expense it amounts to on yr side, and of inutility on mine, is quite becoming a distress to me.Lady Ashburton had hampers of food and flowers sent to Cheyne Row from Addiscombe since at least Feb. 1860; see 36:59TC to TLMM, 6 Feb. 1860.

As to MarienbadLady Ashburton was planning to go to Marienbad; see TC to JCA, 20 June. &c, i shd cordially second yr determinatn towards “a Cottage at Strathpeffer,”Strathpeffer, spa town 25 mi. (40 km.) NW of Inverness, where Lady Ashburton had been in 1870; see 47:46TC to LLA [29 July 1870]. and yr own Jewel MarykinLady Ashburton’s da., Mary Florence Baring. &c &c with you. As to “waters,” one might ask; How does Dr WeberDr. Hermann Weber (1823–1918), Austrian born doctor who lived at 10 Grosvenor St.; he had been a traveling doctor for Lord and Lady Harriet Ashburton; see 27:174TC to LA, 21 July 1852, and 309TC to LA, 1 Oct. 1852. He specialized in the treatment of consumption, and was one of first doctors to recommend Alpine health resorts. know that Strathpr is not preferable, having never seen it? Of “waters” I know nothing, and believe little; but think only of being with the souls you love, among yr native hills and breezes, instead of lodging in littery parched desarts, amid dirty Czechs and unwashed sinners of the Earth!

The second of yr Notes I got this morning (as flavr to my cup of coffee);—coffee done, I walked across to Burgess:Andrew Hutton Burgess, who had previously cataloged Lady Ashburton’s library at Melchet (see 46:69TC to LLA, 19 Aug. 1869), lived near TC in Chelsea. He is delighted to think of going; & undertook to write by this same post, asking you the When &c,—and doubts not to have done long before “the 18th.”— — Keep an eye on Ritualist Clutton!Henry Clutton, architect; TC’s use of the epithet “Ritualist” implied disapproval of Clutton’s conversion to Roman Catholicism, 1857. Clutton had designed Lady Ashburton’s house, Melchet Court (see Surtees, Ludovisi 87–88 and 135), and was now designing her new London home, Kent House, near Hyde Park; see TC to JAC, 27 April, and Surtees, Ludovisi 151. I wd make a stand on that “£600,” Stand must be made somewhere, or he is capable of eating you all up!
This little scrap, how many hours has it taken me? Adieu, Adieu.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 9 July. MS: NLS 1763.317. Hitherto unpbd. Written by TC in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Dear Jean,—I felt a little disappointed by yr peremptory Negative: I had cut yr long ride into 3 stages for you (Birmingm, Chelsea, Seaton), and pictured to myself a mournfully beautiful little month of absolute seclusion, trustful talk,—and actual Sea-bathing, realiseable at last (if that shd prove worth anythg at all to me on trial!).TC had apparently decided to take up Lady Ashburton’s offer of Seaforth Lodge for a holiday (see TC to JCA, 20 June); he had hoped Jean would join him in Chelsea if he did not go to her in Dumfries (see TC to JCA, 22 June) but meanwhile decided on Seaton rather than Chelsea, perhaps because John A. Carlyle wrote to Jean suggesting this; see TC to Lady A, 13 July. As to “great houses,” or “great people” (except ourselves three), there was simply nothing of all that: one housemaid, a solitary pretty little cottage, and at 2 minutes distance the ever-pure Atlantic Ocean. It was even to have been “ourselves two,” as I first contrived it,—tho’, on reflexn, it was evidt the Doctor also, if witht plan of his own, ought to have the offer.— Howr, I by no means blame yr decisn, dr Sister; I applaud yr sincerity,—and can too well understand how unequal you feel yrself to such an adventure, after all that has come and gone!Jean had recently lost two of her sons: Thomas, d. 13 Oct. 1869 (see 46:87–88TC to JCA, 15 Oct. 1869), and James, d. 20 Sept. 1871 (see 47:226TC to JAF, 26 Sep. 1871). Let us each try faithfully to do the wisest we can, apart, since not togr.

Most probably my “Sea-bathing” may turn out to be of no use to me;TC wrote in his journal, 12 July: “John has been at Vichy; came back abt a fortnight ago: I had a 6 days (contemptibly miserable, sleepless &c) at Melchet,—returned rather before him. We are now looking somewhat towds Lady Ans empty sea-cottage in Devonshire: but the decisive ‘Rise and march, then!’ whh rests with me, is idly slow of coming. Idle, idle, every way—shame on me, shame!” (TC’s journal; privately owned). and
indeed, while the hot July has almost daily a tolerable shower, London with its clean pavets shady green Parks, and one’s own poor nest (the quietest I find in the world, and so full of memories sacred to one’s soul)TC was thinking of JWC. is probably the best place for the time being. Probably I may keep lingering here till fairly burnt away.
docBody.closer: God bless you all / Ever yr affecte Brr / T. Carlyle

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 13 July. Addr: Melchet Court / Romsey / Hants. PM: London, 13 July 1872. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. In TC’s hand, mostly in blue pencil; envelope addressed in an unknown hand; TC wrote “T.C.” on the front.
bibl.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Dear kind Lady,—Nothing has specially gone wrong with me; health &c not worse than what you saw;—and today I have got yr Letter, whh I was looking for, & whh is a blessing over and above. To you and Mrs Watkins,Mrs. Watkins, presumably a servant at Melchet. I will say, “Rest, rest, perturbed spirits!”See Hamlet 1:5. Nothing can be done for that man,—whose “fit” place is in his own tub, and not under the canopies of costly state at all!— He does look forward to a week or two of quiet sea-bathing, truly; but that is all at prest; and the time does not yet quite come.

My Sister, whom John wrote to on the subject, renounces at once, and, terrified at the “long journey,” the &c &c, dare not be of the party: she was (under yr gracious permission) my main outlook for company there, and she is off. John (a little skittish at first as to said “permission,” but now convinced as to it and its perfectn) is still here,John returned from France early July. Soon after, he and TC sent money to Margaret Otthenin, living in France with her sister Irma Durival (see 45:130TC to JCA, 18 May 1868, and 47:195TC to JAC, 22 April 1871); John recorded in TC’s checkbook: “12 July 1872 / for Madlle Otthenin £50 from T. Carlyle & £50 from Dr Carlyle / £100 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). comfortably doing nothing,—and waits in peace till I give signal; that is to say (I believe), “write to Mrs Gandy,”Mrs. Gandy, Lady Ashburton’s housekeeper at Seaforth Lodge; see TC to LLA, 22 July. and lift anchor. “In abt an 8 days hence,” I say to myself; to him I say nothing, nor he to me; but both of us seem to consider it a settled kind of possibility, lying pleasantly ahead.

“The season” seems to be abt over, here; not the fifth part of the equipaging & display in the Park, at least;—whh contributes to one’s bodily safety, if nothing more. You, I can believe, are better at Melchet than anywhere else; nothing equal to those rides with Mary in the balmy sumer morning cd be found for you either in Bohemia or Britain!—

Tourguieneff,Ivan Turgenev. I learn, is going to the Highlands to shoot grouse; asks if he will find me here “on Augt 10th.”The grouse-shooting season started 12 Aug. Great is grouse in this epoch of man’s histy!

Hy CowperHenry Frederick Cowper. told me a pretty thing of The Lady Marian.Lady Marian Alford. She was dining with the Rothschilds,Probably Baron Lionel Nathan de Rothschild (1808–79; ODNB), banker, M.P. for the City of London 1858–74, and his wife, m. 1836, Charlotte, b. von Rothschild (1819–84; ODNB), philanthropist. They lived at 148 Piccadilly. Rothschild also had two surviving brothers, both bankers, also living in Piccadilly: Sir Anthony Nathan Rothschild (1810–76; ODNB), and Mayer Amschel Rothschild (1818–74; ODNB). all the wealth of this world encircling & irradiating: unlucky R. poured her, or caused be poured her, a glass of unparalleled champag[n]e:TC omitted “n.” “Nothing equal to it, I assure yr Ladyp; costs half a crown every glass!”— Ladyp “cdn’t for the world think of drinking such a precious thing!” and, in her sprightly way, compelled the wretched R. to swall[ow]TC omitted “ow.” it himself, and so save or half-save his most vulgarious Half-crown!—
Here is Froude; and I must go at once. Blessings be on Mary & you.
docBody.closer: Yrs ever truly / T. CarlyleTC wrote a short piece on Trade Unions about this time, later pbd. by William Paterson as Last Words of Thomas Carlyle on Trades-Unions Promoterism and the Signs of the Times (Edinburgh, 1882); TC dated it within the text: “Most blessed of all the “Trades-Unions’ yet heard of! (12th July 1872)” (15). The “J.C.A.” who signed the short preface was not Jean Carlyle Aitken (as suggested by Marrs 780), but John Carlyle Aitken who was now writing checks (several in June and July) and letters for TC (see TC to JCA, 22 June). John Aitken noted in the preface (dated Oct. 1882) that it might “be called the great outline or index to The Literary Will and Testimony of Thomas Carlyle. It was written at Chelsea, in the seriously obstructed handwriting of his 78th year, and bears date the 12th of July 1872, about which time the original MS. was presented to us by the Author.” Subsequent to its publication, Mary Aitken Carlyle bought up the stock, “at the cost of £30,” to stop sales (Tarr 239).

bibl.sourceNote: TC-BB, 13 July. MS: NLS 3278.162. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:339 (where incorrectly dated 1874). Written by TC in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO BETTY BRAID

docBody.p: Here again we have arrived at the eve of a DayJWC’s birthday, 14 July. whh is forever memorable to both of us,—to me memorable, beautiful, and sad (with the shadow of April 21The date of JWC’s death. TC wrote in his journal, 12 July: “A long interval, filled only with pitiful miseries and confusions (best forgotten),—empty otherwise, except for here & there an hour of serious, penitent reflen, and of a sorrow whh cd be called loving, calm, and in some sort sacred and devout! Pure, clean black, amid the genl muddy gloom far hitherward of those it is worth being sad of heart for!” (TC’s journal; privately owned; Froude, Carlyle 4:418, corrected against original). resting on it!) beyond all other days of the Year. Accept this little GiftTC recorded in his checkbook: “13 July 1872 / to Betty Braid (Her dear old Betty!) / £5 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). from me, as a sign of what I recognise you to be, my true associate on this occasion, who shares and will do while we live, in all the feelings that belong to it. I know well that, except myself, there is no other who so loved her, & loves, and daily thinks of her, as even you do. In her dear and blessed name, and in my own, I return you thanks and blessings.

I shd like to hear some tidings of yr health and welfare, dear Betty; but will not ask you to write anything just now;—send me an Old Newspaper addressed in yr hand; that will be sign enough for the present, if, as I hope, nothing have gone notably wrong.

Several months ago, I had a most interesting Letter from Coll Davison; detailing with great clearness his first visit to you in the new House,TC omitted the “d.” David Davidson visited Betty Braid, 17 Feb.; see TC to DD, 22 Feb. Betty had recently moved two doors along the street in Greenend, Liberton. —above reporting to me, almost as if in yr own words abridged, that tragic Narrative, whh nobody but you cd give,—and whh, often enough as the Tragedy itself was hinted at here, I never had in completeness before.The story of the death of JWC’s father, Dr. John Welsh, 1822, when Betty was a servant in the house; see Appendix. Ah me, ah me!— I hope Coll Davidson has seen you since, and will from time to time; he promised me as much. I keep his Narrative he got from you, as one of the most precious Documents connected with my life in this world.

Adieu, dear good Betty. I am not ill in health; not sensibly worse than I was last year, tho’ of course one is daily growing weaker, and of mournfuller mood,—may it also be of tenderer and purer (if God will)! I endeavour to wait with pious patience till the end come.
God’s blessing be on you, dear Betty.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-MO, 16 July. MS: NLS 23210.113. Hitherto unpbd. Written by TC in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO MARGARET OLIPHANT

docBody.p: I ardently desire you shd succeed; I have a convictn of yr fitness, too;—and right willingly wd help if in any way I cd. But, knowing personally none of the persons you mention, I was,—yesterday morning when yr Letter came,—much at a loss how to proceed.

After consideratn, I decided to call on Frk Chapman, my own Publisher; did so in the afternoon; found that he was familiar or “intimate” with Mr Virtue,James Sprent Virtue (1829–92; ODNB), publisher; founder, and currently printer, of the monthly Saint Paul’s Magazine. and was going to him “next morng” (i.e. this morng) “at 11,”—and wd punctually deliver my message,—whh he himself quite agreed with, and whh (being a sanguine man!) he thot wd have a profitable influence. Message was to the effect, “That, in my opinion, you had more of the likelihoods for such an office than any other person known to me;It is not known exactly what position Oliphant was hoping for; she supported herself and her two children writing stories and articles for magazines, and since 1870 had also been supporting her bankrupt brother Frank Wilson (1816–75), a widower since 1870, and three of his four children, Frank (1854–79), Margaret (Madge) (1863–97), and Janet Mary (Denny) (1865–1954); the older sister, Jeanie Helen (Nelly) (b. 1856), went to live with a maternal aunt. Oliphant’s two sons and her nephew were all at Eton, but able to sleep and eat at home, as they lived nearby. and that it wd be clear wisdom to satisfy himself completely as to yr qualificatns before going farther, and perhaps faring worse!”— Chapn, no doubt, has delivered something substantially like this “abt 11 a.m.” and what its “influence” is or will be nobody yet knows.

If Mr Virtue wished to consult me farther on the affair, I wd gladly give him a meeting;—the rather as my own persuasion or convictn abt yr fitness is, on all or nearly all points, candidly as above, and I shd have nothing to hide in speaking with anybody on the subject.Oliphant never attained a salaried position with any publisher and was reliant on publishing her writings for income, in addition to her civil list pension of £100 a year, granted 1868.

Writing, as you may perceive, is nearly impossible to me; and I never try it (by dictatn or otherwise) witht disgust: but if there is any service by writing or otherwise that I can do, you in this case have good right to command me.Oliphant replied, 17 July: “How can I thank you for acting for me so promptly and so kindly, and for writing to me with your own hand? … One is so ready to think that nobody cares whether one stands or falls—and there is strength and comfort in every word you say.” However she continued: “Mr Virtue’s letter which you have been so good as to enclose to me is cold and rather discouraging.” She concluded: “I hope that I may require to avail myself of your kind promise and refer to you again.”

I really incline to believe yr chances are good, as certainly I do hope, and with my whole heart wish. Courage!This was possibly the time referred to in Oliphant’s Autobiography: “[I]t so happened that I came to a pause and found that every channel was closed and no place for any important work. I had always a lightly flowing stream of magazine articles, &c., and refused no work that was offered to me; but the course of life could not have been carried on on these, and a large sum was wanted at brief intervals to clear the way” (The Autobiography of Margaret Oliphant, ed. Elisabeth Jay [Oxford, 1990] 133); she had a novel ready which was turned down by two publishers later this year, but the Graphic (begun Dec. 1869) unexpectedly wanted a novel in instalments from her (“they would give me £1300” [134]); she wrote Innocent which they then pbd. Jan.–June 1873. —

closer.salute: Yrs, dear Mrs Olipht, always truly,
closer.note: Isabella Thackeray wrote to Oliphant, July: “Minny met Mr. Carlyle the other day, he still talks about his clock and the paper of signatures” (Anne Thackeray Ritchie, Chapters from Some Memoirs [1894] 142). Isabella Thackeray, b. Shawe (1816–93), widow of William Makepeace Thackeray (1811–63; ODNB), and their das., Anne Thackeray (1837–1919; ODNB), and Harriet Marian (Minny) Stephen, b. Thackeray (1840–75; ODNB), had been among a group of fourteen women who gave TC a clock for his 75th birthday; see 47:190TC to MO, 11 April 1871, and 92TC to JCA, 17 April 1871.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 19 July. Addr: Melchet Court / Romsey (Hants). PM: London, 19 July 1872. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Written by TC in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: How kind of you to write to me, my poor suffering Friend! I am full of anxiety, sympathy, and trouble (great of character, and also small!)—and have not a reasonable word to say, much [less]Word omitted by TC. write. Patience; Patience and shuffle the cards!Cf. Cervantes, Don Quixote, pt. 2, chap. 23. —

I wish often I were sitting silently conversing with the inarticulate Ocean at the bottom of yr Devonshre Cliffs;—and do hope I shall rally strength to move in the course of next Week, and be out of all this miserable whirl-pool of painful contemptibilities, for a little while!— John is, naturally, very willing for Melchet; but his poor weak brother sees certn lions by the way. Let us hope nevertheless.

I beg & entreat of you, for all sakes, take care of yrself, in this to me alarming
crisis;Lady Ashburton was unwell, possibly with a heart condition; see Surtees, Ludovisi 155. and be able to report soon that you are out in the air agn! I never saw in you anything that has so alarmed me as this last sudden fit.
Some daily reports, at least from Miss Jerard,Housekeeper at Melchet; see TC to LLA, 4 July. I do beg.
My kindest love to poor little Mary; of whose terror & agitatns (unless she was happily kept ignorant) I am often thinking.
docBody.closer: God be with you, dear Lady / Yrs ever / T.C.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 22 July. Addr: Melchet Court / Romsey (Hants). PM: London, 22 July 1872. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Letter written by TC in blue pencil to “there be”; from “any” to signature written in ink, with postscript and envelope written in red pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Dear Lady,— Take care of yrself; be quiet, and get well! Quiet, I shd judge is one of the most salutary & essential things for you.

This morng, John has written to Mrs GandyHousekeeper at Seaforth Lodge. that we are to be at Seaforth Lodge on Thursday Evg next. After reflexn, and study of the trains, it appears the direct journey altogethr is scarcely an hour longer than that to Romsey itself, and involves no stoppages or change of trains;—farther that (in spite of yr kind invitatns) it is a charity to keep out of yr prest environment,Romsey, the nearest station to Melchet; presumably Lady Ashburton suggested a visit to her en route to Devon. and not to augment yr many & doubtless hurtful cares and botheratns; but leave Melchet on the left waiting hopefully for a better time. I confess too, on my own behalf, I seldom, almost never, had more need of getting out of this roaring roasting element, into some silent little City of Refuge,—if there be any such attainable, on this side The One that I always devoutly know of.
Adieu, adieu, dear loving Friend

postscript.p: Froude goes off tomorrow morng, on a month’s Yacht-voyaging with Ld DucieHenry John Reynolds-Moreton (1827–1921), 3d earl of Ducie.
Thunder and a blessed dash of rain, to cool us a little today

bibl.sourceNote: TC’s receipt [TC]-FC, 24 July. MS: Morgan. Hitherto unpbd. Written in John A. Carlyle’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO FREDERIC CHAPMAN

docBody.p: I have to acknowledge receipt of your statement of account ending June 30th and also of the three Bills amounting in all to Five Hundred & Forty six Pounds 13/4 for payment of the amount due to me—

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JF, 2 Aug. Addr: Palace-Gate House / Kensington / London. S.W. PM: Axminster, 2 Aug. 1872. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with “gratefully” and the signature written by TC.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.dateline:
Seaforth Lodge Seaton
S. Devon. Aug: 2d. [1872]
docBody.p:
The little note you left for me at Chelsea recorded a little bit of triumphant industry for me which I was really glad of on the whole, and certainly full of thanks for.Forster apparently sent TC a draft announcement of some kind of pension for Geraldine Jewsbury; he wrote, 31 July: “If you approve of the printed announcement—this will be sufficiently known by your not returning it with amendment.” Forster had been attempting to get a Civil List pension for Jewsbury since May 1869; see 46:49TC to JF, 26 May 1869, and with the help of Mary Aitken had obtained signatures from many prominent people in support of the petition; see 47:141TC to JAC, 21 Jan. 1871. Although still unsuccessful with that, they had apparently achieved something. Forster wrote to Frederic Chapman, 28 July: “Your suggestion is clearly an improvement and I have altered the announcement accordingly. When the correction is made, send one or two copies to me at Palace Gate House, that I may let Mr Carlyle have one” (MS: untraced). The printed announcement is untraced. The note yesterday morning also brought good tidings and naturally did me good also. I hope both of you will really profit by these fine summer airs at KnebworthForster wrote: “I got on reasonably well at Knebworth—and have promised to return in a few days for a little longer stay, when I shall take the Small One [his wife, Eliza] with me.” Forster had been staying at Knebworth House, Hertfordshire, home of Edward George Earle Lytton Bulwer, 1st Baron Lytton, his son, Edward Robert Bulwer-Lytton (both close friends of Forster), and Edward Robert’s wife, Edith. for a little while and then go down with new strength and hope to the sea side breezes and many-sounding main.Forster was to go to Torquay on the Devonshire coast, Nov. This is a beautiful silent and solitary place; much grateful to one’s wearied soul. The bathing,
too, is excellent; the air delightful and within doors all that silent hospitality can do for us, is done to perfection;—only sleep hitherto has been a defective quantity; which, you know, is always my weak side. Nevertheless by human ingenuity, travailing assiduously in this high matter, especially making little wedges and putting them wisely and well, and putting them inTC put wedges of paper in the window frames to stop them rattling. ditto, ditto—I think I have at last succeeded; thank Heaven;—for the last four and twenty hours at least, it is certain I have had more sleep, than in any day and night for the last three weeks. So that we may say all is now something like well for except in regard to sleep all was already favourable to me— The very sound of that sea, bodeful, mournful great and continual is like that of Eternity pacifying and purifying to a weary, worn out soul. Allah Kerim [God is generous], as the Moslem says—

The news from Melchet, I am glad to say continues favourable but the poor Lady has had a bad adventure and one that I cannot get out of my mind; she is still very weak can hardly walk even down stairs and is reduced altogether to driving for exercise.

QuainRichard Quain, Lady Ashburton’s doctor. , as usual, is full of encouragement and denies the room for any apprehension but I dont like such attacks: my own private opinion is her poor ladyship might do better here in her own quiet sea cottage than either at Buxton, Wiesbaden,Buxton, spa town in Derbyshire; Wiesbaden, spa town in central W Germany. or any other bath place that could be appointed her—
Good bye, dear Forster
Peace and blessing go with you and your’s—

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 4 Aug. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Surtees, Ludovisi 158. Written by TC in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
My heart bleeds for you, dear Lady; and, alas, in poor me, what help or shadow of service is there?Melchet Court was seriously damaged by fire, 3 Aug.; the Hampshire Advertiser reported, 7 Aug.: “It seems that about half-past 2 o’clock on Saturday morning one of the under gardeners saw smoke issuing from a gable in the roof of the building, at the north-west end, near an attic in the servants’ apartments, and he at once raised an alarm. Mr. Cross, the house steward, speedily summoned the whole of the men about the place to assist him to put out the fire, the flames at this time bursting out, and sent messengers on horse-back to Romsey and Broadlands for help, telegraphing also to Salisbury.” Joseph Cross (ca. 1831–1918), formerly head gardener at Addiscombe, now at Melchet. Many local people came to help with the “removal of the priceless works of art with which the place was fairly crowded, and paintings, sculpture … bronzes, rare and curious china, tapestries, together with the valuable library, were quickly taken to the open air, the most commendable zeal and enthusiasm being shown, not only with the motive of saving such works of art, but from the sympathy and love felt for the noble proprietress … . Her ladyship, notwithstanding being in a delicate state of health, persisted in remaining on the lawn, reclining on a couch, and watching the operations during the whole of the day. … Nearly all the priceless treasures which the house contained were saved. … Not so with the painted ceilings. … Indeed the most stately apartments in the house appear to have sustained the greatest damage, together with some of the rare and costly furniture; and nearly two-thirds of the building have been reduced to a mass of blackened, shapeless walls.” The Salisbury and Winchester Journal reported, 10 Aug.: “Lady Ashburton had … returned to Melchet only a few days before. … What the pecuniary loss sustained by her ladyship may be it is difficult, perhaps impossible, to say. We have heard it estimated at from some 20,000£. to 30,000£.” The Athenæum noted, 10 Aug.: “The splendid new mansion of the Dowager Lady Ashburton, Melchet Court, Hants., has been destroyed by fire. It contained many of the splendid works of art formerly at Bath House, in Piccadilly, and the Grange, in Hampshire, and the library was, perhaps, one of the best private collections in England.” See also Surtees, Ludovisi 157–58. I can fill myself with grief, confusion and astonisht
for yr dear kind sake; but what is the use of that to any one! Seldom in my life have I had such an amazing, sudden & wild bit of Job’s newsEvil tidings; cf. Job 1:14–19. Presumably TC received the news by telegram. as yesterday at dinner!
The one bit of consolatn we have yet had is, that you do not seem to have been hurt in the sudden overturn! God grant it be all true;—for who almost cd believe it?—

Mary does know; we found last night that she had caught suspicion from the look of our faces, & that it was better to tell her.Lady Ashburton and her da., Mary Florence, had apparently been at Seaforth with TC and John A. Carlyle for a few days, and Mary Florence remained when Lady Ashburton returned to Melchet Court; see Surtees, Ludovisi 157. Her one anxiety was abt Mamma,—“so weak, oh you don’t know how weak!” Said she.
I give you my word of honour that she is brilliantly well this morng;—and knowing Mamma to be safe, I do believe cares little if all Wiltshire were on fire. Bonny little woman.
God be ever with you, much-suffering kindest of living Friends.— Think seriously of coming hither, instead of to Wiesbaden &c &c!

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lady A, [ca. 7 Aug.]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote in blue pencil in the margins of Forster’s letter from Knebworth, 6 Aug., written to TC when he had just heard about the fire at Melchet.
bibl.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Right glad shd I be of a bit of articulate writing from you: 1o as to how you really are; 2o as to when we may hope to see you here? No wholesomer or stiller purer place, I believe, is to be found in world!— Yr Darling Mary is in perfect health, & bright as the Morning. Take that for certain. With my heart’s blessing— Read ForsterForster wrote: “Dear Carlyle—if it be in any manner proper & practicable You will perhaps kindly say a word of sympathy for me. … [O]ne trusts that Lady Ashburton’s health, with her courage and all noble qualities, may bear her thru!” before burningCaroline Davenport Bromley also wrote to TC, 6 Aug.: “Was there ever such a Catastrophe! I can think of nothing else & I grieve with all my heart for poor Ly A—the trouble & care of so many years wasted! Thank God it was not in the night —and that she and Mary were spared.” TC also sent this letter on, writing on it: “To my Lady / I send you my blessing, if it were good for anything. Read this, & burn.” Both letters were kept by Lady Ashburton. —

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JF, 21 Aug. Addr: Palace-Gate / Kensington / London. PM: Axminster, 22 Aug. 1872. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd. Written by TC in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p:
We are agn left solitary here, Jack and I,—in the brightest weather, & the deepest silence of all but the ocean & its waves & breezes, fittest collocutors for the utterly idle, placid, passive and mournfully musing soul!— Lady Ashburton, with her little Mary and the rest, went off again to BroadlandsBroadlands, Hampshire, about 3 mi. (5 km.) SE of Melchet Court, and home of William Cowper-Temple (1811–88; ODNB), Whig politician, and his wife, m. 1848, Georgina, b. Tollemache (1821?–1901; ODNB), spiritualist. Cowper-Temple helped rescue household effects during the fire at Melchet and took Lady Ashburton back to Broadlands afterwards; see Surtees, Ludovisi 158. (whh is empty) yesty afternoon; very unwilling to go, but obliged to countermand her horses, and at once remove with retinue,—owing to some failure in the Hydraulics of the placeThe Hampshire Advertiser, 7 Aug., reporting the fire, noted: “In the construction of the noble pile the most minute and elaborate precautions had been taken to have a good supply of water in case of fire, for which purpose the noble building was … overrun with fire hose fed from a water tank in the tower, capable of containing about 3000 gallons. … The pump, however, which was depended on to distribute this through the hose was under repair at the time the unfortunate conflagration occurred.” (a new Cluttonism,After Henry Clutton, designer of Melchet; see TC to LLA, 4 July. TC wrote “Clutt / Cluttonism” at turn of page. of whh so many have
infested her poor life!)—this Hydraulic thing she expects will speedily be cured, whh done she will hasten back. Her health has rapidly improved here; visibly better & better every day: so that I really hope all that (chief) part of the matter will be as it was a month ago,—Clutton & his Angels alone left to strive with!

The new Architect, Nesfield by name,William Eden Nesfield (1835–88; ODNB), architect. was here one day & night; perhaps you may know him, or abt him? He seemed to me a solid, direct-looking, skilful and altogr likely kind of man: I wonder what you will think of him on Trial! For it is a certain that you are to be tried with him,—mea culpa, I am ashamed to say; for I testified that you wd not grudge a great deal of trouble to save her from an infinitude of do, whh after all wd in her hands be futile; and that in short I knew no other man so certain to pierce into all the practicalities of theory, “estimate” &c &c, and to see everything carried out into a very fact before you left it.TC apparently suggested to Lady Ashburton that Forster would be willing to take on the management of her building operations, both at Melchet and at Kent House; see Surtees, Ludovisi 158 and 164–65. Forster wrote, 17 Aug.: “I write by this post to Lady Ashburton, warning her not to place too much trust in your judgment of me; but putting at her disposal from me whatever may be thought the most distantly capable of rendering any kind of help at this time. I could not have a greater pleasure—and my only distress would be that she should scruple to ask me anything!” Forgive me, forgive me! But here is literally a kind of AndromedaIn Greek mythology Andromeda was an Ethiopian princess, chained to a rock and about to be ravaged by a sea monster, but was then rescued by Perseus. (really so, I do sadly think); & where else is the Perseus to be sot [sought]! Laugh at this, if you like: but know that there is a truth in it, too;Possibly Clutton was being seen as the monster from whose clutches Lady Ashburton needed to be saved. as the Lady herself will explain, when she gets to Town & sees you.

I am myself as weak as water; yet certainly a little clearer,—winnowed somewhat by these pure breezes, & dialogues with the “multitudinous Sea.”See Macbeth, 2.1. You go to ChapmandomForster was going to stay at Fairlawn House, Woodmansterne, nr. Epsom, Surrey, a house leased by Chapman, although Chapman himself was in Scotland; Forster wrote, 17 Aug., that Chapman was leaving, 20 Aug., for a fortnight’s grouse-shooting. on Saty, I understand; “Sunday afternoon,” we are vaguely promising (at least John is) to be home!

No more of this “writing” so-called; it is like writing and nightmare! I will
add only my ever affecte regards to yr dear Wife,—of whom make much, make much!

postscript.p: We had a Son of Emerson’s here, for two days; a fine intelligt good yg fellow; who speaks of London for his winter school.Edward Waldo Emerson studied medicine at Harvard Medical School, 1868–74, including periods studying in Berlin and London.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 22 Aug. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Written by TC in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Yesternight’s umbrella, one of the 2, proved to be mine (ever-precious to me!)—the other and the stick belonged to this House. Mrs Gandy was already out abt the Linen; I gave her the rest of the message on her return.
Seaforth felt strangely solitary on the sudden; silent as Death, populous with memories only! Sad enough, and beautiful as well. Whh still continue, and will.—

Major & the GardrBoth unidentified further. were busy, and meant to be; but the faithless “Fitters” (Screw-and-Wrench people)Unidentified. did not “come in the morng,” and are still only to come “in an hour or two”; so that the pump (whh I have been round to look at) is not yet wholly out. There shall be no rest to it while I am here!—

Last night when I came down to tea, the thot of you, still near an hour from Brdlands,Broadlands, Hampshire. was dark and dreary to me;—not going to yr home even: but, Courage, Courage! I went to bed at 1 a.m.; slept, really, till 8½: there is for you!— Tomorrow I hope to hear, how poor you arrived & sped.
I have a long leaf to Forster (with the blue pencil!)—and prepared him for yr full proposals whenr you like. Trust in Forster.For TC’s volunteering of Forster’s help, see TC to JF, 21 Aug.
Time is done it seems. Adieu, adieu. Yesterday I reckon among my Elysian days; so still, so pure, so placidly mournful,—as with a sadness beyond the Grave!
God’s blessing be ever with you, Lady Dear!

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], [24 Aug.] MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Written by TC in blue pencil. The envelope: “Louisa Lady Ashburton / (Augt 24)”; presumably delivered by hand, probably by a servant,
bibl.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: We don’t go, after all, for a day or two yet,—know that, O bountifullest of Friends, kindest of Women! Read Forster’s report of the temperature of London:Forster’s letter, forwarded to Lady Ashburton, untraced; a London temperature of 81.7 deg. F. (26.6 deg. C.) in the shade was recorded, Sat. 17 Aug. (Times, 22 Aug.); the maximum London temperature, 23 Aug. (Times, 24 Aug.), was 73 deg. F. (22.8 deg. C.). I had said Farewell on Seaton sands this morning (“my last bathe” &c): but this makes me revoke;—and I feel as if still with you, still wrapt in yr affection agt the elements & their hate.— — Read F. ’s Letter; & believe it. Note the Address, and whither he is now driving. A most punctually performing man.
The Well will be filled (10 feet) and puddled this night; to stand over sunday, or 2 days longer & try what it can do. Fear not, the Water Problem will be conquered.

A kiss from me for Mary Gold. Alas, the HobbyMary Florence’s rocking-horse. still standing here in the verandah, s[t]ill fiercely galloping, nowhither & with none to ride him, makes me very wae,—as do all things!— Do not doubt of my affectn ever
One word to say yr poor Heart is quieter.

postscript.p: The only sitting- and smoking-place now is in by the main door,—in shadow of the n.e. wall.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JF, 27 Aug. Addr: Palace-Gate House / Kensington / W. PM: London, 27 Aug. 1872. MS: FC. Quot: A. Carlyle, NL 2:287–88. Written by TC in blue pencil; envelope addressed by John A. Carlyle
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p:
Yr Letter frightened us back, on view of the dreadful temperature that appointed; so that instead of going as promised we sent a telegram, & had two bathes more. But on Sunday afternoon, it grew cold enough; and so, yesterday afternoon, thro’ the pleasantest of railway weather (wind at discretn,
sunshine and touches of shower)—here we at last are;TC wrote about their return to Chelsea from Melchet in his journal, 28 Feb. 1873: “Not a word written here since the above [for TC’s previous journal entry, 12 July 1872, see TC to JCA, 9 July]! But there shall now if I live over Tomorrow.— We did go to Seaforth Cottage; had a 5 weeks there of August heat, dusty steeps, toilsome, mournful (oftenest solitary) promenadings, with sea-bathing every morning,—the latter at length faintly recognisable as of benefit to me. Emerson’s son [Edward Waldo Emerson] 3 days. Burning of Melchet Court, and much confusion! Return towards end of Septr [Aug.].” TC’s next entry, 1 March [1873], continued: “Wet muddy evg, that of our return” (TC’s journal; privately owned). surrounded by much rubbish one of us, requiring the aid of fire.TC presumably refers to unwanted correspondence. Courage; swiftly call in fire!—

In spite of 3 trials to have it ready, yr Epsom, Fair-Lawn,Chapman’s rented house; see TC to JF, 21 Aug. Address is not discoverable;—and I am reduced to send you round by Palace-GatePalace-Gate House, Kensington, Forster’s London home. for the above bit of tidings whh is literally all I can send today.
Pity me, pity me, and pardon!— Lady A I rather guess will be in London some day this week.
My best love to yr dear Helpmate. Ah me, ah me!—

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JF, 4 Sept. Addr: Frk Chapman Esq / Fair-Lawn, Woodmansterne / Epsom. PM: London, 4 Sept. 1872. MS: FC. Quot: A. Carlyle, NL 2:287–88. Written in TC’s hand in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Thanks for yr kind little word. I hope you will manage to continue on the DownsSouth Downs, extensive range of chalk hills in SE England. a while yet, and enjoy to best advantage what of summer is still left. Last night’s thunder & rain-deluges, we may hope, will have brightened everything a bit.

Lady Ashburton has gone to BuxtonSpa town in Derbyshire. for a month. She is gratefully determined to accept yr generous help:See TC to JF, 21 Aug. but I reckon there will be nothing practically needed for several months yet; architect, insurance-office, “man-of-busss”The architect was Henry Clutton; the insurance office unidentified; the “man-of-busss” was James William Waterhouse (see TC to Lady A, 1 April 1873, and Surtees, Ludovisi 179), solicitor, of Lawford & Waterhouse, 28 Austin Friars, City of London; he lived at 40 Hamilton Ter., St. John’s Wood. (so-called) &c &c being all still in the fermenting state; and no serious
building to begin till next season & its lengthening days. Finish yr BookForster was finishing vol. 2 of The Life of Dickens, to be pbd. 15 Nov.; see TC to JAC, 26 Oct. therefore, dear F., witht interruptn; and let all the world have agn from you what it is expecting!—

I am completely solitary here; and rather find it profitable to be so, in comparison. Seldom has London so little of raging noise and do nonsense as even now; small still voices can speak to one, and thots high and mournful that wander thro’ Eternity. Mournful exceedingly; yet also with gleams of very blessedness, and love stronger than death! Were not the fountain of tears quite dried in me, I cd feel it a consolatn sometimes to sit and weep, sheer weeping like a girl’s or a child’s all day.— No more of this,—nor to the Philistines anything of it at all.

I finished my Shakspre,—Othello (in Dyce),Alexander Dyce (1798–1869; ODNB; see 43:66TC to JAC, 5 Dec. 1865), literary scholar; he pbd. The Works of William Shakespeare, 6 vols. (1857); TC owned the 9 vol. (1864–67) edn.; see Sotheby’s (1932) 121. Although the plays were published without notes on the same page as the text, they all had comprehensive notes at the end of each play, covering disputed readings, explanatory notes, and comments from various previous editors and critics. Othello is in vol. 7 of the edn. that TC owned. Otho murdering Desdema, last night, with the loud thunder overhead. Unique of Speaking Mankind!— Dyce’s text &c seem to me fairly the best: at the same time, for use it is simply intolerable. A wandering thro’ the Gardens as of Paradise,—accompanied everywhere as with a whirlpool of barking curs, importunate cats, apes, and irrational unclean creatures!—
Let me hear agn, as you promise, dear F.—item even see you some day soon. With many best regards to the amiable One,Eliza Forster. —

bibl.sourceNote: TC-MW, 4 Sept. Addr: Auchtertool Manse / Kirkcaldy / N.B. PM: London, 4 Sept. 1872. MS: NLS 2883.244. Hitherto unpbd. Written by TC in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO MARGARET WELSH

docBody.p:
It is too evidt I shall not get to AuchtertoolAuchtertool Manse; see TC to JCA, 20 June. this year, nor see my poor old Scotland, or the dear & sacred things that are there for me!— John & I had nearly five weeks of the best Sea-bathing,—down in S. Devon, in a bright Sea-“Lodge” of Lady Ashburton’s, quite overhanging the perpetual brine of the Atlantic, & where one had “solitude & silence” nearly at discretn:—this, if it
be anything, I have attained; & “Sea-bathing” can do no more. John left me for Dumfries last Saturday;Sat. 31 Aug. and solitary, clear breezy London, as you perhaps know, is practically among the quietest places in Her Majty’s Dominions for the next five weeks.It was customary for the upper classes to leave London during the summer. So I sit here sparrow like, compannless on the housetop,See Ps. 102.7. alone,—as probably the best thing I can do for the poor sick soul of me just now.

As to the disappointt abt Auchtertool, the only remedy I can see is, That you, Maggie, lay yr plans for coming soon to pay me a considble bit of visit: that will be a remedy; and all others are [word illegible] or impossible!—

From John you will get the Fraser,Fraser’s Magazine was regularly sent to Auchtertool by TC; since 1866 it had been sent via John A. Carlyle in Dumfries; see 43:102TC to JAC, 9 Jan. 1866, and 44:116TC to JAJR, 30 Dec. 1866. almost as soon as this from me. Let me have a Letter soon at any rate.
With many kind regards to Walter, I am as always, Dear Cousin Maggie,—

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 5 Sept. MS: NLS 527.69. Hitherto unpbd. Written by TC in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Thanks for the care you have for me, and the news you send. I am much grateful to hear that you have determined on a daily lesson for my dear little Mary; keep that up, I beg of you: look into her German, too; she was having a silent daily spell at that, she once told me,See TC to MAI, 18 June. —and, I doubt not, will have improved. And don’t say a word agt the Peter Taylor’s;Mary Aitken had been offered work by Clementia and Peter Taylor at their school for disadvantaged children; see TC to JAC, 29 May. they are really very good honest-hearted people,—and their “Philanthropy &c &c won’t infect her clear little head or heart. Encourage in everything; and say, wht I really believe, that all this sorrow be for her good, and will lead to far better employt for her here than she ever cd have from poor old dreary Me and the fag-end of my days.— You may add with certainty that my heart is very wae for her (and for Another!).TC presumably referred to the dispute between Mary Aitken and Lady Ashburton; see TC to LLA, 12 Sept. That I never shall forget her unwearied loving-kindness to me, her canty little ways, and what a light she was in this dim scene. That this heart is always gratefully open to her; and this house and its helps always to be as
a paternal home & refuge to her in big waste London, while I live. Finally if she write to me, her kind, clever, true and cheerful bits of Letters have always been among the welcomest I read. (Bad luck is come,—in the shape of TwisletonEdward Twisleton. ½ an hour ago:—and I must end abruptly and let him come down stairs!)

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 9 Sept. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:258.
bibl.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: [I am much as usual] silent mostly as a stone. … Twisleton (who called the other day, and talked, and poked my poor ribs through the Park) sent me next day an excellent little German book about Schiller’s Father and Mother (my best reading,Ernst Julius Saupe, Schiller und sein väterliches Haus [Schiller and His Father’s Household] (Leipzig, 1851). TC’s “Supplement of 1872” to the people’s edn. of The Life of Friedrich Schiller, was a trans. of Saupe and passages from three other German books on Schiller; see Carlyle Works 25:207–88. Johann (1733–96) and Elisabeth (1732–1802) Schiller. Ernst Julius Saupe (1809–71), German literary historian. except the finis of Shakespeare, since I saw you),—and along with it a Note,—which, were it only for the Copperplate hand, deserves to be sent to your Ladyship specially.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 12 Sept. Addr: Buxton / Derbyshire. PM: London, 12 Sept. 1872. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Kaplan 510. Written by TC in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: That is the best bit of news I have heard for months past, that you seem to be getting fairly well agn; thank Heaven along with me for that, and may Heaven mercifully confirm it! As I love to hope Heaven,—and Earth (i.e. yr careful Self) assisting!—graciously and mercifully will. Continued languor, weakness and pain are a dreary accompaniment to the moil of troubles you are already in!—

That Letter you have written to my SisterTC apparently told Lady Ashburton that her affectionate behavior towards TC had been misinterpreted by Mary Aitken who apparently suspected Lady Ashburton of wanting to marry TC; see Surtees, Ludovisi 158–60. Lady Ashburton wrote, [5 Sept.]: “I cannot tell you with what feelings of sorrow, & perplexity I left you today—How can it be otherwise?— As far as my poor judgment on my own conduct serves me, I feel I have nothing to reproach myself with—How can I fail to revere, & love you?—you who were my young enthusiasm, the prophet of my soul. … You who were the chosen friend of my husband—the only person as he often told me, whose approval, or disapproval were of real importance to him—& who have been my unchanging friend, all these years—it grieves my very soul, to feel that I have brought a moment’s trouble to your life—& that I have been so Misunderstood.” Lady Ashburton wrote a letter to Jean Aitken on the subject, sending it to TC for forwarding. Kaplan interpreted the “altercation” with Lady Ashburton as the latter being critical of Mary Aitken’s “unwillingness to continue as her uncle’s attendant” (Kaplan 509). seems to me a condescenscion
[sic] witht parallel;—and it is simply my doubt whether she is worthy of it in this matter that has kept the Letter still here in silent suspense. A phrase in Jean’s one Letter to me were as if— Or perhaps I mistook it? In short I did not entirely like it: and being fixed not to speak agn at all on that inane & mad affair, I kept, & still keep, the Letter.Jean Aitken’s letter to TC and Lady Ashburton’s letter to Jean are both untraced. All yesterday, my notn was, to destroy the generous little Document, & let my own mind be the only record of it in Creatn. Today agn, I have a kind of feeling that perhaps John ought to see it, and have the deciding abt it. Today it shall continue here; and tomorrow I will either send it to him, or else burn it,Lady Ashburton replied, 13 [Sept.]: “I have just got your letter of yesterday … & am but much distressed at the news that you have not sent that letter & are doubtful about sending it at all. I don’t want to obtrude my feelings on this subject, but I feel really it is only fair to me that some one of your family shd see what I have written—when you are gone away, & your niece still continues to hold the opinions she does of me, & will not be restrained from expressing them, by fear of yr displeasure, or your pain, there is no saying what harm my good name may endure, or what pain Mary & I may suffer from the distortion of our friendship. I must therefore in justice to myself, beg of you at once to send the letter to Dr Carlyle, if you will to Mrs Aitken much better—as it is quite clear the poisoned tongue of calumny, added to the natural inclination to believe her own child, has made your sister take a jaundiced view of the matter.” as an oblation to the silent gods.— Think no more of it, therefore; except that you have done well in the matter, and wished to do!—

My faithful regards to Mary Gold: is she still continuing her pretty little “Private Hour”?Mary Florence Baring; Lady Ashburton replied, 13 [Sept.]: “Poor Mary’s little private hour has been quite broken in to—for she has been in her bed for some days—with a very bad irruption which is now going.” Did the Gazettr & Dicty ansr?Lady Ashburton replied, 13 [Sept.]: “Gorton’s Biograp Dicty came not so Brookes Geog: but it is coming.” Probably John Gorton, A General Biographical Dictionary, new edn, with a supplement by Cyrus Redding, 4 vols. (1851); and Richard Brookes, A General Gazetteer, or Compendious Geographical Dictionary (most recent edn. 1865). If not, tell me at once— I am glad to think of Lady MnPresumably Lady Marian Alford. coming to you. Go to “Dovedale,” &c &c; first, howr, to Castleton and Peak Cavern!Dovedale, picturesque limestone valley, about 17 mi. (24.5 km.) WSW of Buxton; Castleton, village, and Peak Cavern, famous huge cave just outside Castleton, about 10 mi. (16 km.) NE of Buxton. TC and JWC visited there Aug. 1847; see 22:34–35TC to JCA, 17 Aug. 1847. —

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 16 Sept. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Kaplan 510. Written by TC, mostly in black lead pencil, with the signature and postscript in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Yr Letter will be in Sister Jean’s hands Tomorrow morning witht fail; John has had it,—poising and pondering, poor cautious soul, about nothing at all!—since Saty morning last.John A. Carlyle wrote to Lady Ashburton, 16 Sept.: “Yesterday my sister Mrs Aitken received your kind letter, which had been sent round by London; & being unable to write herself she desires me to thank you for it. … As for little Mary’s business it was settled more than a week ago, & I should say settled in the only possible way, so that it is useless & painful to say any thing more on the subject” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). Mary was still considering the Taylors’ offer of work early Sept.; see TC to JAC, 5 Sept.; for her acceptance, see TC to LLA, 28 Sept. —— Yr message from Buxton surprised me (painfully and pleastly both at once) past 10 on Saty nightFor Lady Ashburton’s reply, see TC to LLA, 12 Sept. Sat. was 14 Sept. What a kindness, benignity, and yet unreasonable anxiety on the part of that mysteriöses Geschöpf [mysterious creature]! Dismiss wholly the anxiety, I entreat you! No shadow of mendacity, or mean dishonourable malice, is in poor luckless Mary herself; only self-deceptn; and the facts as they really are must & will, one day, shew themselves as facts! Fear nothing, nothing in that quarter.

A fortnight ago I had written to Miss Welsh,“Welsh” repeated at turn of page. See TC to MW, 4 Sept.; Maggie Welsh often came to stay with TC, most recently in spring 1871; see 47:203TC to JAC, 15 May 1871. abt (precisely) a “visit.” She ansrs, She will “be delighted” (her enthusiasm visibly great); but unluckily she is to have a new Housekeeper to instal with her Brother first,Her brother Walter Welsh, at Auchtertool Manse; housekeeper unidentified further. —so it will be end of Novr at soonest, I doubt! (Oh what a “pen,—sic a pen”!Coterie speech; see 6:363TC to JAC, 29 March 1833. )

I am trying to begin some semblance of WorkTC was thinking about his translations for the “Supplement of 1872” to his Life of Friedrich Schiller; see TC to LLA, 28 Sept. perhaps;—pray for me! Meanwhile (woe’s me) I have to dine with Forster this night. Time more than up. Not a word more permitted me.

Give Miss Hosmer, with my respects, the inclosed Letter,—and ask her to consider it.Lady Ashburton wrote, 13 [Sept.]: “Miss [Harriet] Hosmer says, may she send you ‘her kindest regards’—it does me good to hear the deep reverence & enthusiasm with which she talks of you.” “The inclosed Letter,” unexplained.

postscript.p: Take care of my dear Mary,—and soon report her well.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 16 Sept. MS: NLS 527.70. Hitherto unpbd. Written by TC blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I perceive you have not yet deliver Jean that Letter, but are still carefully deliberatg.Thus in MS; John delivered the letter, 15 Sept.; see TC to LLA, 16 Sept. I write now today clearly, Deliver it at once. Late on Saty night there came a Letter from the poor Lady, much in a pucker abt the non-delivery; begging that at least I wd deliver it to you &c &c; and visibly anxious on that poor little matter. She had inferred (I cd observe) from the very fact of my not-delivering that Jean’s opinn was now probably agt her;—and she has always expressed a great regard for Jean’s fairness and good sense. Please, deliver quàm primùm [as soon as possible], and take the result, if any!— Repeatedly, long since, she urged to let her “Speak to Mary herself”;Apparently Mary Aitken had been suspicious of Lady Ashburton for some time, although the problems had only recently come to a head. but, being a believer in silence, I never wd;—tho’ now agn I am not so certn that right “speaking” might perhaps have quenched some of these incipiences whh have now grown to such a blessed maturity as we experience!—

Ask Mary to ansr in a line that Letter of Mrs George’s.Although currently staying in Dumfries, Mary was still helping TC with his correspondence; see TC to MAI, 18 June. “Mrs George” was Lady Ashburton’s sister-in-law Maria Louisa Stewart-Mackenzie, b. Marriott (b. ca 1826), widow of her brother George Augustus Stewart-Mackenzie (1824–52); she was always known as “Mrs. George”; see 43:26643:biographical notes. — I am trying a little (tho’ only with the graver,TC possibly means an engraving tool, referring to his difficulty with writing which he often likened to “engraving … on lead”; see 47:203TC to JAC, 15 May 1871; or possibly a knife for sharpening his pencils. —God help me!
JohTheir nephew John Aitken; TC omitted “n.” came to me yesternight at dinner ending. He looked fatigued, poor fellow,—no wonder. Adieu, dear Bror. I send my love to all of you.

postscript.p: If you like, shew Jean Lady A.’s Letter to me,—or any Letter “you like”!

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 28 Sept. Addr: Buxton / Derbyshire. PM: London, 28 Sept. 1872. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Written by TC in both blue and black lead pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Thank dear little Mary for me: a most welcome Document, that pretty little Notekin,Mary Florence Baring; “Notekin” untraced. here this morning,—with Mamma’s P.S., whh otherwise perhaps I shd have still been uneasily expectg!—

For the last ten days I have been below par in health, and far above it in busss and bother. Health included a despicable week of “sniftering,” and streaming at the nose,—now gone agn; fair wind to it! Business related to a piece of new Writing (Translatn mainly) whh has to be inserted in the poor “Life of Schiller (People’s Editn)”;See TC to LLA, 9 Sept. & the talking & considering with PrintersCharles Robson & Son. &c how it cd be printed,—and with myself still more, how it cd be got written (“wi’ sic a pen,”—namely, Maggie Welsh not possible for 2 months yet, &c &c)! After some hesitatn this latter too has been settled the best I cd (on the terms): and—poor Niece Mary (whose Bargn with her Mrs Taylor,Clementia Taylor; see TC to JAC, 5 Sept. all but the day is fixed) appears here on Wedny morning next, pen in hand; to finish, as is counted, “in 6 weeks”; by whh time Miss Welsh will be abt ready. Wish me well thro’ this 6 weeks;Wed. “next” was 2 Oct. Mary Aitken wrote, 25 Sept.: “all my arrangements with Mrs Taylor are made—only the day of my going not fixed; and … it will be a great pleasure to me to be of any use whatever to you till Maggie comes. … I shall look for one other small word from you to tell me when I am to start. … I need not say, dear Uncle, that I look forward with much pleasure to seeing you again.” TC wrote in his journal, 1 March 1873: “dreary, dreamy Nothingness till after John’s departure,—till perhaps middle of Octr [Sept.], when Twistleton having brot me that Saupe’s Schiller, I sent for Niece Mary to help me in making it into the ‘Supplement of 1872,’ which has just last week got published” (TC’s journal; privately owned). in my weak minded state of “snifters” &c, I am not witht misgivings!

FroudeFroude was invited to lecture in the U.S. by James K. Medbury, president of the American Literary Bureau; although initially reluctant to lecture on the topic of Ireland, Froude agreed in order to defend British policy in Ireland against the attacks launched against it by Jeremiah O’Donovan Rossa (1831–1915; ODNB), Irish Fenian leader and member of the Irish Republican Brotherhood, exiled to the U.S. upon his release from prison in 1870 (Waldo H. Dunn, James Anthony Froude, a Biography [1963] 2:371). Froude prepared a series of five lectures on “Relations between England and Ireland,” which he intended to deliver in New York, Philadelphia, Boston, Ithaca, Washington D.C., Brooklyn, and Chicago. & TyndallTyndall’s tour of the U.S., Sept. 1872– Feb. 1873, organized by his friend Joseph Henry (1797–1878), American scientist, sec. of the Smithsonian Institute, 1846–78, took him to Boston, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Washington, New York, Brooklyn, and New Haven. His lectures were later published as Six Lectures on Light: Delivered in America in 1872–73 (1873). have both put to sea this morng from Lrpool, both for
America, to Lecture,—and by a lucky accidt, both going in the same Packet. Tyndl was here night before last; speaking with profuse loyalty abt yr Ladyp among other topics. “Till after January” nothing more from either Fre or him.— Adieu, dear Lady;“La” of “Lady,” repeated with a line over it at turn of page. nobody ever wrote under such intolerable difficulties!— Take care of yrself, take care.
