And don’t let poor me want for news of you!

bibl.sourceNote: TC-UC, 30 Sept. Quot: Catalog of Francis Edwards Booksellers, London, ca. 1980. “Autograph note signed, in pencil.”
bibl.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p: The Calvert Book on GoetheGeorge H. Calvert, Goethe: His Life and Works. An Essay (Boston, 1872). George Henry Calvert (1803–89), American editor and essayist. has been sent to Marshall of Weimar,James Marshall; see TC to JM, 23 Dec. 1871. there is an end of that!

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 2 Oct. MS: NLS 527.71. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: MaryMary Aitken. arrived this morning shortly after I had done breakfast; looking very sun brown, fresh and well; had got no sleep, but would not consent to complain of anything; and is now writing for me (here and elsewhere) at a very brisk rate.

The Fortnightly Review has in it an Essay by Stirling;James Hutchison Stirling (1820–1909; ODNB), Scottish philosopher, known to TC since 1840; his essay was “Kant Refuted by Dint of Muscle,” Fortnightly Review 18 (Oct. 1872): 413–37. Immanuel Kant (1724–1804), German philosopher. which, though it is an abstruse, technical and altogether dry affair,—unintelligible or not worth
the trouble of understanding,—I thought you might consent to readJohn A. Carlyle replied, 7 Oct.: “I could not read the whole of Stirling’s article … which looked very much like threshing straw.” at the easy rate of 2½d, and to send on to RussellDr. James Russell. when you have done with it. Macmillan, which has come this morning, appears to have one or two things in it worth looking at;Macmillan’s Magazine 26 (Oct. 1872) contained several interesting articles, including “Thoughts upon Government, Ch. 4, Sanitary Affairs” (26:457–60) and W. K. Clifford (1845–79; ODNB), “On the Aims and Instruments of Scientific Thought” (26:499–512). tomorrow or next day I will send it on to Jean, and you also may try it if you care. Sir Baldwyn sent me down the current Blackwood, which contains in it an Article by the “world famous Author of the Battle of Dorking,” said to be highly worth my perusal. I read it yesterday in great haste; and consider it to be, as a shadow of the future Catastrophe of Trade’s Strikes and Laissez faire, worth nothing at all;Sir Baldwyn Leighton wrote, 29 Sept.: “Herewith I send you the two books I spoke of the Blackwood (“Glimpses of the Future”) & “Maurice on Field Manoeuvres.” George Tomkyns Chesney (1830–95; ODNB), army officer and author, The Battle of Dorking: Reminiscences of a Volunteer (Edinburgh, 1871), an imaginary tale about a successful, surprise, German invasion of Britain. His “Glimpses of the Future,” Blackwood’s Magazine 112 (Sept. 1872): 282–305, was pbd. anonymously. but, as a proof of considerable aptitude in the man for writing Novels, should he choose to develop himself in that way, which probably is his real line, a thing capable of being hastily looked into. Get the Magazine No, if you are languidly disposed, and read it, as the Irish say, with one eye shut and the other not open. Along with the Blackwood Sir B. sent also a Prize Essay on the modern Art of War, on the new manoeuvres, tactics, methods and habits that will be indispensable in the British Soldier of the time now come,—all by a “Lieutenant F. Maurice, R.A.”: having heard you mention a Son of Maurice’s, an Artillery Officer, I fancied this might be he;7.Lt. John Frederick Maurice (1841–1912; ODNB), army officer and military writer, who won the Wellington Prize, 1872, for the best essay on military tactics, The System of Field Manœuvres Best Adapted for Enabling Our Troops to Meet a Continental Army (Edinburgh, 1872). He was the son of John Frederick Denison Maurice (1805–72; ODNB; see 8:196JWC to JCA, [Aug. 1835]), theologian and Christian socialist, who d. 1 April, known to TC since the mid-1830s. and, partly by way of solving the guess, looked through the little Book, for which he has got £100; and found on every page abundant evidence that the putative Father was actually the real one;—a fiking, fiddling, restlessly conscientious individuality, deep-read in recent German Military pamphleteering; but of course in regard to all parts of his subject of no use to me whatever. The only conclusion I could draw was, that the kind of British Army he wanted would and must be, for years and ions, under the present invaluable British Constitution, entirely a desideratum. Mary has also being doing for me
a little bit of Cromwell Letter copyingCromwell letter unidentified. (altogether unimportant); and even proposes, were this done, to try some elucidating of the Cromwell piece by researches in the Commons’ Journals. This is all our Literary news.

I have repeatedly been thinking of what you said about the wet climate of winter in Dumfries, and of the probable preferability of London with its resources.John A. Carlyle wrote, 24 Sept.: “I know not whether I shall be able to remain here during the winter, as the dampness of the climate seems to suit me badly; & sometimes it seems possible that we might keep house together, & I relieve you from all the botheration of household accounts by taking my half of all expenses—a plan that might require only a little exercise of patience at the outset.” I can well enter into all your feelings on the subject; and am myself frequently considering what could advisably be done. Beyond question, it would to me be very agreeable to have you within speaking distance instead of far-off, as now! It is certain also that the very loneliness of a Dumfries winter, to say nothing of the wet and mud &c, must be widely inferior to London as a life-element with so many possibilities of intelligent society, useful reading and even some intellectual employment. But this is all the length I have yet got; and the poor sum of all I can yet do is to bid you revolve it with all the clearness, candour and justness of insight that you can command; and not to dismiss it (as I too will not) till you have come to a solid decision on it. No more today. My kindest regards to James to Jean and to all and sundry. We expect to begin our Schiller here tomorrow morning; no[w] to make good progress. JohnJohn Aitken, Mary’s brother; “w” of “now” obscured by binding. is due here in the evening, while I try to sleep upstairs.

closer.note: Baldwyn Leighton wrote, 29 Sept.: “You will be pleased to hear that the baby arrived quite safely this morning—a little girl—& both mother & child are doing well.” Allingham noted, Dec.: “One day Carlyle said, ‘I stood sponsor the other day to Sir Baldwyn Leighton’s child; I didn’t like it, but was told it was only a form. I don’t think it was right. I have an unfortunate difficulty in saying No’” (Allingham Diary 217). Leighton’s da. was Meriel Gundrede Leighton (1872–1947).

bibl.sourceNote: TC-HH [HHO], 17 Oct. MS: Hosmer Papers, Schlesinger Lib., Radcliffe Institute, Harvard Univ. Harriet Hosmer was staying with Lady Ashburton; see TC to LLA, 16 Sept. Hitherto unpbd.
bibl.head: TC TO HARRIET HOSMER

docBody.p:
I usually conclude my poor bit of work here about 3 p.m. If you did me the
honour to call any day about that hour you wd have the best chance to find me; and I shall be very glad to see you.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 26 Oct. MS: NLS 527.72. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I am deeply in your debt in the letter way; but I have been very busy; and you are beautifully tolerant in that respect. Thanks to you for that; and for the two letters you have sent me which are welcome proofs of the same.

Mary and I are faithfully standing to our poor bit of work; the translation fairly ended & mostly recopied & put right: but it will still involve me in good deal of petty fash, piecing and shifting into new combinations; & I often fear no silk purse can be made of Saupe,Ernst Julius Saupe; see TC to LLA, 9 Sept. who, though very honest, is intrinsically something of a sow’s ear.In both his letter to Lady Ashburton, 9 Sept., and in his introduction to the “Supplement of 1872” (Carlyle, Works 25:207), TC was quite admiring of Saupe’s book. On the whole it keeps my hands and my head pretty full through the few working hours of the day;—and in that respect may be counted a kind of blessing to me; Saupe’s botchings and my own bother with them being better than the poor gloomy meditations which I should otherwise awake to every morning. I have got several other much superior Books about Schiller’s early wanderings (especially one Schwab,Gustav Schwab (1792–1850), German writer, Schiller’s Leben [Life of Schiller] (Stuttgart, 1841); see Carlyle, Works 25:207. which will be well worth your reading by & by): all these I am looking into & mean to read in some loose way; but I must avoid also carefully going into investigations & details on the subject; or even to seem to have taken much trouble with this “Supplement of 1872” or have made any serious study on what is so insignificant to me now; and upon a Book which I have always felt & declared to be entirely insignificant. Enough of all that for the present!

My health, sleeping &c &c are not to be called very bad, in spite of the shocking weather, perpetual rain, either drizzling or pouring; hardly above one dry day for a fortnight past: I think the bathing did me real good; and in a kind of central way; but of course I do feel that I am dragging back towards the old state of matters; no cure yet discovered for the real disease I have, old age and its steadily increasing incapacity of digesting any food! Let us be thankful things are no worse than they are.

Poor Forster has been very ill for a three weeks past, mostly confined to
the house; but for the last few days he is visibly better; has finished his second vol. of Dickens’s Life (which is to come out next month, after which there will be a third and last still in posse [in process]); he talks of going to Mentone for a 3 months; actually talks but I don’t know whether he will go. He is endlessly kind to me; and has in reality saved me I think, with complete success a very great deal of bother with Chapman and these poor Books of mine. Froude & Tyndall, as you doubtless know, are both in America; Tyndall lecturing in Washington by this time; Froude do in New York, with great splendour of reception,J. A. Froude’s American publishers, Scribner, Armstrong & Seymour, hosted a lavish banquet for him at Delmonico’s Restaurant, New York, 15 Oct., which included speeches from several eminent writers, including Ralph Waldo Emerson, who gave the welcome address. —as you see by the little slip, enclosed, from his WifeHenrietta Elizabeth Froude. last night; to be burnt when you have read it. Perhaps by this time you may have heard from young Emerson, who is walking hopefully St. Thomas’s Hospital;Thus in MS; Edward Waldo Emerson, son of Ralph Waldo Emerson, was studying medicine at St. Thomas’s Hospital, Lambeth. and came here last Sunday and said he wd write to you. Perhaps he told you, withal, what is a great secret that Emerson Father, with his unmarried daughter, is now on the seas for England!Emerson and his da. Ellen Tucker Emerson sailed for England, 23 Oct. His house in Concord had been partially destroyed by fire, 24 July, and his friends organized a subscription to rebuild the house; during the renovations, he was persuaded to take a tour of Europe and Egypt with his da. Actually so; but means to keep it secret all he can, being out of health & sent straight way for Italy; not till after some months in which, will he return and openly shew himself to England; I fear he is not in a very good state of health,— Perhaps beginning, like the rest of us, to feel that he too is entering the gloomy valley of Old Age. Meanwhile I shall be greatly interested to see Emerson once-again, on the terms there are.

Thank Jean for her letters to me; say I had already punctually heard from Mary about the flannels &c; but that I did not immediately need any; and that we agreed to put off the question till this stupendous Literary Enterprise of ours were once got off the stocks.— I am terribly whipt by want of time; and must add nothing more.— With my love to you all, I remain, ever,

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 2 Nov. MS: NLS 527.73. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Being good for little during the last 2 days, and indeed sitting idle as to Schiller work, I may at least write you a few lines before the week end. The weather has been very wet; I myself very languid and lazy. This, with the other extraneous interruptions which have occured, has considerably retarded the poor Saupe redaction,—which essentially lies on the edge of completion too;—and I see that nothing but remorse of conscience rousing me up into a certain small fury of real execution for a four and twenty hours or so will end that paltry enterprise,TC wrote about his dissatisfaction with the process, 1 March 1873: “My delays & hagglings (due chiefly to my impatience under the miseries of writg by dictatn, which were & are inevitable, & only to be lessened by perfect patience!) filled me with dissatisfaction, sharpened latterly by prickings of remorse. Do better next time: that is the one useful kind of ‘remorse’!— Since then, except rather idle reading, and helpless musing, sad enough but mostly silent, my Histy again nothing” (TC’s journal; privately owned). —probably some time next week! I have got, in the meanwhile, a great deal of interesting satisfaction from reading those other books about Schiller;As well as Gustav Schwab, Schillers Leben (Stuttgart, 1841) (see TC to JAC, 26 Oct.), TC also consulted Caroline von Wolzogen (“Schiller’s sister-in-law”), Schillers Leben (Stuttgart und Tübingen, 1845), and Baroness von Gleichen (“Schiller’s youngest daughter”) and Baron von Wolzogen (“her cousin”), Schillers Beziehungen zu Eltern, Geschwistern und der Familie von Wolzogen, aus den Familien-Papieren (Stuttgart, 1859); see Carlyle, Works 25:207. which bring him so much more clearly than ever before my mind; and, along with him, so many memories, emotions and associations that now lie full 50 years behind me.TC’s Life of Friedrich Schiller was first pbd. 1825. He is upon the whole a most loveable fellow-man, full of affection, enthusiasm and nobleness of mind; but as a Poet, Man of intellect or otherwise of supreme talent in any kind, I do not recognise him more than heretofore. Poor Schiller, the account of his death, which I read yesternight the last thing (vividly described by one Voss,Presumably Johann Heinrich Voss (1751–1826), German dramatist; see Carlyle, Works 25:287–88. who sat up with him 12 nights, and saw him the day before he died, look at his last little BabyEmily Henriette Louise Schiller (1804–72). with inexpressible love and Wehmuth [sadness], and then bury his head among the pillows in a flood of tears) brought me also to the edge of weeping, or even over the edge.

Last night, before all this, we had been dining with Forster, as you are to
understand! Allingham and young Emerson besides our two selves were the only company.Allingham recorded the event in his diary, 1 Nov.: “Dined at Mr. John Forster’s, Palace Gate House, Kensington” (Allingham Diary 214). Emerson spoke to me of your letter to him, and of his writing to you, as he had undertaken, when I saw him last, about 2 weeks ago. He now suddenly annnounces to us that he is just about leaving London, were his Father once fairly arrived! He goes to France I think, thence to America, for the sake of some privelege in the Boston Hospital, which he expects there. He was rather pleasant company last night,—much as we found him at Seaforth in August last.Edward W. Emerson sailed from Liverpool to Boston, 12 Nov., to return to Harvard. He visited TC and John A. Carlyle at Seaforth House mid-Aug.; see TC to JF, 21 Aug. His Father it appears, he privately expects to arrive at Liverpool early next week, Father is then to be carried off to Chester for quiet’s sake; to come almost incognito to London thereafter,Ralph Waldo Emerson arrived in Liverpool, 3 Nov., met his son in Chester the next day, and then traveled to London, 6 Nov. and, with a minimum of delay, make for Egypt for the winter. I made him, with sincerity the offer of his old lodging in this house; but do not think he will accept, nor indeed can regret if he dont;Emerson stayed at Cheyne Row 25–29 Oct. 1847, see 22:137–42TC to JCA, 26 Oct. 1847; JWC to LHB, [28 Oct. 1847]; and JWC to WEF, [28 Oct. 1847]. On this visit he was to stay in lodgings at Mrs. Bennet’s, 11 Down St., Piccadilly. so feckless fidgetty and dreary is my own way of life here.— Forster is still in considerable afflutter, tho’ fairly a little better; and means to be off straightway to Torquay; to return before Xmas, and not go to Mentone or any whither else. Of Froude’s operations in America you probably hear through the newspapers; something of it you may see in this week’s Public Opinion,Reports from the New York Herald and the New York Tribune of Froude’s opening lecture on relations between England and Ireland at Association Hall, New York, were carried in Public Opinion 22 (2 Nov. 1872): 555: “Mr. Froude, as is natural in a stranger to the American nation, and especially in an English stranger, makes the mistake at the outset of assuming that America and England are kindred. Our people are more Irish than English, and as much German as either” (New York Herald, 18 Oct.); “The mission of Mr. Froude is to be no holiday progress. The thesis which he only partly set forth last night—that the misfortunes of Ireland are rather due to the congenital qualities of the race than to wrongs inflicted by their conquerors—will excite earnest interest and perhaps bitter controversy” (New York Tribune, 17 Oct.). if you care to read it, which is not much worth while.— I see a good deal of James (or FitzJames) StephenJames Fitzjames Stephen returned to England from India, April 1872; see 47:20TC to JFS, 3 June 1870. latterly he is good solid company for intelligence, sincerity and information about his own late & present industries,—which, however, tho’ really important to the world, are not so to me. Allingham too appears about once a week, with a great deal of innocent ingenious but croaky conversation, which is rather cheerfuller to me than none.Allingham reported, 5 Nov., TC’s words about a Fenian meeting in Hyde Park, 2 Nov.: “‘Fitzjames Stephen and I passed through the tail of it; they were mainly London idlers. What are we coming to? People intend to try Atheism awhile. They will not find it answer’” (Allingham Diary 215).

From Ruskin I hear nothing whatever; not even his Clavigera for this month
has yet come:Ruskin’s Fors Clavigera Letter 23 (Nov. 1872), “The Labyrinth.” Ruskin wrote from Brantwood, 30 Aug.: “I should have written to you long since, but had only horrible things to write—I am under more kindly stars, now. … I am to be here, arranging rooms in my new home, till the middle of October I believe.” TC wrote on reverse: “Ruskin (Nothing farther yet: 28 Septr!).” today I had from Larkin the enclosed Letter about Ruskin & his Fors, which is worth your reading;Henry Larkin (1820–99; see 45:22645:biographical notes) had been a friend of the Carlyles for many years, and he helped TC with maps and indexes for Frederick; their last recorded contact was Dec. 1868; see 45:200TC to HL, 23 Nov. 1868. He wrote from Rivington, nr. Chorley, Lancashire, 31 Oct.: “I have to thank you for the No. of ‘Fors Clavigera’ you so kindly sent me. I have now obtained and read the whole series so far as published, and have been very deeply interested.” He wrote eight pages criticizing Ruskin’s arguments, concluding: “I have written from the depth of my sympathy with their object, and not in any captious spirit … and I again very heartily thank you for … calling my attention to them.” TC presumably sent him Letter 22 (Oct. 1872), “The Mount of Compassion,” which dealt among other things with capitalism and the charging of interest. On Larkin’s envelope, TC wrote: “Larkin (on Interest): good (Novr 1872).” John A. Carlyle replied, 4 Nov.: “Larkin’s letter is much cleverer than I should have anticipated, & what he says of Ruskin’s Fors Clavigera is generally true.” please send it back to me; Please send back the Duffy LetterCharles Gavan Duffy; see TC to CGD, 28 May; Duffy’s letter untraced. too; which perhaps is do; and is withal much shorter. There is a Mr Norton, whom you used to hear of in connection with the Boston Books;Charles Eliot Norton; for the bequest of TC’s books to Harvard College, see 46:163TC to CEN, 2 March 1870. and whom I used to like; he has turned up here again, and under mournful conditions poor fellow; he had brought his Wife away from Florence towards England, hoping a happy confinement for her there; but at Dresden she was taken ill and died of her pains.Susan Ridley Norton d., 17 Feb., from complications relating to the birth of their sixth child, Richard. Poor soul, he looks ten years older: a very wise, amiable and, to me, pathetic looking man.Norton wrote to his friend James Russell Lowell (1819–91), 20 Oct.: “One afternoon I went to see my kind old friend [John] Forster … who is ill, and in his room met Carlyle. He was very cordial and very entertaining. … I had a walk with Carlyle afterwards, and he spoke of himself in answer to my question, as very well, ‘perfectly healthy in every function and organ, but for the tremblin’ o’ me hand which hinders writin,’ so that now-a-days many reflections are born in me that will never find utterance. But I’m a verra old man, and for seven years now I’ve been sorely burdened, and I often think that the best thing that could befall me wad be to be taken from this lonesome valley.’—I hope to see more of him” (Norton’s Letters 1:422). Plenty of company here you see; “but whats ty use on’t?”Coterie speech; see 5:268TC to WG, [May 1831]. — — We greatly wondered at the presence of your guest, or poor Jean’s rather, Thomas Cooper,Thomas Cooper (1805–92; ODNB; see 19:185TC to TCO, 1 Sep. 1845), former Chartist, and religious lecturer; John A. Carlyle wrote, 20 Oct.: “Mr. Cooper, the lecturer whom you know, came here yesterday from Moffat, & is likely to stay most of this week as he has three Lectures to give in Dumfries. He has also to preach today both morning & evening. I once saw him at Cheyne Row, a long time since, & he had now grown so much stouter that I could hardly have recognised him as the same man. He takes no exercise except that of Lecturing & Preaching.” In his autobiography, The Life of Thomas Cooper (1872), his only mention of visiting Cheyne Row was in 1855, just after the publication of his novel Family Feud (1855); he did not mention meeting John (Life 347–48). —“a tiger
that has had the small pox,” tho’ really a wholesome, useful & very tolerable man!— But the hour is come & even the paper is done. I send my poor love and blessings to you all; and am ever

bibl.sourceNote: MA [MAI]-UC, 5 Nov. Pbd: The Literary World 20 (26 Oct. 1889): 370; Wilson, Carlyle 6:265.
bibl.head: MARY AITKEN TO AN UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p: Dear Sir: Mr. Carlyle bids me say that he has never in his life heard a madder proposal than the one you have just made to him. He would advise you by no means to quit your present employment. He thinks it would only be a degree less foolish to throw yourself from the top of the monumentThe Monument, a column 202 ft. (62 m.) high in the City of London, built 1671–77, commemorating the Great Fire of London, 1666. in the hope of flying.

closer.salute: I am, dear sir, yours truly,

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 13 Nov. MS: NLS 527.74. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand; TC signed his initials.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Half a word before I run out to extort from the cold day my bit of walk. Your letter came yesterday while Mary and I sat at work; thanks for your unwearied punctuality

Perhaps you may like to read this hand fast clear and solid Letter of Froude’s which camesThus in MS. to us first two days ago, and a second time this morning back
from his Wife, whose Letter too you may take the trouble of reading; both will come back at anytime. Froude’s outlooks I consider to be good and useful. I have read most of his Book; and emphatically agree with nearly all I find there.John A. Carlyle replied, 22 Nov., that he had read Froude’s first vol. on Ireland, “very interesting … . Here & there it is not quite so mature & complete as it perhaps might have been … it is perfectly true so far as it goes.” True words,Froude delivered his series of five lectures at Cornell Univ., Ithaca, N.Y., 28 Oct.–1 Nov.; the Ithaca Daily Journal reported, 4 Nov., that the fifth and last, “The relations between England and Ireland,” “was the most interesting lecture of the course, as it treated of the relations of the countries down to the present time and the large audience listened with unabating attention and interest to the earnest sentiments which the great historian uttered.” On the subject of Fenianism and Home Rule, Froude declared: “what the Fenians accomplished amounted to nothing. … Gladstone’s [Land-reform] measure, passed three years ago, was the most healing measure ever adopted, and one for which English and Scottish farmers have pleaded in vain. … But the Irish are not satisfied. They want home-rule. … The only result of home-rule would be to compel the Protestants to vacate their properties in the Southern counties. And if Protestant ascendancy was evil, surely Catholic ascendancy would be more so.” in spite of all the blustering Irish rowdiesThe New York Times reported, 21 Oct.: “We must spare a few moments for a neat little controversy which has broken out in this city between two of our distinguished guests, one of the most famous of living English historians, the other perhaps the most brilliant of living Irish orators. The battle began suddenly and sharply, and it promises, if all goes well, to result in a polemical engagement of the most dashing and entertaining character.” The orator was Thomas Anthony Nicholas Burke (1830–82; ODNB), Irish Dominican friar, who was sent to the U.S., 1871–72, to preach and fund-raise for the Roman Catholic Church. in creation, do bear fruit at last. The Professor who speaks with such superhuman candour to Froude at Cornell University, I now gather to be acrid shallow and windy Goldwin Smith.Goldwin Smith (1823–1910; ODNB; see 30:220JWC’s Journal, 21 Oct. 1855), journalist and historian, a contemporary of Froude’s at Oxford; prof. of modern history, Oxford, 1858–65, honorary prof., Cornell Univ., New York, 1868–70, and currently delivering a series of lectures at Cornell on the history of England. He had attacked Froude’s History of England, vols. 1–4 (1856–58) in the Edinburgh Review 108 (July 1858: 206–52; he described it in a letter to Charles Eliot Norton, 1 Oct. 1865, as a “mendacious and sophistical romance” (“Letters of Goldwin Smith to Charles Eliot Norton,” Proceedings of the Massachusetts Historical Society, 49 [Dec. 1915]: 126).— —“a devil of a thing wind!”.— —

Emerson was here yesterday and we had a long talk,Emerson first visited Carlyle 7 Nov.; he wrote to his wife, Lidian, 8 Nov.: “Yesterday I found my way to Chelsea, & spent two or three hours with Carlyle in his study. He opened his arms & embraced me after seriously gazing for a time, ‘I am glad to see you once more in the flesh,’—& we sat down & & had a steady outpouring for two hours & and more on persons, events, & opinions, & I could heartily wish that I could render his words to you as Ellen would, had she been there. As I was curious to know his estimate of my men & authors, of course I got them all again in Scottish speech & wit, with large deduction of size. He is strong in person & manners as ever though so aged looking, & his memory as good. I saw his niece, & he and she also are to call upon Ellen, who cannot so easily go to him” (The Letters of Ralph Waldo Emerson, ed. Ralph L. Rusk [New York, 1939] 6:226–27); Ellen had sprained her foot (Letters of Ralph Waldo Emerson 6:229). and do muddy walk:
very gentle; clear and pure on his part; but less of real heart interest coming out of it than one expected. He goes for Paris thence for Marseilles and thence across by Rome to Brindisi, and so for Egypt till Feb. or March next. His Son is actually embarked at Liverpool,—privately bound for New England,—we here privately surmise intending instant marriage there.Edward Waldo Emerson did not marry until 1874. Emerson Senior had spoken of you very kindly, and enquired considerably about your Dante &c, the first time we met.— — Adieu, dear Brother, in much haste;—wind sharp, and stiff at N.E.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JF, 22 Nov. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Many thanks for your welcome Letter, which we were much longing for here; you know what pleasure it must give to hear that all goes not ill but well, and that you find Torquay and its Hotel and your way of life there surpass expectation;Forster wrote from Cumper’s Hotel, Torquay, 18 Nov.: “You will have thought me, dear Carlyle, a little unmindful of my promise—but I wished, before writing, to give the place something of a trial; and now, for both of us, notwithstanding the doubtful variable weather, I have fair report to make. We are in a very comfortable … hotel; kept by a nobleman’s retired Cook who married a ‘German governess,’ and this worthy couple have the good sense not to depute to others, but themselves to discharge in person, the requirements respectively of kitchen and of servants’ hall. … After some difficulty, I have found a sheltered place to walk in, with view of a magnificent expanse of sea stretching out to Torbay point; and here, in the intervals of rain, I have managed nearly everyday to walk an hour and a half.” —this, alas, is what we are bound to call “well,” since better is not to be had just now. We hope to see you come back with some real improvment.

Mary and I are in the death throes of that miserable Saupe (or Schiller) enterpriseSee TC to Lady A, 16 Sept. and do hope at last to see the end of it tomorrow. In the rash, nearly vain, attempt to help poor Saupe into something of artistic improvement, I have never felt the want of fingers of my own tenth-part so much; nor seen so clearly the truth of the proverb, that one cannot make the least resemblance
to a silk purse out of a sow’s ear,—which kind of enterprise I will not for the world attempt again.— I have had a good deal of broken sleep too, and in the dismal mud-element, feel generally as if I were losing strength. To gain any, in whatever element, cannot now be among my rational hopes.

Emerson, with his eldest Daughter, as I think you knew, was here about the time of your departure, but lying perdue [hidden] for health’s sake. He is now gone about a week ago for Paris, Rome, Brindisi, Egypt; but reappears publicly in February, towards the nation with redoubled [word unclear].Possibly a badly written “energy.” Young Emerson, your late guest, must be near Boston by this time,—hastening to be married, think some. Lady Ashburton set off yesterday for Paris and Italy, under escort of little HosmerHarriet Hosmer. the Yankee Sculptress; QuainDr. Richard Quain; see TC to JF, 2 Aug. was justly urgent that she should be carried off immediately; she carries with her a deep sense of a certain person’s excellence as a man of business,John Forster himself; see TC to JF, 21 Aug. to say nothing of his farther or primary good qualities. This I think is nearly all our news.

Like all mankind, I have been reading your Life of Dickens, which came to me correctly, according to programme, and has gone finally to Dumfries some days ago.Forster’s Life of Dickens vol. 2. John A. Carlyle wrote, 22 Nov.: “As usual with Forster’s Biographies it is too diffuse & overcharged, but at least it gives the materials for any future work of the kind that may be found necessary.” It is a work of wonderful diligence friendliness & clearness of detail; gives us, as it were, a complete Photograph of Dickens’s existence, literary and other; everything is said too with perfect neatness graceful precision and propriety: some complain that there is an over-minuteness of detail; but Norton said well of it in my hearing, “That probably you wished to leave nothing for the greediest cormorant of a HottenJohn Camden Hotten (1832–73; ODNB), publisher and writer, famous for publishing pirated edns. of authors’ works; for his unauthorized edn. of TC’s On the Choice of Books, see 43:187–89TC to JWC, 15 April 1866, and 207JWC to TC, [19 April 1866], and for his pirating of Emerson’s works, see 47:210TC to RWE, 4 June 1871. He had published a biography of Dickens, 1870, allegedly written by Henry Thomas Taverner. or other volunteer Biographer to pick up after you had done.” Perhaps in the third vol. you will gather yourself more into epochs, and direct your chief force of detail in making visual the last American voyage, which has to me always so tragical a character; and stands in such strange and mournful contrast to the First, and to its own external splendour of colouring, Ah me, Ah me!—

Froude’s last Lecture report I got hold of, after what you said of it; and read with much the same feeling as your own.Forster wrote, 18 Nov.: “If I could waft a word over the Atlantic, it would be to tell Froude (who heaven has given me small reason to think he’d care for anything I said) that I thought that last Lecture of his replete with courage, manliness, and truth. And I don’t quite see how he’d mend matters by making the peasantry & small farmers proprietors of the land.” Froude’s final lecture expressed support for Gladstone’s Land-reform act of 1870; see TC to JAC, 13 Nov. His Book, the first Vol. of his Book,
I like in parts still better; one way and another there is real hope that he will depict to intelligent readers the thrice despicable Irish muddle more clearly and indisputably than was ever done before. In no province of human affairs at any time or in any place did I find so despicable and even ignominious and hideous an attempt at governing made by any Nation. Lord help the People’s William and us all!— Adieu, dear Forster; my walking time is fully come. Give my best love and regards to your dear good Wife in which Mary cordially desires to join. I am

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 29 Nov. MS: NLS 527.75. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Here is the Dale Park Letter; which was well worth my reading. They seem to be all heartily desirous of a visit from you;John A. Carlyle wrote, 22 Nov.: “The enclosed is from Mrs Fletcher who wants me to go to Dale Park.” For the Fletchers, see TC to JAC, 24 Feb. John wrote again, 2 Dec.: “No farther letter from Mrs Fletcher. I refused to go at present to Dale Park, on the score of my sleeping badly & being unable to venture on any distant change.” Dale Park was in Arundel, W Sussex. and if you did think of breaking up the stagnation of a winter wholly at Dumfries by a little change of scene, this might do very well; especially as you dont care much for the long journey; and indeed have a resting point (as you always well know I hope), which wd break it in two, both in going and coming. Our own arrangements here are as follows, if you do not already know them. Mary goes to her place with the TaylorsPeter and Clementia Taylor; see TC to JAC, 5 Sept. (which really looked quite inviting and reasonable) some time about New year’s day; Maggie Welsh has long ago engaged to be with her Brother AlickAlexander Welsh in Liverpool. at Christmas, and after him to make her appearance when I like. I often think of the grand proposal you made some months ago,Possibly John’s suggestion that he might come and stay with TC during the winter; see TC to JAC, 2 Oct. and were I not so weak a vessel, becoming daily weaker and more in physical respects
becoming a baby again, fitter for a cradle than for housekeeping, I should have come nearer a decision and declaration than I yet can.

Your Dale Park letter might have come four or five days sooner had it mattered much. Since Monday we are out of that unutterable Saupe business. Mary’s clean copy finished, and only some dirty burbles lying to be settled with my own hand some day when I feel in the vein (if ever I do so again). If I even dont I must do as my Father used to say gar myself do it:Coterie speech; see 17:292TC to AC, 3 March 1844. with my own hand in a slow determined manner, it will still be possible I hope! But at any rate since Sunday last I have been idle altogether, “idle as a dry bone,”For TC’s previous use of the phrase, see 34:219TC to AC, 15 Oct. 1858, and 42:79TC to RWE, 14 June 1865. and that of full purpose, and resolution prepense. I have done nothing but read; only 2 of my books worth anything; 1° a little Pamphlet of the Early English Text Society (which perhaps you have?) about the Wälsche Gast,Thomasin von Zerclaere (ca. 1185–ca. 1235), Italian poet, “Der Wälsche Gast” [“The Italian Stranger”], a treatise in verse on the intellectual and moral life of man, trans. Eugene Oswald with explanatory essay, in Queene Elizabethes Achademy, A Booke of Precedence, &c., with Essays on Italian and German Books of Courtesy, Early English Text Society, Extra Series 8 (1869): 77–148. Eugene Oswald (1826–1912; ODNB) translated “Wälsche” as Italian, its meaning in this context, but it could be applied to people from many parts of Europe, including those of Celtic origin, North French, and Welsh. which has really some interest. If you have not got it, say so and a penny will bring it you. The second Book is one by an Augustus Hare, nephew of Julius and of his Brother Augustus;Augustus John Cuthbert Hare (1834–1903; ODNB), author, Memorials of a Quiet Life, 2 vols. (1872); Hare was the nephew of Julius Charles Hare (1795–1855; ODNB), clergyman, known to TC since 1840 (see 13:220TC to JAC, 20 Aug. 1841), and Augustus William Hare (1792–1834; ODNB), clergyman. an artless wide-wandering sort of book; but of much interest to me; treating of all the Hares, Stanleys, the Bishops HeberThe Hares and the Stanleys were related by marriage; Augustus William Hare m., 1829, Maria Leycester (1798–1870), and her sister Catherine (1792–1862) m., 1810, Edward Stanley (1779–1849; ODNB), bishop of Norwich, younger brother of John Thomas (1766–1850), first baron Stanley. Reginald Heber (1783–1826, ODNB), clergyman, neighbor of the Leycesters, bishop of Calcutta 1823–26; see 6:213TC to JSM, 28 Aug. 1832. &c &c, full of vanished personages whom I knew, and of letters and diaries from beautiful religious women (true schönen Seelen [beautiful souls] many of them)TC used this phrase about Maria Hare when he first met her; see 12:223TC to JAC, 10 Aug. 1840. which has affected me more than any book I have read for years.Allingham noted in his diary, Dec.: “Speaking of Memorials of a Quiet Life, he said, ‘I cried over it. It brought back my old world—I used to ride to Hurstmonceaux in summer—couldn’t stay on the road. I was strong enough for anything then’” (Allingham Diary 218). Julius Hare was rector of Herstmonceux in Sussex. Charles Eliot Norton wrote in his journal, 2 Dec.: “Carlyle spoke warmly of the pleasure he had had in reading … ‘Memorials of a Quiet Life’ … ‘a verra true and delightful picture of all that is best in our poor old Church o’ England, that’s become so decrepid o’ late, and is hastenin’ towards its much to be desired end,—a verra sweet picture o’ piety and purity with not much o’ priggishness. The story of poor Hare’s death did what I had thought might never be done again, made tears flow of which the fount has long been dry’” (Norton’s Letters 1:433). My copy is from
Miss Bromley’s Library; but it is to be had in the London Library, I should think. Speak if you want it; we will see what possibilities there are.

Tom Wilson and his WifeThomas Wilson; see TC to JM, 23 Dec. 1871. came here one evening; talked me, not unpleasantly for the moment, into sleeplessness for the night: they are off now but speak of returning “for good,” perhaps in a few months, the ever restless Wilsons. The War,Franco-Prussian War; Wilson had been teaching in Weimar. it seems, has broken up Tom’s Pupilry; instead of 10 or 12, he has now at the utmost 4 & thinks of shifting again,—a man has many fitches, as I once said to poor Jamie Bretten,James Bretton, probably the Carlyles’ servant at Craigenputtoch, known as “Canny” Bretton, who left in Oct. 1830 (see 5:170TC to MAC, 10 Oct. 1830); presumably related to John Bretton of Annandale; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 30. meeting him one Whitsunday night, with his Kist on his back; and the words “I’se fitchin’ again ye see!”—“Ah yes, one has many fitches before one gets to the crown head!“Fitch” and “crown-head” are moves in draughts (board game similar to checkers); see 8:128TC to MAC, 4 June 1835. Tom is clear for leasing this house No 6, which is still standing empty,—a mere policeman & his Wife living in it.Policeman and wife not further identified. London PO Directory (1872) lists James Waylen (1810–94), historian and artist, originally from Wiltshire (see 22:269JWC to JCHI, 11 March [1848], and 29:262–63TC to JWA, [14] Feb. 1855), as now living at 6 Cheyne Row with his 2d wife, Sarah, b. Tompkins, and their son.

Two days ago there entered with the most unmelodious shriek of voice impossible for anything but the biggest “Macour,” or a “Macaw” as big as a man. The figure of Alan Ker, Chief Justice of Jamaica,Alan Ker (1819–85), lawyer, judge of the supreme court of Jamaica 1861–85, known to TC since the mid-1840s; see 18:146TC to JWC, 19 July 1844. very white of head, but in good physical preservation, and intending to return soon. He did not appear to care much about me or anybody; but one was glad to see him strong and alive, poor shrieking creature. By this time probably he has written to you, or at all events will soon do.John replied, 2 Dec.: “I enclose a letter which came today from Alan Ker. It may perhaps be worth Mary’s reading to you.”
A “Mr Church” (probably James Church?)Mr. Church not further identified. is waiting for me below in speechless company with Allingham. I must end with the abruptest brevity

bibl.sourceNote: TC-HF [HFR], 5 Dec. Pbd: Dunn, CLF 591–92; Waldo H. Dunn, James Anthony Froude, a Biography (1963) 2:383–84.
bibl.head: TC TO HENRIETTA FROUDE

docBody.p: Your letter of yesterday morning was warmly welcome to me, and I am very much obliged by your sending of it so punctually. For two weeks or more I have been totally without news from our American Missionary; didn’t even know with any certainty where he was till two days ago,—when a slight Note from Emerson’s Son-in-law (the Col. ForbesWilliam Hathaway Forbes; see TC to JAC, 20 April. who was here some months ago) informed me that he was at Boston “lecturing with the old success.”

The loss or delay of his letters was naturally a great affliction to him, amid the raging of the Heathen all round; but on the whole there is nothing I seriously lament, or am anxious about except his loss of sleep. For Heaven’s sake bid him be careful about that, take double and treble care in regard to diet and regimen, and by every method try to keep himself quiet, and as much as possible (which I doubt is not very much!) to avoid company or communing except with himself.

The rest of the affair, all that loud whirl-wind of Bully Burke,For Father Thomas Burke, see TC to JAC, 13 Nov. Saturday ReviewIn a review of Froude’s The English in Ireland in the Eighteenth Century (1872), the Saturday Review commented, 30 Nov.: “It is not a History, at least if by a History we are to understand a narrative with some approach to chronological order. … Irish affairs are apt, even without Mr. Froude’s help, to look very like an insoluble riddle. … [W]e cannot make out what is Mr. Froude’s object in the book. … In his picture, the native Irish, the English colonists in Ireland, the English Government at home, all treat one another in such a way that … we certainly cannot wonder at any of them doing anything to any of the others by way of retaliation” (Saturday Review 34 [1872]: 698–99). In the previous issue, 23 Nov., declining to review the book until they had properly read it, the reviewer focused instead on an advertisement for Froude’s History of England on the fly-leaf at the end of the book: “We have often said—judging from the book itself—that Mr. Froude did not set to work to write history because he had given his life to the study of history. … [I]t was plain that Mr. Froude had rushed at one particular part of history without any general historical training, without even thoroughly mastering the earlier history [of his proposed period]. … And now he tells us … . [h]e wrote, not because he loved history, not because he had studied history, but because he wanted something to do … . An escape from involuntary leisure” (658–59). and Co. both at home and abroad, I take to be, in essence, absolutely Nothing; and to deserve from him no more regard than the barking of dogs or the braying of asses. He may depend on it, what he is saying about Ireland is the genuine truth, or the nearest to it that has ever been said by any person whatever; and I hope he knows long ere this (if he like to consider it) that
the truth alone is anything, and all the circumambient balderdash and whirl-winds of nonsense tumbling round it are, and eternally remain no-thing. Tell him I have read his Book, and know others who have read it with attention; and that their and my clear opinion is as above. To myself there is a ring in it as of clear steel; and my prophecy is that all the roaring blockheads of the world cannot prevent its natural effect on human souls. Sooner or later all persons will have to believe it.

My notion is, were I in his place, I would make next to no apologies or explanations, but quietly and firmly read my lectures in the pre-appointed places; and that done walk silently about my own business,Froude’s public reception in the United States was considerably more hostile than TC realized. “Irish servants in hotels and private homes … declared that either he must leave or they would. Other partisans insulted him at railway stations. His life was threatened, and a special guard had to be provided for him” (Waldo H. Dunn, James Anthony Froude, a Biography [1963] 2:378). —especially not to be too long in walking home again to my own hearth and known friends; there to feel [words missing]Part of the MS cut away. and at rest.

[words missing] and should, with all the old acceptance, be delivered in all the appointed towns. Perhaps I told you this before, but I consider the thing to be essentially proper and even necessary. Did I tell you also, what I learnt by a hint from Emerson, that the supernaturally candid Professor in Cornell’s University was—Goldwin Smith,See TC to JAC, 13 Nov. the illustriously acrid? No man living but himself capable of such a bit of heroism!

I rejoice much to hear that the children are still doing well; and that Rose herself is not suffering hitherto.Rose Mary Froude was an invalid. What a blessing for her Father beyond the sea!— Do not neglect sending me any news you get; letter from the place itself, F. knows how welcome it would be; but I won’t expect, or the least bother about it, well knowing what his already botherations are.

closer.note: Remainder of letter cut away, including the signature.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-EF, 7 Dec. MS: Trinity. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO EDWARD FITZGERALD

docBody.p:
Dear FitzGerald,—I am sorry to hear of all the bother you have had and of the small result yet realized. But at least you have not gone astray or accomplished
any error. The deliverance from that monumental triangle with ball surmounting ought to be reckoned as a bit of good luck.The memorial stone for the Battle of Naseby; see TC to EF, 15 June; FitzGerald’s letter untraced. FitzGerald wrote, 15 Aug., reporting on the progress of the proposed Naseby monument; he wrote twice to the agent, Thomas Watts, sending him “a sketch of the Inscription and a rough Indication of the size and shape of the Stone on which it might be cut”; he then wrote to the Naseby Estate Trustee, 12 Sept., approving a design they had sent him which “will surely satisfy Mr. Carlyle. … The triangular top is, I conclude, necessary to let rain run off.” He wrote again to the Trustee, 6 Oct., thanking him for the latest plan, but saying “I must defer to my Master Carlyle’s wishes in this matter”; quoting from TC’s letter, 15 June, and adding on a sentence from another, untraced, letter: “I should guess that a good solid block of four, or four and a half, feet high would be sufficient, and that a square, or squarish, form might be the suitablest.” He concluded: “[TC] insists on ‘the most perfect simplicity’… [as] befits the Puritan Cause” (FitzGerald’s Letters 3:365, 373, 375–76). Courage! In a new year you will get the real plan realized into a solid stone Fact original more or less Cyclopean block original simple English inscription upon it (letters cut very deep, stone Portland) and our poor little enterprise will be comfortably completed. A thing worth doing; though we have been too long about it; and have waited till we are both of us become so stiff and hard to move from our place.

For my own share I am not in respect of health worse than usual; I might say almost a shade better; and am peaceably struggling through the mud element on patient and altogether idle terms. What you say of Forster is true; I find in his big Book a veritable Photograph of all the days of the years of Dickens, which will be held in some remembrance so long as Dickens himself is considered worth remembering.FitzGerald wrote to his friend William Aldis Wright (1831–1914) about Forster’s Life of Dickens, 10 Dec.: “I suppose that (as far as Volume I goes) Dickens did tell Forster of all he did; and I find the Book written unaffectedly and justly. And (as far as Volume I goes) I love Dickens” (FitzGerald’s Letters 3:387). Today I send you a wonderful Irish puddle of a Book properly a huge jar of Sarpants the wonderfulest and ugliest in nature; which a good humoured loyal kind of man, much a blockhead, has been at the pains to gather: read if you can; at any rate light your pipe with the thing and let me hear no more of it. Adjoined is a Sermon from Salt Lake City and Brigham Young’s own mouth: use that in the same way.FitzGerald wrote to Wright: “I have Carlyle’s yearly (dictated, but self-signed) Letter, telling me that he is much as before—perhaps even a “shade better,” and I think his Letter shows more vivacity than for the last three or four years. He also posts me a ‘Deseret’ Newspaper (of 1871) [Deseret Evening News, Salt Lake City] with a real Sermon of Brigham Young in it. … Also, a Book of Irish Atrocities … by a Mr. FitzPatrick, who politely sends Carlyle a copy, and gets called a Blockhead for his pains. I am ordered to read, or light Pipes with, the Book—anything but return it to Chelsea” (FitzGerald’s Letters 3:387). FitzPatrick and his book unidentified further. — Should you like to see Froude’s Book on Ireland I will send it (an excellent work it) on the smallest hint from you; and so Adieu, dear F; my blessings and thanks be on you Always

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 7 Dec. MS: NLS 527.76. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,—I am very glad to think of you as flying towards Edinburgh today,John A. Carlyle wrote, 6 Dec.: “I purpose starting tomorrow afternoon for Edinburgh. Two days ago I heard from poor Miss Orrock that none of her rooms had been let, & her sister & she were taking a gloomy view of prospects for the winter.” Agnes Orrock (b. 1817) and her sister Elizabeth (b. 1819), lodging-house keepers at 73 George St., Edinburgh; John A. Carlyle had lodged with them for many years (see 42:147TC to JAC, 25 July 1865). and seeking covert and refuge there for a little while till the year and the elements turn round. Seldom or never in my time has there been a muddier or more tepid winter. In Italy I hear of huge ruin in many parts; inundation of the Po &c.The Times reported, 5 Nov.: “The rains that have so grievously affected Italy during the past month seem now to have everywhere ceased, but the inundation is not on that account at an end, and there is no saying when the waters may subside in the districts near the Po, where they are deepest.” The Po, northern Italy, longest river in Italy, flows eastward to the Adriatic Sea. Edinburgh and the sight of old acquaintances, some of them friends and all of them friendly will surely do you good.— I myself am not worse in health than usual; sometimes I feel almost as if I were a little better, easier, quieter,—which, if accurate, is surely singular. Robson is to be here in a day or two, and take the Schiller BlotchHis “Supplement of 1872” to the Life of Schiller; see TC to Lady A, 9 Sept. TC’s short introduction was signed “T.C. / Chelsea, Nov. 1872” (Carlyle, Works 25:208). away: in February he has to publish Friedrich vol iii and the Schiller both. Poor fellow, Chapman told me yesterday R’s bankruptcy is of £25,000,—and all he can offer is 2/6d per.Charles Robson had been involved in bankruptcy proceedings since 1864; see 47:48TC to FC, 31 July 1870, and 53TC to JF, 26 Aug. 1870.

Enclosed is a letter from Canada which came on Thursday last; the melancholy meaning of which you will at once understand. I wish you wd write a few words to this poor fellow, to tell him at least what yr addresses are.Presumably announcing the death of their half-brother, John Carlyle, 5 Nov. John A. Carlyle replied, 11 Dec., thanking TC for sending on various letters, and saying: “[T]omorrow [I] will try to send some reply to young James Carlyle’s of Toronto.” Had not poor old John 2 Scholastic Sons at Toronto;John Carlyle’s two “scholastic” sons were James and William, both school teachers in Toronto. I always somehow think so,
but perhaps am wrong. Enclosed also is a Letter from Fitzgerald about the “Monument on Naseby Field,”See TC to EF, 7 Dec. poor monument and poor fellow. Perhaps you cannot read it; but it is no matter. I enclose also Forster’s last. I rather guess, in spite of his complainings, he is slightly better; the sale of his Dickens has reached the eleventh thousand and goes on apace.

I am very idle & have been; nothing else is open to me but reading; good if one cd attain it, but one almost never can. I have a long walk every day, rain or no rain. One of my more interesting companions twice or thrice has been Norton the Boston Editor &c whom you have heard me speak of,—a very candid, quiet, friendly kind of man, sad at heart as he may well be from the loss he lately had.Charles Eliot Norton; see TC to JAC, 2 Nov. TC wrote, 1 March 1873: “An amiable, very friendly, sincere & cultivated Chas Norton, from Boston, is here all winter, & much a favite with me” (TC’s journal; privately owned). —— Give my kind regards to Masson, to Laing, to Gordon:David Masson, David Laing, and John Gordon. paper is done I abruptly end.

bibl.sourceNote: TC’s receipt-C&H [CAH], 9 Dec. Source unknown. See also TC to CH, 13 Feb., and 21 May.
bibl.head: TC TO CHAPMAN & HALL

docBody.p: Received from Messrs Chapman & Hall, for Voll V, VI, VII of Miscellanies, and Latterday Pamphlets (People’s Edition), Three Bills for One Hundred & fifty seven Pounds Five Shillings and 10d, dated respectively: 2 September, 2 October, 2 Nov. 1872; and One Bill, for One hundred and twenty two pounds eighteen shillings and 4d, dated 2 Decr 1872.

postscript.p: Chelsea, 9 Decr 1872.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 14 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Written in TC’s hand in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Dear Lady Kindest,—Here is yr second Note to me, just arrived, safe and clean; a bright product of the new muddy everraining Hours; whh is a real comfort to me. Greatly am I yr debtor generally,—were I at all able to pay! Yr first Note, just after the stormy passage to Boulogne, how kind was that
felt to be; gratefully recd, and burnt.Lady Ashburton left England, late Nov., en route to Italy for the winter. (“Br—g?”Probably Robert Browning; unexplained further. I said, with some surprise: “HE is the unutterable; n’en parlons plus [let us speak of him no more]; a man ought to hang himself that thot it possible to imitate him;—and so burnt the bit of paper after well reading it).— There followed then days on days of utter silence; not the least notice to be had of you anywhere:—so that Miss Jerrard’sRebecca Jerrard, Lady Ashburton’s housekeeper at Melchet; see TC to Lady A, 4 July. nice clear Letr was a real relief to me; and I have been thinking every day of sending 2 or 3 painfully engraved words, via Palermo;It is not known exactly where Lady Ashburton was at this time; TC implied she was staying in Hanbury Villa by early Jan. (see TC to Lady A, 10 Jan. 1873); she was in Rome from sometime in Jan. 1873 (Surtees, Ludovisi 161). —and at length, on new hint this morng, do it. Except the face-ache, whh we can hope is quite gone agn, all seems to be well.

You are not going to the Hanbury Villa,Hanbury Villa (Giardini Botanici Hanbury), estate on the coast road between Menton and Ventimiglia, on the Italian side of the border. The ruined Palazzo Orengo and its surrounding grounds was purchased by Thomas Hanbury (1832–1907; ODNB), merchant and gardener, in 1867; he and his brother Daniel (1825–75; ODNB), pharmacologist, created a medicinal and botanical garden. Thomas Hanbury and his wife, m. 1868, Katharine, b. Pease (1842–1920), rebuilt the house and lived there from 1871, sometimes spending the summers in Britain, renting Addiscombe from Lady Ashburton; see Letters of Sir Thomas Hanbury, ed. Lady Katharine Hanbury (1913) 6. then? I confess I am better pleased to imagine you in the bright little TownPerhaps Menton, where TC stayed with Lady Ashburton, winter 1866–67 (44:112–81), or Ventimiglia where they visited (44:132). among yr fellow‐creatures than in the damp solitudes out yonder: if you will only take good [care] of yr health and Mary’s I persuade myself this Italn Expeditn will prove a clear success, and do us all a great deal of good. Courage, courage always!—

There is nothing here but rain & mud; in my life I have not such a dark puddle of a winter: rain, incesst deluges of rain, the very atmosphere become as if it too were of attenuated mud;—nor on the spiritual side, with continual “strikes” and insolent mutinyGas stokers in London came out on strike, beginning Dec., in support of a co-worker they felt to have been unjustly dismissed; after several days 1,400 strikers were sacked, others hired in their place, and many of the strikers imprisoned (Times, 20 Dec.). —and universal anarchy and greedy baseness (under the Devil’s and the People’s Wm’s guidance), is the aspect joyfuller to a serious heart. So that in fine one has nothing for it but makintosh, walking-stick and a few books, plus silence & patience. Rejoice that you are out of it!—

Froude, from whom I hear sometimes thro’ his Wife,See TC to HF, 5 Dec. seems to be Lecturing bravely over America (things that are verily true, and will do good), but to
be raising a dreadful whirlwind among the bewildered canaille of Irish here & there.

Forster is still at Torquay; rather ill, I fear agn, but still talking of a Xmas dinner (save the mark!)Forster wrote from Torquay, 12 Dec.: “I have been very ill—and am only just on my legs again. … I have … suffered incessantly … from acidity and misery in the stomach aggravating my cough to a frightful degree. Until yesterday I could get no relief, but I have a hope now that things are coming a little straight again—or as much so as they will ever again be with me. … A dreary story to send you, dear Carlyle … and one that makes me very anxious about Christmas.” at Palace‐Gate‐House.— This morning came a Letter from Turgueneff,Ivan Turgenev. reporting that he is down of gout these many months, at Paris, and doesn’t expect to get out till spring. Ho, Hoo!—

I am myself not fallen much below par,—nor intending to be so, if I can help it.—Niece My goes to her new (much to my pity, poor foolish soul)Word omitted after the brackets; Mary took up a teaching position with Clementia and Peter Taylor in the New Year; see TC to JAC, 29 May, and TC to Lady A, 28 Sept. soon after New year’s day; Maggie Welsh is already at LiverpoolMaggie Welsh was visiting her brother Alexander in Liverpool; see TC to Lady A, 16 Sept. on way hither.— Brother John has run into Edinbr for a few weeks.— Oh enough, enough.
Kiss and bless yr little Mary for me. I am, while I live

bibl.sourceNote: MA [MAI]-MW [MEW], 14 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 9207. Hitherto unpbd.
bibl.head: MARY AITKEN TO META WELLMER

docBody.p:
I would not have been so long in expressing to you, on my Uncle’s part and my own, the grateful thoughts which have been entertained of you here since the 4th of this monthTC’s birthday; Wellmer wrote from Zurich, 2 Dec.: “In my life, now so sad, there is a bright moment when I send you happy birthday wishes. … [G]ood health and as much happiness as is possible. … Most of all I would like to know what a great man like yourself thinks about people today and public affairs. The 5 million and the great victory [in the Franco-Prussian war] seem to have brought little happiness to Germany where people look for wealth and reputation rather than inner happiness. All over Germany, in cities and in the country, there seems to be dissatisfaction. It is deplorable that the best people do not seem to be in charge of this our poor country but rather second- or third-rate, or mediocre or scheming people. … How different would it have been in Europe—or indeed in the whole world—if a great man, like yourself, most learned Sir, had had the control of a great country during the last 50 years! The moral development of our superior men makes but slow progress among the mass of people in these materialistic times” (editor’s trans.). —on which day your kind letters came; but that I have
been kept very busy finishing off—that is to say re-copying &c—some work which he had been doing, viz: translating a German Pamphlet, Schiller und sein Väterliches Haus, by Saupe of Gera, which is to be added to the Life of Schiller and published early next yearSee TC to Lady A, 9 Sept., and 28 Sept. in the cheap edition of my Uncle’s works which is being issued and very extensively sold in England at present. It was curious to see on the Steamboats on the Clyde last Summer so many tourists and ordinary travellers with their Copy of the “people’s edition” in their hand.

My Uncle’s health is, I am glad to report to you, pretty good. I can hardly say I think him stronger then he was last year, but on the whole he keeps well in the midst of the horrible element of mud and rain we have had this winter;—people count that we have not had a day without rain for three months;—he takes a cold bath in the morning and then walks or almost runs for a quarter of an hour before breakfast; then walks for an hour or an hour and a half, often with some friend, in the afternoon then has another short walk in the evening before tea,—after and even during this meal he always reads, and he looks upon this as the most enjoyable part of his day. He takes a sleep after dinner too, and I always wrap him up with your pretty warm quiltFor the quilt, see TC to MW, 29 May. —and he finds it most comfortable.

Many thanks for your photograph. I like it very much, but I do not think the attitude is quite so good as the other one you were so kind as send, and which I have now got fixed in to a new Scrap-Book I made up while I was idle in Scotland last summer, but I mean to put this one beside it.Wellmer sent the previous photograph with the 1871 birthday letter; see TC to MW, 7 Dec. 1871. Vol. 7 of the Thomas Carlyle Photograph Albums, Columbia, lists together four images in ovals, one of Jean Aitken, and one of Jean and Mary Aitken together, and two unidentified women, both seated. These may be the photographs of Wellmer. — I am very glad to hear of your Lady students at Zürich.This was not in Wellmer’s letter to TC; presumably it was in an accompanying letter to Mary. I am not one of the people who believe that by being educated as well as men are, women will become less “womanly.” I believe the more women’s brains are cultivated, and the more they are given their freedom and looked upon as being equal with men the more apparent will become the difference—people shriek that they will cease to care for domestic life if possibilities of earning their livelihood apart from men, that is to say, independent of men, are allowed to them; but I not
only think they will not cease to care for domestic life, but that they will like it ten times more than if they found themselves, as is too often the case, with no alternative before them than that of “comfortably settling down” (as it is called) when that event becomes expedient in the family arrangements.Presumably Mary’s own struggle to plan her own path had contributed to her change of attitude; for her earlier, more conventional view, also expressed to Meta Wellmer, see 47:117TC to JAC, 3 Dec. 1870. — —

We are very sorry to hear your health is not good; but I am to urge you in my Uncle’s name “to continue to write and work.” I can well understand all your feelings in regard to your dear Mother.Wellmer’s mother, Eva Margaretha Wellmer, b. Wirth, d. early 1871; see 47:171MAI to MEW, 12 March 1871. Wellmer wrote, 2 Dec.: “Since my mother’s death it seems my sensation of the world has been cut off, I live from day to day, see all sorts of people, read or hear about all sorts of things, without being able to summon up interest in any of them, or find the energy for any occupation or show interest in anything. This is a sad state of affairs. My only comfort is that time will pass, and at last, at last my last day will come, and release me from this awful, wicked dream called Life and I will waken to a better existence” (editor’s trans.). Time softens but does not drive away one’s grief over such a loss.—
I did not receive the Article which you said you had been so kind as send—it is just possible it may still arrive—if it does we shall have much pleasure in reading it.
It is very late now—and I have grown so sleepy I must stop for this time.— With kindest regards and thanks from my Uncle and myself, I am dear Miss Wellmer, Most truly Yours

closer.note: Wellmer also wrote: “My modest literary productions are finding good outlets in papers” (editor’s trans.).

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JF, 20 Dec. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p:
You know how the news of your sudden illness would affect us here; and also how your ever-mindful recognition of the poor BirthdayForster’s letter for TC’s birthday untraced. was received: so that on these points I need say nothing. I ought indeed to explain my silence, which has been so complete latterly in regard to everything; but this, too, as you already guess has been the fruit of mere indolence and utter languor and torpor, produced mainly by the unexampled weather we have had,—an element
of darkness, rain and mud, day after day and week after week, such as no force of human nature with so many years as mine on its back can in the end resist. In such an element one feels at last as if the right thing were to be a fish; mute as to one’s own feelings and everything else! The universal noisy stupidity of men is also in such circumstances is also a notable thing; and gives rise to reflections. Patience, patience, there is no resource in anything else.

By the dear bit of letter we received yesterday, it is evident the Christmas at P. G. House has become impossible;Letter untraced; Forster always invited TC to Palace Gate House for Christmas dinner; he replied, 22 Dec.: “I can never tell you what bitter pain & disappointment this break-up of our Xmas gives!” no help for it: but I trust you will personally reappear before long, in better case than now,—and bring your friend LyttonEdward, 1st Baron Lytton; see TC to JF, 2 Aug. TC had met Lytton (then Sir Edward Bulwer) through Forster in 1839; see 11:49 TC to JAC, 11 March 1839, and 61 TC to RMM, [26 March 1839]. with you, whom I should regret to miss seeing again. The essence of the thing will thus be achieved; & with that we will rest content. ‘Merry Xmas,’ alas, to some of us that is becoming a very singular adjective; still more singular the adjunct to it “and many of them.”

Froude is raising a dreadful disturbance in America; your prophecy about him altogether coming true. In the last two days the report was he had resolved to come home at once, and leave the inane hurly-burly to settle of itself. But today we hear from Mrs F. that his “Bureau” wont let him; and that he has decided to quit the Irish subject altogether and give them five Lectures on certain more pacific subjects.See TC to JAC, 13 Nov.; the American Literary Bureau organized Froude’s tour and wanted him to complete his planned series of lectures; but, out of concern for his own and others’ safety, he decided to leave after his final lecture in Philadelphia on 21 Dec.; see Waldo H. Dunn, James Anthony Froude, a Biography (1963) 2:387. I wish we saw him back again safe and sound after this tremendous raid across the Border! I never could more than you see what propriety there was in taking our extremely dirty Irish linen to wash it there, and call America to see. But probably in the whole civilized history of man there is no more despicable stupid and and deplorable phenomenon than the management of Ireland by England has generally, for seven centuries, been, and now is and continues. The biggest richest and essentially the grandest Empire now under the Sun perpetually tormented with the meanest of dirty dish clouts pinned to the tail of it, which might be settled, one would think, with a comparitively small investment of human genius! The “Curse of Cromwell”Oliver Cromwell led a particularly brutal invasion of Ireland, 1649–50, massacring many thousands of Irish Catholics, banning their religion, and seizing their lands, for which his name has ever since been cursed in Ireland; see Cromwell 7:165. had completely done it at one time, and is clearly the one elixir for the case,—unsuitable for the People’s William in a high degree.

One very wet day I went by appointment to Nortons, there to have sight of RuskinCharles Eliot Norton spent the winter of 1872–73 in London with his family, staying at 33 Cleveland Square. He wrote in his journal, 13 Dec.: “Ruskin and Carlyle came to lunch with us—both in their sweetest and best moods. Their talk was extremely characteristic, and full of interest. I am struck more and more with the depth of Carlyle’s sympathies, and the delicacy and keenness of his sensibility. The essential quality of his talk and Ruskin’s alike is not so much in the words of it as in the manner and expression. … Each was delightful with the other, and each so perfectly at ease, so entirely free from self-consciousness of any disagreeable sort, so devoid of arrogance or disposition to produce false effect, each also was so full of humour and of thought, that the talk was of the best ever heard. … After lunch we had a Punch and Judy show before my study windows. I had engaged it for Ruskin’s sake, for he is fond of it and of seeing the children’s amusement at the performance. Carlyle smoked a pipe by the fireside,—and after Punch went off, we had more talk, and at sunset, Ruskin took Carlyle home in his carriage” (Norton’s Letters 1:441). after so long an absence.Ruskin was now living at Brantwood in Cumbria; their last recorded contact was in Aug.; see TC to JAC, 2 Nov. The Norton party, children, sister, and mother, was all very nice,—Norton a man I like more and more;—Ruskin too was very good and affectionate, but I got little light out of him, except that he was fallen into thick quiet despair again on the personal question;TC presumably refers to Ruskin’s passion for Rose La Touche (1848–75). and meant all the more to go ahead with fire and sword upon the universal one. James Fitz Stephen on a long walk each Sunday is the main company I have had. He is writing weekly an Article or two in the Pall Mall of a considerably forge-hammer type,James Fitzjames Stephen was publishing a series of articles in the Pall Mall Gazette from 5 Nov. (later pbd. as Liberty, Equality, Fraternity [1873]), attacking John Stuart Mill’s On Liberty (1859) and Utilitarianism (1863). For TC’s most recent contact with Mill, see 46:30–31TC to JSM, 16 March 1869. which it would do you good to read; extremely busy upon Law too, and beating Mill’s “Liberty” into small brayed glass (in a way rather wearisome to me); and indeed I think has a real stroke of work in him, if only he do not overtask the giant strength of muscle and heart he now has.

Adieu, dear Forster; don’t let us fret about the poor spoiled Xmas; it is the will of the upper elemental Powers! Give my loving regards to the excellent little Wife; and get well yourself, were it only for her sake. Ever yrs

postscript.p: P. S. My Sister writes about Miss Cunningham and that it is your time,TC, John A. Carlyle, and Forster had arranged to send money every six months to Wilhelmina Cunningham; see TC to JCA, 13 Oct. 1871. Aha, my Friend!

bibl.sourceNote: TC-ABR, 20 Dec. MS: Univ. of Rochester. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature. Alfred Bate Richards (1820–76; ODNB), author, dramatist, and promoter of the rifle volunteer force.
bibl.head: TC TO ALFRED BATE RICHARDS

docBody.p: I am glad to hear your Cromwell is to come upon the boards after all;Richards’s play Cromwell (1847) had not previously been staged; opening at the Queen’s Theatre, 22 Dec., it was widely reviewed, most agreeing with the verdict of the Morning Post, 23 Dec.: “From the dramatic point of view … the play is hopeless. Judged by a purely literary standard there is much to say in its favour. It incorporates into the text absolute utterances of Cromwell, and presents a picture of the leader of the Commonwealth striking in many respects, and life-like in some.” A review in Lloyd’s Weekly, 29 Dec., commented that Cromwell’s defiant soliloquy in act five might be taken “as the estimate which Colonel Richards forms of Cromwell, and it coincides exactly with that of Mr. Carlyle.” where I hope it will succeed according to its merits and your wishes. The miserable Turnip LanternTurnip lantern, epithet of abuse. of a “Charles I”Charles I, play by William Gorman Wills (1828–91; ODNB), dramatist and artist, opened at the Lyceum, 28 Sept., featuring Henry Irving (1838–1905; ODNB) in the title role. The play was a huge popular success. which I heard of lately will have had one good result if this ensue!

It would have been pleasant and interesting to me to witness the first night of your CromwellThe Times reviewer of Cromwell wrote, 23 Dec.: “Whatever may be thought of the free view of history taken by Mr. W. G. Wills in his drama, Charles I. … there is no doubt that it has more claim to be considered an epoch-making play than any work produced on the London stage for many years. … / [A. B. Richards] has taken an ideal view of Cromwell, as a patriot in the abstract, with the least possible tinge of colour, puritanical or otherwise; and the abundant words which he puts into his mouth are replete with weight and dignity.” had health, spirits and liberty otherwise been at my disposal; but unluckily none of these items are, and I must decline with regret your kind offer; I thought next of appointing my Niece and a little party of hers to represent me on this occasion but she too I find is specially engaged for tomorrow night. So that all I can return is good wishes and thanks.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 23 Dec. MS: NLS 527.77. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I am sorry to confess that there has been considerable remissness in my writing to you lately; it was not from intention you were already sure nor from want of remembering you often enough; but only from mere idleness languor obsuration & utter stupidity,—produced mainly by the shocking weather and general element of Mud-in-solution, which has latterly been our allowance here. 106 days, somebody counts during which we have not had one 24 hours together of dry, generally too there is darkness; no trace of the Sun discoverable; and even for idle reading one needs to sit on the sofa with one’s back to the window here

Nor have I today the least thing of interesting to tell you; only the assurance that nothing sinister has happened & that my bits of embarrassments with regard to sleep &c have in some degree yielded to the measures I used, and that neither my health nor anything else is sensibly worsened. Nay today we have again actual sight of the Sun; Streets still moist but sky clear & calm with a temperature I should say of cool summer.— Forster is still at Torquay; has had a bad relapse of giddiness & cannot return into this mudelement for that sacred “Xmas dinner” there was to have been,—a result on wh. I am by no means inconsolable He encloses moreover the little Draft for Miss Cunningham;TC to JF, 20 Dec.; Forster wrote, 22 Dec.: “I am so glad you told me of the Enclosed, dear Carlyle, which you were under pledge to me to do.” wh. I had considerable difficulty in bringing myself to mention; but wh. is now by this post fairly dispatched to Jean & put an end to.— James Stephen volunteers weekly to visit me on Sunday with a long walk & do intelligent discourse; wh. however relates mainly to objects rather foreign to me, Indian matters, effete English Officiality in the home departments, projects of codification &c. Good little Allingham too is sufficiently constant and generally better to converse with than one’s own gloomy silences.Allingham noted in his Diary, 23 Dec.: “Carlyle’s. Drove to Athenæum Club. Natural scenery: ‘any part of Nature is wonderful.’ His first view of the river Annan, ‘running solemnly down with a slight rippling.’ I said I dreamed much of wonderful landscapes. Did he? C.—‘I do work upon Scenery sometimes; I dreamed every night, for about six months, of Ecclefechan as a wild wide moorland’” (Allingham Diary 217). Froude’s answer to Bully Burke will appear in the next Fraser;“Address by J. A. Froude, Delivered November 30, in the Association Hall, New York,” Fraser’s Magazine ns. 7 (Jan. 1873): 1–21. and prove readable to you. It is polite, clear and conclusively ruinous with all rational men to Bully Burke
& his roaring platitudes & ignorances: my own thought about it was, Why answer such a loud vicious longear at all? but Froude found it needful in the given element I suppose; and he has done it well.
