We heard for a day or two that he was to be at once expected home; but it turns out the “Bureau” will not let him; and he is to get up 5 lectures upon peaceable subjects & deliver these in the Western Cities,See TC to JF, 20 Dec. without offence to Burke & Co or reference to them farther

I sent you on Friday (not having then time to write at all) a little yellow Pamphlet of the Ginx’s Baby species[John Edward Jenkins], Ginx’s Baby: His birth and Other Misfortunes (1870); see 47:42TC to CDB, 11 July [1870]; pamphlet unidentified. it is worth little; but may harmlessly amuse you for an hour.

Here have come Darwin & Fritz FrankauErasmus Darwin (1804–81), friend of the Carlyles since 1835; see 44:76TC to [CAW], 22 Oct. 1866. Fritz Frankau, probably Frederick Joseph Frankau (b. 1854), nephew of TC’s old friend Joseph Neuberg; see 45:22845:biographical notes. —not a word more.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 27 Dec. MS: NLS 527.78. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand; TC’s signature cut off.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Except that our weather is much improved, and the last three days have been rainless, sometimes with a sunny sky and unusually warm for the time of year there is nothing to tell you; but your welcome letter came yesterday, and I will send a word of answer before the week ends. Things here are in statu quo; Maggie Welsh is expected on Tuesday from Liverpool; and Mary goes in few days after to the Taylors, the exact day not yet fixed.See TC to Lady A, 14 Dec.; Tues. was 31 Dec.

I have not heard again from the Forsters—though he promised to write during the Xmas week, that will be tomorrow, if he be punctual. I am afraid they are not well, especially he; he is often in the hands of Quain, and seemed very depressed on leaving me; but I still pretty firmly persuade myself that he is slowly getting better. The Dickens has had some abuse by the penny-a-liners I believe but is selling vigorously to the extent of 16,000 JohnJohn Aitken, their nephew, who was working for Chapman & Hall, publisher of Forster’s Dickens. tells us.

There is not the least news farther of Froude, only that it seems his Answer to Father Burke (wh. Allingham is making such a mystery of) has been published in the Times and doubtless in many other Newspapers!See TC to JAC, 13 Nov., and TC to JF, 20 Dec.; the Times pbd. “Mr. Froude and Father Burke,” an abbreviated version of Froude’s speech, 21 Dec. I wish he were home again out of all that inane hurly-burly.

You do not again mention the John Knox monument business.John A. Carlyle wrote from Edinburgh, 11 Dec., that David Laing “was going to some disorderly committee or meeting for erection of some monument to John Knox. I advised him rather vehemently not to attend … because Knox needs no monument, & if he did need one, there is no possibility of getting it … in Scotland just now.” Laing reluctantly chaired the first meeting, at which many different kinds of monument were discussed; the Scotsman reported, 23 Nov.: “In connection with the ter-centenary of the death of John Knox, a meeting was held yesterday afternoon … ‘to form a committee of all denominations for the purpose of raising subscriptions for a suitable memorial to John Knox, the Scottish reformer.’” John Knox (ca. 1514–72; ODNB), Scottish religious reformer. They sent to me (a certain Revd Graham of TrinityRev. William Graham (1820–87), minister of Newhaven Church, Trinity, Edinburgh; one of the committee members and author of Robert Bruce and John Knox (Edinburgh, 1873). did) to put my name on their committee, wh. I at once emphatically declined. There came afterwards some private application to Mary from the same Graham; but no answer was made,John replied, 29 Dec.: “You did well in emphatically refusing to have anything to do with that invitation to become a member of the committee for memorial to Knox. I have heard of the man who invited you & then wrote to Mary. He is described as even worse & more stupid & obstinate than the Rogers who sought subscribers for the Wallace monument.” For Rev. Charles Rogers (1825–1890; ODNB), Church of Scotland minister and historian, and the Wallace monument, see 38:164TC to JCA, 27 Aug. 1862; for Rogers’s most recent venture, the Bruce monument, see 47:35–38TC to CROG, 25 June 1870. John continued that Laing had told him that the recent meeting resolved “to appoint a committee, & wait till £10,000 had been subscribed for a monument of Knox, it being taken for granted that ‘many noblemen & gentlemen would give £500 a piece’ for such purpose; after which the committee might decide what sort of monument it should be. … Laing expects no £500 subscriptions, but still hopes that ‘at least a good statue of Knox may be realized for the honour of Edinburgh,’ where there are so many statues which serve only for ostentation.” A statue of John Knox, by John Hutchison RSA (1832–1910), was finally raised in New College quadrangle, 1896, and another inside St. Giles Cathedral, 1906, by Pittendrigh MacGillivray RSA (1856–1938; ODNB). nor was any to another application to myself from a Coll DavidsonCol. David Davidson; see TC to DD, 22 Feb. (well known to my Aunts at Morningside):JWC’s aunts Elizabeth and Ann Welsh; John reported, 11 Dec.: “Yesternight I called at Craigen Villa, & found Miss Welsh & Miss Anne looking unusually well. They made many minute enquiries about you & Mary. … Miss Anne moves about as formerly in her missionary work & could talk infinitely about it if one could willingly listen.” nothing but nonsense and disgusting vulgarity unveracity and absurdity seemed likely to result from such a movement, so originated. I dont even expect they will realize a supportable bust of Knox,—the general belief (even Laing’s), being in some Cnox of, I think, “Bezas Icones”The Scotsman reported Laing’s words during the initial meeting: “We have a portrait of Knox, published by his colleague Theodore Beza, and there can be no doubt that it has a sort of general resemblance” (23 Nov.). Theodore Beza (1519–1605), French protestant theologian; his book Icones (Geneva, 1580) included a portrait of Johannes Cnoxus Giffordiensis Scotus (Knox) which TC found unbelievable; he was to include it in “The Portraits of John Knox” (1875), Carlyle, Works 30:313 and 318; see 127. and total incredulity in the picture at Torphichen(?) engraved
in Craiks pictorial history,The Torphichen portrait (Carlyle, Works 30:opp. 330) was, according to TC, an attempt to improve on the Beza portrait, but very similar; see 128. The portrait that TC believed to be a true likeness, engraved by Benjamin Holl, was the Somerville portrait. TC noted in “The Portraits of John Knox” that he had first seen it in Charles Knight’s publication of George L. Craik and Charles MacFarlane, The Pictorial History of England (1849) 2:opp. 548; “as soon as possible, [I] had another copy of the Engraving framed and hung up beside me” (Carlyle, Works 30:opp. 313, 30:360); the engraving is still in Carlyle House, Chelsea; see 129. TC’s “The Portraits of John Knox” was first pbd. in Fraser’s Magazine n.s. 11 (April 1875: 407–39; see CL vol. 49. which to me has always appeared the one credible or conceivable likeness of Knox. Tell me a little how that affair, if it have not altogether collapsed, is going on. I hope Laing has nothing to do with it,——tho’ if it is to go on at all, he would doubtless be a salutary element.

We are glad to hear of your meaning still to stay for a little while in Edinburgh. John had heard you were meaning to leave as if today or tomorrow [words missing] good you have [word missing]Words missing because the signature on the other side of the paper has been cut away. intention In Edinburgh the weather cannot well be worse than in Dumfries, and the resources for managing in it are evidently far superiour where you are.

A knock at the door and word that “Miss Thackery”Anne Isabella Thackeray; see TC to MO, 16 July. a very rare individual here is waiting in the dining room below. I must quit this agreeable if somewhat idle dialogue with you, dear Brother.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 30 Dec. MS: NLS 527.79. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: This morning I recd the enclosed 2 letters (cover of them nearly altogether open) wh. you will read and send to Jean and the rest of the kindred in that region. Tom’sTheir nephew Thomas Carlyle. Letter gives clear account of those Canada family affairs and will please you in the reading; the picture of poor AlicksTheir brother Alexander. old age was mournful and beautiful to me,—calm Sunset, under tolerable circumstances, steadily approaching there as here.

Between 12 & 1, earlier than was to be expected, your own letter was handed in; and pleasantly interrupted the reading of a dull Life of RaleighJames Augustus St. John (1795–1875; ODNB), Life of Sir Walter Raleigh, 2 vols. (1868). I was engaged in, and have now concluded. It is by one St. John, of Chapman’s publishing, a gloomy haggly intemperate dim & boisterous piece of writing; wh. for almost sole result has left some faint notion in me of looking into Raleigh’s Works,—if perhaps one’s spirits rose to such a pitch sooner or later!— Your account of the Knox Memorial is completely satisfactory. I conclude no result will be the issue, not even a portrait of Knox that is not worse than nothing. I have now another little matter to trouble you with proceeding from Norton the worthy American you know of in reference to the Harvard Bequest of Books.See TC to JAC, 2 Nov. Norton called the other day, on behalf of a message he has had from Childs Editor of the Collection of Scottish Ballads wh. you used to think so well done;Francis James Child (1825–96; ODNB), U.S. scholar, philologist, and folklorist, prof. of rhetoric and oratory at Harvard; he was an authority on early English literature, publishing various works on the subject, including English and Scottish Ballads, 8 vols. (Boston, 1857–59). He was a close friend of Charles Eliot Norton. Norton wrote in his journal, 28 Dec.: “In the afternoon went to see Carlyle. Miss Bromley Davenport … was sitting with him. Carlyle was most pleasant”; in his letter to Ruskin, 29 Dec., he described TC as “very well, and very beautiful his sweet, stern, rugged old face” (Norton’s Letters 1:449 and 451). Childs appears in America too to be regarded as a man of real merit. He is now about publishing an improved & enlarged edition of said Ballads;Child was working on a definitive collection of ballads, and was requesting information from scholars all over the world, which would result in his master work, The English and Scottish Popular Ballads, 5 vols. (Boston, 1882–98). & Norton’s object here was to see if I could give him, or direct him to, any list of Scottish Schoolmasters; to all of whom Childs was anxious that a printed set of queries on this subject should be sent, soliciting their best assistance in the matter. I cd only answer that in all probability there was such a list somewhere, and that I should by the first opportunity write and ascertain. I wish you would therefore someday, if you do not yourself already know about the thing mention it to Gordon,John Gordon, old friend of both TC and John A. Carlyle. and instruct me what is to be done. There is no manner of hurry, Norton told me; perhaps some fortnight yet before anything can be done in it from this end of the chain: only let us be sure to have some definite word ready for him when he applies again.

There is no word yet from Forster,Forster wrote, 31 Dec.: “This day week … if all go as at present, I hope we shall be moving homeward. … We have gone on quietly here of late: suffering much from cough at all hours, but not otherwise disturbed.” wh. raises a little uneasiness as to his state of health. I must enquire again within a day or two if nothing come. Mrs Warren has got a sore throat (probably the fruit of Xmas dinner &c); by
aid of the common recipes things look better this morning. Maggie Welsh is expected tomorrow. Mary goes next Monday.Mon. 6 Jan. 1873. Mary apparently began Wed. 8 Jan. 1873; see TC to Lady A, 19 Jan. 1873, I had yesterday a long walk not with James Stephen alone but with him & John StracheySir John Strachey had served with Stephen on the Indian Legislative Council. together wh. was considerably more comfortable to me. Strachey, a brown little fellow of evident energy, tho’ his cheeks are a little baggy is Leading Member of the Indian Council, and has got home for a 15 months of furlough. Last time I remember to have seen him was as a bright black-eyed little Boy at Shooter’s Hill, some 48 years ago!Strachey was the fifth son of the Carlyles’ old friends Edward and Julia Strachey; for TC’s memories of the Strachey family and their home at Shooter’s Hill, see Carlyle, Reminiscences 283–85. We went into Battersea Park, wh. was dry, almost altogether solitary; and had an almost more than usually tolerable walk for 2 hours.——
Lecky & Mrs LeckyWilliam and Catharina Lecky. announce themselves down stairs (3 p.m not yet struck, tho’ warned for) and I must abruptly close. Good be with you, dear Brother,

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JH [JCHA], 2 Jan. Pbd: Charles Townsend Copeland, “Unpublished Letters of Carlyle. IV,” Atlantic Monthly (Dec. 1898) 82:790; Copeland 242–43.
bibl.head: TC TO JANET HANNING

docBody.p: Dear Sister Jenny,—I please myself with the thought that you will accept this little Newyear’s GiftMary Aitken noted in TC’s checkbook: “2 January 1873 / Mary C. Aitken / (for Aunt Jenny in Canada) / £10 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). from me as a sign of my unalterable affection, whh tho’ it is obliged to be silent (unable to write as of old) cannot fade away until I myself do! Of that be always sure, my dear little sister,—and that if in anything I can be of help to you or yours, I right willingly will.

“Clinthill’s”Hill near Ecclefechan; see 5:78TC to JAC, 19 March 1830; presumably TC referred to someone from there who had immigrated to Canada. Photograph is wonderful and deeply affecting to me. Not one feature in it can I recognise as his: such are the changes half-a-century works upon us! If you have any means, send him my affectionate remembrances and unchanged good-wishes.
No more from this lame hand, dear Sister Jenny,—except my heart’s blessings for the year and forever.
docBody.closer: Yr affecte Brother, / T. Carlyle.Allingham noted in his diary: “January 1, 1873.—To Carlyle’s at 3. … This morning he said, ‘after midnight, as Mary and I were sitting together, we heard a chorus of male voices outside the window singing Auld Lang Syne. We peeped out, and saw five or six figures on the other side of the street. I was really touched. I put up the window and said “Good-night!” one of them eagerly replied “Good-night!” and then they all vanished silently away’” (Allingham Diary 219).

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 4 Jan. MS: NLS 527.80 inc. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:422. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: This morning I was a little disappointed that there came no letter from you; but Mary suggested there would be something by afternoon Post; & here accordingly your letter is, & along with it a complete solution of the Norton Schoolmaster Problem:John A. Carlyle wrote, 3 Jan., replying to C. E. Norton’s inquiry about Scottish schoolmasters for ballad-collector F. J. Child to contact; see TC to JAC, 30 Dec. 1872. John wrote: “I applied to Gordon for the list of schoolmasters in Scotland, & he has given me a big report that Mr Childs could hardly understand. But I have today myself found a more complete list of them, & also of Free Church Schoolmasters (some of whom like our acquaintance Johnstone of Dunfermline might be able to give more information of the kind Mr Childs wants than any belonging to the Established Church); & it will be quite intelligible at first sight.” The Free Church of Scotland broke away in 1843 from the established Church of Scotland. William Johnstone (1803–74; see 31:118TC to RLE, 8 Jul. 1856, and 33:169–70TC to WJO, 22 Jan. 1858), ed. of the Dumfries and Galloway Standard, 1843–46, and instructor at the Free Abbey Academy, Dunfermline. for all which many thanks to you. I shall now be able to meet Norton any day; or will probably send him the excellent little Almanac itself that he may study it before beginning.

The want of the Post-town may prove a little hindrance; but it is irremediable by any method visible to me; & of course the name of the County townThe almanac apparently listed schoolmasters by county rather than by town or village. will essentially suffice.

Mary is gone out to a Saturday French lesson, which she is very diligent about; & Miss WelshMaggie Welsh arrived 30 Dec. 1872 to stay with TC. as you see drives the pen for me in her stead. I wish to send you this small notice, round by Dumfries; which will bring it you on Monday Morning.John replied, 6 Jan.: “I have received your letter this morning from Dumfries. … . No time was lost by sending it round that way, for we have no delivery here on Sundays.” We have the same wild blusterous weather as you; this or
some other set of bad circumstances has of late begun to interfere with me a little, & ever since Monday last I have been considerably bothered (though nothing like so much as sometimes in years past) for want of sleep &c.; but at last by aid of my two friends Blue pill & Castor I hope I have got the victory again. I often feel as if this winter I were a little clearer than common, but also in the same degree weaker & more sensitive.

I am perfectly idle latterly; & do or attempt nothing but reading;——sometimes with some result of edification; oftenest with none or the reverse of any. Lecky’s attack on Froude you will by this time have seen in a copy of your own;W. E. H. Lecky, “Mr. Froude’s English in Ireland,” Macmillan’s Magazine 27 (Jan. 1873) 246–64. John wrote, 3 Jan., that he had read the article. I meant as you would no doubt understand that the Macmillan was for Dumfries when you were done with it.

Lecky’s article is decently & clearly written, with earnestness too but of a very shrill & shallow sort, & will do in the way of confuting Froude simply nothing. With respect to that poor heresy of Might being the symbol of Right to a certain “Great & Venerable Author” I shall have to tell Lecky one day that quite the converse or reverse is the “Great & Venerable Author’s” real opinion, namely, that Right is the eternal symbol of Might,—as I hope that he one day, descending miles & leagues beyond his penny-a-liner philosophyLecky, born in Ireland and a passionate advocate for that country, began his attack on Froude with a condemnation of Froude’s “might equals right” principles, which were derived from TC: “The character of a writer is one thing. The principles he advocates are quite another, and nothing which is here written about the latter is intended to cast reflection upon the former. … No system can strike more directly at the root of all that is noble and generous in human nature than this deification of success, this worship of force as the incarnation of right, this hatred of all that is weak and of all that is unsuccessful. … It has led one great and venerable writer to make Frederick William a hero. … It has made another great writer [Froude], the panegyrist of Henry VIII., the apologist for the use of judicial torture, and the author of one of the most uncompromising defences of religious persecution it has ever been our fortune to peruse” (Macmillan’s 247). John replied, 6 Jan.: “Lecky’s article as you remark is nothing more than an excellent specimen of penny-a-lining, & he will probably make amends for it by writing something better whenever he comes to sounder information.” “Penny-a-liner”: a writer for hire or a hack; Lecky was a historian, possibly a populizer of others’ ideas, but not a journalist writing for a living. will with amazement & real gratification perhaps one day discover if he be a good boy; & in fact that he probably never met with a son of Adam more contemptuous of ‘Might,’ except when it rests on the above origin.

Poor Lecky he is really a good giraffe of a creature quite of graminivorous character not of carnivorous at all; & is living in terror & tremorLecky was tall and thin, with disjointed limbs and a long nose, rather shy and gentle, so maybe he resembled a giraffe. just now about the deadly offence that he thinks he has committed against Froude,—offence like that of the vehement Navvie, Navvie declaring that as it was a
comfort to her it did him no conceivable mischief.Unexplained. Poor James Baillie we heard last night is believed to be dying.James Baillie, JWC’s impoverished cousin to whom TC regularly sent money (see 47:187TC to WILL, 11 April 1871), was to d. in 1873. Maggie went this morning, is to go again tomorrowThe Baillies lived in 12 Caroline St. (see 47:186TC to WILL, 6 April 1871), possibly nearby. offering any little help that man can yield to man in this solemn situation. Poor Baillie was there ever such a life as his been! He keeps his perfect equanimity it seems. His death lags hold of me,

bibl.sourceNote: TC-AC, 7 Jan. MS: MUL. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:293–95 inc; Marrs 777–80. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO ALEXANDER CARLYLE

docBody.p: Within the last week or ten days I have had two short letters from you; one of them accompanying a much long longerThus in MS. one from my Nephew Tom, which last gave me a great deal of satisfaction,—so minute and clear was its account of many things concerning you all not clearly known to me before.— Pray tell Tom of this; and that I feel as if he should be the individual replied to; but that he must excuse me for taking you as the one I am used to from of old! another time I hope to use him better; and in the meantime wish he wd try me again with a new letter like the last.

Your account of poor old John’s death,Their half-brother John; see TC to JAC, 7 Dec. 1872. though very brief, was very touching to me and abundantly clear. A death from weary, old age alone; no disease visible, only a tabernacle wornout with 80 years of work, and the wheel at the cistern falling slower & slower till at length it silently stops. The way of all the earth; none of us will escape it, and to some of us it naturally seems close at hand. We have only to say, in such dialect as we have, God’s just and holy Will be done.

I forget when it was I last wrote to you, dear Brother; but suppose that since last Autumn you have heard little special of my history; and therefore I will begin there. John and I, after his return from France, escaped out of the sultry whirlpool of London down to the Southern coast of DevonshireSeaforth Lodge, Seaton, Devonshire; TC and John A. Carlyle stayed there from mid-July until the end of Aug. 1872. (London smoke following us perceptibly for the first 30 miles; but the rest of the country green and beautiful as you can anywhere see). We went to a grand
little Cottage overhanging the salt water; a place belonging to Lady Ashburton,—where, in 1865, I and Another,TC and JWC visited Seaforth Lodge March 1865; see TC to JCA, 20 June 1872. not now here, made our last considerable visit in this world; you may conceive my thoughts on coming back to it again after such a 7 years as I have had! But we need not speak of that. I will say only that, in spite of my weakness, I walked a great deal, John oftenest accompanying; that the splendid cottage was by no means proportionately adapted for lodging a weak old man, liable to great misery from sounds and the like; and that there, as everywhere, though the kindness shown us was supreme, one daily needed all the “philosophy” one had; however I managed to get down every morning to the sea side; where you could bathe at any hour, and there had a hearty swash in the sea, as the first thing done for the day. In the course of 2 weeks or so I began to perceive some influence from this practice, and before the end of the month, wh. was the limit of our stay there, I had judged it was an influence for good;—wh. I continue still to think it. The only kind of medical appliance that for the last 20 years has had any effect upon me at all. John staid with me a while after our return hither; after which he went to Dumfries & from there I believe you have more than once heard of him and from him. Of our other kindred the accts are generally good; to the effect “going on as usual.” Brother Jamie is reported as going & coming between Scotsbrig and Craigenputtock; & rather in better health than has been usual for long years back. The Austins are very anxious about the new lease of their farm, wh. falls vacant next year: I always hope they will get the place again; but a painful uncertainty lies in such things. They have been prospering; they and most farmers, I understand, of late years, except the last one wh. has been very unfavourable in all parts of this country. Such a winter of rain I have never in my life seen; & in Scotland last year the people were generally comparing the season to that of 1815,—which you and the rest of us dismally, though with a pathetic beauty in it too, so well remember in Mainhill!Mainhill, Hoddam parish, Dumfriesshire, where TC’s father farmed 1815–26. The eruption of Mount Tambora in Indonesia, April 1815, produced an ash cloud which caused global cooling; many crops failed that summer, which was followed by a cold and wet winter, and a cold and wet summer in 1816, causing much hardship and famine. Date probably 1815 on MS, altered from 1816. — For myself, dear Brother, I have only to say that there has no work come out of me whatever, except an accidental & very simple bit of addition to the Life of Schiller; which, if my right hand had been my own, I could have finished in 5 or 6 days, though to poor Mary and me it cost 7 or 8 weeks of a very confused labour! This inability to write with my own right hand is a heavy calamity at present, and prevents all literary labour, of which otherwise I were now and then perhaps capable.—I think I must send you that pitiful bit
of addition to Schiller, or rather the Schiller volume altogether. It is to come out next month,See TC to Lady A, 9 Sept. 1872; Chapman & Hall announced, 1 March: “The LIFE of SCHILLER. By thomas carlyle. Forming the New Volume of the People’s Edition of Mr. Carlyle’s Works. Crown 8vo, price 2s. This day. This final Edition contains a Supplement from the German, giving account of the Schiller family, as well as of much in the early life of Schiller himself, which has not hitherto been known to English readers” (Athenaeum, 1 March 1873). soon after the end of February I expect you may have it.

The Dr is in Edinburgh at present; some three weeks ago or more he went off thither to vary a little the rainy and muddy monotony of his life at Dumfries, where he has almost no society except within the house; in Edinburgh he is extremely popular; dines out almost every day; and complains rather of too much society than of anything else. He will probably stay there a week or two longer; the rather as there is now singularly bright weather; and paved towns are all trim and clean, though the country is still drowned in mud, and great part of the middle of England especially is a lake of water from overflowing of the rivers. Winter wheat is said to be all rotted; potatoes were a bad crop too, and between the farmers and their labourers there is rising everywhere a trouble, which it will be difficult to settle.In its review of the year, the Times reported: “The extraordinary rainfall which has now lasted for seven months has been a grave drawback to the general prosperity. … In the month of June there were heavy floods in many parts of the country, and the harvest was deficient both in quantity and quality. The consequent loss will be greatly aggravated by the unprecedented wetness of the Autumn, which has rendered it impossible to sow wheat except in the lighter soils. The potato crop was the worst for six-and-twenty years. … Between bad weather and Labourers’ Unions, farmers have not enjoyed a cheerful year” (31 Dec. 1872). Times not bright here at all, more than elsewhere!

Try if you can persuade your Tom to write to me again. Alick too I should be well pleased to hear from; the Dr, by my suggestion, I believe, has been writing to your James;See TC to JAC, 7 Dec. 1872. & probably there will be some specific tidingsWord inserted in TC’s hand. got by him before long. I send my blessing, if it were worth anything, to you and all of them, my ever-dear Brother. Well may you fare, & brave may yr lives be, yonder far over the sea!— Before very long, I hope to write to you once again. Mary’s kind regards. Ever your affecte Brother,

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 8 Jan. MS Copy: NLS 20.5.25.62. Hitherto unpbd. The letter was copied by Susan Stirling, who wrote at the top: “Copy of a note from Thos Carlyle to his brother here asking him to get a sight of Mrs Carlyle’s letters to me wh the doctor had seen—He wishes to have them copied—& will return them soon.” At the end she wrote: “(The signature in a very infirm hand the letter in his niece Mary’s) SS.”
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: This is upon a very trifling matter, & will need only one or two words. You told me in your last letter of Mrs StirlingsSusan Stirling, old friend of JWC’s. John A. Carlyle wrote, 6 Jan.: “Mr [James] & Mrs Stirling I see most frequently. … Mrs S. gave me some excellent letters of Jane’s, last night to read & return. Mrs S. is a most affectionate & excellent woman; & she has much to tell about old friends that are gone.” having given you certain letters to read;Susan Stirling, old friend of JWC’s. John A. Carlyle wrote, 6 Jan.: “Mr [James] & Mrs Stirling I see most frequently. … Mrs S. gave me some excellent letters of Jane’s, last night to read & return. Mrs S. is a most affectionate & excellent woman; & she has much to tell about old friends that are gone.” —I should like very much too—to have a sight of those letters & to get them copied!TC had completed collecting and copying JWC’s letters, July 1869 (see 46:64TC to JAC, 26 July 1869), but added to them when new letters were offered. I beg you therefore to ask Mrs Stirling, with my affectionate regards & manifold remembrances in preface, if she will let me have sight of them for a little while. I vividly remember her presence here in old times;Susan Stirling visited Cheyne Row several times; see 8:197, 10:110–11JWC to SS, [13 Aug. 1835][20 Aug. 1835], and 26:98JWC to SS, [30 June 1851. Their last contact had been JWC’s letter to her ten days before her death, when TC was in Edinburgh for his rectorial inauguration; see 43:179–80JWC to SS, [11 April 1866]. I do not think she will refuse me. Say the letters shall be punctually returned.John sent the letters, 9 Jan.: “Mrs Stirling tells me she has shown to me only, otherwise kept them quite private all along. She desires me to send kindest remembrances to you, & say you may keep them as long as you find necessary.” The letters were returned 14 March; see MW to SS, 14 March. — Yesterday DarwinErasmus Darwin; see TC to JAC, 23 Dec. 1872. called, took me up to Nortons; and there I left the School board lists;See TC to JAC, 4 Jan. so that this small business is successfully completed. Forster ought to be here about this time; but has not yet appeared. Froude is on the waters probably about half way over.Froude sailed from New York, 18 Dec., arriving Queenstown, Ireland, 15 Jan. We expect to see him before next week end—if all go well. Tell me when you write what became of the Knox Monument;See TC to JAC, 27 Dec. 1872. John wrote, 9 Jan.: “I send the Scotsman of today. … Nothing more done about the Knox monument, & no report of last meeting of committee.” The Scotsman pbd. various letters both in support of and against the idea of a monument to Knox, including, 7 Jan., a letter from Francis Richard Charteris (1818–1914), Lord Elcho, MP for Haddingtonshire 1847–83, explaining his refusal to contribute to the Knox monument fund: “I did not subscribe to the memorials to those almost pre-historic Scottish heroes, Wallace and Bruce, believing the independence of my country from Saxon rule, and the embalming of their memories in the living verse of ‘Scots wha hae,’ [patriotic song by Robert Burns] were finer and more enduring memorials than any which the sculptor’s or mason’s art could raise. And so in the case of the proposed monument to John Knox. I am inclined to think that the Presbyterianism of Scotland and her freedom from Romish spiritual thraldrom are more satisfactory memorials of the great religious Reformer than sculptured stone.” but indeed I may perhaps get a Scotsman from you tomorrow
docBody.closer:
Adieu dear Brother
Ever affectly yours
T. Carlyle—

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 10 Jan. MS: NLS: Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I am very impatient to hear some news of you; & no wonder, for it is many weeks since your second & last letter came. Mine, in answer to it, I rather doubt doubtWord repeated in error. if you could read; the day when I wrote was excessively dark, & before finishing it I had lost light very nearly altogether, & had to go by grope.

Mary went away to her new placeMary was going as a teacher at Clementia and Peter Taylor’s school, Aubrey House, Camden Hill; see TC to JAC, 29 May 1872. two days ago greatly to her own regret, poor little Soul, & also to mine had there been any remedy; but I could find none. My persuasion is that this separation will have good results for both of us, especially for her. I never saw a creature kinder to me than she evidently is, or intends to be; I was much struck with the magnanimity & clear stoicism of her taking her departure. Miss Welsh, as you doubtless discern is now my ready writer & companion: she had already been here some ten or twelve days, Mary’s new place not being quite ready; her kindness to me also is constant & unlimited, & we hope to have a quieter house henceforth than latterly.

Almost before my letter had gone to you I discovered that Palazzo Orango was verily the Hanbury Villa where I had wished you to be. It is no doubt by far the comfortablest English residence on all the Cornice,Corniche (from the Italian “cornice”), road on the side of a cliff; the Hanbury estate (see TC to Lady A, 14 Dec. 1872) was on the lowest corniche; there were two other higher corniches also running above the coast, SE France, past Menton (where TC had stayed) into Italy. & I have all along been hoping that the good weather & it, & the profound composure that environs it may have been silently doing you good all this time. Nobody had more need of rest; & nowhere in all the world could you have found (I suppose) a
more perfect resting place. My hope is that you won’t stir from it till all the inundations &c are absorbed again, & the season fairly got to be inviting.

We have had here such a winter for rain as was never seen by the oldest inhabitant. England in general has become a Continent of mud, & in the midland Counties hundreds of square miles are lying now as lakes; the winter wheat was all rotted, & a bad outlook for the next year’s farmer! TwisletonEdward Twisleton. told me lately as the latest bit of ham-strung wit on the part of English hunters & their Meet at Burton-on-Trent that the Advertizement now ought to be “Trent-on-Burton”:Burton is a town on the river Trent in Staffordshire, in the middle of England. —very ham-strung indeed.— For my own share I have had a most dim, oppressive & depressive element to live in (the want of light especially a grievance); but have not essentially suffered in health from it: I figure myself in general as being perhaps a little clearer than last year, but also perceptibly weaker; as regard to sleep I have had no unusual difficulties, nay, I should say rather less than usual.

The pouring deluges do at least tend to abate noise! The worst item in my affairs is that I cannot myself write; and am thereby reduced to a Life definable as one of perfect idleness, plus a good deal of botheration, which, day by day fails not. My one employment is reading,—lucky if it be in good books; but these I think are about as rare as good people!—

A while ago there came to me from AshridgeAshridge, Hertfordshire, family estate of Adelbert Wellington Brownlow Cust, 3d earl Brownlow; his wife, Lady Adelaide, had invited TC to visit the previous spring; see TC to JAC, 13 April 1872. Lady Adelaide was the younger sister of Lady Lothian, widow of William Robert Kerr, Lord Lothian; see 47:41TC to RDK . a very kind invitation to join for two or three days a most eligible looking party (Kers mostly with Lady MarionLady Marian Alford, Lord Brownlow’s mother. etc.) which the young Countess had assembled round her there: She was very gracious and winning, but I absolutely durst not go. I have heard nothing more, nor seen anything of Lady Marion or her environment since then. I trust always the Great Lady is all vigilant upon your quack Architect & his Edifice in Knightsbridge.Kent House, Lady Ashburton’s new house, designed by Henry Clutton. I see that Edifice enveloped in clouds & rain now & then from under the brim of my hat; but can only offer a silent prayer as to what is going on in the inside there.

Poor Forster has been at Torquay all this while, amid incessant rains and winds; & only got home two days ago, instead of two days before Christmas, as his fixed purpose was. The consequence is (not an important one) that we have to eat our “Christmas Dinner” at Palace-Gate House next Monday! that is literally the fact; it being a sacred object with Forster not to omit for any consideration under Heaven one Christmas dinner with me while we live. He
has been and still is suffering an immense deal of physical misery, incessant coughing, want of sleep &c. &c.—yet I always struggle to persuade myself that there has nothing deep gone wrong with him, & that by degrees deliverance from toil will bleach him white again. He is always upon the inquiry as to the amiable Lady Ashburton & Her affairs,—but that Amiable Lady may herself know how unsatisfactory my replies are!—

Froude is expected home from America next week. He has stirred up such an Irish tempest in America & at home here as was never seen before; but all that he has said seems to me the indubitable truth said for the first time; & I feel certain all manner of good will come of it by-&-bye.

My brother John is shifted to Edinburgh some weeks ago to vary the wet monotony of Dumfries, but is not likely, I think, to stay many days more,—there being too many dinners there.— He reports of the Knox Monument project that it originates with scrubby, noisy persons, utters a great deal of noisy & impracticable nonsense for itself, & is expected to break down shortly into ruin and silence.
Here has entered the inimitable Allingham! the paper too is done & the time.——— Do please send me at once a long & precise account of how you are, what you are doing & what you propose to do.
A thousand regards to that bonnie Bairn & perpetual good wishes. Always Dear Lady,

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JC Jr. [JACA], 11 Jan. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE JR.

docBody.p: We were shocked & astonished to hear of your strange & perilous accident of which my Sister Mary sent us the first even slight description we had got. It seems next door to a miracle that you escaped with life! We heard from the first that there was no breaking of bones or other injury counted serious; but that you had got to Craigenputtock safe after such a hair-breadth escape.

The meaning of my writing you a word today is that we wish, all of us, to hear more specifically from yourself what the accident really consisted in, & how it came about,—for example if you leapt or fell straightforward, & whether towards the Villagewards side of that Bridge, or the opposite side; whether you were at once noticed, or how notice was had; in short all the particulars
that you can find time to write to us. This is the first thing wanted; & the second, which we still more pressingly want is, to hear from yourself what injuries you have received; & what the progress of amendment, or prospects of such, accurately are.James Carlyle replied, 14 Jan., that he was taking his rams to Scotsbrig to be wintered there; usually this would be done by the shepherd, but as the shepherd’s sister (neither identified further) was getting married, James took them, driving them from Craigenputtoch to Auldgirth Station, then taking them by train to Cummertrees Station, 31 Dec.; James intended spending the night at The Gill, driving the sheep to Scotsbrig the next day. He wrote: “On arrival [at Cummertrees Station] the night being very dark & foggy the train was stopped before the Engine quite reached the Platform and while the Break-Van (in which I was seated) was a few yards nearer Dumfries than the top of the bridge across the road from Annan to Dumfries. … I therefore got out, thinking from the appearance of the station light that I was much nearer than the position above described. I had a sheep-dog with a cord round its neck the other end of which was firmly tied round the middle of my walking stick and thinking we should be safer on the side than the middle of the Railway I walked in a slightly slanting direction right over the bridge taking the dog with me. The Breaksman, who left the Van just before me, was walking down by the side of his Wagons and turned his light to see which way I had gone and shouted ‘Mind the Bridge there’!—but I had begun to descend on the side of the Bridge next the Village and landed in the rib of the road which would be ‘left hand’ going up to the Gill. I must have landed half on my back & right side. I was quite sensible and felt my cheek laying in mud and heard the sound I made in recovering my breath. I was soon surrounded by several men with lamps and young James Austin who was waiting for me at the Station. … James went for the Gig and took me to the Gill. Got a Doctor from Annan, who said no bones were broken and prescribed fomentation with hot water for an hour at a time. By 4 am. I was sitting up in bed writing notes in pencil to John at Scotsbrig and to my Father & Kate here. / The bridge is 22 feet high I have been informed without parapet of any kind. That I shd have fallen from such a height and travelled from the Gill to Craigenputtock … within a week is really marvellous. My head must have been saved by a hard felt hat I wore and the rim of which was broken on the right side. / My right shoulder and right loin are still sore; but I can walk about a little on hard ground with two sticks. I have never been sick and have been able to take food quite well considering I that have been confined to the house.” This is all my request at present dear James:—

Our own state here is quite the usual one (except that Mary is gone to her new place, & that Miss Welsh is here in her stead); & in point of health, sleep &c. I cannot call myself below par, nor much above it either.
Many thanks for the excellent grouse &c., which were very wholesome eating. We wish you in the language of the Season a luckier year than the last has been.
docBody.closer: I ever am / Your affete / T. Carlyle

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 14 Jan. MS: NLS 527.81. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Your strong pouch of one envelope brought us the precious letters quite safe;For JWC’s letters to Susan Stirling, see TC to JAC, 8 Jan. Maggie is busy copying them. They are naturally of the tenderest interest to me; very beautiful, very mournful, and bring back into clearness of an almost preternatural sort the days that are for ever gone. Most of the letters are undated, indeed all of them, except some of those that have covers: but I can recollect nearly every event they touch upon, & by dint of strict search among the documents here, Maggie & I ought to get an accurate or approximate date for almost all of them.

Mrs Stirling shall soon have the letters back; in the meanwhile if she could recollect for us the dates of her several visits to London, of her first acquaintance with us (at Edinburgh in 1833?); at any rate, of her own marriage and removal from Dundee to Edinburgh,JWC apparently first met Susan Hunter (before her marriage) during the five months the Carlyles spent in Edinburgh, Jan.–May 1833; see 6:383–84JWC to SS, 6 May 1833. TC may have met her in London, Aug. 1831; see 5:331TC to JWC, 15 Aug. 1831, and 399TC to JWC, 4 Sep. 1831. She married, 1837, and moved to Dundee with her husband, James Stirling; they returned to Edinburgh 1846. —all this or any part of it will be an essential help in the process. Thank her very much for her kindness to me, now & always; assure her of my affectionate wishes, & best regards so long as I live.

The thin book sent herewith is a gift to me from Norton, & tells its own story. He did not put my name in it, in case I “might wish to give it away to any body”:Maria Francesca Rossetti, A Shadow of Dante, Being an Essay Towards Studying Himself, His World and His Pilgrimage (1871); its frontispiece was “Dante’s Portrait by Giotto, and his Death-Mask.” Norton wrote, 10 Jan.: “Here is a little Essay on the Portrait of Dante. The photographs it contains will interest you. I do not write your name in the volume, because you may like better to give it away than to keep it.” TC wrote on the back of Norton’s letter in blue pencil: “Norton (jany 1873) / Dante Portrts.” John replied, 17 Jan., that the book was interesting but he did not want to keep it: “I already have better photographs of Giotto’s Portrait & the Masks … together with fuller information about both.” to you, if you have it not already, it will doubtless be of interest, even more than it was to me; & if you care to have it, please consider it as yours,—subject to my possible but not very probable asking you for a loan of it. It seemed to me that the actual face of Dante might fairly be considered to be in all likelihood actually represented to us by that mask, coupled with that Giotto.

Mary has gone to Brighton with her new people, & seems to like them well; the only drawback seems to be she is much held to the side of Mrs Taylor, with perhaps little of importance to do; but perhaps this too will mend when they come to their place in London “about a week hence.”

For the last three nights I have been unlucky in my sleep, worst of all last night, when our inevitable Christmas dinner came off: the dinner itself with Norton for company was altogether wholesome & pleasant & harmless;Norton wrote about the dinner in his journal, 13 Jan.: “Dined with Forster—Carlyle, Miss Welsh … and Miss Hogarth, the only other guests. Forster much better than before his late stay at Torquay, but I fear he will never be well again. … Carlyle talked excellently of many things, and he and Forster are such old friends that it is pleasant to see them together” (Norton’s Letters 1:457). He saw TC again a few days later, recording in his journal, 17 Jan.: “He was in a most pleasant mood;—as I grow familiar with him … his character becomes more and more open and delightful. … He is one of the most sympathetic of men. ‘I’ve not had much sleep since I last saw ye. It’s an old complaint, and I’m wonted to it. That dinner at Forster’s gave the finishin’ stroke … I did not get to sleep till six o’ the clock next morning. And one’s troubled with all kinds o’ whirlin’ thoughts in the long nights; spectres and hobgoblins, that won’t be laid by any exorcisms, dance a wild reel through one’s head’” (1:458). but I had been ruined two days before, by dining on boiled mutton & eating a slobbery spoonful of boiled onion &c. (much against my will too)! Last night’s dinner brought all this to a crisis. Pity me as proprietor of certainly the worst
stomach in the world, amongst my other wonderful gifts! For the present again I hope the crisis is over. My idleness is nearly as complete as ever.—— You can return me Miss Bromley’s note of this morning, which is the only human bit of writing the Postman has brought me from my world-wide correspondence,—mainly with fools, or even people absolutely mad.

I should have told you long since that we are busy here building a tremendous “Embankment”The Chelsea Embankment, opened May 1874. of which one can see nothing (owing to a paling they have set up) except the infinite of mud & pother, & a towering Bridge, which was open at the rate of one halfpenny on New Year’s Day, but stands ever since amid its lofty wooden scaffoldings barricaded from the feet of the profane.Albert Bridge opened for a day on 1 Jan., but did not then reopen until Aug. 1873. For an illustration of the building of both the bridge and the embankment, as well as the paling that blocked the view of the Thames and the building works, Illustrated London News, 14 June, see 145.
Albert Bridge and Chelsea Embankment
Illustrated London News, 14 June 1873
God bless you dear Brother; I hope to be not so feckless next time I write.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 16 Jan. MS: NLS 527.82 inc. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Pray thank Mrs Stirling for her prompt & kind compliance with my request,John A. Carlyle wrote, 15 Jan., enclosing Susan Stirling’s replies to TC’s queries; see TC to JAC, 14 Jan.; Stirling’s letter untraced. For TC’s notes on JWC’s letter to Susan Hunter, [June or July? 1835], probably written at this time, see 8:160–61JWC to SS, [June or July? 1835]. & return to her this curious Hunt letter.James Henry Leigh Hunt (1784–1859; ODNB), writer, friend, and neighbor of the Carlyles, and a friend of Susan’s brother, John Hunter (1801–69; see 8:159JWC to SS, [June or July? 1835], and 61TC to MAC, [1 July 1835). Leigh Hunt and Susan Hunter had great affection for each other; see 8:161, and 224–25JWC to TC, [12 Oct. 1835]. John wrote, 17 Jan.: “Leigh Hunt’s letter of Jany 8th 1836 seems to give the approximate date of one of her visits to London.” Several of her dates will be of use here, & we will carefully employ them;—you need not add that the early part of her Chronology is considerably at fault, & that we will have our eyes open to every thing that is questionable.John wrote, 17 Jan.: “Queen Victoria’s Coronation, for which you gave a ticket ever memorable to her, took place 28th June 1838 & fixes the date of a second visit & of what she saw by your kindness”; see 10:114TC to JCA, 6 July 1838. She anti-dates, by at least five years, her first acquaintance with us as a pair of persons; I did not even know Jeffrey
till 1827;Francis Jeffrey (1773–1850; ODNB), writer and judge; for TC’s first meeting with him, Feb. 1827, see 4:190TCJWC to MAC, 17 Feb. 1827, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 359. He m. Catherine, b. Wilson (d. 1805), Susan Hunter’s aunt. & did not know Sir J. Richardson at all till 1845 or 6.Sir John Richardson (1787–1865; ODNB; see 16:131TC to JCA, 19 April 1843), physician, naturalist, and Arctic explorer, whom TC met Nov. 1845; see 20:64JWC to AB, 26 Nov. 1845. No wonder Mrs S.’s memory, like that of others of us, is grown dim about extraneous little matters! I brightly remember the Dundee Steamer, for I was the unconscious spectrum in her perspective;TC visited Thomas Erskine at Linlathen, 11–13 Sept. 1843, and traveled back to London by steamer from Dundee; he called on the Stirlings before the boat left, but “found them out.” He later heard that the “good Susan … had, from her windows, with a prospect-glass, singled me out on the chaotic deck of the Steamer abt to leave; and kept me steadily in view for abt an hour” (17:116). if I can make that empty letter-cover fit, & tell me what the year really was, it will be a welcome thing to me.— My first visit to Linlathen, & my last sight of John Jeffrey, who met me in the rapid vehicle I was driving down in, but who passed without recognizing me.While driving from Linlathen to the steamer, TC “distinctly recognised, on the Pathway, John Jeffrey … quiet amiable man, with his face (whh was towards me, but intent on the constitutional walk only) grown strangely red since I had seen him. … He died soon after; my last sight of him this” (17:116). John Jeffrey (1775–1848), Francis Jeffrey’s brother, m. to Elizabeth Helen, b. Hunter (b. 1798), Susan Stirling’s sister.

The Canada letter I do now return: in my dim state I had forgotten that you wanted it back, or expected any help of counsel from me, as to what could be done or tried for James out there.John A. Carlyle wrote, 8 Jan., enclosing a letter from their nephew James Carlyle in Canada: “Farming at present is rather a poor occupation in most parts of Canada, but what better occupation can one suggest for James? Please send the letter back as soon as convenient, & I will answer it, & do whatever is best to help James.” He wrote, 15 Jan.: “I asked you to return James’s letter which spoke of his application for a situation at Hamilton where Mary Hanning’s husband is, & I wanted to know what you thought would be possible in trying to help him.” I think I had already said, that in whatever thing you could do for him, I would cheerfully go halves. Farming seems to be what he most affects: you might ask cautiously whether he could find no location of that sort near his Father’s place; & signify that in such case we two would be willing to help if it seemed wise. I hear of some place beyond Montreal where great work in carpentering, & subduing wild fertilities of soil, &c.In a report in the Northern Whig, 9 July 1872, the Commissioner of Immigration for Quebec summarized the results of a recent survey of farm land by the province: “Having divided into farm lots 6,400,000 acres of land, [the provincial government] next caused the greater part of the territory to be traversed by great colonisation; founded colonisation societies … laid the basis of a wooden railway scheme … gave two millions of acres to build a large arterial line of railway … spends thousands and thousands of dollars on education; so that our system is unrivalled in point of excellence.” is going on of late years; but that I suppose is far away from his kindred, & would probably suit much less. You must just exercise your own best judgment, dear Brother; & understand that in whatever help, or cautions delay of help, you may decide upon, I will stand good. Perhaps there may be some occupation, like a general apprenticeship to business in Hamilton itself, which might do the worthy
(incomplete)

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JF, 30 Jan. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd. Written in TC’s hand in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Dear Forster,—I am grieved to the heart to hear that you are so ill: Patience, Courage!—and oh why shd you bother yrself with me in such a situatn of affairs?—

With the “since” instead of “if,” the Enclosed will be a dear & welcome thing.Forster had been helping TC with the drafting of his will; see TC’s 1873 Will, 6 Feb. TC originally indicated that he wished to be buried next to JWC in St. Mary’s Church, Haddington, “if” that were possible; apparently, through inquiries made by John A. Carlyle, he learned that it was not possible, so substituted “since” for “if.” He enclosed the paragraph written in another hand on a separate piece of paper: “—and it is my express instructions that, if I cannot be laid in the Grave at Haddington, I shall be placed beside or between my Father and Mother in the Churchyard of Ecclefechan” (MS: FC).
Maggie is in hot search of the “Copy,” but rather dubious of finding it. But Mary is certainly coming home on Saty or else of monday; & we shall then, or sooner, beat the bottom of that.

There was another thing I grudged abt yesterday, but cd not clearly see it till I was gone from yr door. It was that my Brr John & You shd be Executors,—Fa[i]ling both, of whom (whh, I think, can only be by death), but only failing both,—James my youngest Brr and J. A. Froude (to whom I have not yet spoken, but will directly)

Item, abt the “Copyrights, “—were it not well to mention the stereope Boxes in Robson’s hand?Charles Robson’s involvement in bankruptcy proceedings, July 1870, raised concerns about TC’s stereotype plates, which were kept by Robson; Forster had reassured him that they were safe; see 47:48TC to FC, 31 July 1870, and 53TC to JF, 26 Aug. 1870. — And especially I must not forget to examine what clear Doct I have here (you with me, when well agn) that they are mine!—
On the whole, Dear F., I will call on you tomorrow (I hope) soon after 4; & had better perhaps take that Paper home with me for a deliberate perusal here, in the silence of the night.
God bless you, dear Forster;—I never can forget what you are now doing for me & have before this done!

postscript.p: (Yr Messenger detained till 1.20 p.m.)

bibl.sourceNote: MA [MAI]-MW [MEW], 3 Feb. MS: NLS Acc. 9207. Hitherto unpbd.
bibl.head: MARY AITKEN TO META WELLMER

docBody.p: Pray excuse me for not answering your Letter sooner; but as the question in it was for my Uncle, not for me, I could not answer it till I had seen my Uncle; I saw him last week and showed him your Letter (which I had received down here). He said he himself was very fond of animals—and was always kind to them when they came in his way. But he would not care to write anything on the subject—for he thinks they have a position in this world in many cases superior to that of human beings. He is sorry you have taken to vegetarianismMeta Wellmer wrote in her birthday letter to TC, 2 Dec. 1872 (see MA to MW, 14 Dec. 1872): “[I]n these last years I would like to write for like-minded persons a few articles on vegetarianism and animal welfare organisations, subjects that lie very close to my heart” (editor’s trans.). She was later to publish The Vegetarian Way of Life and the Vegetarians (Berlin, 1889). for he thinks it must of necessity hurt your health—he says that he himself would feel like the horse which his master had taught to live on a pile of corn a day—but just when the horse had completely learned to live on this it died! I can not argue on the subject myself for I have not thought of it much—when one thinks of the slaughtering of the animals for the use of man it is very disgusting; and yet it is clear that we cannot live without animal food—at least from my own experience I should say it was a complete impossibility for a race of sturdy men and women to be reared on vegetables alone. I knew a family of children who had been so brought up—they having a slight tendency to consumption—and they died off one by one before they got to the age of 5 and 20. You will say that might have happened in any case; but my Uncle who is a physician said there was not the smallest doubt that they died from the want of animal food—that their frames were so weak they cd stand no stress at all. But perhaps you think we ought to run the risk for the sake of the Animals’ Lives. Death is appointed to every one; and if a bullock meets its death a little sooner than it would naturally do—it escapes the tortures of old age—and does not suffer more but rather less.
My Uncle is pretty well at present—he said I was to send all sorts of kind messages to you and to say that he would have liked to comply with your request it he had been able.
With best regards, dear Miss Wellmer, and the hope that I may hear from you again before very long.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 5 Feb. MS: NLS 527:83. Quot: A. Carlyle, NL 2:295–96 inc. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Long ago I well meant to have written to you, but this last week has been of such bitterly bad weather, that I have fallen (being bothered on the score of sleep too) into a marked increase of languour, dis-spiritment, & in fact for very laziness have been incapable of doing anything at all, but sit & passively read,—or perhaps speak to any talking one that came. On Sunday last, after a week of fierce cold, we had a night & day of tumbling & tumultuous snow; so that I did not go out at all till late in the afternoon; & strenuously, in Jean’s stocking-shoes,Possibly the buckskin shoes Jean sent him Oct. 1871; see TC to JCA, 1 Nov. 1871. not without difficulty make out a bit of walking along the solitary streets. London even seems quite taken aback; I met only two cabs, & never in my life saw London so solitary, silent, & deserted: everybody seemed to have a look of surprize, & tremulous quasi heroism; for the snow was still driving about, & had heaped itself at all convenient places into a kind of wreaths, surprizing & terrible to the Cockney mind. We have now for the last three days got veritable thaw; streets again, or at least pavements, swept clear, & hopes risen among us that we shall have no more of such adventuress for this year.

Except, this morning, looking over the first half of the poor Schiller Revise, which was almost as good as altogether correct, I have done nothing this day either; but do feel a little more equal for any poor vestige of work, should such turn up. The Schiller Revise has still the latter half of it (two sheets & a half) in Robson’s hands; on the days after tomorrow I can hope to discharge it also with equal ease, & so wash my hands of that poor little enterprise for ever & a day. It has turned out, after all the confusion poor Mary & I had with it, a much better thing than I expected; & will do very well as an adjunct to Schiller.For the republication of TC’s Life of Schiller, see TC to AC, 7 Jan; for TC’s “Supplement of 1872,” his trans. of Ernst Julius Saupe, Schiller und sein väterliches Haus, see TC to Lady A, 9 Sept. 1872. I keep a spare copy of the Revise, privately intended for poor Mary: this I will send to Jean, who can forward it to Mary after a reading for herself.— Mary called yesterday in person, looking fresh & hopeful, considerably cheerfuller than the former time; they have a grand Reception,The Taylors, at their home at Aubrey House. en frac [in frock coat], this night, to which also JohnJohn Aitken. was invited, but won’t go till
next Reception. After Parliament opens tomorrow TaylordomParliament opened Thurs. 6 Feb.; Peter Taylor was the M.P. for Leicester. goes back to Brighton, but returns “for good” in a week after. Mary is to dine with us on the Sunday following.

Poor F[orster is]Words cut away with signature on the other side of the sheet. still in great distress; not dangerously ill (thinks Quain)Dr. Richard Quain, who was attending Forster; see TC to JF, 22 Nov. 1872. but really in a bad fit, he admits,—incessantly coughing & with very little sleep. Latterly there is some appearance that Quain is right in calling the disorder gout; & there is even now some appearance of actual gout unfolding itself in the right foot;—which would evidently be the best symptom of all. During the whole of this misery Forster has been strenuously busy for me, upon a matterTC’s Will; see TC’s 1873 Will, 6 Feb. which you will much approve when I tell you of it on our first meeting again, which I love to hope may not be far distant.

By every symptom you perceive clearly that I really have nothing to say, dear Brother; add to which the fact, that Henry CowperHenry Frederick Cowper; see TC to Lady A, 13 July. has come in, & is waiting down-stairs; I therefore honestly close, & will say adieu with my blessing to one & all of you.

bibl.sourceNote: TC’s 1873 Will [WILL], 6 Feb. Pbd: J. A. Froude, My Relations 71–77. Much of this 1873 Will was already present in TC’s earlier 1871 Will (see TC to WILL, 11 April 1871), but, for clarity, it is reprinted here in full. We have followed without correction the inconsistent punctuation used in the Will in My Relations.
bibl.head: TC TO WILL AND CODICIL

p.note: TC’s codicil, dated 8 Nov. 1878 (My Relations 77–80), will be included at that date, vol. 50.

docBody.p:
I Thomas Carlyle of 5 Great Cheyne Row Chelsea in the County of Middlesex Esquire declare this to be my last Will and Testament Revoking all former Wills.TC’s most recent will was 6 April 1871. I direct all my just debts funeral and testamentary expences to be paid as soon as may be after my decease And it is my express instruction that since I cannot be laid in the Grave at HaddingtonJWC was buried next to her father, John Welsh, in the Abbey Kirk, Haddington; see 43:216TC to WDO, 22 April 1866, and 250Haddington Courier’s Description, 27 April 1866; see also 43:236TC to WDO, 21 June 1866; 240, and 241TC to JCA, 23 June 1866; and TC to JF, 30 Jan. I shall be placed beside
my Father and Mother in the Churchyard at EcclefechanFor the Carlyle family gravestone, that included the names of TC’s father, James Carlyle, and mother, Margaret A. Carlyle, see 35:229TC to AC, 7 Oct. 1859. I appoint my Brother John Aitken Carlyle Doctor of Medicine and my Friend John Forster of Palace Gate House Kensington Esquire Executors and Trustees of this my Will If my said Brother should die in my lifetime I appoint my Brother James Carlyle to be an Executor and Trustee in his stead and if the said John Forster should die in my lifetime I appoint my friend James Anthony Froude to be an Executor and Trustee in his stead I give to my dear and ever helpful Brother John. A. Carlyle my Leasehold messuage in Great Cheyne Row in which I reside subject to the rent and covenants under which I hold the same and all such of my Furniture plate linen, china, books prints pictures and other effects therein as are not hereinafter bequeathed specifically. My Brother John has no need of my money or help, and therefore in addition to this small remembrance I bequeath to him only the charge of being Executor of my Will and of seeing everything peaceably fulfilled. If he survives me, as is natural, he will not refuse My poor and indeed almost pathetic collection of books (with the exception of those hereinafter specifically given) I request him to accept as a memento of me while he stays behind I give my Watch to my Nephew Thomas the son of my Brother Alexander, “Alick’s Tom”For an 1870 photograph of “Alick’s Tom,” see 42:223TC to JAC, 14 Sep. 1865. as a Memorial of the affection I have for him and of my thankful (and also hopeful) approval of all that I have ever got to know or surmise about him He can understand that of all my outward possessions this Watch is become the dearest to me. It was given me on my Wedding by one who was herself invaluable to me;JWC; for the watch, see Carlyle, Reminiscences 87. It had been her Father’s. made to her Father’s order; and had measured out into still more perfect punctuality his noble years of well-spent time; and now it has measured out (always punctually, it) nearly forty-seven years of mine,JBW and TC m. 17 Oct. 1826; see 4:150–52TC to JBW, [9 Oct. 1826]. and still measures, as with an everloving solemnity, till time quite end with me: and may the new Thomas Carlyle fare not worse with it than his two predecessors have done. To Maggie Welsh my dear Cousin (and Hers) One hundred pounds. To my House servant Mrs. Warren if in my service at the time of my decease Fifty pounds. Having with good reason, ever since my first appearance in Literature, a variety of kind feelings obligations and regards towards New England, and indeed long before that a hearty good will, real and steady, which still continues, to America at large, and recognizing with gratitude how much of friendliness, of actual credible human love, I have had from that Country, and what immensities of worth and capability I believe and partly know to be lodged, especially
in the silent classes there, I have now after due consultationTC mainly consulted with Charles Eliot Norton and Ralph Waldo Emerson; for these consultations and the arrangements for the bequest of his Cromwell and Frederick books to Harvard College, see vol. 46 and 47. as to the feasibilities, the excusabilities of it, decided to fulfil a fond notion that has been hovering in my mind these many years; and I do therefore hereby bequeath the books, (whatever of them I could not borrow, but had to buy and gather, that is, in general whatever of them are still here) which I used in writing on Cromwell and Friedrich and which shall be accurately searched for, and parted from my other books, to the PresidentCharles William Eliot (1834–1926), president of Harvard; see 47:72TC to JTY, 28 Sep. 1870. and Fellows of Harvard College, City of Cambridge, State of Massachusetts, as a poor testimony of my respect for that alma mater of so many of my Trans-Atlantic friends, and a token of the feelings above indicated towards the Great Country of which Harvard is the Chief School, In which sense I have reason to be confident that the Harvard authorities will please to accept this my little bequest and deal with it, and order and use it, as to their own good judgment and kind fidelity shall seem fittest. A certain symbolical value the bequest may have, but of intrinsic value as a collection of old books it can pretend to very little. If there should be doubt as to any books coming within the category of this bequest my dear Brother John if left behind me, as I always trust and hope who already knows about this Harvard matter and who possesses a Catalogue and List drawn up by me of which the Counterpart is in possession of the Harvard Authorities, will see it for me in all points accurately done. In regard to this and to all else in these final directions of mine I wish him to be regarded as my Second Self, my Surviving Self. My manuscript entitled “Letters and Memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle” is to me naturally, in my now bereaved state, of endless value, though of what value to others I cannot in the least clearly judge; and indeed for the last four years am imperatively forbidden to write farther on it, or even to look farther into it.Most of TC’s work on JWC’s letters was complete by Sept. 1869; see 46:80TC to LA, 1 Oct. 1869. Of that manuscript my kind considerate and ever faithful friend James Anthony Froude (as he has lovingly promised me) takes precious charge in my stead. To him therefore I give it with whatever other fartherances and elucidations may be possible, and I solemnly request of him to do his best and wisest in the matter, as I feel assured he will. There is incidentally a quantity of Autobiographic Record in my notes to this Manuscript; but except as subsidiary and elucidative of the text I put no value on such. Express biography of me I had really rather that there be none. James Anthony Froude John Forster and my Brother John, will make earnest survey of the Manuscript and its subsidiaries there or elsewhere, in respect to this as well as to its other bearings; their united utmost candour and
impartiality. taking always James Anthony Froude’s practicality along with it. will evidently furnish a better judgment than mine can be. The Manuscript is by no means ready for publication; nay the questions How, when (after what delay, seven ten years) it, or any portion of it, should be published, are still dark to me; but on all such points James Anthony Froude’s practical summing up and decision is to be taken as mine.TC’s bequest relating to JWC’s “Letters and Memorials” was essentially the same in his 1871 Will; see 47:183–84TC to WILL, 11 April 1871. The imperfect Copy of the said Manuscript which is among my papers with the original letters I give to my Niece Mary Carlyle Aitken, to whom also dear little soul I bequeath Five hundred pounds for the loving care and unwearied patience and helpfulness she has shown to me in these my last solitary and infirm years. To her also I give at her choice, whatever Memorials of my Dear Departed One she has seen me silently preserving here, especially the table in the Drawing-Room at which I now write and the little Child’s Chair (in the China Closet) which latter to my eyes has always a brightness as of Time’s Morning and a sadness as of Death and Eternity when I look on it;For TC’s writing table and JWC’s child’s chair, see 47:184–85TC to WILL, 11 April 1871. and which, with the other dear Article, I have the weak wish to preserve in loving hands yet awhile when I am gone. My other Manuscripts I leave to my Brother John. They are with one exception of no moment to me. I have never seen any of them since they were written. One of them is a set of fragments about James First which were loyally fished out for me from much other Cromwellian rubbish, and doubtless carefully copied more than twenty years ago by the late John Chorley who was always so good to me.For John Rutter Chorley’s copying of material on James VI and I (1566–1625; ODNB), king of Scotland, England, and Ireland, see 47:184TC to WILL, 11 April 1871. But neither this latter nor perhaps any of the others is worth printing. On this point however my Brother can take Counsel with John Forster and James Anthony Froude and do what is then judged fittest. Many or most of these papers I often feel that I myself should burn; but probably I never shall after all. The “one exception” spoken of above is a sketch of my Father and his life hastily thrown off in the nights between his death and burial,See Carlyle, Reminiscences 4–39; for James Carlyle’s death, see 6:102–8TC to MAC, 24 Jan. 1832, and TC to JAC, 24 Jan. 1832. full of earnest affection and veracity, most likely unfit for printing; but I wish it to be taken charge of by my Brother John and preserved in the Family. Since, I think, the very night of my Father’s Funeral (far away from London and me) I have never seen a word of that poor bit of writing. In regard to all business matters about my Books (of which not only the Copyrights but all the Stereotype plates from which the three several collected EditionsUniform edition, 1857–58, cheap edition (vols. 1–16 used plates from the uniform), 1864, 1869, library edition, 1869–71, and people’s edition, 1871–74; see Tarr 447–51. have been respectively printed and which are at present deposited with my
Printers Messrs. Robson and Son belong exclusively to me)See TC to JF, 30 Jan. Copyrights, Editions, and dealings with Booksellers and others in relation thereto. John Forster’s advice is to be taken as supreme and complete, better than my own ever could have been. His faithful, wise, and ever punctual care about all that has been a miracle of generous helpfulness, literally invaluable to me in that field of things. Thanks, poor thanks, are all that I can return, alas! I give the residue of my personal estate to my Trustees before named, In trust to convert into money such part of my Estate as shall not consist of money or securities for money, and Upon trust to invest in such securities as they shall think fit the moneys to arise from such conversion and the moneys and securities of which my personal Estate shall consist at the time of my decease: With power to change investments from time to time And to stand possessed thereof In trust as to one-fifth part thereof to my Brother Alexander absolutely And as to one-fifth part In trust for my Brother James absolutely And as to one other fifth part thereof In trust for my Sister Mary Wife of James Austin, farmer at Gill Cummertrees, Dumfriesshire absolutely for her separate use independent of the debts control or engagements of her present or any future Husband And as to one other fifth part thereof In trust to my Sister, Jean, the Wife of James Aitken of Dumfries absolutely for her separate use independent of any debts control or engagements of her present or any future husband And as to the remaining fifth part thereof In trust for my Sister Janet, Wife of Robert Hanning of Hamilton Canada, absolutely, for her separate use independent of the debts control or engagements of her present or any future husband. Provided always that if my said Brothers Alexander and James or my said Sisters or any or either of them shall die in my lifetime, the share or shares of him her or them so dying shall be In trust for the Children of my Brothers or Sisters respectively so dying who shall attain the age of Twenty-one years or being Daughters shall marry in equal shares but if there shall be no such Child then such share or shares shall go to the others or other of my said Brothers and Sisters in equal shares but so that the shares which may thus accrue to my Sisters shall be for their separate use in the same manner as their original shares. I direct all legacies to be paid free of duty I direct that notwithstanding the trust for conversion hereinbefore contained my Trustees shall have absolute authority to postpone the conversion for any period not exceeding two years after my death of all or any part of my personal estate and I say this with especial reference to my Copyrights. And the income to be derived from my Estate previous to its conversion shall be applied in the same way as the income of my estate if converted would be applicable To my dear friends John Forster and James Anthony Froude (MassonDavid Masson. too I should remember
in this moment and perhaps some others) I have nothing to leave that could be in the least worthy of them but if they, or any of them, could find among my reliques a Memorial they would like, who of Men could deserve it better. No Man at this time. If no such choice be made by themselves I leave to Forster Faithornes Print of Cromwell between the Pillars, now in the Drawing Room here,William Faithorne (ca. 1620–91); his engraving, “The Embleme of Englands distractions as also of her attained, and further expected Freedome, & Happines” (1658), was commonly known as “Cromwell between the Two Pillars.” Carlyle’s House lists it as in the drawing-room, on the east wall, and names it “Cromwell trampling on the Scarlet Woman” (105); see oppabove. and to Froude Pesne’s Portrait of Wilhelmina with the
Fontange on her brow, now in the same Room.Antoine Pesne (1683–1757), portrait painter at the Prussian court, painted many pictures of Frederick’s sister Friederike Sophie Wilhelmine (1709–58), including “The Little Drummer”; see 41:88–89JWC to LA, [2 Nov. 1864]. Carlyle’s House lists “Wilhelmina (oil painting, with fontange on brow)” as in the drawing-room, on the east wall (105); this was probably a copy of the portrait, “Frederike Sophie Wilhelmine, Margravine of Baireuth,” used by TC as frontis. to Frederick 5 (see Carlyle, Works 16: frontis.), in which she is wearing the simpler version of the fontange (a cap that was also used as a base to hold a high structured headdress, also known as a fontange); see above. In witness whereof I the said Thomas Carlyle the Testator have to this my last Will and Testament set my hand this sixth day of February One thousand eight hundred and seventy-three.
William Faithorne, “Cromwell between the Two Pillars” (1658)

bibl.sourceNote: TC-WBP, 7 Feb. Pbd: Wilson, Carlyle 6:282–83 inc. William Black Pullar (1844–1919), lived at 77 Queen St., Glasgow, with his wife, m. ca. 1867, Eliza, b. Frost (d. 1930), and three children. They later moved to Coniston, Bridge of Allan, where he worked in the family firm, Robert Pullar & Sons, dyers.
bibl.head: TC TO WILLIAM BLACK PULLAR

docBody.p:
