I grieve much to find you so entangled, sunk over head and ears in the black and disgusting outburst of Atheism and Spiritual Confusion which has lately come upon us,Pullar wrote, 3 Feb., a long and anguished letter: “Being much troubled and perplexed with many things … I have at last made up my mind … to lay before you one or two of my difficulties, not knowing where else to turn or whom else to trust. You occupy to my mind such a pre-eminent position for experience, for truthfulness, for sympathy.” He had been: “Evangelical at 15, a doubter at 16, a raring infidel of the Shelley stamp … at 18, a Kantean … at 21, a general jumble of Tennyson, George McDonald, exact science … Darwin &c [at 23].” George MacDonald (1824–1905), Scottish poet and novelist; see 38:139–40TC to JWC, [14 Aug. 1862, and 145TC to JWC, 17 [16] Aug. 1862. But now as “a Father of three … [he] finds that while he managed to get along tolerably well with more or less unrest of mind while he was alone … he cannot … remain in this state of passivity, but it is demanded of him to teach his children some positive good”; this led to “terrible bewilderment of his own mind … daily more painfully evident.” and seems to be carrying our afflicted generation into depths
of the “Blackness of Darkness”Cf. Jude 1:13. it never knew before. I compare this ugly Spiritual upburst to the Physical one of Solway Moss (in 1783),In Dec. 1771, after the heaviest downpour of rain in 200 years, Solway Moss, a lowland peat bog in Cumbria, burst and overflowed, drowning some 400 acres of surrounding farmland with mud. See “Irruption of Solway Moss,” Philosophical Transactions (Jan. 1772) 62:123–27. —both of them proceeded out of what we may call Dropsy: Solway Moss had long been dropsical, from the partial stoppage of a little brook; our generation has been growing so, ever since the times of Oliver Cromwell, by the stoppage of all real Reform, and the introduction of the “Putty and Varnish”Phrase popularized in the 1860s by U.S. humorist Josh Billings, pseudonym of Henry Wheeler Shaw (1818–85); see also Carlyle, Works 16:391. kind instead (in a word by continual hypocrisy and unveracity persisted in so long); and now it rolls and rushes in this proud manner; covering the green earth and face of Nature with liquid Peat, and miscellaneous and unfathomable slobber, such as the World never saw before!

I deliberately advise you to quit all that, and rigorously lock it away from you in silence till your own mind at least re-acquire its clearness, and can serenely look into what is written in yourself; and read, as all true men in all ages have been able to do, what the finger of the Most High has written there. You may depend on it these long-eared Sages of “Science” very “falsely so-called,”—as men without reverence or piety of mindSee TC to UC, 23 June 1872. —have not any word to say on this subject; and that every faithful and humble man possessing those first qualities of manhood has a word, and for himself a conclusive word, to say upon it. Lock them all away I seriously advise you, and try by all good methods (especially by more and more faithful performance of every Duty that is already clear to you) to get hold again of “that Light, which lighteneth every Man that cometh into the World.”Cf. John 1:9. One of your first discoveries and conclusions I think will be, that no Entity could have gifted you with longings towards nobleness; with love and pious feeling and the infinite sense of Right and Wrong, unless He had himself such qualities to give away!

Logic, I believe, will do nothing farther for you;—but thus far all blow-pipes, crucibles, mineralogical hammers, Origin of Species, Descents of Man,Publications of Charles Darwin; see TC to UC, 23 June 1872. etc. etc. will never, and can never bring you.

For the rest I would advise you (so far as my light goes) to give up the Spiritual training of your children to their dear and loving Mother, who will teach them everlasting Truths,—precious and everlasting, though clouded over in their vesture at present, far beyond what long-eared Owls-of-Minerva,TC often uses the epithet “long-eared” to mean an ass; Minerva, the Roman goddess of wisdom, was usually accompanied by an owl; TC meant that however clever the scientific thinkers were, in face of God they were as stupid as an ass. with their Blow-pipes and scientific gear, have the least notion of, or are ever likely to have.

Your dear children, if they question you on such subjects, you can for the present study to answer evasively, though with cautious admission of whatever soul of truth may be in their bits of beliefs,—which will be more and more possible for you the farther you yourself advance in real Truth: speak to them at all times with perfect veracity, and above all things study to awaken in their minds the feelings of reverence, of pious awe, and of the infinite, eternal difference between right and wrong; which is the corner stone and foundation of all real knowledge and intelligence, as of all other worth in Man.

And withal, know in general that for yourself too there is no other road towards Light and Peace, but ever more perfectly Doing what is commanded you, what your hand findeth to do. “Doubt of any kind,” says the wisest man of these latter ages most truly, “is of Infinite nature and cannot be removed, except by action.”Goethe, Wilhelm Meister, book 5 chap. 16; see Carlyle, Works 23:386. Pullar thanked TC, 9 Feb., continuing: “I am at present at the footstool of John Ruskin … and seem to feel he is a safe guide.” He wrote to Ruskin, who replied, 18 Feb.: “I am deeply interested by your letter, and heartily glad of it—thankful above all for the change in your religious feelings, and for your being able to see what Carlyle means, and how one may live in peace and honour in spite of science” (Ruskin’s Works 37:62).

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 11 Feb. MS: NLS Acc.11388. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature. MS accompanied by an envelope, with in unknown hand: “Lady Ashburton / with Mr Emerson’s / sincere thanks.” Emerson was in Rome ca. 26 Feb.–10 March; probably Lady Ashburton loaned to him the letter which he returned in this envelope.
bibl.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
I ought to have written to you twenty days ago; & indeed have been helplessly thinking to do so more than ten times in the course of these, but was held back daily by the usual trifling interruptions & bothers; & chiefly by the
feckless, poor and pining condition into which this dismal Winter, & its unexampled course of weather, had reduced my own poor self. I know well you will understand, & forgive all this. Your letter delivered me from a world of anxiety, & I should, in spite of hindrances, have answered sooner,—& will, as usual, hope to do better another time.

This winter has been unusually hard upon me: ten weeks of incessant rain, dark incessant mud-bath, terrestrial & aerial; no weak person could endure it without damage, & I do feel weaker, blinder too, & more entirely useless for the time being, than I almost ever used to be. We have now, for a three weeks, got into paltry, uncertain frosts, with snows, & their slushes, & their slippery streets intervening,—to me more unpleasant than even the mud baths.The Globe reported, 11 Feb.: “In London last night there was another fall of snow, which was sufficient to cover the ground in many places to the depth of nearly half an inch. … The atmosphere this morning is intensely cold and the snowfall has not proved sufficient to interfere with the street traffic.” But at any rate the days are lengthening, the Sun must vindicate himself at last, & time & hours, as usual, will wear out the roughest day. I am often thankful when I think what you have been escaping by this forced banishment to warmer latitudes; you, to whom such a Winter might have been still more dangerous.

Yesterday I saw Miss Bromley here, who had found a letter of yours after her return from the Country;Either from one of Caroline Davenport Bromley’s country houses, Wootton Hall, Staffordshire, or Ripple Court, nr. Dover, Kent, or from a visit to friends. she was speaking very kindly of you; grieved that you had had another fit of heart;—I try to believe it was the same you spoke of to me, & not another? tell me that it was not.— During her three weeks of Country, Miss B. had met with the John StanleysCol. John Constantine and Susan Stanley; she was a niece of Lady Ashburton’s; see 47:225TC to JAF, 26 Sep. 1871. somewhere; & liked them both well. Since her departure yesterday, & my forced refusal to dine & meet them at her house some “evening,” she has sent another pressing note, to the effect, “Stanleys coming tomorrow night; are you absolutely impossible”? to which I have had again to answer “Absolutely.” Stanley is going in as a Tory Parliamentary candidate for Maidstone, & writes to me in great spirits about it.John Stanley came from a family of liberals, even radicals, so to stand as a Tory was surprising; the two Maidstone seats both went to the liberals in the 1874 election. A good kind of fellow; with an honest, & a brisk, light heart in him, this poor Colonel Johnny, to whom I wish heartily well! Miss Bromley notices that his wife, in the quietest way, has absolute command of him, & leads him like the tamest Behemoth, with a thorn in his snout,Cf. Job 40:15–24, and Carlyle, Works 18:153. —and invisible halter fixed there. I have seen them here some twice, & each time judged her completely equal to such a feat.

My own sole work, if work it could be called, since October last, has been that poor bit of Supplement to Schiller, which, had I possessed a right hand of my own, might have done in one week! however, I did yesterday complete the last Printers’ Proof, & take leave of it for evermore. It is not a bad thing after all, but rather a good,—presents the finest scene of Poverty ennobled (that worthy Schiller’s paternal house) that I have almost ever seen in Literature. It awakens all the old thoughts of fifty four years ago,TC had been reading Schiller since at least 1820; see 1:255TC to EI, 3 June 1820. & has kept up, all the time I was working over it, a kind of pious Worship in my mind, & thus been not without a certain benefit to me after all. It comes out in March; & I will please myself with keeping a copy of this poor Schiller volume for your Mary,Mary Florence Baring. to whose bright little soul I know this Supplement will be bright & instructive. My kindest love to that dear little lady,—& say, by the way, that she is not to be grown too big next time I see her.

Poor Forster is still labouring, coughing & suffering; confined to the house this last three weeks: Quain calls it undeveloped gout, and owns that this is a bad fit (got, I believe by the putting of Lord Lytton in his last bed in Westminster Abbey,—rather superflous operation).Edward Lytton Bulwer, Lord Lytton, close friend of Forster (see TC to JF, 2 Aug. 1872), d. 18 Jan., Argyll Hall, Torquay. The Times reported, 27 Jan.: “On Saturday [25 Jan.] afternoon Lord Lytton was buried in Westminster Abbey, the grave being dug in St. Edmund’s Chapel … a few yards beyond Poets’ Corner.” Forster was listed among the chief mourners. Quain, however, bates no jot of hope. Poor Forster to me, even during this bad misery, has been signally helpful & obliging; & would not, & could not be forbidden, for all I could say.

Froude, as you may guess, has been safe among us again for a four weeks past; reckons himself, & is reckoned by us all, to have been essentially victorious in America, in spite of the Irish noises; & indeed he has set forth, for the first time, the real & veritable history of Ireland versus England, (fully more to the disgrace of England than of Ireland, I should say); and no power of noises & nonsenses in Ireland or elsewhere can prevent its being acted on, some day coming. He, & James Stephen, home from India, with another Member of Council, one Strachey, whom I recollect long since as a beautiful little boy of five or six, youngest son of two valued ones, long since gone,Sir John Strachey, see TC to JAC, 30 Dec. 1872. —these are my chief walking companions at present; Allingham, your poor Friend, occasionally intervening, though seldomer than formerly.

Mary C.A. is still mainly at Brighton; takes handsomely, so far as I can see, to her new Secretariat, which seems to be a place of light work, among essentially worthy people, chiefly distinguished by punctuality,—as of clock-work, a conditon that will not fail to do the Secretary good! She was up here Thursday
last, seeing the Parliament open (more power to its elbow!) she is to dine here along with her Brother next Sunday—good little Soul, whom I have a true love for after all!
Adieu dear Lady. Here has the unwearied BaronetProbably Sir Baldwyn Leighton. come, & sits waiting below. God help me, & all of us in this wearyWord repeated at turn of page. world!
I ever am & remain

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lady T [TAT], 11 Feb. MS: Bodleian. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature. Theodosia Alice Taylor, b. Spring Rice (1818–91), m., 1839, Henry Taylor (1800–1886; ODNB), civil servant and poet, KCMG, 1869; old friend of TC; see TC to MAC, 10 Nov. 1831. Sir Henry Taylor was last mentioned when he called on TC, 13 May 1866, after JWC’s death, see 43:230TC to LA, 20 May 1866.
bibl.head: TC TO LADY TAYLOR

docBody.p: You are very kind to me, & always were. I wish much I durst venture out among you before Lent come;In 1873 Lent began Wed. 26 Feb.; presumably TC meant it as a generalization rather than a specific date. but, Alas, Alas, I am in so weak a way, bodily & spiritually, I must in prudence answer that I cannot. With many regards & regrets,

bibl.sourceNote: TC-UC, 16 Feb. MS: Berg. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p: It is not for want of sympathy that I have left your sad letter so long unanswered; but I have been much engaged, & in a weak way of health, little suited for work of any kind, & for writing, least of all.

I perceive with sorrow that you have got involved in that singular black deluge of Atheistic “Science falsely so-called,” which has suddenly broken
out of late years on our faithless, sinful generation; that it has drowned away from you your religious Faith, & that in this you justly feel bereft of everything that was vital & precious to you. In this unhappily you are not singular;See also TC to UC, 23 June 1872, and TC to WBP, 7 Feb. sincere inquiring minds, on all hands, are your brethren in this miserable calamity. My advice to you would be to push away from you all this miserable stuff, & to consult it no longer on such questions;—I can predict that one day you may come to see clearly that it, whatever self-conceited airs it give itself, is much mistaken in regard to such, & can never, with its visible irreverence & impiety, utter anything in regard to them that is not false, vain & delusive.

In regard to these highest Spiritual Questions, my own conviction & experience is that the Light is either written dimly in our own souls, & growing ever clearer by reverent meditation, & perhaps still more by faithful performance of whatever duty it commands us, or else is not to be found any where at all. The clear rule for you therefore is, Persist with your whole heart, in more & more perfectly discharging what you feel to be laid upon you; that will mean also the clearer & clearer development in your own mind of the Eternal Sense of Right & Wrong, which all wise men have taken, & will for ever take to be, the handwriting in us of the Most High.

By far the highest speculator among the thinkers of our generation, Kant, the German Philosopher has said: “Two things strike me dumb, the Starry Firmament above me, & the sense of Right & Wrong in Man.”TC used the quotation from Immanuel Kant in Shooting Niagara: And After? (1867), citing its German source, Kant, Sämmtliche Werke (Leipzig, 1838) 8:312; see Carlyle Works 30:29. For TC on Kant, see 45:46TC to JHS, 8 Oct. 1867. Another still to me far higher & grander Intellect has this maxim: “Speculative Doubt is by its nature endless,” speculation can only Change it into new forms, Action alone more & more faithfully prosecuted can abolish Doubt.”Goethe, Wilhelm Meister; see TC to WBP, 7 Feb. Remember also what Samuel Johnson said, “this is a World where much is to be done, & little is to be known.”Samuel Johnson (1709–84; ODNB), “Against Inquisitive and Perplexing Thoughts” (12 Aug. 1784), Prayers and Meditations (1785).

There is no specific book that I can recommend to you; it is serious & reverent Meditation of your own, rather than much reading of books that can bring Light & Wisdom to you; but there is one precept in regard to books that I will venture to give, or rather there are two, but the first of them you seem to be already fulfilling: these two precepts are, Diligently & steadily employ all your leisure in endeavouring to acquire true insight, by reading & otherwise; secondly, avoid reading unwise books; namely in whatever book you find the author is of an irreverent, mean & impious spirit, avoid reading farther in him, as you would avoid intercourse with the man himself, & expect only harm
from him; by this practice, faithfully followed, you will get to know more & more decisively good books from bad, & be able to avoid the latter more & more, & know them for Spiritual Poison.

Adieu my dear Sir, I can predict for you success & progress into spiritual clearness if you bravely persevere. Hope always, do not despair; this World, wild & waste as we find it, is still for all of us the Place of Hope.See Carlyle, Sartor 121.

closer.salute: Believe me, Yours with true good wishes

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 19 Feb. MS: NLS 527.84. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I return to you Mary Hanning’s letter, which is a snappy, gleg-like production, & interests one for the poor little being with her difficulties over yonder. I should be extremely willing to help in getting the poor souls a wholesome, dry house, if you see your way to a wise solution of that little problem.John A. Carlyle wrote, 17 Feb.: “Here is a rather good letter from Mary Holden, Jenny’s second daughter who has been so long unwell, as her husband too has been all along till this year when he has no Drs bill to pay, for the first time since their marriage. I feel a tendency to help them in getting a house of their own. Jenny herself seems to get much good of her house wh we bought for her. Can anything be done to help poor Mary to get one too in some equally wholesome place?” Mary and Charles Holden lost a da., Dec. 1870; see 47:156TC to JCHA, 13 Feb. 1871. For TC and John A. Carlyle’s help with money for their sister Jenny Hanning’s house, April 1869, see 46:38–39TC to JAC, 15 April 1869. think it would be good to have them first settle upon a bit of ground, wholesomely situated, & to have shaped out by them an exact estimate of what the cost would be, house included. They should not be encouraged to consider that gifts of that kind drop into one’s mouth by merely opening it;—in fact that is the one questionability of the matter to us; and that once guarded against (as no doubt you can completely do by a little study & precaution), I am willing and desirous to go halves with you in whatever you see good to do on that head.TC’s checkbook recorded: “12 April 1873 / (for Mary Henning’s House) to Dr Carlyle / £100 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). I hope also you have by no means given up poor Nephew James,James Carlyle, son of Alexander and Janet; see TC to JAC, 16 Jan. who seems to me a very honest, likely kind of person, with perhaps more good stuff in him than any of the Hanning kind.

We hope soon to hear what your deliberate report of Dr Russell is. I never knew till your last letter that he had been “lying five weeks in bed”: but before that the straggling lights I had got about his situation were an uncomfortable, questionable nature.For Dr. James Russell’s illness the previous year, see TC to JAC, 23 March 1872; John A. Carlyle wrote, 10 Feb.: “by want of caution the Dr had brought back something of the ulcers he had last year, & has now had a whole months illness in consequence.” John then wrote, 17 Feb., that he had heard from Mrs Russell, Sat. [15 Feb.]: “[Russell] had ventured out of bed that day, the first time for more than five weeks.” By 19 Feb., John had been to see Russell, who was “better than I had anticipated. He had got out of bed, had slept pretty well … & looked cheerful, though still very weak.” I hope you may be able form a clearer & more pleasant opinion; the advent of the Spring weather, which cannot now be distant, seems at any rate to form a hopeful feature in the business. But old men, alas, are a feeble kind of goods; & Russell has always been so steadily healthy up to this point. Give my kind regards to him, & to good Mrs Russell as well: the thought of Her, in case of any thing going wrong there, is very mournful to me; they are a pair of people I never can forget,—for reasons you well know.JWC often stayed with the Russells, who had looked after her during her illness, July–Sept. 1864; see 40:149JWC to TC, 25 July 1864, and 41:58JWC to MR, [3 Oct. 1864].

Mary dined here on Sunday night, looking quite brisk & hopeful; John took her off to the proper under-ground Station,Probably either Sloane Square or South Kensington (both opened 24 Dec. 1868), stations for the underground railway. while I lay dozing up here. Maggie I think proposes making a call on her this afternoon, with some letters that have arrived. Mary had not got proofsheets of Supplement to Schiller; but it is little matter; the book itself is, I understand, to be out very shortly. Sister Jean shall have the first copy I send away;Jean Aitken acknowledged, 23 Feb., TC’s letter and “The Schiller too with its affecte inscription.” TC also sent a copy to Mary Austin, which she acknowledged to John A. Carlyle, 26 Feb. (MS: NLS 1775E.211). tell her I was much gratified with the kind, sincere & affectionate bit of letter she sent me. I send her today a really ingenious, easy-going, amiable book by poor Allingham,Allingham pbd. Rambles (1873) under the pseudonym Patricius Walker, based on his article series pbd. over several years in Fraser’s Magazine (which continued after 1873). Jean wrote, 23 Feb.: “I cannot tell you how grateful I am for all yr mindfulness in sending me the two Bks. ‘P. Walker’ we have been reading diligently in the evenings & find it interesting.” which I hope she (& you too, if you have not already seen it) will find comfortable to read.——

Forster within the last four days is decidedly better; that is the best bit of news I have to send you. Duffy, in Australia, has been made a K.C.B (Forster tells me) & is coming homeCharles Gavan Duffy, see TC to CGD, 28 May 1872. Duffy had been prime minister of Victoria, but was defeated in a no-confidence vote in 1872; he apparently considered returning to Britain, as Forster wrote to him, 5 Sept. 1872, hoping that he would return to his friends, “noble and dear old Carlyle among them” (Charles Gavan Duffy, My Life in two Hemispheres [New York, 1898] 2:343). Duffy traveled in Britain and Europe, 1874–76, but did not finally leave Australia till 1880. “with the time of day in his pocket.”A. Carlyle added above the line: “a watch in his pocket, to wit.” I do not
quite feel sure of Duffy’s loyalty in spite of stroke of sword on shoulder-blade.The London Evening Standard wrote a critical editorial, 12 Feb.: “The British public have become accustomed to Mr. Gladstone’s peculiar mode of dispensing the honours of the Crown, to his propensity to view good offices rendered to himself and homage paid to his person and genius as public service, and especially to his system of governing Ireland by administering to the sentiment of Irish disaffection. On his own merits, it is impossible to perceive in Mr. Duffy a fit recipient for any mark of Royal favour. … In this country he is best known by his participation in the events of 1848, and in Ireland by his virulent invectives, both in prose and verse, against the English dominion. … No more virulent hater of British rule has ever appeared than the man who … narrowly escaped from a conviction for high treason.” Duffy had been a member of Young Ireland when he first met the Carlyles; he was arrested and tried for treason but not convicted, 1848–49; see 19:64–65TC to MAC, 28 April 1845.
We have dreadfully black weather these three days, no Sun, & indeed hardly any light— Paper is done I must say Adieu. Blessings to you all / Ever your affect Brother

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 26 Feb. MS: NLS 527.85. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
By all means accept that honour the Edinburgh Senatus have done you;John A. Carlyle replied, 27 Feb.: “I have told Masson that I mean to accept the unanimous offer of the Senatus to make me an L.L.D. as proposed by him.” John was awarded the honorary degree of LL.D at a graduation ceremonial in the Assembly Hall, Castle Hill, 23 April. Prof. Norman Macpherson (1825–1914), dean of the Faculty of Law, made the award: “I have next the honour to present … a graduate in medicine of this University, who bears worthily the name made so illustrious by one whom he will gladly allow me to call his greater brother—Carlyle … the historian, philosopher, and moralist, recently Rector of our University and perhaps her most eminent living alumnus. Dr John Carlyle … the friend … of most of the best literary and scientific men of the day, has long enjoyed among them a consideration which could only be acquired by one possessing high intellectual qualities. The range of his linguistic studies has been very extensive. I shall only specify his minute acquaintance with Icelandic scholarship, and his mastery of Italian, evidenced by his translation of the ‘Inferno’ of Dante, so often attempted, and achieved by Dr Carlyle with a success which makes the public much desire to have from him his rendering of Dante’s other works” (Scotsman, 24 April). of course you will accept: if it do anything it will do good to both you & them;
and at any rate it is sure to produce for the time-being an altogether honest & mutual glow of friendly feeling between you.

I inclose farther a “Dividend” paper, which came to me last night, meaning 5£ & certain shillings,Dividends from his shares in the Artizans, Labourers & General Dwellings Co.; see TC to JAC, 23 March 1872. but which it seemed to me ought to have been sent, as I suppose the last was, to Adamson,Samuel Adamson, of the British Linen Co. Bank, where TC had an account. for my behoof. Please step over to him with the two papers, one of which I have endorsed;—& pray do not leave him till you have assured yourself that he henceforth is to be the recipient of such things for me. If that cannot be secured I will sell out altogether rather than be bothered with such method farther! Verily & practically so: but I suppose you & he will have no difficulty about it.— I don’t understand either, the amount of Income Tax—Yes, oh yes! on looking at it again I do; it is about 15/ or 16/ for 100£. (not of income but of property?)John wrote: “I read the Report for last year, & thought the company was getting on well; but like you, could not understand by what ‘Income Tax deducted’ our Dividends of six per cent each could be reduced to £5 .. 4 .. 4. About that matter Adamson is to enquire. … The enclosed letter from Mr Martin of Birmingham, who got the Shares for us, asks us to take more shares, & I should be willing to take ten more, & ten for you too … provided that the Dividends can be paid in the usual way to our Bankers.” J. Royle Martin was the company’s manager. Along with Masson’s letter I inclose one from Forster, which you may keep, or give to Jean as a Memorial of the utterly extravagant man;John wrote: “Forster’s note looks extravagant at first sight, but one sees by it how he feels that all that is required & useful in Biography may be told completely & coherently in few words.” & along with these a quantity of tag rags which may amuse you for the moment, but are of no interest farther.

I write in the greatest haste, Miss Bromley sitting upstairs, waiting to take me to poor Norton’s, who has had a dangerous illness (inflammation of the lungs) which is not yet altogether void of danger as I hear, but which I never heard of till not many days ago. I am glad of this opportunity of at least leaving a card.Norton wrote, 26 Feb.: “I am very grateful to you for your kind inquiries concerning my health. I have had a slight attack of pneumonia, from which I am pretty well recovered. It has, however, pulled my strength, and I am likely to be a prisoner in my chamber for a week or ten days longer. … I have missed nothing so much as my walks with you. Your friendliness has given the winter a different character from what it otherwise would have had for me, and the memory of it will be a lasting possession. … I will not ask you to come and see me, for I am up three flights of stairs,—but I hope it will not be very long before I have the pleasure of going to see you.”
Adieu therefore, with my best blessings to you all

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Sir JW [JOWH], [late Feb.]. Pbd: County Express; Brierley Hill, Stourbridge, Kidderminster, and Dudley News, 31 Jan. 1874 inc; Edwin Paxton Hood, Thomas Carlyle, Philosophic Thinker, Theologian, Historian and Poet (1875) 358–60 inc; Glasgow Herald, 13 July 1901; Wilson, Carlyle 6:319–20 inc. Quot: John Morrow, Thomas Carlyle (London and New York, 2006) 117. Joseph Whitworth (1803–87; ODNB), mechanical engineer, machine tool manufacturer, and inventor. Both TC and JWC met and admired him, and toured his Manchester cotton mill, JWC in Aug. 1846 (see JWC to TC, 17 Aug. 1846, and JWC to TC, [23–24 Aug. 1846]), and TC in Sept. 1847 (see TC to JWC, 9 Sep. 1847). The letter is dated late Feb 1873 by Whitworth’s offer of contributions of interest on deposits, late Feb. (reported 20 Feb. 1873; see below); TC’s letter was then used as part of a speech at the annual prize-giving of the Stourbridge School of Art by Rev. William Henry Lyttelton (1820–84; ODNB), rector of Hagley, Worcestershire, 26 Jan. 1874, which led to its publication in many newspapers. Text: County Express. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 31 January 1867.]
bibl.head: TC TO SIR JOSEPH WHITWORTH

docBody.p:
My dear Sir— Last night I heard, through the newspapers, of your offer on behalf of the thrifty work-people of Darley,Whitworth moved to Darley Dale, Derbyshire, 1872; late Jan. 1873 he had offered to contribute: “for the next five years such a sum yearly as will give to the inhabitants of North Darley three per cent. more interest on their deposits in the savings bank, thus making the total interest six per cent on their savings. Such inhabitants must be the working classes, receiving wages [including] domestic servants and children at school. … If this proposal is found to work well in North Darley, he hopes to see it extended … to the whole county” (Manchester Evening News, 20 Feb.). and of the thankful acceptance of it by the district authorities of the place. I cannot resist the highly unwonted desire that has risen in me to say that I highly approve and applaud the ideas you have on the subject, and to declare in words that in my opinion nothing wiser, more beneficent, or worthy of your distinguished place as a master of workers has come before me for many a year. Would to heaven that all or many of the captains of industry in England had a soul in them such as yours, and could do as you have done, or could still further co-operate with you in works and plans to the like effect! The look of England is to me at this moment abundantly ominous; the question of capital and labour, growing every more anarchic—insoluble altogether by the notions hitherto applied to it—is pretty certain to issue in petroleum one day, unless some other Gospel than that of ‘Dismal Science’TC’s phrase, first used in “Occasional Discourse on the Negro Question” (Fraser’s Magazine [Dec. 1849]; renamed when reprinted as a pamphlet: “Occasional Discourse on the Nigger Question” [1853]); see Carlyle, Works 29:354. come to illuminate it. Two things are pretty sure to me; the
first is that capital and labour never can or will agree together, till they both first of all decide on doing their work faithfully throughout, and like men of conscience and honour, whose highest aim is to behave like faithful citizens of this universe, and obey the Eternal commandment of Almighty God who made them. The second thing is that a sadder object than even the ‘Coal strike,’ or any conceivable strike, is the fact that, loosely speaking, we may say all England has decided that the profitablest way is to do its work ill, slovenly, swiftly and mendaciously. What a contrast between now and, say, only a hundred years ago! At that latter date, or still more conspicuously for ages before that, all England awoke to its work with an invocation to the Eternal Maker to bless them in their day’s labour, and help them to do it well. Now, all England—shopkeepers, workmen, all manner of competing labourers—awaken, as if with an unspoken but heartfelt prayer to Beelzebub, “Oh, help us, thou great Lord of Shoddy and Adulteration and Malfeasance, to do our work with a maximum of slovenliness, swiftness, profit, and mendacity, for the Devil’s sake; amen!

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lord N [FN], 3 March. Pbd: A Selection from the Correspondence of Abraham Hayward, Q.C., ed. Henry E. Carlisle (1886) 2:250. Correspondent probably Francis Napier (1819–98; ODNB), 10th Lord Napier of Merchistoun and first Baron Ettrick, diplomat and administrator.
bibl.head: TC TO LORD NAPIER

docBody.p:
Will you present my homages and very kind remembrances to Mrs. Norton,Caroline Norton, b. Sheridan (1808–77; ODNB), author and law reform campaigner; see 8:354TC to JSM, [25 June 1836], and 31:33JWC to LOP, 16 Feb. 1856. She had requested that Lord Napier ask TC about an anecdote recently pbd. by Abraham Hayward in “The Pearls and Mock Pearls of History,” Biographical and Critical Essays, 2 vols. (1873) (first pbd. in the Quarterly Review, April 1861). For JWC on Norton, see 23:70JWC to HW, [16 July 1847]; for TC on her, see 28:272TC to JROS, 19 Sep. 1853. and say that there is not anywhere in nature the faintest vestige of evidence for that poor story about Friedrich and the officer writing to his mother,Hayward included an anecdote about an officer who was caught in camp by Frederick the Great finishing a letter to his wife after lights had been forbidden; the officer begged for mercy and Frederick replied, “Add a postscript. Before this reaches you, I shall be shot for disobedience of orders” (Biographical and Critical Essays 1:31). A review, Spectator, 22 Feb. 1873, criticized Hayward for exaggerating some of his anecdotes. Norton had earlier written a song based upon the anecdote called “King Frederick’s Camp.” &c.; and that I clearly believe it to be as perfect a fable as ever a spasmodic fool invented in his own idle brain or caught out of empty rumour, and was at the pains to write down in some vague anecdote book or sentimental tirade, and send floating into a foolish century! In no work historical, or in the least pretending
to be historical, did I ever find it mentioned or hinted at, as indeed it would have greatly surprised me to do; for the thing is not only untrue, but inconceivable and incredible; unworthy of a moment’s notice from anybody that has gained the faintest notion of Friedrich’s character and ways.Hayward wrote to Norton thanking her for her help: “Carlyle’s letter is a good specimen of his characteristic and shallow dogmatism. I never yet followed him to the authorities without finding him wrong” (Correspondence of Hayward 2:251).
With many regards, I remain,
Your Lordship’s most obedient servant,

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 7 March. MS: NLS 527.86. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: These four days I have been determined to write a word to you, but every day have been prevented; & today had determined to do it in spite of all the world,—which accordingly (just after your Scotsman, with the Article on GladstoneProbably the article in the Scotsman, 3 March, criticizing Gladstone’s Irish University Bill for being too ambitious: “Theoretically, the Government Bill is a measure having national objects in view. … It fails because it does too much. … On the one hand, we now have the Senate of Trinity College denouncing the measure because it will remove from them much of the power which they possess; on the other hand, we have the Roman Catholic prelates denouncing the measure because it does not give them at once all that they demand.” Gladstone’s plan was to construct a federal university in Ireland to which colleges could affiliate, specifically the Anglican Trinity College, Dublin, the secular Queen’s Colleges of Belfast and Cork, and the Catholic University in Dublin, with no religious requirements for students, scholarships, or professorships. It would be funded partly by the state and partly by Trinity College’s endowments. The govt. lost the vote on the 2d reading of the bill, 12 March, 284 to 287 votes, with 36 Irish Liberals voting against and only 15 Irish M.P.s voting in favor. has come to hand) I now proceed to do, with the necessary brevity.

There is in fact very little to be said of essential, no news whatever as to health or the like; & in regard to those Building shares, only necessary to say, that the explanation of the 6 per cent, & other points, is clear & complete; & that if you want to venture another £100 in the thing, or another £200, I am perfectly ready to go along with you.John A. Carlyle wrote, 2 March, with the explanation of the dividends sent him by the secretary of the Artizans, Labourers & General Dwellings Co.; see TC to JAC, 26 Feb. He continued: “I think [the company] … is in a fair way of accomplishing much more, & should be encouraged as far as possible.” But in fact you alone can judge in
the matter. They seem to be a restless, agitating kind of people, these Birminghamites (“secular Education,” Suffrage for the Labourers &c. &c.);——& perhaps their Building Concern will not strike very deep root either for the times coming. Though of course the houses will still be there.J. Royle Martin, TC’s original correspondent and company manager of the Artizans, Labourers & General Dwellings Co., lived in Birmingham, whose town council, mid-19th century, was dominated by radical liberal reformers who wanted to improve the lives of working men and women in every way: through housing, slum clearance, education, libraries, clean water provision, and public parks; many radical organizations sprang up, such as the Birmingham Education League which promoted free, non-denominational education for all. On the whole you alone can judge, & shall.

It is very true also what you say about money lying idle at 1 per cent Interest; when it might be invested & of some use.John wrote: “Both you & I have too much money in Bank at one per cent interest lying quite idle; & this year I should like to double the amount of my shares in the Company, which has so laudable & necessary an object in hand, if you would join me.” I, for my own part, never in the least want above £1000 lying in Adamson’s hands; & I dare say there are at present several thousands so lying,—though the fact is I do not know with the least accuracy, & you, I always reckon, do. If you care to inquire of Adamson,John replied, 10 March: “On receipt of your last letter I went to the British Linen Co to ascertain what was the balance in your favour there, & found it was … £5416 .. 16 .. 2. My advice would be to put the larger part of it on Deposit Receipt, say £4000 or £4400 … . I myself have Deposit receipts for nearly £4000, & last year it produced on an average 3½ per cent.” & decide on taking a couple of thousands to invest in some good stock (say your South Western Railway, your Caledonian ditto, or where you like best),For previous purchases of railway shares, see 47:196TC to JAC, 22 April 1871. John advised against railway shares: “Railway Shares have been very unsettled in price for some time past, Caledonian Ordinary Shares have varied more than 40 per cent. Glasgow & S. Western are very high just now, & may fall after certain amalgamations which are proposed.” it will be a real favour done me; & I could at once write the necessary Bank Precept for you. Enough of all that till you have time to answer.

The whole world is in a mighty fuff here about Gladstone & his Paddy Cardinal Bill, & the question, “what is to become of him”? in consequence of it.Gladstone’s Irish University Bill; it eventually led to his resignation and a general election which he lost, Jan. 1874. To myself, from the beginning, it seemed the consummation of contemptibilities, & paltry trickeries on his part; one of the most transparent bits of thimble-rigging to secure the support of his sixty Irish votes (the Pope’s Brass Band),Of the 103 Irish M.P.s elected in the 1868 general election, 66 were Liberals. They were by no means all Catholics. & to smuggle the Education Violin into the hands of CullenPaul Cullen (1803–78; ODNB), Roman Catholic archbishop of Dublin, opposed Gladstone’s bill, wanting government funding for a Catholic university, and persuaded many Irish Liberal M.P.s to vote against the bill. &
his sacred sons of Belial & the Scarlet Woman,TC had several times referred to politicians as sons of Belial; see 27:54TC to LA, 28 Feb. 1852, and 83TC to MAC, 10 April 1852. For the Scarlet Woman, see Rev. 17. I had ever seen, even from him before. And that seems fast becoming the opinion of all the World. At Forster’s, about ten days ago, the Attorney-General, one Coleridge, a most clean-starched, serene Coleridgeian gentleman,John Duke Coleridge (1820–94; ODNB), 1st Baron Coleridge, judge, attorney general of England and Wales 1871–73; the great-nephew of Samuel Taylor Coleridge (1772–1834; ODNB), poet, whom TC met in 1824; see 3:90–91TC to JAC, 24 June 1824, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 288–89. did me the honour to step down-stairs into Forster’s sick-room, with the sublime intention, “having the honour of being introduced &c. &c.” Introduction was hardly done, when Forster started upon him like a volcano, & very soon involved me too in the debate,—our unanimous conclusion being, that for the instruction of Ireland there was absolutely nothing requisite or possible, but to secure by Law the noble offer of Dublin University, by passing Fawcett’s Bill of last year.Henry Fawcett (1833–84; ODNB), economist and politician, Liberal M.P. for Brighton 1865–74, opposed Gladstone’s bill on the grounds that it perpetuated religiously segregated education; he argued that government funds should only be used to promote non-denominational education. He had introduced a Bill, May 1872, to abolish any tests at Trinity College that restricted professorships, fellowships, or scholarships to Anglicans. Adding only the corollary of an effective Gallows for murder in that Country! which indisputably would be the most didactic Clause of all! The poor Attorney was dreadfully flustered, & I really ashamed of myself for twenty four hours after.— Froude is come in, waiting. I send my love & blessing to Jean & to you all, & Ever am your affectionate

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 8 March. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Your letter was a great relief to me from my many uncertainties. I found it one evening, above a week ago on returning from my nine o’clock walk; it lay in the lobby there with others, but I knew it by the feel of it, & it was my reading so soon as I got up into the light. Thank Heaven you have had no more of those heart attacks,Lady Ashburton suffered from a heart condition, rheumatism, and, late 1872, an attack of mumps; see Surtees, Ludovisi 155 and 158. but seem to be cheery, content, & doing altogether well.

Almost every day of this week I have been resolved to write, in token of my being a good boy; but every day there has something or other occurred to say absolutely No to my pious intention;—every day, & this day too, had I not, in clear rebellion, determined to push it aside & write you a little word in spite of very fate. The truth is I have been busy with some old Letters which have come to me (you may guess perhaps, of what authorship),Letters from JWC to Susan Stirling; see TC to JAC, 8 Jan., and MW to SS, 14 March. & have not yet got done, so incessant are the interruptions & intrusions upon me, mostly from persons altogether indifferent to me, or worse. Add to which my languor, torpor, & utter laziness are extreme; the fruits partly, no doubt, of the dismal Winter we have had, & are now getting through, with, as yet, only the hope of improvement.— The main errand I had to Rome today, however, is to send my poor little Mary, or rather your rich little Mary, rich in all good gifts, dear Soul, her copy of Schiller, which is now lying ready. Maggie has wrapped it up, will address it & post it punctually, & we hope it will arrive safe. The new part of it, which is called ‘Supplement,’TC’s “Supplement” to The Life of Friedrich Schiller (1873) contained an account of Schiller’s family life; see TC to Lady A, 9 Sept. 1872. will surely interest her young soul; & I hope will be pleasant to you too, who are a lover of beautiful people in this world. The Schiller people, especially the eldest Sister, & the younger,The eldest and youngest were Christophine (1757–1847) and Caroline (Nanette) (1777–96); the middle sister was Luise (1766–1836); see Carlyle, Works 25:277–88. they & their humble Life-Scene are the beautifullest thing I have seen for a long time.

Another, & in fact still more important matter, was, to tell you that poor Forster got out of his dismal gouty cough, which really seems to have alarmed both Quain & himself, & ceased coughing, & sat in comparative ease, though weak as water nine or ten days ago; & has since been taking a drive daily, & oftenest a walk too, in some horticultural promenade under glass, which stands near him;Probably the covered area of the Royal Horticultural Society garden, Kensington. daily gathering strength, as I still understand. I have not seen him since your letter came, or at least have not had any opportunity of mentioning your present wish for help for your Man of BusinessProbably James William Waterhouse; see TC to JF, 4 Sept. 1872. from him; but I believe I may confidently say, as if he himself had said it, that he would be both willing & able to see that Helpless Gentleman at any time, on your note of introduction, & to give him all the help in his power; which I believe might be very considerable, versus the vulpine Clutton.Henry Clutton; see TC to Lady A, 4 July 1872. Think seriously of this I beg of you, & put it in practice, if you have need, as I doubt not you may often feel to have!

I have seen or heard nothing of Lady Marion or of the Brownlows: I called
some three weeks ago, & left a card;Lady Marian Alford and her son and his wife, Lord and Lady Brownlow. Their London house, 11 Princes Gate, was not far from Forster’s at Palace Gate House. was informed that Lady M. had not been in Town for a good while, nor was expected soon; & I have heard or seen nothing since.

We are all in a mighty toss about Gladstone’s amazing Irish Education Bill,—the most contemptible bit of Parliamentary thimble-rigging, & the foolishest Parliamentary Bill I can remember ever to have seen; which everybody now tells me has no chance of passing. The only speculation is, whether it wont turn the People’s William out;—but alas, if it should, & then only turn the people’s Dizzy in,Gladstone’s govt. resigned briefly, 13 March, after the defeat of the 2d reading of the Irish University Bill. Benjamin Disraeli, leader of the conservative party, refused to form a ministry, and Gladstone resumed as prime minister, 20 March. what better were we!——

These were very interesting Roman news you sent me; especially that digging out of the ancient burned mansion with the skeleton in it still in the attitude of prayer, was one of the most impressive things I had heard of for a long time. You say his, the skeleton’s name was there; of course therefore his epoch or date could be guessed at: I wish you would remember and instruct me on that point.

Poor Lecky is sitting down-stairs for the last half hour, no doubt waving his long neck with some impatience, like a giraffe who cannot get at his leaves!William Edward Hartpole Lecky; see TC to JAC, 4 Jan. I must therefore, in sad truth, abruptly close. They are going to make an L.L.D. of my Brother at EdinburghSee TC to JAC, 26 Feb. the beginning of April coming; several Reverends, unknown to me, & his Grace of Buccleugh are to be of the same batch.John A. Carlyle wrote, 10 March: “The Duke of Buccleuch, Professor Lushington of Glasgow, & two others whom I know” would also be awarded honorary LL.Ds; Edmund Law Lushington (1811–93; ODNB), prof. of Greek, Glasgow Univ., 1838–75; the other two were George James Allman (1812–98; ODNB), naturalist, prof. of Natural History, Edinburgh Univ., 1856–70, and John Mackenzie Lindsay (1792–4 Aug. 1873), W.S. [writer to the Signet], Clerk of Session, 1847–58, Director of Chancery, 1858–73. Walter Francis Montagu-Douglas Scott (1806–84; ODNB), 5th duke of Buccleuch, received his LL.D in 1874. John’s award of LL.D., 23 April (see TC to JAC, 26 Feb.), was at the same graduation ceremony as the “several Reverends” reported by the Scotsman, 24 April, as receiving Doctorates of Divinity: Rev. Marcus Dods (1834–1909), minister of Renfield Free Church, Glasgow; Rev. James Oswald Dykes (1825–1912), minister of English Presbyterian Church, Regent Sq., London; Rev. John Forbes (ca. 1803–99), prof. of Hebrew at Univ. of Aberdeen; and Rev. John Stuart (1819–88), minister of St. Andrews Church, Edinburgh, and chaplain in ordinary to Queen Victoria.
Give a kiss along with the Book to dear little Mary from me.
Believe me, She & You, Ever affectly, (& wishful of letters)

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 12 March. MS: NLS 527.87. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I did not send any Cheque to you yesterday; nor will now, till as you propose you have deliberated for a little on the condition of Railways & other investments. The instant you give me warning I will despatch for you the command of £4,000. If Railways have then given signs of settlement, especially if the price of Stock there be lowish, or down to the average, invest there;John A. Carlyle wrote, 11 March: “If you have not already sent off for me a cheque to get part of your money in the British Linen Co’s Bank put in Deposit form, please delay a little till I can see my way more clearly. Railways at present both in England & Scotland are in a somewhat disorderly state, owing to competitive schemes.” if not & there is no immediate prospect of such a thing, then I will recommend Deposits in the Bank; three and a half percent instead of one and a half being a manifest advantage which is not to be neglected, & so enough of that.

Kirkpatrick’s letter,John also forwarded Edward Kirkpatrick’s letter “which came today [11 March] & affected me much. He is a really good man, & an excellent scholar & teacher, & I hope he is now beyond his greatest difficulties, & will come out of them a better & a wiser man.” Edward Kirkpatrick (ca. 1821–1901), drawing teacher and artist (see 46:173TC to JAC, 19 March 1870); b. Charleston, S. Carolina, son of John Kirkpatrick, cotton merchant, and Caroline Pratt, he lived at 5 Picardy Pl., Edinburgh; by the 1881 census, he was m. to Eliza Moncur (1841–1909), with one son, Edward (b. ca. 1880); by 1891 he was a lecturer in classics and they lived at 52 Grange Rd., Edinburgh. which I return, is that of a very earnest & useful-looking man; happily, so far as one can see, got over the shallows with a judicious, diligent & prosperous voyage now lying ahead. As to poor Gladstone’s Bill, it continues tumbling about in the maddest manner: I hear now that the second reading is to pass; & that in Committee the whole bowels of it are to be torn out & flung to the dogs,—Gladstone himself soon going the same road,See TC to JAC, 7 March, and TC to Lady A, 8 March. as I, for one, rather hope than fear. He appears to me one of the contemptiblest men I ever looked on; a poor Ritualist, almost spectral kind of phantasm of a man, nothing in him but Forms & Ceremonies & outside wrappages; incapable of seeing veritably any fact whatever, but seeing, crediting, & laying to heart the mere clothes of the fact, & fancying that all the rest does not exist. By this manoeuvring with his Bill he hopes to escape the stroke of Fate for some time, as no doubt many of the Radical Cohort, quite in a rage
with this Bill, still wish; but everybody seems to think it can but be for a brief time. “Let him fight his own battle” in the name of Beelzebub the god of Ekron,See 2 Kings 1.2. who seems to be his “God,” poor Phantasm. We have cold, showery & vigourous weather here, & the Winter has evidently done me ill: but I still keep creeping about as before; & for one thing have a little more steadiness of sleep than formerly,—the worst kind of sleep, which mine generally is: (night-mares, hagglings & painful confusions &c &c) is much preferable to none at all. Tonight we are to dine at Miss Bromley’s; a poor adventure, & not likely to be profitable, but which cannot be longer delayed.—— Forster, whom Froude & I saw the other day, continues to gather strength, & indeed was in excellent spirits for the moment, & stormily pressing upon Froude & me the necessity of agreeing upon a day of dinner with him. Will you ask Jean if she have a copy of Jean Paul’s “Flower, Fruit & Thorn Pieces & if she (or you) have any desire to read it anew? I had a copy of the book once many years ago, but it has now gone, which makes me darkly guess, or inquire whether I did not give it to Jean.Jean Paul Richter (1763–1825), Flower, Fruit, and Thorn Pieces, trans. Edward Henry Noel, 2 vols. (1845); TC gave a copy to Lady Harriet Ashburton; see 18:290TC to WBB, 21 Dec. 1844. The Boston publisher Ticknor & Fields pbd. a new edn., 1872. John replied, 20 March: “Jean says she never had a copy of Richter’s Flower, Fruit & Thorn Pieces; but when staying with you some years ago found one in your Library (‘shelves of back dining room between the two garden windows’), read a good deal of it & liked it well, & would now be glad to read the rest of it.” There is come a brand new Copy from Yankee Land, & I have myself no great appetite for it just now:

Emerson, it seems, is in Rome, & may be expected here before long. I send you the Lady Ashburton Letter, my alone authority for this little fact; & put along with it the only other letter I had yet had from Rome. Please return them after your own reading. Can you throw any gleam of prophecy into the new lease of the Gill?John replied, 14 March: “The present lease runs out at Candlemas next [2 Feb. 1874], & I do hope for poor Mary’s sake it may be renewed. … The Factor, I think, is friendly.” Factor not further identified. Poor Mary’s interests in it make me very anxious; & right willingly, if I in the least saw how would wish to help for a good issue.—— The inevitable Leighton BartSir Baldwyn Leighton. is waiting downstairs; & Henry Cowper I next hear has been refused & sent away. Adieu dear Brother

bibl.sourceNote: MW-SS, 14 March. MS: NLS 20.5.25.66. Hitherto unpbd.
bibl.head: MAGGIE WELSH TO SUSAN STIRLING

docBody.p: Mr Carlyle in returning these precious letters,Susan Stirling loaned JWC’s letters to her to John A. Carlyle in Jan.; she then gave permission for them to be sent to TC for copying; see TC to JAC, 8 Jan. For Susan Stirling on JWC and her “remarkable power of narrating,” see 46:199–20046:appendix one. begs me to give his warmest regards & many many thanks to you for having so kindly & thoughtfully sent them to him. You can well imagine the deep, heartfelt, though sad interest each one of them has had for him: recalling so graphically to his mind many little incidents never forgotten by him; most of all bringing back so vividly the remembrance of those whose long & faithful friendship both he & she prized so warmly.

The Letters have all been copied, & are now put past beside other similar precious ones. Mr Carlyle bids me say that we made out all the dates of those letters not dated, he thinks almost quite accurately; he thought you would perhaps be glad to have the original Letters also dated as the Copies are, so I have ventured to similarly date them.

It has given Mr Carlyle true pleasure to hear often of you & Mr Stirling from his Brother during the last Winter; he trusts sincerely that you are at least as well as when he last heard of you; though of late truly the variable weather has tried those not too strong at the best of times. Mr Carlyle himself has, as I know you will be pleased to hear, been pretty well on the whole, but he does feel the cold and the sudden Changes of temperature very much too. Now one begins to try & look forward to something a little more genial. By & bye he hopes to have the pleasure of seeing his Brother here; & that will a little cheer him up.
Having so very often heard Mrs Carlyle speak of you & of your kindness to them (from my earliest recollections) may I venture to offer my own kind regards—

closer.salute:
I am, / Dear Mrs Stirling,
Yours respectfully,

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 20 March. MS: NLS 527.88. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Except the bitter March winds, which probably would not be news at Dumfries either, I have nothing that can deserve the name of tidings to convey: But Maggie & I have been annihilating a great heap of rubbish here, & the poor remnant saved here may perhaps be worth inclosing with the assurance that, in spite of these boisterous north Easters, we are all well. Tom Wilson’sThomas Wilson, probably still teaching in Weimar, although he had been intending to return to Britain; see TC to JAC, 29 Nov. 1872. half legible note, where the ChristophineFor Christophine Schiller, see TC to Lady A., 8 March. Autograph &c. came from, which done you may burn Tom. I myself can hardly read a syllable of the Christophine autograph, & Miss Reichenbach’sEither Elizabeth or Hedwig Reichenbach. copy of it has but a dim sense to me anywhere, & in the last stanza of it refuses to have any. If your superior skill both in Cursiv-Schrift & literary style would make a brief sally upon it, perhaps you might succeed better.John A. Carlyle replied, 21 March: “I return the German & other articles … except Wilson’s letter which was difficult to read & deserved nothing but the burning you ordered. I cannot make out the little poem ‘Auferstehung [Resurrection]’ & Miss R’s copy of it can hardly be correct, for it makes no sense, especially in the first & last stanzas.” “Cursiv-Schrift”: old German script. If not don’t waste time upon it, let it remain dark to this & all generations. The little notice of Schiller’s Friend Streicher, which came to me curiously from Chesterfield, is worth noticing & at least reading to Jean.Johann Andreas Streicher (1761–1833), German pianist and composer, close friend of Schiller. T. Frederick Smith wrote from Chesterfield, 17 March, saying that as well as TC’s Life of Schiller he had been reading “Schiller’s Leben und Werke von Emil Palleske (5th small ed. 1872), and have found in the latter work two facts about the ‘good Streicher’ which I think will be of interest to you. I therefore venture to send you two excerpts from Palleske.” Emil Palleske, Schiller’s Leben und Werke, 2 vols. (Berlin, 1858) was trans., 1860, by Grace, Lady Wallace (1804–78; ODNB); she ended her preface with a quotation from TC’s “fine tribute to Schiller” (xi). Henry Inglis (1806–85; see 43:27243:biographical notes) translated the poetry. I never heard of the Schiller Bio-grapher from whom the words are quoted, nor does he state what the title of his book on Schiller is, otherwise one might conclude to buy it:—but n’importe, n’importe.

Several days ago, a mass of Caledonian Railway remonstrances, criticisms &c. came to me from one Richard Wilson of Edinburgh, & others; by way of clearing my poor desk of an unsightly mass of rubbish I have first signed
a Proxy for the said Wilson, & subscribed ten shillingsRichard Wilson (b. ca. 1829), accountant, 28 Frederick St., Edinburgh. TC noted in his checkbook: “20 March 1873 / Richard Wilson Esq / Caledonian Railway Shareholding Association / £0 .. 10 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). to him for the purpose of helping to overhaul those ambitious Caledonian Directors, & others of the like, & compelling them to stand to their real business, & give up their competitive & other strategic & ambitious operations. They have, those Caledonian Gentlemen have, so far as I can see the very best line for traffic that exists on the Planet; if they turn their attention almost exclusively towards the better & better management of that, by promoting thrift, fidelity, punctuality & safety over all their line, no Company in the World could surpass them in real success; & it seemed to me that before burning that hat-ful of paper-litter I should give my vote & half sovereign towards that side of the question. I had a sneaking expectation of some notice from you on the subject;John’s letter, 20 March, presumably crossed with TC’s: “After due consideration I do not find it advisable to invest in Railway Shares just now. … I should advise you to put your money on Deposit in the Bank, as I have put mine for the present.” but none came, & the gradually increasing litter became intolerable to me.——

In looking at that matter with reference to the purchase of Shares, I think it may possibly take some considerable time before Railway matters settle again. If you, on considering & inquiring are of that opinion, it would perhaps be proper to put the four thousand pounds at once into the shape of Bank Deposits; changing them again when Railway Shares do become safely purchasable? It is evidently proper to take the best Interest one can safely get, & two per cent on 4,000£ will amount to something noticeable every week. Consider this, & write to me should you find it wise. I saw John Aitken yesterday at Chapman’s looking brisk & well; Mary has been here this morning do do,—John had been at their great Soirée last night,Peter and Clementia Taylor, Mary Aitken’s employers, apparently held regular soirées; see TC to JAC, 5 Feb. his first appearance I think in any society in London! Mary, I think, is doing well, & serving an apprenticeship that will be very useful to her: it is possible she, as well as John may join us at dinner next Sunday; but the Taylors themselves are to be off for Brighton tomorrow or even today.— Tell Jean I read her letter with great sympathy, and affection, as both her Bairns have since done; nothing has so affected me for a good while as that departing phasis of poor Nith,“The dog” was inserted later (above “Nith”) by A. Carlyle. —her last journey upstairs, the copy of her first; there is a force of gloomy depth in the inarticulate feeling of that poor dumb animal more eloquent than could lie in any words!— Tell her further I have not failed to meditate her hint or request about the Johnstone Testimonial, but that I find it impossible to arrange
myself under any clear category of his testifying Friends;John replied, 21 March: “I can well understand your reluctance in having anything to do with Free Kirk testimonials. … Jean will tell them her opinion that the money collected shd go direct to Mr Johnstone & not be spent in buying any sort of silver plate for him in an ostentatious fashion.” For William Johnstone, see TC to JAC, 4 Jan. & that all I can with perfect truth say is, that I, vaguely, have always had a good opinion of him, & am heartily sorry his finance so much requires the intervention of friends. I have therefore inclosed a ten pound for Jean herself, which I request her to forward for the Testimonial in her own name;TC’s checkbook recorded: “20 March 1873 / Mrs Jean C. Aitken (Dumfries) / £10..0..0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). she can call herself “Mrs Carlyle Aitken” & people will sufficiently know what Clan she is of.

Here is quite enough of writing about nothing, & I may now fall back upon a mouthful of idle reading till my hour for sallying out arrive. My reading is, alas! very idle: about Napoleon I, & his now far off affairs; it began with Ségur on the Moscow exhibition,Maggie wrote “exhibition,” in error for “expedition.” Philippe-Paul de Ségur (1780–1873), Histoire de Napoléon et de la Grande Armée pendant l’année 1812, 2 vols. (Paris, 1825). The Athenaeum reported, 8 March: “The death, in his ninety-third year, of General Philippe Paul, Comte de Ségur, the oldest member of the French Academy, took place last week [25 Feb.]. His principal work, often reprinted, and translated in several languages, ‘Histoire de Napoléon’ … is a striking narrative of the greatest blunder of Napoleon the First—the disastrous campaign in Russia.” Napoleon I (1769–1821), emperor of France, 1804–14. a book of considerable talent though fettered & hamstrung & distorted by much French epigram sublime sentiment &c. &c.; but representing such a possession by Lucifer himself, of a poor deliriously ambitious & fatally blinded fellow mortal as I never saw before in any record of men. Adieu dear Brother. My blessing to you one & all,

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 22 March. MS: NLS 527.89. Quot: A. Carlyle, NL 2:296; Wilson, Carlyle 6:286; John Morrow, Thomas Carlyle (2006) 213. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Yesterday we sent off the Richter Book for Jean; & hope it has arrived safe. I meant well to send by the same Post the Four Thousand & Fifty-Pound, but unhappily Miss Bromley stept in at the moment, & she & the wild stormy day
swallowed me from all work from thenceforth. Today I send it, naturally with satisfaction that our notions in the matter have so coincided: tomorrow perhaps you can announce to me in a word that the Cheque has arrived safe,TC’s checkbook noted: “22 March 1873 / Dr J. A. Carlyle for Bank Deposits of mine / £4050 .. 0 .. 0 (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). John acknowledged receipt of the check and confirmed the money was in the bank, 24 March. & that I can dismiss that matter out of my head. I am farther gratified that the Johnstone matter has been undertaken by Jean, & seems to have been the true plan of managing that affair. Yesterday was a miserable cold slobber of hail, rain & bitter wind: I made Miss Bromley take me up to Norton’s (poor N. has had an attack of Pneumonia, & been prisoner for many weeks, though now nearly well again);Charles Eliot Norton wrote in his journal, 20 March: “Five weeks to-day since I was shut up by illness,—a slight attack of pneumonia. Not yet out” (Norton’s Letters 1:469–70). he is a fine, gentle, intelligent & affectionate creature, with whom I have always a pleasant, soothing & interesting dialogue when we meet,—the only fault yesterday was I liked it too well, & staid too long. He read me a bit of letter, which reported Emerson’s safe arrival in Paris, with “his age renewed” by his Egyptian Winter, & in particular instead of the utterly bare, or slightly wooly scalp, a visible coat of hair growing again, or under way. I suppose he will be here in not many days, probably I told you already he contemplates six weeks in England, Heigh ho!—some goose or other has addressed from Rome, the other day, a letter for him to my care, which Maggie has put under lock & key. Another gooseCorrespondents not further identified. today requests me from Durham to say (for settlement of a dispute there) what is the meaning of Sartor Resartus. We confiscate his penny stamp & fling him into the fire. A most extraordinary sea monster, or Madman, a German now in Lime House, lately Mate in something,Limehouse, area of E London on the river Thames inhabited by dock workers and sailors from many countries. has written in the last weeks, first in Cursiv-Schrift, & latterly in English, whole acres of tumultuous stupidity, in very enthusiastic tone; next to nothing of which have I read: but do begin at last to perceive that the poor goose is out of his wits; and will be probably the better for one word of answer to that effect. Is it not a glorious thing to have achieved “Fame” in this world? to be the visible Horn Lantern in a world all sunk in stupor & darkness, & be impinged upon by all the owls that are on wing in the Creation.

Forster keeps going on well, & is already beginning to work again;—walks daily under glass cover in the Horticultural Conservatory; sees many visitors &cForster wrote, 21 March: “You gave me such a pleast evg the other night (the first for many long weeks) that I should be grateful for just a verbal message—one word—to say that you were none the worse for the pleasure you gave”; see also TC to Lady A, 8 March. —

I have no more to say dear Brother, having indeed already spent nearly all my day in trifling, though inevitable inanities (inane all of them & not my own, except this poor note): I will now have an hour of clear reading, if it please Heaven before I sally out.— With blessings on you all Ever Your affecte Brother T. Carlyle

bibl.sourceNote: TC-CEN, 23 March. MS: Houghton. Pbd: Norton’s Letters 1:470 inc. The book titles and bibliographic details are written in Maggie Welsh’s hand; the comments, and the remainder of the letter, are in TC’s hand.
bibl.head: TC TO CHARLES ELIOT NORTON

docBody.p: Köhler [Johann David Köhler]: Reichs Historie (Franckfurth und Leipzig, 1737).
A most solid, lucid & well authenticated old Book.
Köhler, Historische Münz-Belustignungen 21 voll. small 4to.
(Eine-und-Zwanzister Theil [21 vols.]. Nürnberg, 1749)
with Two Volumes of Index (Nürnberg, 1788). Excellt.
Bünau [Heinrich von Bünau], Deutsche Kaisere und Reichshistorie (Leipzig, 1728–43).

4 voll (and still incomplete): vol 1, I think treats of Barbarossa; & was to me full of interest; authentic wholly; and with clear vistas (face-to-face vision) here & there, in the genlly dimish twilight element.Norton replied, 23 March: “I thank you very much for the list of books you sent me yesterday. I shall have reason to thank you often when I read them hereafter,—and when, if I come on dull pages, the remembrance of your kindness will illuminate them with a steady glow.” The first two books are listed in HCC, but not the third.

postscript.p: Don’t wait for me tomorrow; I begin to fear it may not be well possible for me to come.

Give the Bonny little Bairn sight of her poor bit of Book, and keep it carefully for her!This was probably the copy of Cromwell he gave to Norton’s da. Sally, with the inscription “to be read so soon as she is ten years old” (Norton’s Letters 1:491). Norton replied, “I add my thanks to those of my little Sally for the book you have sent her.” — — And come yrself to see me quàm primùm [as soon as possible].Norton wrote in his journal, 28 March: “In the afternoon went to Carlyle’s. … [He] seemed a little weary, perhaps weakened by the mild, unbracing weather; but was full of kindness and humour” (Norton’s Letters 1:470–71).
Saty 22 March 3 p.m. / 1873

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 29 March. MS: NLS 527.90. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:286. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Canada James’Their nephew James Carlyle. letter, which I now immediately return, pleases me very much. He writes in a distinct, brief & lucid way; & it seems to me he gives a clear answer as to his modest wishes, & unpretending capabilities for farming as being decidedly the eligiblest-looking aspirations he has formed. You spoke more with him than I that day at Inverness,TC and John A. Carlyle met their nephews James and Alexander Carlyle in Inverness, 9 Aug. 1871. Alexander later wrote: “We spent the whole day together, walking, dining and talking on endless subjects … [TC] treated us most kindly … and knowing we were going straight to London, wrote to his housekeeper … telling her to use us well so long as we liked to stay in Cheyne Row” (“Jottings on Alexander Carlyle’s Life and Work,” Carlyle Annual 11 [1990]:70). See also 47:222TC TO SWA, 9 Aug. 1871. & may perhaps know more; but then, as in this letter, I discerned no signs of weakness or sluggishness in his character: & it seems as if a modest, manageable little farm in his Father’s neighbourhood is decidedly the tendency of his mind. My notion is you might with propriety (taking his Father into the consideration of the affair) intimate that if he can find a likely farm, at a fair price, we could jointly advance the purchase money to him, depending on his honour, diligence & integrity for paying the yearly instalment there,—& even for returning (if that could be a wish of his) to us or to our heirs here, the original purchase-money, should that ever be a possibility or a wish of his (which perhaps it won’t)! If you took Alick himself into the Consultn; & received his consent before doing anything, it seems to me this would be a safe operation, & the best that could be done for the poor fellow. But, for the rest, I leave the whole to your better study & deliberation, & merely say that I will go halves with you in whatever you decide on, that no kind of beneficence seems to me so beneficent as that as helping a diligent young soul into tools & arena, for the Work he is faithfully longing towards.John replied, 1 April, that he had written to James: “I told him … you would be ready along with me to assist in getting him the farm he wants near Brantford. … [H]e should have the approval of his Father & his brother Tom … & then … we should be ready to furnish the money required.”

I am often thinking of poor Margaret Stewart’s loss of her fine brood mare,Their widowed niece, Margaret Stewart, was running her farm on her own; see 46:102TC to JAC, 3 Nov. 1869. John wrote, 1 April: “Margaret’s foal mare is not dead. … It was James Austin who led me into mistake, thinking I was asking about a foal of his own.” He continued: “Margaret has really managed very well, & made a good figure in farming without making any stir about it.” She was gradually paying back money lent by John: “It is really a pleasure to me to see how thriftily & wisely & temperately she has managed since her husband’s death; & she is very generous too on all hands to her Mother & sisters.”
which will be very considerable to her, poor Soul. If you, who know her circumstances better, think she really can support the evil, & get over it without too much difficulty, perhaps it would be wise, & charitable too, to leave her alone just now, (& in the end strengthened by consciousness of victory!)— But if otherwise, & we two can do anything, I will cheerfully go with you on the terms usual to us in such cases.

We have good March weather here also, but nothing like so warm as yours, or at least not till this day, our breath of wind, which is sometimes a very strong one, being always from the North East hitherto, with a dark fog till about eleven every morning. Forster is progressing slowly but steadily; wind to West, with weather dry would greatly accelerate him. Yesterday I had a pleasant walk with Froude (who is busy at the Record OfficePublic Record Office, Chancery Lane. on his 2nd Irish volumeFroude, The English in Ireland in the Eighteenth Century, 3 vols. (1872–74). but made a holiday yesterday)—& with Mr Norton the American, whom I find an extremely amiable man. He had no farther news of Emerson, who seemed to him to be amusing himself in that beautiful, but too petrolean [fiery] City, where good Yankees go. If you have not seen that sermon of Paddy Vaughan,Herbert Alfred Henry Vaughan (1832–1903; ODNB), Roman Catholic bishop of Salford, 1872–92, delivered a sermon at the Conventual Church of St. Isidore, Rome, an Irish Franciscan church and monastery, on Saint Patrick’s day, 17 March. According to the report from the Manchester Examiner’s correspondent (quot: The Freeman’s Journal, 26 March), Vaughan’s message was that the Irish were the inheritors of the Jews as God’s chosen people, who, through the spiritual training of oppression, wretchedness and poverty would rise to save the world: “It had not been to a comparatively great and powerful nation that the duty was entrusted of keeping alive religious truths in the ancient world when it was imposed upon the Jews; and in like manner, in the modern world, oppression, wretchedness, and their consequent poverty, were the blessed means by which the Irish were fitted for their sublime task of regenerating and purifying all the nations of the earth. … The powers of the low Irish, as they were sometimes contemptuously called, were in reality at the present moment the greatest moral powers in the whole world. … [This] was a force different from that of the hypocritical kings and ministers and parliaments, the legalised bandits who, in all European countries, were now oppressing and persecuting the Church.” read it with attention, with amazement. It transcends all hierophantic utterances I have ever heard. Couldn’t you send it to some newspaper, Scotsman, Dumfries Courier. Herald, to be printed in big type, & circulated over the Universe as a thing wonderful to all the generations of men. I am in my usual state of torpid health, fixedly mournful, though not miserable spirits & contemplations; & (paper being done) will add no more. With my love to every one of you Yours affecte

bibl.sourceNote: TC-UC, 31 March. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd. Presumably an autograph.
bibl.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p: In pencil alone is it well possible. Trace in ink if you like!—

postscript.p:
Chelsea 31 March
1873

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 1 April. Addr: 26 Quattro Fontane / Roma / Italy. PM: London, 1 April 1873. MS: NLS Acc. 11388 inc. Quot: Surtees, Ludovisi 164. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature. The text of middle pages of the letter is taken from typescript; MS missing.
bibl.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
For the last two weeks I have been expecting to hear from you, & sometimes fretting myself with conjectures why I didn’t; but at length it struck me that our last two letters crossed one another on the road, & that probably you are expecting first to hear from me again. I write a word therefore; so except what the “Times” newspaper will already have told you, there is no news from this quarter of the world; as in particular from this house in Chelsea, there is absolutely none for the Times or any other vehicle. Maggie & I go on here with the utmost composure; are in a silence which is probably beyond example between this & Rome.
