I do know nothing, am good for nothing but idle, or semi-idle reading, all the forenoon; take a gloomily peaceful walk along the Park, with company or without, I am careless which; return home wearied to death about six o’clock, smoke my Calumet of peace, drink my drop of Brandy grog, grind my three snaps of peppery parkins, & tumble into my warm wrappages (the chief of them a certain yellow-brown extensive sheet, as soft as eider, & as snugly warm) upstairs, in my excellent dark cell of a bedroom, & fall sound asleep, quiescent as a stone for one hour; generally by far the soundest hour I get in the course of the four & twenty. After what is called “dinner” (a thing I would daily give a guinea or more to anybody who could eat for me), & then after the chaotic half hour, of what in the language of flattery is again called sleep, followed by the languid feeble tottery walk along the streets, & the due cup of tea that follows it, I get out my “good book,” & sit reading there, Maggie also reading or knitting opposite to me, & as quiet as a dream; in which attitude we sit, not a sound to be heard within doors or without till one A.M. come; & some imagination of supper closes up the torpid day: one other day of my remaining few thus gone to its account,—conscience often mournfully
asking “How?” & mournfully answering “but, Alas, could I help it?” I feel as if the Winter, horrid, muddy, dark & torpid season as it was, had done me sensible mischief, & that I feel perceptibly weaker than ever before. But perhaps this is mostly a morbid imagination too, & it is possible the fine Spring weather, which is at last come, may perhaps restore my strength a little. At any rate, as I often whisper to myself, I am still left graciously Here, permitted for a season to gaze with pious wonder into the Eternal Mystery near at hand, & with unspeakable reflections of mute awe & wonder, consider what has been, & what can yet be. Without spleen I may call myself sated of life, ready to go when my hour comes, & entirely Commander-in-Chief at last of my poor wreck of a world, till it please to disappear from me altogether. This what I suppose Philosophers call Euthanasia; if Old Age be a blessing (which I doubt, or rather don’t believe) then this is it; & so let us all be thankful,—& quit these unfathomable subjects for others more practical on this occasion.

The one point I had to urge concerning my last letter was, that there went along with it, a Copy of “Schiller” for Mary. Do not forget to tell me the next time that the dear little Bairn has got it:See TC to Lady A, 8 March. Mary Florence Baring wrote from Rome, 28 April: “I am so sorry not to have written before to thank you for sending me the Life of Schiller it will be doubly precious to me as coming from you. … We see so many things that it is like a new world opening to one. … I want so much to read some of the Middle Age history of Rome do you think Sismondi would be too old for me?” Jean Charles Léonard de Sismondi, Histoire des républiques italiennes au moyen âge, 16 vols. (1803–18); see 1:259TC to JOFE, 3 June 1820. TC recommended his writings to JBW in 1822; see 2:115TC to JBW, 27 May 1822. if there has been any failure, we will at once send another Copy for there are plenty here, & I want Mary to read that innocent “Supplement”; which seems to me to hold in it a beautiful little picture of human life, such as these tempestuous, loud-rumbling nugget ages do not any longer offer,—more is the pity, for said ages & us. Gold nuggets, “& nothing to buy with them,” that is not a good condition for an Age!—

I notice your new House in Kensington Gower when I pass that way; it looks very stately & fashionable, with the planks all cleared away from it; but I am sorry to understand there is again internallyMS ends. some haggle with that arch-quack and son of Beelzebub, Architect Clutton! Forster, however, has vigilantly his eye upon it, and I firmly believe will do whatever is humanly doable in the matter. He called here yesterday, the first time he has been for many months; he had got your letter; had written to Clutton and expected soon to have a face to face meeting with that man of frauds and bunglings.See TC to JAC, 27 April. Forster had written to Lady Ashburton, 10 March that he was in some doubt “As to the degree of blame fairly attributable to Mr Clutton in regard to the obstructions and hindrances which have given you so much annoyance. Without clearer information as to this, I could hardly advise you. … The object of this letter therefore is … to ask you to send me a letter asking Mr Clutton to see me simply as your friend in the matter” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388).
I wish to Heaven he (that man of frauds namely) were for ever and a day out of your books! In a former interview Forster, who had just been consulting with WaterhouseJames William Waterhouse, solicitor; see TC to Lady A., 8 March. about this affair, seemed to see nothing positive in it at that time, but the clear desirability of Waterhouse also being gently laid upon the shelf, for behoof of your Ladyship’s affairs; a man unstable as water, Forster seemed to say; capable of veering round the whole compass in regard to any practical point; and in fact, equivalent to zero, and of know-nothingism, if Clutton was a ditto of subtle knowery,Probably “knavery.” & still more dangerous qualities. Truly my very heart is sad for you, dear Lady, in the midst of such an imbroglio! I am very sure Forster’s business quality is of a very superior order, & also that if he can do anything for you, he will faithfully and eagerly do it. I am in quiet hope that he actually will (consulting with Lady Marion candidly surveying matters with his own best insight) do some real good.

But the grand question with me now is, when you yourself are to appear on the scene again, & let us see you in temporary settlement in England for the summer? I myself vaguely scheme out Seaforth Lodge as the prettiest position for you I can think of. If, as I suppose, the Water questionFor the water problem at Seaforth, see TC to Lady A, 22 and [24] Aug. 1872. was all got settled about Christmas time, & those huge pumps (the sound of which I shall never forget) fairly supplied with an inexhaustible current, there is not in England or the world a prettier little jewel of a residence; Melchet & London alike accessible to it, both; wholesome breezes to be found in England; all your friends within reach & the place your own—I cannot think of any place so fit for dear little Mary & you. Rome, I suppose, must be already getting too hot, & our brightness of Spring is already fairly beginning. What can you do so wise as come home; & especially as your health seems now to be taking a favourable turn. Tell me about this, all you can as yet, especially about that latter point, your health, which I naturally regard as more important than any other. Your Doctor Pianta Leone, I find, is an old Roman acquaintance of my brother’s, a most acute, intelligent & clever little man he says; by far the best Doctor he ever met in Italy; this was his experience 40 or 30 years ago.Dr. Diomede Pantaleoni (1810–85), Italian doctor and politician. John wrote, 14 March: “The Dr Pantaleone who is attending [Lady Ashburton] must be an old acquaintance of mine & fellow-practitioner when I was in Rome. … I thought him a very dexterous, clever & shifty man, beyond any Italian doctor that I had ever seen before. He was small in stature but most active, had studied abroad … & also had the art of ingratiating himself with rich foreigners.”

Emerson is still in Paris, & I hear nothing from him;—& nothing about
him except that he is coming hither; & that his head, instead of mere child’s down, is getting, or has got, a visible cap of human gairIn error for “hair.” again; Egypt having visible mended his health a good deal. I liked much what you told me of him. As to his daughter, Mrs. Forbes’ treatment of you,Edith Forbes’s “treatment” unexplained. I dimly guess that whatever was unusual in it must have sprung chiefly or altogether from Allingham’s rather than any other person’s loose tongue, and that it is a thing at any rate altogether superficial & capable of being altogether expunged from your consideration. To me both she & her husband seemed to feel truly obliged to you; (as they might well do) for your cordial welcome, & the visible service you have done them.

Froude is busy the whole day now over his Irish Records & foundations of Vol. 2nd, unless he play truant some day for my sake, it is usually only on Sundays that I see him. His volume on Ireland is visibly rising in Public Opinion; indeed I believe it will form an epoch in regard to our relations with Ireland, & mode of dealing with that unutterable bit of savagery. The People’s William though again got on the top of his dung-heap, is not thought to be long for that sorry elevation: No man in my time has made to me a more fantastic, dishonest and utterly imbecile appearance than the People’s William, in his attempt to govern the British Empire by choosing Cardinal CullenPaul Cullen; see TC to JAC, 7 March. & his tag-rag of Irish savagery, as a fulcrum for that operation. Various reports are current about him; sometimes of his still crowing very high in bright moments; but it is generally understood that his crowing days are numbered; & that no mortal can guess what delirious mischief & nonsense he may yet embark in, when driven down from his sublime dung-heap, & obliged to scratch for worms in a subaltern position. Let him fight his own battle, however, why should I expectorate my spleen upon him. One strong rumour I have heard, that he wishes (being dreadfully astounded with his discovery of Strauss & Company)David Friedrich Strauss (1808–74), German liberal theologian and philosopher, who distinguished between Jesus as a historical figure and the “myth” of his divinity. Gladstone talked at length about Strauss in “Address delivered at the Distribution of Prizes in the Liverpool Collegiate Institution,” 21 Dec. 1872: “He has published during the present year a volume entitled The Old Belief and the New [The Old and the New Faith (Leipzig, 1872; English translation by Mathilde Blind, 1873)]. In his introduction he frankly raises the question whether, considering the progress which culture has now made, there is any longer occasion to maintain religious worship in any form whatever”; he advised the students, “in preparing yourselves for the combat of life, I beg you to take this also into your account, that the spirit of denial is abroad, and has challenged all religion … to a combat of life and death” (Times, 23 Dec. 1872). Gladstone was criticized for taking upon himself, as a politician not a churchman, “the office of directing the public mind in regard to matters of religious belief” (“Gladstone on Strauss and Modern Thought,” The Theological Review 10 [April 1873]: 259). Gladstone was very well read in modern theological thought, and he had read Strauss’s Life of Jesus (Tübingen, 1835–36; English trans., Marian Evans [George Eliot (1818–80; ODNB)], 3 vols. 1846) in 1848. to
quit politics altogether, & stem the tide of infidelity, which he sees clearly will be an infinitely higher enterprise.
My clear vote is, that they should give him the highest pension on record, & strictly bind him to stem said tide & try nothing else so long as he lives.

Excuse this ramblingMS resumes here, written at the top of the first page. diffuse & even absurd flood of scribble. Do send me news so soon as possible. Do always believe me yours & dear Marigold’s Herzen’s Freund [heart-friend].

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lady S [LST], 7 April. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO LADY STANLEY

docBody.p: For your own sweet sake I regret extremely that I cannot come; but, in very truth it is not possible for me tonight.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 12 April. MS: NLS 527.91. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
This day I had decided to write to you though without other purpose than that of quashing any groundless anxieties that might be pressing in about me: but in getting down stairs there presents itself, come by Post a sufficient mass of idle written matter to form a Post packet simply on its own account. The Letter for yourself, which I perceive to be from the blathering Blackie,John Stuart Blackie. will probably relate to your coming Doctorate,—concerning which I have been daily expecting to hear some prophecy of your journey to Edinburgh & your motions afterwards. But I suppose the ceremony will not be till towards the
end of this month;John A. Carlyle replied, 13 April: “Blackie tells me he is to be the ‘Orator’ on Wednesday 23d when the L.L.D. degrees are to be conferred, & that I must dine with him in the evening as part of the ceremony. … I shall have to go to Edinr about the end of this week, probably on Saturday, & may get back on the Thursday following if all goes well. Miss Orrock can give me my usual lodging—which is one comfort at least.” For Miss Orrock, see TC to JAC, 7 Dec. 1872. & that you will probably return straight to Dumfries soon after that. It is possible you may find the illustrious Martin TupperMartin Farquhar Tupper (1810–89; ODNB), poet and writer; see 47:140MAI to MT, [Jan. 1871]. performing publicly in Edinburgh! The poor goose, after selling fifty editions of his Proverbial Philosophy, or whatever he calls it, & being so universally sneered at, & treated as the King of Geese by every penny-a-liner in the World, has at last, it would appear been cut off from readers to a dreadful degree; & not having saved against a rainy evening is now sadly crippled in finance, & been obliged to set out on a career of Reading from his own Works.Tupper’s Proverbial Philosophy: A Book of Thoughts and Arguments (1838); a great success, it was trans. into most European languages and reissued in 38 editions. By the 1860s it was out of fashion, and Tupper was in financial distress. His reading tour of SW England, April–May, was followed by a Scottish tour, Oct.–Nov.; it is not known if he performed in Edinburgh, but he did stay there on his way home (Derek Hudson, Martin Tupper: his rise and fall [1949]). Later in the year, on the advice of Queen Victoria, Gladstone awarded Tupper a civil list pension of £120. I civilly declined recommending him to the Edinburgh Philosophical Institution,TC was honorary life president of the Edinburgh Philosophical Institution; see 45:163TC to HBO, 10 Aug. 1868. but advised him to try hopefully in his own well known name. Poor Soul! I think you once saw him: an innocent, honest minded long-nosed famous & volubly stupid man; Alas, is he now driven about upon the idle winds, financeless, & symbolical in two ways of the Chaos Literature & all else is in among us! Mit der Dummheit Kämpfen [with stupidity contend]——as Schiller has it!Cf. “Against stupidity the gods themselves battle in vain,” Schiller, Die Jungfrau von Orleans [The Maid of Orleans] (1801) 3.6. ——

The Letter to myself about LivingstonePresumably David Livingstone (1813–73; ODNB), explorer and missionary; he had been searching for the source of the Nile; he became very ill and d. 30 April. is my second on that subject, neither of which have I answered nor mean to; burn it even without reading if you like. Few wandering asses in the World are more indifferent to me than Livingstone has always been; & as to Mrs D. O. Hill’s illustrious sculpture of him,Amelia Robertson Hill, b. Paton (1820–1904, ODNB), sculptor, m., 1862, David Octavius (1802–70; ODNB), painter and photographer. The bronze memorial statue of Livingstone was designed by Hill, 1875, made in bronze by the founders, R. Masefield & Co., London, 1875–76, and installed in Princes Street Gardens, Edinburgh, Aug. 1876. For Hill’s bust of TC, see 46:167TC to JGD, [7 March 1870]. the only question or notion it suggests is, Could not you or any kind human Friend I may still have in Eding contrive gratis, or for a moderate
sum of money to find some beneficent individual, who would take his hammer & beat into powder the egregious stone-blockheadism of my poor self, which she has got stuck up in the Museum there?John replied, 13 April: “I am told that Miss D. O. Hill’s bust of you is taken out of the College & Woolner’s put in its place, but shall see when I go there.” Thomas Woolner’s bust of TC was commissioned by Lady Ashburton; the first sitting was April 1865 (see 41:203TC to JAC, 6 April 1865), the last sitting May 1865 (see 42:19TC to RO, 12 May 1865); it was completed early 1866, and was sent to Edinburgh for exhibition, Feb. 1866; see 43:114JWC to GLC, [24 Jan. 1866]; see oppabove. It now belongs to Edinburgh Univ. — But I know too there is no remedy, & that absurdest of Sculptural abominations must be left to the slow tooth of Time. Was thut’s [What does it signify], after all:—
Thomas Carlyle by Thomas Woolner
Courtesy of Aileen Christianson
As to the poor Warrand Carlyle letterWarrand Carlile (1796–1881), clergyman and missionary, m., 1820, Agnes Irving, youngest sister of TC’s friend Edward Irving; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 253 and 453. John replied, 13 April: “The letter of Warrand Carlyle is one of the most curious I ever read. What it says seems quite sincere, & is expressed with some talent. Last time I saw Warrand was at Edinr some ten or twelve years ago.” it is such a clash of innocent, hopeful, joyful Jinner Janner as I never heard before from any human creature: in which sense you may perhaps run over it before calling in the Element of Fire. The small caricature of Darwin & Huxley looking into broken Clockers’ eggs,Untraced. by way of catching Nature in the fact, & showing us how we were made by No God is said to be of German origin, & was left me the other day by Madame Venturi.Emilie Venturi. Please give it to Jean if she have any scrap book or place of refuge for such rubbish.

Emerson, as probably you know, is come to us this day week. He called here on Sunday last looking a great deal better for his Winter voyage,Norton noted in his diary, 12 April: “Mr. Emerson and his daughter Ellen have returned from Egypt, and came to see us two days ago. The Nile has renewed his youth, and brought back to him a becoming growth of hair. … He is the pattern of the cheerful philosopher in our modern times” (Norton’s Letters 1:477). & is going about ever since, dining &c.,—I myself had to dine with him at Froude’s last Wednesday; more sorrow to me, for I am hardly yet quite out or of the penalty that forced adventure brought upon me. I understand he means to visit Edinburgh before leaving; probably about the beginning of May;The Scotsman reported, 10 May, that Emerson, “[t]his distinguished philosopher, accompanied by his daughter, has this week been on a hurried visit to Edinburgh, residing with his friend Professor Fraser. Mr Emerson leaves today.” Alexander Campbell Fraser (1819–1914; ODNB), philosopher, prof. of logic and metaphysics at Edinburgh Univ. 1856–91. for it seems he has settled to go home with Norton weighing anchor on the 16th of that month.Norton and Emerson sailed together for the U.S., 15 May; see Norton’s Letters 1:502. TC noted in his journal, 9 June: “Emerson & Norton with family sailed for Boston from Lrpool, 15 of last month—kind parting from both, from Norton almost a pathetic, not to meet agn. Idle, sad and idle; why shd I meet anybody more, except those sacred Ones that are already whither I am bound!” (TC’s journal; privately owned). He is very gentle, very amiable, clear & wonderfully happy, but
I do not get much solid talk with him, nor indeed does is much avail me when I do.“Is” in error for “it”; Norton wrote in his diary, 12 April: “The difference between Emerson and Carlyle is very wide … the outcome of their creeds and philosophies is so unlike as to limit their mutual sympathies. … They will be friends to the end; but neither is dependent for sympathy on the other” (Norton’s Letters 1:477). His Daughter; with him here, is a pleasant looking, rational person, probably over thirty; their address is “16 Down Street, Piccadilly.”Presumably lodgings, in the home of Philip Govett; otherwise unidentified.

For the last two weeks we have had extremely uncomfortable weather, wild blasts of continual east wind; which I think must have been unfavourable to me on the health score:—it seems as if I had been living in a perpetual pluister, deeper than usual, & generally of a slightly deeper tint of gloom, about all I have been doing or saying. What a contrast between Warrand Carlyle & me, though he is within six months as old as I am.TC was b. Dec. 1795, Warrand Carlyle (previously Carlile), b. 1796. Courage, Courage nevertheless. Forster I have not seen for above a week, but I hear he is going on prosperously in spite of the weather: my last sight of him was at a dinner still more unwholesome than Froude’s,—the chief guest there being Lytton Bulwer’s Son & Heir, now Lord Lytton the second, who is not a man to get into dyspepsia for, though a very much superior person (as I judge) to his foolish Father, now vanished from the World.Edward Robert Bulwer Lytton, 2d Baron Lytton, succeeded on the death, 18 Jan., of his father, Edward George Earle Lytton Bulwer, 1st Baron; see TC to Lady A., 11 Feb. But why do I go on with all this my dear Brother; there is nothing here that profits you or me.

We had a note this morning, by the by, from Mary, who professes to have quite recovered her little whiff of illness or incommodity, & to be now doing well in spite of the cold. John also was here this morning, is gone to the Library on my account for books, & is due here directly intending to go with Maggie to the National Portrait Gallery this afternoon. I know not whether “Easter Monday” also is a holiday, but he has already had two, which were very welcome. Adieu dear Brother. Give my love to Jean & everyone. I always am & remain,

postscript.p: Your letter just come 3 P.M.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-EF, 14 April. MS: Trinity. Pbd: FitzGerald’s Letters 3:415–16. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature, written on C. E. Norton’s letter to TC, 13 April.
bibl.head: TC TO EDWARD FITZGERALD

docBody.p: Mr Norton, the writer of that note,Norton wrote, 13 April: “I enclose a note which Ruskin wrote some year or two, or even more, since, addressed to the Translator of Omar Khayyam, that ‘Old Mohammedan blackguard,’ as you call him. He took a fancy to the productions of the reprobate poet, and he left this note with an acquaintance of mine to be forwarded to the translator if ever his name should be discovered. The note has been lying all this while in a desk, and I am asked now to ask you to forward it.” The “acquaintance of mine” was presumably Georgiana Burne-Jones, b. Macdonald (1840–1920; ODNB), as identified by Norton in his letter to her, 22 May 1902 (Norton’s Letters 1:425–27), rather than her husband, Edward Burne-Jones (1833–98; ODNB), artist, whose copy of the poem Ruskin had read (FitzGerald’s Letters 3:414–15). is a distinguished American (Co-Editor for a long time of the North American Review) an extremely amiable, intelligent & worthy man; with whom I have had some pleasant walks, dialogues & other communications, of late months;—in the course of which he brought to my knowledge, for the first time, your notable Omar Khayyam,FitzGerald first pbd. The Rubáiyát of Omar Khayyám (1859) anonymously, at his own expense. & insisted on giving me a Copy from the third edition, which I now possess, & duly prize. From him too, by careful cross-questioning, I identified, beyond dispute, the hidden “Fitzgerald,” the Translator,—& indeed found that his complete silence & unique modesty in regard to said meritorious & successful performance, was simply a feature of my own Edward F.!Norton noted in his diary, 9 Dec. 1872: “Carlyle told me that he had known Edward FitzGerald well, though he had not heard of his translation of Omar Khayyám till I mentioned it to him” (Norton’s Letters 1:439). — The translation is excellent; the Book itself a kind of jewel in its way,Norton later recalled TC saying: “I’ve read that little book which you sent to me, and I think my old friend FitzGerald might have spent his time to much better purpose than in busying himself with the verses of that old Mohammedan blackguard” (Norton’s Letters 1:426). I do Norton’s mission without the least delay, as you perceive; Ruskins’s message to you passes through my hands sealed.Ruskin wrote, 2 Sept. 1863: “My dear & very dear Sir / I do not know in the least who you are, but I do with all my soul pray you to find and translate some more of Omar Khayyám for us: I never did—till this day—read anything so glorious, to my mind as this poem” (FitzGerald’s Letters 3:416). I am Ever Your Affectionate

bibl.sourceNote: TC-CEN, 18 April. MS: Houghton. Pbd: FitzGerald’s Letters 3:418 inc. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO C. E. NORTON

docBody.p: It is possible Fitzgerald may have written to you; but whether or not I will send you his letter to myself,FitzGerald replied, [15 April], to TC’s letter of 14 April: “Thank you for enclosing Mr. Norton’s Letter: and will you thank him for his enclosure of Mr. Ruskin’s? It is lucky for both R. and me that you did not read his Note; a sudden fit of Fancy, I suppose, which he is subject to. But as it was kindly meant on his part, I have written to thank him” (FitzGerald’s Letters 3:417). as a slight emblem & memorial of the peaceable, affectionate, & ultra modest man, & his innocent far niente [idle] life,—& the connexion (were there nothing more) of Omar, the Mahometan Blackguard,Norton later noted: “I was amused that Carlyle had let his phrase about the ‘Old Mohammedan blackguard’ reach FitzGerald’s eyes” (Norton’s Letters 1:427). & Oliver Cromwell, the English Puritan!FitzGerald also wrote that he had as yet heard nothing from either the agent or the lawyer dealing with the Naseby estate about their plans to erect a monument to the battle there; see TC to EF, 15 June 1872, and 7 Dec. 1872. —discharging you completely, at the same time, from ever returning me this letter, or taking any notice of it, except a small silent one.
I don’t see Emerson since Sunday last, & am a little anxious about the question of his health you mentioned when we last met.

On Monday Evening, if all go well, at Forster’sNorton noted in his journal: “On Monday, April 21, according to a long-standing engagement, Jane, Grace and I dined at the Forsters with Mr. Carlyle, Miss Welsh, and Miss Hogarth. … It was a pleasant dinner, for Forster was in far better condition than in the early winter, and in one of his mild and simple moods. The effect that Carlyle has on him is always beneficial, and their humours played well together. Carlyle was very sweet, a little quiet, but ready to be animated and vivacious” (Norton’s Letters 1:487). I hope to hear of this among other things.
With many affectionate regards,
I am, & remain always / Yours sincerely

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 26 April. MS: 527.92. Quot: A. Carlyle, NL 2:297. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: The third Post card missive, came this morning, kindly announcing, though in such hurry, that your Edinburgh journey, with all its errands, had got prosperously terminated.John A. Carlyle had been in Edinburgh to receive his degree of LL.D.; see TC to JAC, 26 Feb., 8 March, and 12 April. He wrote, 27 April: “The graduation was gone through in excellent style, & there were about 160 graduates in all, but only four LL.D.s & four D.D.s who sat in the two front seats. … I brought away with me what is called a ‘cowl,’ sky-blue on the outside, & very questionable in shape as you may see some day.” While there he had visited various friends, including JWC’s aunts at Morningside; see also TC to JAC, 27 Dec. 1872. Many thanks for your punctuality in carrying me along with you throughout. These Post cardsJohn replied, 27 April: “My postal cards, as you remark, were rather disorderly, but I had no time for any formal letter or details of any sort.” For John’s earlier use of postcards, see TC to JAC, 30 March 1872. are very handy, but they have one considerable drawback, that of letting the whole world into your family & other secrets, which entirely condemns them in my practice; indeed I rather disapprove of the invention altogether, & for my own share have always preferred any odd bit of paper, slipped into an actual impenetrable cover at the expense of one halfpenny more! I have no doubt various people, Post office clerks & the like learned at Edinburgh & here how you were to dine with Blackie, to call at PeeblesJohn wrote, 20 April: “I mean to take poor Mrs Hunter, who lives solitary at Peebles, on my way [home] & spend a few hours with her. She has lost her husband, three of her sons & one daughter, & now has only two daughters left, one in Liverpool & the other in India.” Helen Hunter, widow of John’s friend John Hunter, living at Kingsmuir House, Peebles; her surviving das., Jane and Henrietta, were married to John A. Carlyle’s step-sons, Henry and Arthur Watt (see under John A. Carlyle, biographical notes). John wrote, 27 April: “I found Mrs Hunter looking very thin & worn, but resigned to what has taken place in the loss of her husband & children.” &c. &c,—though indeed except to one’s imagination it made no matter at all. John Aitken amused me the other day by reporting how some fellow clerk in Chapman’s office naïvely applied to him for help to read one of those Post cards he was handing to him from the Postman,—“cannot quite make out this sentence,” said the naïve clerk.

In return I have next to nothing, or altogether nothing of news to tell you. Except indeed that Emerson is just leaving us, & that except in Edinburgh, about ten days; hence, I know not where there is any chance of meeting him. He came down hither day before yesterday, sat about a couple of hours, talking
cheerfully in his mild, modest, ingenious but rather theoretic way; & then rose inexorably to go for Forster’s, who had asked him to dinner for this (Saturday) night, but was to find him inexorably engaged elsewhere. So he went his way, & it is probable I shall see him no more, as he departs punctually tomorrow morning for Merthyr Tydvyll, Oxford, Manchester &c. &c; nothing fixed but that he is to be in Edinburgh, & that he sails with Norton from Liverpool on the 16th of next month. I think sometimes the Edinburgh University people should give him a public dinner;John replied, 27 April: “As to Emerson I dont think there could be any chance for a public dinner in honour of him just now. All the professors … are out on holiday till the middle of May.” things of the kind have been proposed here, but given up, or perhaps declined; Edinburgh is perhaps the fitter place, if any place can be fit. Should you be writing to Masson, you might fling out such a hint?———
——Alas, a good while before this (about the top of last page in fact) a flood of mostly stupid interruptions poured in & still continues: Out, out upon it! I have not time for another word.

Tell Jean that Mary came to me yesterday, sat a good while talking, & seemed well-doing & cheerful. John is here at this moment intending a journey with Maggie to Hampstead to call for Mrs. Frankau,Rosetta Frankau, widowed sister of Joseph Neuberg, living at Roslyn Park, Hampstead. & now not a word more. Ever your affectionate Brother

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 7 May. MS: 527.93. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
I suppose you are meditating now & then upon your Summer movements, & how to repair a little the injuries that Winter brings upon us; & I have been expecting latterly to hear something from you on that subject.John A. Carlyle replied, 8 May: “I have not yet formed any plans for the summer, except that I shall in any case endeavour first of all to see you again in Chelsea. … I could start for Chelsea next week if that would suit you, say about the Thursday or Friday, & then we should be able to talk over all plans that might suggest themselves.” It is very natural & proper to employ to one’s best advantage the bright months of the year & gain a little new strength, if it be possible! I myself feel to have suffered very considerably from the dark muddy Winter that is passed; & if I had any
basis to work upon (that is to say if I had any place in the world where I could be reasonably sure of getting sleep), I should really incline to migrate a little & shift about on the green surface of the Earth. But with me that preliminary consideration is usually a check-mate; & I have to continue in my own cell, which is at least utterly silent, till the heat & smoulder burn me out.

For you it is considerably different;—& in case you should be thinking of Chelsea as a primary stepping stone (which you mentioned in one of your notes lately) I write to say that Chelsea is now, & at all times perfectly open to you; & that a change thither might probably elucidate the matter to both of us. I am today in rather special hurry & special disability; but wish to say this before undertaking anything else;—& indeed I have nothing else that it is worth while to say at present.

Within an hour I expect Forster, who is to carry me up to Norton’s (too far for a walk),The distance from Cheyne Row to Cleveland Sq. is about 3½ mi. (5.5 km.); presumably TC meant it was too far for Forster to walk. & there to bid the good Norton Farewell along with me. I expected he was to stay for another week; but it seems Friday is his last day here, as he has visits & errands to accomplish between this & Liverpool for the 16th. He is an excellent, sincere, & affectionate person, in mournfully pathetic circumstances,Norton’s wife, Susan Ridley Norton, d. 17 Feb. 1872; see TC to JAC, 2 Nov. 1872. & has been all through Winter the most human & really interesting of all the companions, or fellow-promenaders I had. And now to that also there is Finis. Of Emerson I hear nothing whatever; but suppose him to be flourishing & of good cheer at Edinburgh or wherever his wanderings lead him. He is an excellent, pure & placid soul; the only fault I have to him, that which the Prophet Isaiah expresses in these words “Woe to them that are at ease in Zion”!Not Isaiah, but Amos; see Amos 6:1. His Daughter is a much more determined kind of person; at least so I judge from this trait of her, that she openly expresses her utter weariness & disgust at the Nigger, & has one hope concerning him, that he will utterly perish out of the way of the United States, where he is nothing but a superfluity & nuisance. This, after such an expenditure of broken bones & exploded human brains upon the Controversy, is a little strong!—— Froude is intensely busy upon his final Irish volume, & when I see him has nothing else that he is so free to talk upon. I confess my feeling sometimes about Cardinal Cullen & his conciliation of his Paddy Savagery is a little analagous to Miss Emerson’s about the Niggers.

John & Maggie are bound this evening to the Peter Taylors’ Soirée;The Taylors held regular soirées; see TC to JAC, 20 March. Mary, we expect & understand to have returned yesterday;—& John (who was here last night, for a few minutes) seems to be awakening to an interest in human
society not hitherto noticeable here. My love to Jean & all the household.

closer.note: Letters obscured by fold in paper.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-MN [MNO], 9 May. Pbd: Norton’s Letters 1:494. TC, on his last visit to Norton, 7 May, gave a locket to Norton’s da. Sally; Norton recorded in his journal: “Little Margaret, with a strong sense of individual rights and interests, longed for a present also, and, going quite fearlessly up to the old man, began to feel the capacious pockets of his great coat” (Norton’s Letters 1:491).
bibl.head: TC TO MARGARET NORTON

docBody.p: Sent to frank Chelsea Autographs; could n’t act in that capacity; go now, as spolia opima [rich spoils]TC had noticed Maggie’s search and, when Norton called on TC, 9 May, he had prepared a little package for her, “the gift I ought to have brought her.” He wrote on the envelope: “Dear little Maggie Norton’s little conquest in England! To Papa’s care.— T.C. 9 May, 1873” (Norton’s Letters 1:493). The package contained some U.S. postage stamps and four little U.S. coins, presumably originally sent by U.S. admirers. He had also looked out some books for Norton to read during their voyage home (Norton’s Letters 1:490–91, 493–95). , a better road!— T.C.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 10 May. MS: 527.94. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:419–20; A. Carlyle, NL 2:297–98; Wilson, Carlyle 6:296. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I must not let this otherwise utterly idle Saturday quite pass without a word of answer to your last letter, which was very welcome to me; there is nothing to hinder you, from coming up to us any day you like; nor, since you have already decided to come, does there seem to be the least reason for putting the day off beyond your own best convenience. Unless we hear to the contrary therefore, let us from this day expect you sometime about the end of next week.John A. Carlyle replied, 14 May: “[I] hope to be with you again in time for dinner on Friday evening.” He planned to go via Liverpool to visit his step-son Henry Watt. Some day toward the end of the week (not Saturday I suppose for the Crowded Railway’s sake; you can judge of that yourself far better than I): let us know the day before if not sooner, & your room & every thing will lie ready. You never found me idler than I am at this time, & indeed am obliged to be, having neither strength nor spirit for anything worth calling employment: a series of little walks or excursions with you would probably be a wholesomer resource than any other open for me at present.

Today I have spent, for example, wearisomely reading Browning’s last new Poem,Browning’s Red Cotton Night-Cap Country, or Turf and Towers (1873), based on the scandalous story of Antoine Mellerio (1827–70), heir of the French jewelry house Mellerio dits Meller. The Athenaeum reported, 15 April: “Mr. Browning’s poem. … is a poetic version of a great tragedy which came before the law-courts in a department in the North of France last year, and … the poet has in the outlines of the story kept closely to the facts” (440). Allingham wrote in his diary, 12 May: “C. tells the story [of Browning’s poem] very clearly (he always likes doing this kind of feat), and says there are ‘ingenious remarks here and there; but nobody out of Bedlam ever before thought of choosing such a theme’” (Allingham Diary 224–25). which was forced upon me yesterday by Forster;—I do think the despicablest, most conceited & utterly worthless performance I ever met with from the hand of a man of talent! I have still perhaps a hundred pages of it to read, & vote then that I never think of it or hear of it more. Poor Browning: as Forster says, “he is really gone altogether to the Bad.”— Yesterday I took leave of Norton, who came down to have one last walk with me, but to our regret the walk was interrupted by rain, & then he had to call a cab, being rather on the sick-list at present; & I had to take shelter at Forster’s, which was close by,In his journal Norton described his final walk, 9 May, with TC: “As we were going up Queen’s Gate the rain began to fall and during one shower we sought shelter under a porch. The shower passed and we started to walk again, but before we had reached the Park the rain began again, more heavily than ever. … We hailed a hansom, Carlyle said I might take him to Forster’s, close by. … ‘I’m sorry to have ye go. The relations between us this winter have been very humane,’ were among his last words to me. He was very grave, very tender, and my last sight of him was as he waved farewell to me with his hand from Forster’s door” (Norton’s Letters 1:500–1). —whence this Browning infliction, which I would gladly have avoided, had not Forster been so irresistible. I was really sorry to part with Norton, & his interesting family of little Motherless children,See TC to MN, 9 May. good Sisters, & venerable Mother: he has been through Winter the most human of all the company I, from time to time, had. A pious-minded, cultivated, intelligent, much suffering man. He has been five years absent from America & is now to return One instead of Two as he left! He is off today for Oxford; will meet Emerson at Liverpool on Thursday next, whence Westward-ho!Cf. Charles Kingsley, Westward Ho! (1855). by the best Steamer they could fix on.

Yesterday I got a great shock when Norton told [me]Word omitted by Maggie Welsh. when we were stepping out into the street that John Mill was dead!John Stuart Mill d., 7 May, at Avignon, France, from an attack of erysipelas, a bacterial skin infection. Norton recalled in his journal: “As we went out of the door I spoke to Carlyle of the sad news of Mill’s death. He had not even heard of his illness, and he was deeply moved at hearing thus without preparation of his death. ‘What! John Mill dead! Dear me, Dear me! John Mill! how did he die and where? And it’s so long since I’ve seen him, and he was the friendliest of men to me when I was in need of friends. Dear me! It’s all over now. I never knew a finer, tenderer, more sensitive or modest soul among the sons of men. There never was a more generous creature than he, nor a more modest. He and I were great friends’” (Norton’s Letters 1:495–96). I had heard no whisper of
such a thing before; & a great black sheet of mournful more or less tragic memories, not about Mill alone, rushed down upon me: Poor Mill, he too has worked out his Life Drama in sight of me; & that scene too has closed before my old eyes, though he was so much my junior!— Goose WaylenJames Waylen, Wiltshire historian and artist, now living at 6 Cheyne Row; see TC to JAC, 29 Nov. 1872. came down to me today very dirty, very enthusiastic, very stupid & confused with a daily newspaper “containing two Articles ineffably sublime & heart interesting upon Mill” one little bit of which he read, & then pressed the paper on me; which I thinking it had been “the Times” accepted, with the thought of sending it to you. Two more blusterous bags of empty wind I have seldom read, & withal on looking at it I found it to be the “Daily Telegraph” & not “the Times”; but such as it is I spend one halfpenny upon it, in case it can find any reader at the Hill. “Immortal Fame,” “First Spirit of the Age,” “Thinker of Thinkers”:The Daily Telegraph reported, 10 May: “It is difficult to estimate the heavy loss which his death has inflicted, not only on England, but the world; for he was incomparably the most influential speculative intellect that, in our time, has attempted to apply abstract theory to the facts of every-day life. A century may go by before men may be instructed again by a mind at once so acute and so intrepidly logical. … Fifty or sixty years hence, when our thoughts and doings shall have become a subject of study, it is not to Parliamentary debates or to the lives of statesmen that inquirers will go to for the explanation of its character. They will search the pages of Carlyle for its mournful yearnings, and the pages of Mill for its systematised aims and thoughts. The one is its chief seer, the other has been its greatest philosophical teacher, and they have done more, perhaps, than any other Englishmen to give our period its shape and time.” For a second Daily Telegraph report, see TC to HM, 17 May. what a piece of Work is ManSee Hamlet 2.2. with a penny-a-liner-pen in his hand!

We saw Mary this morning, bright & fresh as a May-flower; going off again at 1 P.M. for Brighton till Tuesday next. She does not seem to dislike this locomotive, shuttling life, or at least expresses no shadow of dislike over it or any thing in her present employment & environment;—& indeed appears to me to be behaving very well & wisely in the position she has. Tell her Mother punctually that such is my opinion, which doubtless will be a kind of pleasure to her. Bring up accurate news about our kindred, especially about Mary at the Gill; & give my love to Jean, to her & all that is theirs.— LeckyWilliam Lecky. —or Necky as some call the long waggling flail of the man is waiting down below, so I must not add another word.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-HM [HAMI], 17 May. Addr: 2 Longton Grove, Upper Sydenham / S.E. PM: London, 17 May 1873. MS: NLS 1778.1. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Maggie Welsh’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO HARRIET MILL

docBody.p: Your little note is very touching & pathetic to me; & I regret much that that poor story of the burnt Manuscript had ever oozed out (what surely was not owing to me or to mine) into the ear or the imagination of the idle Public; or especially that the babbling newspapers should have brought it home to your sad heart in these solemn moments.Harriet Mill wrote, 15 May: “In all the more elaborate accounts of my dear brothers life, in the Newspapers, there are some mistakes; But in the notice in the D. Telegraph of Saturday [10 May], mention is made of the unhappy loss of your Manuscript.” My clear advice is that you dismiss it wholly from your thoughts as a thing, which to me is now grown a No-thing,—nay has even risen (by the sacred memories connected with it) to be a real possession, which it is blessed for me, & as it were sacred, to look back upon!TC learned from Mill on the evening of 6 March 1835 that his MS of the first vol. of The French Revolution had been burned; for TC’s view of the incident at the time, see 8:66–68TC to JFR, 7 March 1835, and for his later recollection, see Carlyle, Reminiscences 92–93. TC told Norton during their walk, 9 May, about the loss of the MS, “a calamity quite irreparable” (Norton’s Letters 1:496). This is truly the character of it to all that are concerned—both to me, who still linger on this Earth, & to your dear Brother whose memory alone now remains to us.

The Daily Telegraph writer in all his details of the matter is purely imaginary; though by no means disobliging either to me or to Him who is gone;The Daily Telegraph reported, 10 May: “Carlyle was writing at the time his ‘History of the French Revolution’. … He had lent the manuscript of the first volume to Mill, who handed it on to Mrs. Taylor. … One day, as Mr. and Mrs. Carlyle were sitting in their house in Chelsea, a cab rattled to the door, and John Mill immediately afterwards came into the room. Instead of saluting his friends, he threw himself down in a seat by the fireside, and buried his face in his hands with a passion that betokened speechless grief. Carlyle kindly asked what was the matter. Mill sobbed out, ‘The manuscript! the manuscript!’ and rushed out of the room in a state of uncontrollable emotion. The sad truth was that Mrs. Taylor, to whom he had lent the manuscript, had left it lying on the table of her library, that it had fallen on the floor, and that some stupid servant, fancying it to be waste paper, had used it to light a fire! At first the loss seemed irreparable, for Carlyle had no copy of the manuscript, and his rough notes gave scarcely a fragmentary basis for what was really a great epic rather than a history. That fact drove Mill into a state almost of despair. … Then, with a wonderful exercise of will and intellect, the great historian sat down to compose once more his magnificent rhapsody.” & in fact my impression really was, that night when your Brother came to us
pale & agitated, as I have seldom seen any mortal, that Mrs Taylor’s house & some trifling neglect there, had been the cause of the catastrophe;Harriet Mill wrote: “Mrs Taylor is described as the ‘heroine’—(a sad misnomer) of that incident. As far as my recollection goes, the misfortune arose from my brother’s own inadvertence, in having given your papers amongst waste paper for kitchen use. I can perfectly well remember our search and my dear brother’s extreme distress. … My brother would surely have told you exactly how the disaster had come about; and if I am right, I should much wish to have this published account corrected.” TC told Norton that it had been burnt at Harriet Taylor’s house. By the time of TC’s death, Harriet Mill accepted that it had not been burned in the Mill household; see 8:68TC to JFR, 7 March 1835. —but in fact, to prevent him almost perishing with excess of misery, we had to forbear all questioning on the subject, which indeed was of no importance to either of us, & to bid him “Be of Courage, never mind, Be certain I can write it again & will”! He sat a long time with us gathering some composure; & I for ever since remember the beautiful & heroic encouragement & consolation I got from her, who then & always loved me as her own Soul.JWC. Whether permission had been asked to show Mrs Taylor the M.S. I don’t the least know; but that it did not the least need to be asked, in the relation she then had to us & Him, I do well know;Harriet Mill wrote: “I cannot think that my brother would have shewn your manuscript to anyone, without your permission. I shall feel indebted to you if you can spare the time to let me know the truth on this point.” & that your dear Brother’s conduct to me in this matter, as indeed in all others, then & afterwards, was conspicuously noble, generous, & friend-like,—conduct of the First, almost only Friend I then had in London, one who would have made any sacrifice for me & what I then had most at heart. Believe this dear Miss Mill to be a very Truth; & dismiss from your sorrowful heart all thought of the empty newspapers; for I again bid you clearly understand, that neither in my mind, nor in that of my heroic Life-Partner, was there ever at that time or afterwards, attached to your Brother the least shadow of blame in regard to this affair. But, in the contrary, grateful recognition of his unwearied loyalty, affection & readiness to help; a feeling still fresh in my mind, & tender & true at this moment. Nor, widely as our roads parted, & little as we saw of one another in later years, did I ever change in my intrinsic feelings towards Him, nor do I believe his did towards me. Which to me is now a real consolation in regard to many things, & ought to be to you a remedy in this paltry little item, which is now, as I said, become a Nothing, or even a beautiful little bit of gain. Adieu dear Miss Mill. Old & weak as I am, if I ever get to Sydenham again I will actually try to see you, whom of all the Family, except Him, I most distinctly remember; & you, if you ever feel the kind impulse to come & see me while in London, will do me
a welcome favour.Harriet Mill replied, 10 May: “Your most kind and feeling letter has done me much good. … I shall gladly take advantage of your permission to come to see you.” With the heartiest wishes & sad & affectionate regards, I remain always,

bibl.sourceNote: TC-HC, 20 May. Pbd: Fifty Years of Public Work of Sir Henry Cole, K.C.B., 2 vols. (1884) 1:346. Henry Cole (1808–82; ODNB), civil servant, director of the South Kensington Museums 1856–73; see 44:26TC to JAF, 2 Aug. 1866.
bibl.head: TC TO HENRY COLE

docBody.p: I went yesterday with two companions for a look at your Bayeux TapestryThe Bayeux Tapestry, an embroidered cloth depicting the events leading to the Norman conquest of England, 1066, thought to date from the 11th century. Cole negotiated with the civic authorities in Bayeux for photographs of the entire tapestry to be taken by Joseph Cundall (1818–95; ODNB; see 46:119–20TC to JF, 19 Nov. 1869), publisher and photographer, who was in charge of the South Kensington Museum’s publications and reproductions, 1866–89. The Illustrated London News, 15 March, reported: “Among the reproductions of works of art that are to be included in the forthcoming International Exhibition will be a full-sized photographic copy of the Bayeux Tapestry. This famous piece of needlework is about 230 ft. in length and 22 in. in width, and the copy will be the largest reproduction hitherto executed by means of photography” (247). The photographs remain at the V & A National Art Library. in the Albert Hall,Cole was instrumental in the building of the Albert Hall (part of the South Kensington estate of museums and gardens), the large public hall suitable for exhibitions and concerts, opened 1871. and I cannot but express to you at once my very great contentment with what I saw there. The enterprise was itself a solid, useful, and creditable thing; and the execution of it seems to me a perfect success—certainly far exceeding all the expectations I have entertained about it. Mr. Froude, who was one of my companions, was full of admiration; and a brother of mine, who had seen the tapestry itself at Bayeux last year,John A. Carlyle visited Bayeux July 1872; see TC to Lady A, 4 July 1872. seemed to think that this copy you had managed to make (I hope in a permanent and easily repeateable manner) was superior in vivid clearness, beauty of colour, &c., to the very original. Nothing amiss in any part of the series did I notice, or suspect, except perhaps, in one part of the series, the Funeral of King Edward preceding his Death; which is a point you can easily examine, and, if wrong, put right.Edward the Confessor (1003–66; ODNB), king of England 1043–66; the panel in the tapestry showing his funeral procession at Westminster Abbey comes before that showing his illness and death; see http://www.bayeuxtapestry.org.uk/Bayeux13.htm

As the work is in essence photographic, I flatter myself you have preserved the negative and other apparatus whereby the thing can be completely repeated as often as you like, and at moderate expense—in which case it might, with evident and great advantage, be imparted in the same complete form to all British large towns, British colonies, and even in America itself would be precious to every inquiring and every cultivated mind.The Bayeux Tapestry was to be copied by Elizabeth Wardle (1834–1902), embroiderer, and 35 members of Leek Embroidery Society, using the Museum’s hand-color photographs for reference. First exhibited in Leek, Staffordshire, in 1886, it was then sent around towns and cities across Britain and abroad. It is now in Reading Museum; see http://www.bayeuxtapestry.org.uk/Index.htm In a word, I am much obliged to you for sending me to see this feat of yours (by far the reasonablest in completeness of its kind yet known to me), and very much obliged, above all, for your having done it, and so done it.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-WDC, 18 June. MS: London Lib. Hitherto unpbd. William Dougal Christie was TC’s main helper in the setting up of the London Library and remained a committee member until his death; see TC to WDC, [26 Feb. 1840]. and Carlyle and the London Library, ed. Frederic Harrison (1907) viii. Written in TC’s hand in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO WILLIAM DOUGAL CHRISTIE

docBody.p: For various reasons, whh I think wd seem valid to you, cd I get them fully stated (as is not possible at prest), I find myself forbidden to be the vehicle to Ld Stanhope of the Letter you have sent me.Philip Henry Stanhope (1805–75; ODNB), 5th Earl Stanhope, historian, vice-president of the London Library. TC returned Christie’s letter to him; for TC’s description of it, see TC to JF, 24 June.

My “Presidantship” of the London Library was from the first, by express stipulation, and must continue so long as I am in it, altogether Nominal or Titular only, no duty attached to it whatr;TC accepted the presidency of the London Library in 1870 on condition that it involved no work or responsibility for him; see Kenneth J. Fielding and David R. Sorensen, “‘The supreme comfort of your presence’: The Letters of John Forster to Thomas Carlyle,” CSA 31:58. —so that, in this astonishing Harrison Donation Affair“Harrison Donation Affair” unexplained; however there were continual disagreements between Christie and Robert Harrison (1820–97; ODNB), librarian of the London Library, 1857–93; see John Wells, Rude Words: A Discursive History of the London Library (1991). See also TC to JF, 24 June. (on whh privately I may have thots perhaps not unlike
yr own), I am totally hors de combat, and must not officially say one word, or make the least sign.

Permit me to add, what is a weightier & public consideratn, that I think the sending of such a letter thro’ whatr conveyance cd have only the effect of increasing irritatn and confusion; and of considerably obstructing the one good result now visible ahead,—or perhaps the 2 good: 1° that of getting an additn of salary to the excellt & meritorious Jones;John Edward Jones (ca. 1824–93), asst. librarian 1844–after 1888; he and Harrison also had a difficult relationship; see Rude Words 97–98. and 2° (whh ought to be possible) that of ascertaining, clearly to the bottom, what the actual essentil & practical (not financial merely) conditn of the London Ly is, and thus judging whether the pudding has been excellently baked, or not excelltly.— — It is ev[ident]Letters omitted by TC at top of page. to you I can write no more letters on this subject!TC probably referred to his difficulty in writing; presumably he did not want to dictate on this subject as it was private and sensitive. —
Sorry not to be able to do yr will on so small a matter, or on any matter,
docBody.closer: Yrs sincerely / T. CarlyleTC wrote in his journal, 9 June: “More and more dreary, barren, base and ugly seem to me all the aspects of this poor down-rushing Quack world,—fallen openly anarchic, doomed to a death whh one can only wish to be speedy!— Visit (yesterday, Sunday [8]) from Masson, always a friendly, gentle and welcome presence to me. Admonished him, with eulogy duly intermixed, abt the fatal conditn of his Milton, and how it might & shd, as the one remedy, be ended quam primum. Witht the least effect, most probably: but I had to do it” (TC’s journal; privately owned; Froude, Carlyle 4:419 inc). Masson continued to work on The Life of John Milton: Narrated in Connexion with the Political, Ecclesiastical, and Literary History of His Time, 6 vols. (1859–94); vol. 3 was advertised as to be pbd. “in a few days” (Athenæum, 21 June).

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JF, 24 June. Addr: The Lord Lytton, &c &c / Knebworth Park, / Stevenage / Herts. PM: London, 24 June 1873. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd. Written in TC’s hand in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p:
Many thanks for yr kind little Bulletin, whh I had been expectg for days before.Forster wrote, 22 June: “I have not been very brilliant since I came here—or you would earlier have had a word from me. Now I write out of mere selfishness—for I cannot get on comfortably … without knowing how you are.” The only Deficit is a clearer acct of yr own hygienic conditn and the dear and ever patient Helpmates, in that new element:The Forsters were staying with Lord Lytton at Knebworth Park. —however, I will try
to believe that all does go well & that the omens are good.
For myself, I am no worse than usual, nor perceptibly any better,—how can I ever hope to be? Till the signal of Departure come, and one shuffle off, once for all, a great many irremediable things!—

I don’t hitherto suffer from the heat, but only get into sumer clothes, and rather like it. Not till the heat burn me out have I the least thot of leaving; middle of July, say: Mary Aitken is then to carry me (softly as on a wishing-carpet)Favorite image of the Carlyles for traveling; see 36:243TC to SGS, 13 Sep. 1860. to a month’s sea-bathing with her Mother & her;—in some serenest solitude, either “in the Isle of Bute, or nr Stranraer,” we are not particr whh! Other program have I yet none. I must pass thro’ Edinr, however; that is more fixed than any other point. Ah me, ah me!—

Christie wrote me last week, (the instant his tremendous Anti-Hayward Pamphlt was out,Presumably Christie’s John Stuart Mill and Mr. Abraham Hayward, Q.C., a reply about Mill to a Letter to the Rev. Stopford Brooke (1873); it was privately printed and circulated. Abraham Hayward (see TC to Lord N, 3 March) had pbd. a critical obituary of John Stuart Mill in the Times, 10 May, where he denied Mill’s importance as a thinker: “[M]any of his opinions on society and government have been generally and justly condemned. … He was often a wrong headed, but always a kind-hearted man.” Rev. Stopford Brooke (1832–1916; ODNB) criticized the Times obituary in a sermon, 11 May; Hayward replied to Brooke with an even harsher indictment of Mill’s career, condemning him not only for his political and economic views, but particularly for his views on marriage, and his relationship with Harriet Taylor. Hayward privately printed and circulated his letter among many friends and acquaintances, including a number of leading public figures. Christie, a close friend of the Mill family for over 40 years, responded angrily, publishing the correspondence and his own defense of Mill. whh I have never yet seen) a very angry and unpractical kind of Letter “to be transmitted to Ld Stanhope,” abt those Harrison &. Jones miraculous procedures by his Lordship:See TC to WDC, 18 June. Forster wrote, 29 June: “I have a letter also, in confidence, from Harrison of the London Library, which moves much pity in me, perhaps unwarrantably, for that poor mortal, whom the obdurate Christie makes wretched in his present place, and eager to change it for another. … That was wise kind counsel of yours in the matter of Jones whom I shall hope to serve by attendance at the next committee.” I returned XtieFor “Christie.” his Letter with advice to suppress it; & try calmly to get poor Jones some Additn (and perhaps the State of the Library, not its finance merely, to be examined & made clear), as the only useful result that cd now be expected from such a huddle! Item no Letters more to me on the subject,—still less from!—

Let me not forget to return Lady A’s Letter; which was very welcome, & the first credible word I have yet had from Marienbad. Tomorrow, if I can, I partly mean to despatch a couple of lines thither. Please say, at any rate, that I did write to PerugiaForster enclosed, 22 June, a letter to himself from Lady Ashburton: “I send it to you to read because of the things in it about yourself. You will kindly let me have it back.” Lady Ashburton was in Perugia at the end of May, and on her way to Marienbad (see TC to JCA, 20 June 1872); see Surtees, Ludovisi 164. Perugia, city in central Italy. a long Letter, whh appears never yet to have got to hand.

Adieu, dear Forster; alas I can write nothing, as you see; nay the very paper is done. Report me affectionately to yr dear Wife; offer my kind thanks & regards to Ld Lytton;—and believe me, yrself, dear F.,—far beyond what I can write,—Yrs T. Carlyle

bibl.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 6 July. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Surtees, Ludovisi 167. Written in John Aitken’s hand; TC signed it and wrote the postscript.
bibl.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Your Letter came to me three nights ago. I had long looked for it; & the news it gave me of your own improved health & outlooks was extremely gratifying. About my dear Mary’sLady Ashburton’s da., Mary Florence Baring. “nervousness,” & the complete absurdity of that foolish rumour I had been already satisfied; but the news you now send, which I have heard of in various successive Letters of Forster & others, of her precious young health being somehow out of order is altogether on the wrong! side of the balance. I do confidently trust there is nothing material gone amiss, and that the bright summer weather aided by rest from all but sport & amusement will soon set everything to rights again. I have sought out your poor swampy, rainy, solitary Marienbad in my maps, & do heartily wish you were over the back of the Metal-mountains—on to the Swiss EngadinThe Ore Mountains, between Saxony and the Czech Republic, so called because they contain rich silver and tin deposits; Engadin, an Alpine valley in SE Switzerland, very popular with travelers. —or better still home to your own England again, where for five or six weeks past we have had the finest summer weather I have seen for these several years. Balmy, genial, agreeable to every sense: warm enough in all conscience but generally veiled—grayish & dry enough, or with showers only in the night-time! Perhaps all this may tempt you even in the absence of swamps, scrubby-forests, & baths of ill-tasted water with no certainty (generally to me with none) of help in them to any living creature. “They were not made with the least intention of that kind but are merely accidental dribblings & oozings, through one knows not what:”—that is always my reflection upon them!—

Ever since your Letter came I have been engaged in nothing else but a solution of the little Problem you sent me:The problem was Thomas Woolner’s high-relief sculpture Virgilia Bewailing the Banishment of Coriolanus, originally commissioned for Melchet; completed 1867, it was exhibited at the Royal Academy 1871. By then there was no space for it at Melchet; Lady Ashburton asked Woolner if he might be able to sell it for her, but he had refused (see Surtees, Ludovisi 134–35). to me little but to you I can well
fancy how great in respect of the long-continued provocation, fash & vexation you have long had about it, & are still continuing to have! Since yesterday when I saw Lady MarianLady Marian Alford. upon it (with very great satisfaction to myself) & did not find Woolner but have appointed him hither I flatter myself to have shoved that miserable business into its final posture, & concluded for you all the long continuing bother you have had for this “Exquisite” but too rash bit of sculpture:—except indeed the uses of repentance that may be derived from it, & the resolution never to be so incautious again!

How I have settled it (that is, settled in my own mind how it could & ought to be by way of bringing it to its true & best conclusion) Lady Marian will, most probably by this post, explain to you: she entirely agreed with me yesterday, & indeed seemed greatly pleased with my ideas on that head & on others connected with it, of which she had herself been thinking altogether as I was found to do.— From the first moment it was evident to me that there was not the faintest chance of Woolner’s doing anything but roughly refuse to help you in selling this thrice unfortunate bit of sculpture & that I never could, or must for your own honour’s sake whisper of such a proposal: nay furthermore it was distinctly evident that neither Woolner nor any other person could possibly sell this piece of sculpture within any comfortable length of time, but that it must keep painfully lumbering after us year after year,—nobody could say or guess how long. Then secondly I had ascertained from Lady Marian (whose judgment on such matters I take to be the best) that the position meant for it on the staircaseLady Ashburton now planned to place the sculpture on the staircase in Kent House. was actually good & appropriate,—none fitter for such an article, or giving it a fairer chance of being seen, noticed & examined, I surely fancy? Thirdly my opinion or feeble notion always was that this was really a meritorious bit of sculpture needing only, as I long ago suggested to Woolner, some clear indication such as might be given, if not by some artistic symbol, then by some ingenious inscription, Latin quotation or the like, of what the real subject of it was,The sculpture has the single word “Virgilia” inscribed on the base. or what it meant to tell one,—which was otherwise a total blot of darkness rendering it to my poor practical mind at least a mere insoluble enigma, distress & kind of insult, more to be avoided altogether than sought after at such an expense (£2,000, & a yearly rentShe had paid £2,000 for it, and had since been paying to keep it in storage (see Surtees, Ludovisi 166–68). like that of a horse or pair of horses, standing at Livery without lifting a hoof for you all the year!)—
my Sole request to Woolner will be that he would give us this inscription or symbolic representation & assist us (that is Lady Marian, Forster & Clutton) in choosing the best position &c, for this thrice weariesome bit of sculpture. This I have no doubt he will gladly do, & take perhaps as a compliment to himself to be asked to do. The sculpture will then be off your hands, out of your thoughts altogether; & the value of it, the intrinsic value, whatever that may be, will then be secured to you & yours as in the Bank of England itself:—for we will have Woolner’s inscription upon it & the advantage of Woolner’s highest fame, if it should rise as high as the Empyrean, which let us pray (faintly) that it may do! Enough now of him, & of his exquisite sculpture,—fully as dreary and exquisite vexations that sometimes follow them!—

One word & one only I force myself to add on this subject: That I think you must in nowise commission or permit any other Friend than Lady Marian or Forster to lay the least command or make any communication or suggestion to Clutten direct but always & solely by suggestion, through Lady Marian & F.. This is more necessary than you think: F. alone of all your friends having a hook in the snout of that “Leviathan of Fraud” & intending to keep it, in strict concert with that great Lady (the skillfullest decorator in all England I should think if you leave him & her Ladyship to follow their own course) & rigorously guide the Leviathan as I understand they altogether quietly now do— Finis then at last in regard to this business department.

Of myself I have nothing new to tell you, more especially nothing very cheering or comfortable:Word repeated at top of new page. tho’ also, let it be said, nothing at all expressly of the other type. Miss Welsh, some short time after my Brother came, went away by Liverpool to Auchtertool always very kindly ministering to me there if in any thing she could. One of the last services she did me here was that of writing a long Letter to you from me:—Letter which, I find, you have never yet got—nor probably now ever will. It was punctually addressed to you at “Perugia,” punctually despatched, & would arrive there, as I afterwards found, some day-or-two, after your departure, about June 5 namely. It was a long Letter; rambled about considerably on Mary’s education, her grand necessity of really learning Latin &c. It contained nothing of real importance; and if it wont come to you it can stay away. Dont the least bother about it!

Froude is going off to Devonshire on TuesdayFroude was to stay at Glenlyn House, nr. Lynmouth, N. Devon; see TC to JAF, 30 July. next which will be a loss to me; Fitzjames Stephen going next week (as Substitute-Judge I believe)Fitzjames Stephen had recently been appointed a circuit judge, visiting Winchester and then Dorchester. will be another loss; Forster, as you know, is in HertfordshireAt Knebworth Park; see TC to JF, 24 June. for some three
weeks past, & I see nothing of him. I am perfectly idle except for reading; to say truth good reading when I can get it good suits me better than almost any company for truth to say I am weak, weary, &, if by no means miserable—sad & sombre, & willing that my Inn were here whenever such is God’s will. It seems to be settled that I am to go with Mary Aitken & my Sister, to a month of bathing, in the Island of Rothesay, or on the Galloway Coast about Stranraer;Rothesay, seaside resort on the Isle of Bute, Firth of Clyde; Stranraer, town in Wigtownshire. the strict conditon being that a place for absolutely quiet sleeping is to be found for me!— Until the heat actually burn me out, it is certain I shall stay quietly here. My Brother is very good to me, poor soul; soft, so far as his rough paws can be: and I think will certainly continue with me till I go to Scotland before going on any errand of his own.
Adieu, Dear Lady. God’s blessing be upon you & your Bonny Bairn! I am, & remain,

postscript.p: We have been twice out at Barnes Common;Barnes Common, SE London. Miss Bromley very pleasant, kind & cheerful. Last time she showed me yr newest Letter, from Marienbad: former time, yr Niece with her StanleySusan and John Constantine Stanley. was there,—and had heard that instead of Marienbad, you had struck off suddenly for Paris & Miss Coutts!Margaret Coutts Trotter (ca. 1811–82), old friend of Lady Ashburton, living at La Rocheville, St. Germain-en-Laye, just outside Paris; see 45:102TC to LLA, 3 March 1868. —n.b. I wish Miss Coutts saw Mary, in case anything is wrong with the little Darling!—

Lady Marian had me to a quite artistic dinner lately,—havn’t seen the like of it for ten years past! Several of yr Roman friends were there; especially Hare,Augustus John Cuthbert Hare; see TC to JAC, 29 Nov. 1872. Lady Ashburton had befriended him in Rome earlier in the year; see Surtees, Ludovisi 163. whose singular cutting tone of voice and do aquiline face (with the fine soft eyes in it) I shall not forget.

Of Ld Houghton’s “monographs” and in particr of that One,Lord Houghton, Monographs Personal and Social (1873), the sixth of which was “Harriet Lady Ashburton” (225–55). Houghton referred to “the constant friendship that existed between Lady Ashburton and Mr. Carlyle—on her part one of filial respect and duteous admiration. The frequent presence of the great moralist of itself gave to the life of Bath House and The Grange a reality that made the most ordinary worldly component parts of it more human and worthy than elsewhere” (232). I sorrowfully think like you. Ah me, Ah me!
T.C. (july 7th)—

bibl.sourceNote: TC-BB, 12 July. MS: NLS 3278.164. Hitherto unpbd. Written in TC’s hand in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO BETTY BRAID

docBody.p: This little GiftJohn A. Carlyle noted in TC’s checkbook: “12th July 1873 / Mrs Betty Braid / £5 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). comes to you on a Birthday whh is forever sacred to me, and in memory of One, (and as if by Her command): to whom you were a kind of Second Mother, and still feels as such!— Send an Old Newspaper, in sign that it has come; & I will understand all the rest.

By side channels I always hear of your genl conditn from time to time; but cd like well if, some day, you cd send me from yr own hand a line or two on the subject. I myself write with difficulty; but yr right hand, I think, still continues steadier. Or if you like better, or find it easier, call on my Aunts, and Miss AnnJWC’s aunts Ann and Elizabeth Welsh, at Morningside, Edinburgh. will expressly send me yr news.

In my own health there is no marked change,—nothing but the additn of another year of Time, and the corresponding deductn of Strength whh was to be expected, and is also perceptible as one goes along. The way of all the Earth,See 1 Kings 2:2. —of all the Earth; since Time first was!

James Baillie (Her Cousin, whose shiny ways you may remember)James Augustus Baillie, see TC to JAC, 4 Jan. For his “shiny ways,” see Jewsbury’s account in Carlyle, Reminiscences 49–55. TC continued to send money to Baillie’s wife until April 1876; see 47:186TC to WILL, 6 April 1871. died here, end of March last; in dreary enough circumstances, but with more of magnanimity & composed wisdom than one cd have expected.
God’s blessing be on you, dear Betty. I am & remain

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAF, 30 July. Pbd: Dunn, CLF 592–93. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:419, where dated 29 July. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO J. A. FROUDE

docBody.p:
Thanks for your kind Letter, which is very hospitable, altogether practical and very welcome to me. The prospect I must say, withal, is very seductive,
—ample houseroom, shady silences, neighbourhood of clean sea-water all accessible in one day:Froude had presumably invited TC to visit him at Glenlyn, Devon; see TC to Lady A, 6 July. —you may depend on it, I will not “leave the matter out of mind”; and in the chaos of plans and possibilities, so far as I can judge at this moment, it really has a look of invitation and stands a good chance,—good at least for Niece Mary and me, however it may be with others!

At the present moment I feel considerably drawn towards a preliminary week at Blickling in Norfolk,Blickling Hall, home of Lady Lothian, old friend of TC; see TC to Lady A, 10 Jan. which has many claims upon me; and where the whole society, so far as I can learn, consists of Lady Lothian & her Sister Lady Gertrude,Lady Gertrude Frances Chetwynd-Talbot. in a beautiful Elizabethan edifice (birthplace of your Queen Anne Boleyn)Blickling Hall was the probable birthplace of Anne Boleyn (ca. 1500–36; ODNB), queen of England 1533–36; the Elizabethan building had been rebuilt in the early 17th century. Froude wrote on Anne Boleyn in his History of England; see 47:7TC to JAC, 14 May 1870, and 51–52TC to JAF, 14 Aug. 1870. and filled with nothing but the shadows of old principalities and powers,Cf. Eph. 6.12. from HaroldHarold II (ca. 1022–66; ODNB), king of England 1066, who had owned Blickling Hall. & Battle AbbeyBattle Abbey, Benedictine abbey built after the Battle of Hastings, 1066, to commemorate Harold’s fall, by William I (ca. 1027–87; ODNB), duke of Normandy, 1035–87, and king of England, 1066–87. After the dissolution of the monasteries in the sixteenth century, it became a private house; TC visited the area while staying at St. Leonards in 1864; see 40:101TC to JN, 18 May 1864. downwards: there I think one might have a still week of sunshine, quiet and sad musing. The only drawback is, uncertainty as to the means of getting towards Scotland out of Norfolk. At present the one possibility clear to me is that of coming back to London and starting afresh! That would be the chance upon Glenlyn for us: to have a little human talk and speculation in the shady woods there, and a dip in the sea, withal! We do not settle definitely till after another interview with Lady Gertrude, which takes place tomorrow. If we do go to Blickling we start on Saturday; and at any rate you will hear from us, either thence or from some other quarter within a few days. Esperons.

I altogether sympathize with what you say of poor Sam of Winchester;Samuel Wilberforce (1805–73; ODNB), bishop of Winchester 1869–73; he d., 19 July, after a riding accident nr. Dorking, Surrey. the event is fateful and tragical and altogether sadder to me than I could have expected. He was far from being a bad man; and was a most dexterous stout and clever one; and I have often exchanged pleasant dialogue with him for the last thirty years. Finished now, silent for all eternity. I find he was really of religious nature; and thought in secret in spite of his Bishophood very much in regard to religion as we do.— I was much astonished at Stephen’s Dundee
affair,Fitzjames Stephen had been advised by John Duke Coleridge, attorney general (see TC to JAC, 7 March), that if he stood for a parliamentary seat it would help his career. He went, 25 July, to contest a by-election in Dundee, standing as a Liberal candidate, against two other Liberal candidates, but lost. and cannot yet understand it, but only half understand it; wish, however, heartily he may get in since he has attempted it.
With all manner of friendly regards to every body at Glenlyn, especially to Madame and dear Rose.

closer.note: Allingham recorded in his diary “July 29.—Carlyle tells me he is ‘sitting’ to Whistler.
