If C. makes signs of changing his position W. screams out in an agonised tone, ‘For God’s sake, don’t move!’ C. afterwards said that all W.’s anxiety seemed to be to get the coat painted to ideal perfection; the face went for little. He had begun by asking two or three sittings, but managed to get a great many” (Allingham Diary 226–27). See also Wilson, Carlyle 6:297–98. James Abbott McNeill Whistler (1834–1903), American artist. Whistler’s official title of the portrait, “Arrangement in Grey and Black, No 2: Portrait of Thomas Carlyle,” confirms TC’s view that his coat was important; for the portrait, see 216. Whistler’s 1871 portrait of his mother, Anna McNeill Whistler (1804–81), was also called “Arrangement in Grey and Black,” with “No. 1” later added.

figure.p:
“Arrangement in Grey and Black, No. 2: Portrait of
Thomas Carlyle” by J. A. McNeill Whistler
D. A. Wilson and D. W. MacArthur, Carlyle in Old Age (London 1934)

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JF, 1 Aug. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd. Written in TC’s hand in blue pencil.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Thanks, dear F., for this kind act,Unexplained. —the thousand and first you have done me!—
We go, Mary & I, to Blickling, tomorrow, 10 a.m. Will write soon. Adieu, adieu to dear Madam & you,—T.C.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JF, 8 Aug. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd. Written on Blickling Hall headed notepaper in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p:
We arrived here on tolerable terms last Saturday; a very pretty, high-cultivated and yet wholesome looking and natural country, all this region; and Blickling itself the beautifullest old mansion I have ever seen, built by I
cannot learn what Architect, (about 1620);Blickling Hall was extensively rebuilt by Robert Lyminge (d. 1628), architect and carpenter, 1618–24, for Sir Henry Hobart (ca. 1554–1625; ODNB), lawyer and judge. The main door has “1620” carved on it. but certainly by an excellent noble human creature,—as far from the like of our friend Clutton as one human being cd be from another. The house contains all manner of beautiful antiquities, pictures &c, with a noble old library gathered and catalogued early in the last century by MattaireMichael Maittaire (1668–1747; ODNB), French classical scholar and bibliographer, friend of Sir Richard Ellys (1682–1742; ODNB), scholar and book collector. Elyss’s substantial library was transferred to Blickling Hall after his death; his chief cataloguer appears to have been John Mitchell (ca. 1685–1751), tutor, traveler, tour guide, antiquary, physician, and, in later years, librarian, secretary, and book-buying agent to Sir Richard Ellys. The catalogue is in ten large volumes, much of it in Mitchell’s hand; see Giles Mandelbrote and Yvonne Lewis, Learning to Collect; the Library of Sir Richard Ellys (1682–1742) at Blickling Hall (2004). & in which I am now reading pamphlets by Sir R. Steele & others (the South Sea Scheme,Sir Richard Steele (ca. 1672–1729; ODNB), writer and politician; his A Nation a Family: Being the Sequel of the Crisis of Property; or, a Plan for the Improvement of the South Sea Proposal (1720) was critical of the South Sea Company, a joint-stock company founded, 1711, and granted a monopoly to trade in the south Pacific, including South America. The price of South Sea stock increased dramatically, 1720, as a result of the company’s proposal, endorsed by Parliament, to assume the government’s debt; by Sept. of that year the market had collapsed and many investors were ruined. hitherto an inscrutable mystery to me);—the house, too, has the farther invaluable particularity that it is from end as quiet as Sahara, inhabited only by two of the gentlest young ladies,Lady Lothian and her sister Lady Gertrude Frances Chetwynd-Talbot; see TC to JAF, 30 July. one of them very handsome and both of them full of mild genial & noble and quietly noble qualities. All this you perceive is to be reckoned as clear good luck. For the first three nights I had indeed my considerable difficulties about sleep, but on the fourth night commenced a better course of adjustment, wh. promises now to continue. The weather night and day is exquisite. The woods are in all their beauty, the fields far and wide are a golden sea of wheat (excellent crop everywhere); in short no chance could be more perfect for lounging about and lying and walking and all forms of farniente [idleness], with book in hand or pipe in hand according to discretion. I do feel already perceptibly clearer and purer; but never in my life felt so weak, so skinless, vulnerable as a child of three years;—on the whole very greatly altered from what I was in Chelsea and one hopes altered for the better.

We have had ElwinWhitwell Elwin, rector of Booton, Norfolk, about 5 mi. (8 km.) SW of Blickling; he was a friend of Forster’s. here for a day and night, the excellent sagacious wholesome minded man, with whom a great deal of pleasant frank and solid
talk: evening before yesterday he with great and to us at the time useful kindness, carried Mary off with him and next day was at the pains to rush along with her from Norwich to YarmouthElwin took Mary to Booton, about 12 mi. (19 k.) NW of Norwich. Great Yarmouth, port on the E coast of Norfolk, about 14 mi. (21 k.) E. of Norwich and 33 mi. (53 km.) SE of Blickling. and back searching out to the practical bottom the conditions of the Yarmouth Steamers Northward and ascertaining the clear possibility of our getting to Newcastle by that method and thence in an easy five hours or more to Dumfries,—instead of jumbling back in a painful manner (as had seemed our only recourse) to Chelsea and thence taking a new departure. I really feel it a signal kindness on Elwin’s part and reckon it in great part to Forster and the pleasant hours I have spent with him there. I am really very thankful to him,—and design in future at least always to call him Elwin instead of Alwin which out of mistake or etymological considerations I have been in the habit of doing. We are to sail from Yarmouth on Wednesday evening next, hope to be in Newcastle about five the next day and thence home to Dumfries early next morning; that is the address from Wednesday next; and I need add no more in proof that our history has all gone well hitherto and points rather to some small profitable issue than the reverse.

It seems there was a letter from you to E[l]winMary omitted “l.” the other day; but no special details about the last days of your history since we parted. If you have a moment’s leisure and could write three lines upon that topic before the imminent Sea-journey it wd be very welcome. Do so if you can, dear F.;—and report if it be possible, as my hope steadily is that you are making progress, tho’ it were but slowly, in the right direction not in the wrong.Forster wrote, 9 Aug.: “What a mercy it was, dear Carlyle, that you got your most efficient little amanuensis up to the writing mark yesterday! … Your tidings of yourself have given insuperable delight here. … I have not myself been going on badly, but for the cough which is very unsparing.” Don’t work at your BookForster was writing the third volume of The Life of Dickens (1872–74). above a couple of hours daily; take every care of yourself and dear life companion for my sake and for everybody’s.
With many regards to Madam and you

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAF, 12 Aug. Pbd: Dunn, CLF 594–95. Written on Blickling Hall headed notepaper.
bibl.head: TC TO J. A. FROUDE

docBody.p: We have been here, Niece Mary and I, since Saturday week; and are to go tomorrow by Yarmouth to Newcastle, intending for Dumfries, where by programme we arrive on Friday afternoon. Our stay here has been of the most perfect style procurable on earth, of what may be called Elysian indolence; never before did I meet in the world such perfection of a Castle of Indolence.James Thomson (1700–48; ODNB), poet, The Castle of Indolence (1748); see 4:82TC to HCR, 25 April 1826. So beautiful an ancient palace standing entire, such beautiful silent woods in the brightness of summer weather; our sole company two Beings of the lovelier sex, Lady Lothian & Lady Gertrude her Sister (the invalid Lady ShrewsburyLady Sarah Elizabeth Chetwynd-Talbot, countess of Shrewsbury, an invalid who usually lived with one of her das. we never see, but only hear of as driving out with one of her daughters in the afternoon) who as you know are patterns of human courtesy and every species of kindly humanity;—plenty of tobacco too with liberty to smoke in all places: nothing on earth could in my broken state suit me better. The change accordingly in what I call my “health” has been for the time quite surprising, a change certainly for the better in some respects though whether in all or even on the whole I must wait for time to try. Tomorrow night at 9 we are to go on board a well reputed Steamer and enter on 48 hours of miscellaneous realities aquatic and terrestrial, which, were it possible, I would fain avoid; but these will tell me a more conclusive story.

But why wander further in this inane dialogue with you,—unhappily not to be carried on by word of mouth, but merely to the vain waste of time and paper? The essential thing I had to say is that o[u]r prospect of LynmouthFroude had invited TC to visit him on holiday at Lynmouth, Devon; see TC to JAF, 30 July; “o[u]r” thus in printed text. has sorrowfully faded into the vague (tho’ perhaps it still dimly remains as a shadow) the question of Scotch BathingTC had planned to go sea bathing with Jean and Mary Aitken on the Isle of Bute; see TC to Lady A, 6 July. too becomes problematic as I approach it; nothing certain ahead but that I must be in Edinburgh for one day. So soon as the heat has fairly gone, anchorage at Chelsea is the one thing ahead and a meeting with you once more in the end of September. I hope you will return with your book well forward! Do not neglect that: you were never on a wiser or usefuller bit of work.

Good be with you always, dear Froude, our kindest regards to Madam and to all your household,—especially to dear Rose,Froude’s da. Rose was an invalid; see TC to HF, 5 Dec. 1872. who we hope is prospering in the fine season.

bibl.sourceNote: MW-SW [SWA], 9 Sept. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd.
bibl.head: MARGARET WELSH TO SARAH WARREN

docBody.p: I was indeed glad to receive your note & to hear your good accounts of yourself, & of those around you. I know you will be pleased to hear of Mr Carlyle & perhaps Miss Aitken may not have had time herself to write. However you will no doubt have always been hearing from Mr Aitken,John Aitken, living in London. who I fancy will now be in Scotland for his holiday.

It was, as you can well believe, a very great pleasure to us to see Mr Carlyle here—my only one regret was that his visit was such a very short one, for we had always hoped he would stay some time with us if he found it quiet. He & Miss Aitken came to us on Monday last week, & those few days—until Friday—I really do hope he did find it quiet & pleasant; he slept so well every night, & during the day too at his usual hours; & his appetite too he said he found so much better, that I could not but feel that a longer stay would have done him real good. However he was very anxious, as you know well, to go & spend a day at Haddington (where she is buried),JWC’s grave in St. Mary’s Church, Haddington; see 43:236TC to WDO, 21 June 1866, and 241TC to JCA, 23 June 1866. & unfortunately we found on consulting the Railway books that it would be impossible to go from here & return here the same day; so as this obliged him to remain a night in Edinburgh he felt, I saw, a little afraid of the journey he would again have to make to Dumfries Shire on his way to Chelsea. He made up his mind therefore not to return here but to go straight to the Hill on Saturday, which he & Miss Aitken did on Saturday afternoon. I had hoped we might hear today of their safe arrival there, but tomorrow I quite trust will bring some word of them. Mr Carlyle was so very kind as to ask me to go with him, & you can well believe the real pleasure, though a sad one, it was to me to go with him to Haddington. Neither Miss Aitken nor I had ever been there before. I wish you could see the churchyard where Mrs Carlyle lies—it is a very beautiful spot, & all around the old Church is beautifully kept in order.

In Edinburgh Professor MassonTC stayed with Masson before his last visit to Haddington, Sept. 1870; see 47:55–56TC to DMA, [6 Sep. 1870]. had secured such quiet & most comfortable rooms, so the visit was a less formidable one than one could at all have hoped for. I do trust Mr Carlyle has not been the worse of all the fatigue. On Friday night he said he had slept really very well, & he looked wonderfully well that day when I parted from them on their way to the Station—I then went off to my StationTC’s and Mary’s train left from Caledonian Station, W end of Princes St., and Maggie’s train from North British Station, E end of Princes St. feeling very sorry to be returning here alone.
I know you will be glad to hear about Mr Carlyle. With kind regards dear Mrs Warren

closer.note: TC wrote later, 6 Dec.: “Friday 5 Septr, I was at the grave in Haddington, Had been at Blickling &c before; had to stay one night and most part of two days in Edinr, on that other enterprise whh I defined to myself as the one real errand I had in all that heavy-laden Tour. Left Burnfriar in abt a fortnight after,—much broken by the travelling hardships &c—and hurried straight home with the mournful thot ‘Empty House; empty but quiet, why shd I ever quit thee agn?’” (TC’s journal; privately owned). Burnfriar untraced; TC was staying at The Hill, Dumfries.

bibl.sourceNote: TC-EF, 13 Sept. MS: Trinity. Pbd: FitzGerald’s Letters 3:440–41 inc. Written on The Hill headed notepaper in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO EDWARD FITZGERALD

docBody.p:
There is something at once pathetic and ridiculous and altogether miserable and contemptible in the fact you at last announce that by one caprice and another of human folly perversity and general length of ear,Phrase referring to the long ears of a donkey, meaning stupid and obstinate. our poor little enterprize is definitely forbidden to us.TC and FitzGerald wanted to erect a monument at the actual site of the Battle of Naseby; see TC to EF, 15 June 1872, TC to EF, 7 Dec. 1872, and TC to CEN, 18 April. FitzGerald wrote to TC, 8 Sept.: “Enclosed is the Naseby Lawyer’s answer on behalf of the Naseby Trustees. I think it will seem marvellous in your Eyes, as it does in mine” (FitzGerald’s Letters 3:439). FitzGerald had been to Naseby to look at the spot late June; he wrote to a friend, [July]: “I have a Letter dictated by Carlyle, in which he approves of my Naseby Journey, but insists still on as near a specification as possible of the number of Yards where the Dead may be supposed to be buried. I tell him that he would only believe in one Grave when I had opened it; why should he believe in other Graves from Tradition? But he won’t alter, you know” (FitzGerald’s Letters 3:429). He also wrote to W. F. Pollock (see TC to EF, 15 June 1872), [July]: “I have been a wonderful Journey—for me—even to Naseby … to authenticate the spot where I dug up some bones of those slain there—for [Carlyle] thirty years ago. We are to put up a Stone there to record the fact, if we can get leave of the present Owners of the Field; a permission, one would think, easy enough to obtain; but I have been more than a Year trying to obtain it, notwithstanding; and do not know that I am nearer the point after all. The Owner is a Minor [Henry George Agar-Ellis (1863–95), 4th Viscount Clifden]: and three Trustees must sanction the thing for him; and these three Trustees are all great People, all living in different parts of England; and, I suppose, forgetful of such a little matter, though their Estate-agent, and Lawyer, represented it to them long ago” (FitzGerald’s Letters 3:431). Alas, our poor little “inscription,” so
far as I remember it, was not more criminal than that of a number on a milestone;—in fact the whole adventure was like that of setting up an authentic Milestone in a tract of country (spiritual and physical) mournfully in want of measurement; that was our highly innocent offer had the unfortunate Rulers of the Element in that quarter been able to perceive it at all! Well; since they haven’t one thing at least is clear that our attempt is finished, and that from this hour we will devoutly give it up.— That of shifting the now existing pyramid from Naseby Village and rebuilding it on BroadmoorBroad Moor, the actual site of the battle. FitzGerald continued, 8 Sept.: “You will see that I had suggested whether moving the Obelisk … might not be accomplished in case the Stone were rejected. … I cannot believe the Trustees would listen to this scheme any more than to the other. Nor do I suppose you would be satisfied with the foolish Obelisk’s Inscription, which warns Kings not to exceed their just Prerogative, nor Subjects their lawful obedience, etc., but does not say that it stands on the very spot where the Ashes of the Dead told of the final Struggle” (FitzGerald’s Letters 3:439). seems to me entirely inadmissable;—and in fact unless you yourself cd resolve, which I dont counsel, on marking, by way of foot-note, on the now existing pyramid, accurately how many yards off and in what direction the real battle ground lies from it? there is nothing visible to me which can without ridiculous impropriety be done.

The trouble and bother you have had with all this, which I know are very great, cannot be repaid you, dear old Friend, except by my pious thankfulness, which I can well assure you shall not be wanting. But actual money, much or little which the surrounding blockheads, connected with this matter have first and last cost you, this I do request that you will accurately sum up that I may pay the half of it, as is my clear debt and right.FitzGerald replied, 17 Sept.: “You give me too much thanks for the little Trouble I have taken. … And, as to halving my Expenses! Which have been simply so many sheets of Letter paper, so many Postage Stamps … and a very pleasant Journey to Naseby itself this summer, which really did me good. … This is positively all” (FitzGerald’s Letters 3:441). This I do still expect from you; after which Finis upon this matter for ever and a day.

I have suffered a great deal of misery in this confused of seven weeks; and have come to the conclusion that I ought never to attempt another.FitzGerald also wrote, 17 Sept.: “You make your old complaints about being away from home … but I do think you dictate as if you were well and strong” (FitzGerald’s Letters 3:441). Day after
tomorrow we rush off, my blithe little Niece and I, and hope to arrive at Chelsea with a speed of express train that same night, there to lie dormant. Good be ever with you, dear FitzGerald.

closer.salute: I am and remain / Yours truly,

bibl.sourceNote: TC-UC, 20 Sept. Pbd: Shepherd, Carlyle 2:301–302. This is presumably the “Falkirk man” referred to in TC to JAC, 20 Sept.; unidentified further.
bibl.head: TC TO UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p: Several weeks ago I received from you at Dumfries Herr Moser’s ingenious little book;Samuel Moser, Goethe’s zweiter Faust, oder der geöffnete Walpurgissack [Goethe’s Faust part 2] (Weissenburg, 1864). Samuel Moser, from Alsace, unidentified further. He wrote to TC, 18 Oct. 1873 (see vol. 49). which, in the hurries and confusions then about me, I neglected to acknowledge at the moment. Accept now my thanks for your kind punctuality in regard to that matter.

I have since deliberately read over Mr. Moser’s little book, with agreeable recognition of much talent, diligence and fine intellectual faculty in the same; but am sorry to report likewise (sorry in one sense, and yet relieved and gratified in another,) that I can find in those amazing footnotes of Mr. M. no clear credibility whatever, nor certainly the least explanation of anything that is mysterious in Faust, part II. or part I;—and indeed am astonished that a person of Mr. M.’s good sense and extensive information should have thought of representing Goethe’s high and clear mind as ever grovelling into those base and cynical provinces of human life, from which in all his other writings he is conspicuously, healthily and nobly free. In the final scenes of Faust, from p. 224 and onwards of Mr. Moser’s book, I have found the illustrations perfectly credible, and have gratefully accepted the elucidation they yield. His preliminary excerpts, his epilogue, and indeed all these portions of his book have been new and interesting to me: they have moreover led me into a renewed perusal of this Second Part of Faust, and into an examination for the first time (though hitherto with little profit) of what the German doctors have found good to utter on the subject; a process which is yet by no means concluded on my part.TC was reading widely about Faust; see TC to JAC, 20 Sept.

For all this I am clearly indebted to Mr. Moser; and I beg you will thank him very kindly for his goodness in sending me this book, the results of which may be of more advantage to me than we yet see; and which at any rate I cannot but accept as a proof of his kind regard.

closer.salute:
Believe me, Dear Sir,
Yours also with thanks,

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 20 Sept. MS: NLS 527.95. Quot: A. Carlyle, NL 2:298–99. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
You already know from Mary all of you that the Iron Devil carried us handsomely to London on Monday last15 Sept. John A. Carlyle replied, 21 Sept.: “Thanks for your long letter … & thank Mary too for her punctuality in writing immediately after your arrival in London. It was a great relief to us all to hear that you had got through the long journey so well & with so little trouble.” without the least mistake, and with considerably less of misery than I had anticipated,—nay less than I had lazily suffered in most of the few preceding days of mere torpor and do-nothingism. England was all very wet, seeming to grow wetter and wetter the farther South we went; indeed there was not much of rain, if we had the least cared for that, but the landscape everywhere had a drenched look in parts almost a swampish, the railway stations all lying miserably in dubs &c &c and till RugbyRugby, town in Warwickshire about 80 mi. (129 km.) NW of London. itself wet stooks standing visible whether farther south we cannot say, daylight having there left us. London itself was drooket and glarry as we splashed rapidly through it: but no 5 here was all as clean as new pins and (except for Mills the carpenter,Mills the carpenter unidentified further. who by some mistake had not quite finished his operations on a sofa here, but kept hammering for half an hour longer) all had a calmness and correct composure which was mournfully beautiful to me. Mary’s guidance of me through the transit and since and onwards has been what you may suppose it, mere kindness and affection. Unluckily, with all this, I got only half a sleep in my own welcome bed and was astonished and annoyed by various accursed sounds, miraculous intrusions of
chanticleerJohn replied: “We felt somewhat alarmed about the cock which had waked you the first morning after your arrival, but it seems now to be got rid of.” For TC’s horror of crowing cocks, see, for example, 14:49. and other phenomena;—of which I say nothing more except that they are all victoriously swept into the abyss again, and that last night, after five half failures I have at last got what may be called a good sound sleep again, and feel as if I had fairly got over the hill, and were to have plain stepping and some tolerable composure and perhaps even some improvement for the time next coming.

London is emptier than I almost ever saw it; next to no carriages on the streets, on the pavements, sparse straggles of specimens one has to reckon of the genus Snob, happily all unknown to me. One day Mr Ness the ArchitectWilliam Eden Nesfield; see TC to JF, 21 Aug. 1872. (if you remember him at Seaforth last year)TC and John stayed at Seaforth, 25 July–26 Aug. 1872. leapt from a Cab and ran to salute me face at first irrecognizable with sunburning, for the rest very civil and enquiring in a cordial tone about you. Another day in Piccadilly there suddenly stood beside me a younger unknown figure of Scotch accent, whom I cannot yet name to you, except as the Minister of some place near Kilwinning, who was once Tutor at poor Tom Spedding’s,John Sime (1837–1904), minister of Kilwinning, Ayrshire, 1864–66; he was previously tutor to Henry Anthony Spedding, son of TC’s old friend Thomas Story Spedding; see 42:133TC to JWC, 18 July 1865. he also lovingly enquired for you and hung along with me, rather encumbering my stroll, till in Regent St., I took shelter in a Chelsea Omnibus and got rid. These are the two only known figures I have yet seen on the streets or elsewhere. Forster I called upon, & he has called here; but we missed both times, and the proposed “dinner” on Sunday night had to be declined with civility and even secretly with horror. Froude I have not seen or heard of; didn’t call there yet, nor at Allinghams whom however I dimly understand to be in town, unless I preferred silence as hitherto. For the rest the days are oftenest really beautiful, brisk winds often enough with spotted sunshine, the clearest sleekest streets for promenading, seldom any considerable rain, except by night since we returned. I have also got a number of books, all the critical pamphlets about Goethe’s Faust that are in the Library, and have sent for the others while diligently reading those on hand. Except Falk,Johannes Daniel Falk (1768–1826), German writer, philanthropist, and friend of Goethe, author of Goethe aus näherm persönlichen Umgange dargestellt [Goethe portrayed from personal circumstances] (Leipzig, 1832). Sarah Austin (1793–1867; ODNB), TC’s old friend, trans. Falk’s book as Characteristics of Goethe, from the German of Falk, von Muller, &c. (1833); see 6:242TC to JSM, 16 Oct. 1832, and 272TC to JAC, 2 Dec. 1832. who treats of Goethe generally those latter are all decidedly rather stupid;—but I feel not yet to have done with Faust, part II, nor probably shall have decided for some little while. I wrote to Moser and the Falkirk manFor Samuel Moser and the “Falkirk man,” see TC to UC, 20 Sept. this morning; them I have at least finished.— I wish you would
as minutely tell me, dear Brother, what you are doing; though this is a very dull account I give you.

Inclosed is a rational kind of letter from Leighton,Presumably Sir Baldwyn Leighton. probably worth your reading: please to return it when you write next. The letter forwarded yesterday from Dumfries was some beggarly tag rag about an Autograph which is ended this day.Unidentified further. That of autographs is truly a characteristic, and a highly sordid one, of the humour of young people of this day.

I hope you are a little better than when I left you; and that rigorous attention to diet exercise &c will soon bring you round to the old pitch. I also with much earnestness recommend some translation from the Icelandic or other light work which, far from burdening one’s weak life would, as I know by long experience, sensibly steady and cheer and alleviate it.John replied: “I feel rather better in regard to health, especially sleep, & have not had any very bad night since the Sunday before you started for Chelsea. … I have looked … into some of my Icelandic books and will consider what you advise about translating some of them. … I too know by experience how beneficial it is to have some fixed work from day to day in which one can make progress, instead of mere reading without purpose of actually turning it to account.” Let me beg of you to think seriously of this, and take it as sound advice from your elder Brother. Write to me soon, and as much at large as you can; for I should like well to know, as lucidly as possible, how you and all the rest of you are getting on.

We expect JohnTheir nephew John Aitken, who had been on holiday in Scotland; see MW to SW, 9 Sept. in about a week and send him our united regards. Give my particular remembrances to James,Their brother-in-law James Aitken. who, alas, cannot lend me his umbrella tomorrow or try walking with me again. My kindest love to Jean and the two good lassies.Anne and Margaret Aitken.
docBody.closer: Dear Brother / Your ever affectionate / T. Carlyle

postscript.p: Ps. Mme VenturiEmilie Venturi. who was here last night very pressingly wants to see those pamphlets of Ruskins’s about the Robin & the Swallow,John replied: “By this post I send the two parts of ‘Love’s Meinie’ which I have read a second time & like better than I did at first.” Ruskin’s Love’s Meinie. Lectures on Greek and English Birds Lectures 1 and 2 (1873). wh. you read without much caring for them. Please send them hither by post; and they shall be returned (Mary undertakes whenever you require them, or even sooner!— (Mary sends her love to all)

bibl.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 27 Sept. MS: NLS 527.96. Hitherto unpbd. Written in Mary Aitken’s hand, with TC’s signature.
bibl.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Before the week end I must send you a word;—and unluckily it must be a very brief one, such the poor fettle I am in. In fact it will be pretty much the only thing I manage to get done today; and the hour for walking out is near come. My prophecies of last week have only in part fulfilled themselves: yet in part they have. I have got completely freed from noises in my bedroom;See TC to JAC, 20 Sept. am as free from noises there as if I were in the heart of the wilderness of Ziph;Wilderness of Ziph in the mountains of Judaea, where David hid from Saul; see 1 Sam. 23:14–15. —and that is really a great conquest to me, properly the only one I have yet made; every night too I get some kind of sleep, often of the muddiest vilest quality but still sleep of some kind. Only my digestive faculty seems altogether gone; wretched stomach dragging me down all day, as if into utter wreck,—scarcely ever in my life have I felt so utterly powerless. Nevertheless I steadily keep hoping that, were this fit past, I shall get into my old poor track again, and live with a little less burden tied to my heels than now. So let us say no more about it; only strive to keep out of the “waes of war”Cf. Hector McNeil (1746–1818), The Waes o’ War or, the Upshot o’ the History o’ Will and Jean (Edinburgh, 1796). in time coming!—

The weather in general is good and fine for the season; thick fog indeed till about 10 oclock, then gradual brightening up, till at three or four when one goes out, all is bright as diamonds, fallen utterly silent too, and the grass in garden or park still of emerald greenness only the trees beginning to look a little woebegone, and take on their funerial colours. Nobody is yet, not even Allingham, come to town; but both Froude and he are expected early next week: in truth I cannot much say I would long to hasten their or anybody’s arrival till once I have got a little to my balance again. Forster I saw on Sunday last and walked back with him to his house. He seems very heavy laden dispirited and suffering poor good soul; but I still persu[a]deOmitted on MS. myself he is struggling out of the mass of ailments he has long had. With the Dickens’s Life he proceeds daily; writing down in detached patches whatever has grown clear to him, but never yet having fairly started the beginning. He “must and will at all rates finish in 1 vol.” Mrs F., good helpful being, is fairly better than usual, which doubtless is a great alleviation to poor F.

We got your letter last Tuesday, and read it with great satisfaction. What a deliverance to have got into your old state of health, or to be steadily hoping to get, which means into your old element and the things you had got accustomed to and reconciled to; instead of their still uglier, and unknown successors! I am very glad to hear also that you go down nightly and read a chaunt of the Odessy;John A. Carlyle wrote, 21 Sept., that he was reading aloud “our Book of Cowper’s translation of the Odyssey which seems to give great satisfaction.” William Cowper (1731–1800; ODNB), poet, The Iliad and Odyssey of Homer, translated into English Blank Verse, 2 vols. (1791). which will be cheering both to yourself and to the winsome lassiesTheir nieces Anne and Margaret Aitken. busy with their needles; and ‘twere a pity you should give that up and not rather persevere (Iliad, Aeneid, Milton &c &c there is plenty of store) till you had made it an institution of the house and a thing expected as the lighting of the lamps! I hope also you will fall to your Icelandic translation; nothing cd be more medicinal to the weary wandering mind. I myself have by no means given up my thoughts of something similar but for want of books hitherto, in effect I believe, from the chaotic state of the London Library, I cannot yet get any of the things I had in view begun;—& am yet only haggling in the outskirts; still hoping not quite to break down— Tomorrow forenoon we expect JohnJohn Aitken. and to hear minutely of all yr doings. Mary is powerfully busy, and going on victoriously with her bits of Songs.Mary Aitken was compiling a volume of Scottish songs, which was to be published, autumn 1874, as Scottish Song A Selection of the Choicest Lyrics of Scotland (1874). She included “Come under my plaidie,” a song by Hector MacNeil (see above). We send to you all, our best blessings, both of us;—and, alas, as you see are obliged to endFrom “alas,” the letter was written on the margin and the top of the first page. were there only one reason instead of many; Adieu, dear Brother,

div1.p: Betty Braid’s narrative about Dr. John Welsh’s death on 19 Sept. 1819 was told to David Davidson early 1872. We give it as Davidson reported it; although mainly given in Scots, he anglicized some of the words. For convenience we gloss some of the Scots words in the text rather than in the index.

bibl.sourceNote: Betty Braid on Dr. John Welsh’s Death [DJWD], early 1872. Pbd: David Davidson, Memories of a Long Life (Edinburgh, 1890) 323–24. For the context of Davidson’s report of Betty’s narrative, see TC to DD, 22 Feb. 1872. For JBW’s letters around the time of Dr. John Welsh’s death from typhus, 19 Sept. 1819, see TC to JBW, 15 Nov. 1824, and JBW to TC, 18 Nov. [1824]; for TC’s note about the death, see TC to JBW, 15 Nov. 1824. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 1 Jan. 1872.]
bibl.head: BETTY BRAID ON DR. JOHN WELSH’S DEATH

docBody.p:
It was in the beginning of 1872 that I found myself at the door of old Betty’s “poor cottage at Greenend.” Betty opened to my knock, and exclaimed, “Eh, Maister Davidson!” I was soon seated beside her in her tidy little room, and deep in the memories of auld lang syne. Among other subjects we came upon Dr. Welsh. She said, in reference to his regard for religion, “Some folk didna think sae muckle o’ the Doctor, but I thought a hantle [good deal] o’ him. Ye see, when he got auld, he didna tak’ the lang rides he used to tak’, but he got a kerridge; and just aboot that time I was takin’ in a Bible an’ commentary in pairts,—that’s it on the table there,—and as the Doctor gaed his veesits, mony a read he had o’t. I mind as weel as yesterday his sayin’, as he cam’ thro’ the kitchen to the kerridge, ‘Betty, could ye obleege me wi’ a bit o’ yer Bible?’ Says I, ‘What pairt wad ye like, Doctor?’ says he,—for the Doctor was aye very pelite,—‘Weel, Betty, if it’s quite convenient for you, I wad like a bit o’ the Gospel o’ John!’ Ay! He was fond o’ the Bible.” Then I was telling how I remembered that solemn Sabbath morning when he died, which led her to go into the circumstances of his illness and death. “Ye see,” said she, “the Doctor was a regular man in his habits. He used to come hame at four o’clock, an’ tak’ a bath before his denner; but yae Thursday he cam’ hame, an’ took neither his bath nor his denner, but gaed straight to his naked bed. The next day he was in a high fever, an’ word was sent to Edinburgh for a grand doctor (Hamilton,Dr. James Hamilton Sr. (1749–1835; ODNB; see 6:319TC to JAC, 10 Feb. 1833); JWC continued to consult him when she visited Edinburgh, Jan.–May 1833; see 6:299TC to MAC, 12 Jan. 1833.
I think he was ca’ed), and he cam’ wi’ his cocket hatTC described him, Jan. 1833: “a notable man here, called cockie Hamilton, for he still wears a cocked hat; and is indeed quite an old-fashioned person”; see 6:297TC to MAC, 12 Jan. 1833. an’ gold-headed stick, an’ had a lang consultation wi’ Dr. Howden.Dr. Thomas Howden (1787–1868; see 37:26837:biographical notes), Dr. John Welsh’s partner in Haddington; see 3:352JBW to GW, 19 July 1825. Whan it was ower, he cam’ thro’ the kitchen, for that was the nearest way to the kerridge. Mrs. Welsh was wi’ him, wi’ a bottle in her han’, for she wanted to gie him a glass o’ wine, but we couldna find the screw; so she just took a knife an nicket aff the head o’ the bottle. As he was takin’ the wine, he saw I was lookin’ at him, an’ he said, ‘Ow, he’ll get roon [round], he’ll get roon!’ But he didna get roon ava [at all], for the next day he was waur [worse], an’ on the Sabbath morning he was sae bad they put a laddie on a horse to ride to Edinburgh for the doctor, but before the laddie was weel awa’, the breath gaed clean oot o’ him! There was deid silence in the hoose for aboot half an oor, an’ the first that brak it was Miss Jean. She was sitting on the stair, when up she got wi’ a scream, an’ cried, ‘I maun see my father!’ an’ rushed to the locked door o’ his room; but, before she could open it, Dr. Howden gat her in his airms, an’ she fainted clean awa’. He carried her through the drawing-room, ye ken, to the little bedroom aff it, an’ laid her on the bed beside her puir mother that was lying there in a deid swoon; an’ there they were, like twa deid corpses! Eh, but it was waefu’! I thocht I wad look in an’ say a word, whan the mistress brak oot into sic a fit o’ greetin’ I thocht she wad break her heart. So I went to Dr. Howden an’ telled him to come an’ see her, for I thocht she wad dee, but he said, ‘Oh, Betty, I’m gled o’t, for it’s juist the best thing that could happen to her;’ an’ he only wished Miss Jean could get a gude greet too.” Such was Betty’s account of this tragic event, which cast a gloom over the whole town and countryside. After a little I said to Betty, “Suppose we read a bit out of this same Gospel of John, that the Doctor was so fond of;” and, taking the same Bible off the round table, I turned to the 17th chapter, and read that wonderful prayer, in which our Lord gives vent to the pent-up feelings of His heart;See John 17. Betty now and again making her remarks on the love of Christ to “pair sinners.” “Neither pray I for these only, but for them also that shall believe on Me through their word!” “Aye, Maister Davidson, to think that He prayed for you an’ me!”

div1.p: Adamson, Samuel (1831–80), of British Linen Co. bank, Dumfries, where TC had an account; son of Robert Adamson (1787–1861; see 10:23TC to JA, 14 Feb. 1838, and 37:26137:biographical notes).
Agnew; see Ruskin.
Airlie; see Stanley.

Aitken, James Jr. (1836–20 Sept. 71), son of Jean and James; he worked in a mercantile house in London 1858–ca. 1864, moved to work in Liverpool 1864–66, tried to establish himself as a shipbroker on his own in London 1866–67, then went back to work in Liverpool: “salary £400 & work easy & interesting for him” (JAC to TC, 27 Dec. 1868; MS: NLS 1775C.296); he lived at 29 Rock Terrace, Claughton, Birkenhead (across the river Mersey from Liverpool).

Aitken, Jean (“Craw”) Carlyle (1810–88), TC’s sister; m.,1833, James Aitken (1809–87) from Troqueer, housepainter of English St., Dumfries; they moved from Assembly St., Dumfries, to their new house, The Hill, Lochmaben Rd., Dumfries, 1863. They had two sons who d. in infancy (1834–36 and 1855–56), both named Alexander; James Jr. (see above); Thomas (1841–69), who was at an inst. for the deaf in Glasgow from 1854 (see 29:186TC to WAWI, 4 Nov. 1854), then lived at home from ca. 1864; and John (1843–1911), bank clerk at the Commercial Bank, Dumfries, then moved to London, Sept. 1871, working for Chapman & Hall. Their das. were Anne (1839–1919), Margaret (1845–1932), and Mary (see below).

Aitken, Mary (1848–95), worked as a pupil-teacher in Peebles, March–Sept. 1867, then returned home. She then accompanied TC to London, Sept. 1868, “for about three weeks,” but stayed for more than three years. She continued to live in London, though not always living at Cheyne Row, and to help TC. She m., 1879, her cousin Alexander Carlyle.

Alford, Marianne Margaret Egerton, b. Compton (1817–88; ODNB), Viscountess Alford, known as Lady Marian Alford; art patron and writer
on needlework; widow of John Hume Cust, later Egerton (1812–51), Viscount Alford; they had two sons, John William Spencer Brownlow Egerton-Cust (1842–67), 2d Earl Brownlow, and Adelbert Wellington Brownlow Cust (1844–1921), 3d Earl Brownlow, whom Tyndall described: “a finer specimen of physical manhood I thought I had never before seen” (Tyndall, “Personal Recollections” 22). He m., 1868, Lady Adelaide, b. Chetwynd-Talbot (1844–1917) (for her sisters, see Lothian, below). They lived at 11 Princes Gate, Kensington, Ashridge House, Hertfordshire, and Belton House, Grantham, Lincolnshire.

Allingham, William (1824–89; ODNB), Irish poet; he worked in the Customs Service 1846–70; friendly with TC since early 1850s. He lived at 131 Piccadilly. He m., 1874, Helen Mary Elizabeth, b. Paterson (1848–1926; ODNB), watercolorist; she later painted portraits of TC; she also compiled the list of pictures for Carlyle’s House Catalogue.
Amberley; see Stanley.

Ashburton, Lady Louisa Caroline, b. Stewart-Mackenzie (1827–1903), m., 1858, William Bingham Baring (1799–1864; ODNB; see 11:40 TC to MAC, 8 March 1839 , and later vols.), 2d Baron, politician, and partner in Baring Bros., bankers. They had one da., Mary Florence (1860–1902). Lady Louisa was the da. of Mary Elizabeth Frederica, b. Mackenzie (1783–1862; ODNB), chief of Clan Mackenzie, and James Alexander Stewart (1784–1843); on their marriage(1817) the name Mackenzie was added to that of Stewart. Lady Ashburton was building a new house for herself in London, Kent House; she also owned Melchet Court (see 38:8JWC to LA, [11 Nov. 1861]), a country house 6 mi. (9.5 km.) W of Romsey, Hampshire, on the border between Hampshire and Wiltshire, a farm at Addiscombe, near Croydon, and Seaforth Lodge, Devon. Lord Ashburton’s first wife, m. 1823, was Harriet, b. Montagu (1805–57; ODNB; see 11:40TC to MAC, 8 March 1839, and 26:ix–xv26:introduction); they met the Carlyles in 1839 and became close friends. Where necessary for clarity, we refer in notes to Lord Ashburton’s first and second wives as Lady Harriet Ashburton and Lady Louisa Ashburton respectively, although these are not the correct forms.

Austin, Mary Carlyle (1808–88), TC’s sister, m., 1831, James Austin (1805–78), farmer of The Gill, 6 mi. (9.5 km.) SW of Ecclefechan. They had eight das.: Margaret (see Stewart); Grace (1833–1922), who m., 1856, William Yeoward (ca. 1824–1911), of Toronto, Ontario; Jessie (b. 1836), who m., 1859, George Grierson (b. 1835); Jane (b. 1840); Mary Anne (b. 1842); Catherine (see James Carlyle Jr.); Isabella (b. ca. 1846); and Mary Carlyle (b. 1851); and one surviving son, James Jr. (b. 1848).

Baillie, James Augustus (1799–March 1873), impoverished cousin of JWC’s mother, and his wife, Anna-Maria (1812–after 1876); they had lived in Dover (see 39:136–37JWC to BB, 22 May [1863]), but by the 1871 census they were living at 12 Caroline St., London.
Baring; see Ashburton.
Bismarck, Otto von (1815–98), chancellor of the North German Confederation 1867–71, chancellor of the German Empire 1871–90.
Blackie, John Stuart (1809–95; ODNB), classical and Scottish Gaelic scholar, prof. of Greek at Edinburgh Univ. from 1852; m., 1842, Eliza, b. Wyld (1819–1908).

Braid, Betty, b. Pringle (1795–1875), Grace Welsh’s Haddington servant, close to JWC (see 21:82JWC to JW, 30 Oct. 1846, and 24:221JWC to TC, [5 Sep. 1849]); b. in Prestonkirk, E. Lothian; m. Alexander (1792–1874), stonemason and shopkeeper. Three sons d. in infancy: Alexander (b. 1826), James (b. 1829), and James (b. 1831); George (1827–65) was the only child who survived into adulthood. Previously living at 15 Adam St. (see 17:127TC to JWC, 12 Sep. 1843), they moved, 1858, to Upper Stenhouse, Greenend, Liberton, S Edinburgh.

Bromley, Caroline Davenport (1820–91), da. of Rev. Walter Davenport Bromley (1787–1862) of Wootton Hall, Staffordshire, and his first wife, m., 1818, Caroline Barbara, b. Gooch (1791–1827). A friend of Lady Louisa Ashburton, she became a close friend of JWC’s; she was now friendly with TC. Her London home was at 32 Grosvenor St.
Brookfield, William Henry (1809–74; ODNB), clergyman and school inspector, known to TC since 1841.
Brownlow; see Alford.
Browning, Robert (1812–89; ODNB), poet; friend of the Carlyles since mid-1830s.
Burgess, Andrew Hutton (b. 1835), b. Dumfriesshire, graduated Edinburgh Univ. 1857, journalist, lodging at 36 Park Walk, Chelsea.

Carlyle, Alexander (Alick) (1797–1876), TC’s brother; he m., 1830, Janet, b. Clow (1809–91), and immigrated with his family to Canada, 1843. They settled at the Bield, 4½ mi. (7 km.) W of Brantford, Ontario. They had nine surviving children. Jane Welsh (1831–84), m., 1852, Robert Sims (1825–80); they had four children, Alexander (1855–1922), Thomas (1856–1934), Jessie (b. ca. 1859), and John (b. ca. 1862). Thomas (1833–1921), m., 1867, Margaret, b. MacVicar (1847–1917); they had at least seven children, including Thomas Alexander (1869–70), and Hellen (b. ca. Dec. 1870). Janet (Jessie) (1836–1916), m., 1864, William Apps (1834–1911), miller from Ontario; they had at least five children, including Jessie (b. ca. 1867), Alfred (b. ca. 1870), and a da. (b. ca. Jan. 1872) [“Jessie has another daughter two months old I am sorry they are living so far from us” (JH-JAC, 7 March 1872; MS: NLS 1775E.125)]. John (1839–1924), moved to Brantford and became a carpenter, 1870, m., 1871, Helen, b. McVicar (1851–1927). Alexander (see below). James (1846–1924). Margaret (1847–1935), m. Edward Marrs (d. 1927), widower from Okmulgee, Oklahoma; see 1:166TC to AC, 23 Feb. 1819. William (1849–1935). Robert (1851–1932). An unidentified
son (1832–33), Margaret (1835–36), James (b. 1840), and Euphemia (1853–54) all d. in infancy; see 32:4TC to AC, 3 Oct. 1856.

Carlyle, Alexander (Alick) (1843–1931; see 16:153TC to AC, 4 May 1843), Alexander and Janet’s son, school headmaster; m., 1879, his cousin Mary Aitken; lived with TC from 1879 and ed. various collections of the Carlyles’ letters and TC’s writings. After Mary’s death he m. Lillias, b. MacVicar (d. 1929), sister of the wives of his brothers Tom and John.

Carlyle, James (Jamie) (1805–90), TC’s brother, farmer at Scotsbrig; m., 1834, Isabella, b. Calvert (ca. 1813–59). Their children were James Jr. (see below); John (see below); Thomas (1839–41); and Janet (Jenny) (see Scott).

Carlyle, James Jr. (1835–88 [mistakenly given as 1871 in previous vols.]), James and Isabella’s son, m., 1866, his cousin Catherine, b. Austin (1844–1908); see 44:64TC to JCA, [6 Oct.] 1866. Their first child, James d. at birth 1867; they had nine further children, including Isabella (1868–post-1901), and Mary (b. March 1871). They lived at Craigenputtoch, the tenancy of which had been taken on jointly by James and his father, June 1867; see 44:196TC to JAC, 11 May 1867.

Carlyle, John (ca. 1792–5 Nov. 1872), TC’s half-brother; immigrated to the U.S. in 1837, then moved to Canada (see 12:228TC to AC, 15 Aug. 1840); he lived on a small farm at Mount Pleasant, nr. Brantford, Ontario. He m., 1817, Margaret (Peggy), b. Benn (1798–1867); they had six children: Janet (1818–89), m., 1844, John Randall Ellis (1810–1911), postmaster and carpenter; Mary (1821–50); John (1825–26); John (1827–97), m., ca. 1852, Mary Catherine, b. Smith (1835–79); James (1830–1900), qualified as a doctor but worked for most of his life as a teacher, m. Wilhelmina Deborah, b. Patten (1847–1926); and William (1833–1911), a teacher and later a school inspector, m., 1860, Emily b. Youmans (1835–1912), their da., Florence Emily Carlyle (1864–1923), became a prominent Canadian artist. William visited TC in London, Aug. 1864.

Carlyle, John Aitken (Jack, “The Doctor”) (1801–79; ODNB), TC’s brother, physician, and translator. He m., 1852, Phoebe Elizabeth Hough Watt, b. Fowler (1810–54), wealthy widow of Fitzjames Watt (1809–48), from Leek in Staffordshire, with four sons; she d. in childbirth, the child was stillborn. John A. Carlyle assumed responsibility for his stepsons: Thomas Fowler (1838–62), went to Australia, 1861, and d. on his return (see 38:115TC to JWC, 2 July 1862); Henry (1839–1913), at sea from 1854 (see 29:219TC to EE, 22 Dec. 1854), later master mariner and shipowner; he m., 1863, Jane Wilson, b. Hunter (1837–1908), da. of John A. Carlyle’s friend John Hunter (1801–69; see 8:161TC to MAC, 1 July 1835) and Helen, b. Vary (1804–85), they lived in Liverpool; Arthur Chorley (1840–85), joined the civil service 1862, and was currently an Assistant Judge in Poona, India; he m., 1869, Henrietta Vary, b. Hunter (b. 1846), younger da. of John and Helen Hunter; and William (b. 1842), an officer in the Dragoons, m.,
1866, Mary, b. Smith, da. of E. H. Smith of Grouville, Jersey.

Carlyle, John Calvert (1836–1901), James and Isabella’s son, m., 1868, Margaret Little, b. Murray (1848–92), of Blackwood Ridge, Middlebie; they lived at Scotsbrig with his father; they had 13 children, including Isabella Calvert (1869–1915), Elisabeth Carruthers (1870–1947), and James (1872–1931).
Carlyle, Margaret, b. Aitken (1771–1853), TC’s mother; TC’s father was James Carlyle (1758–1832); they m. 1795.

Chapman, Frederic (1823–95; ODNB), partner in Chapman & Hall publishers, took over the management of the company 1864; he m., 1861, Clara, b. Woodin (1842–66), they had one surviving son, Frederic, and a baby who d. early 1866. He then m., autumn 1870, Annie Marion, b. Harding (b. 1848), da. of Robert Palmer Harding (see below).

Christie, William Dougal (1816–74; ODNB), diplomat and author; known to TC since 1840; see 12:56TC to WDC, [26 Feb. 1840]; see also 44:67–68TC to JAC, 10 Oct. 1866. He m., 1841, Mary, b. Grant (1819–1908), they had several children, including Mary Elizabeth Christie (1847–1906), novelist.
Clutton, Henry (1819–93; ODNB), architect; he converted to Roman Catholicism in 1857.
Conway, Moncure Daniel (1832–1907), American Unitarian minister; came to Britain, 1863, with an introduction to Carlyle from Emerson; see 39:114TC to JAC, 29 April 1863.
Cowper, Henry Frederick (1836–87), M.P. for Hertfordshire 1865–85, brother of Francis Cowper (1834–1905), 7th Earl Cowper.
Cunningham, Wilhelmina (1793–1875), living at 60 Irish St., Dumfries; the Cunningham family had known the Carlyles since the 1820s; see 46:109–10TC to JCA, 16 Nov. 1869.
Darwin, Erasmus (1804–81), friendly with the Carlyles since 1835; his brother was Charles Darwin (1809–82; ODNB), naturalist and geologist.
Davidson, David (1811–1900), army engineer and inventor, childhood friend of JWC’s; see 35:25535:biographical notes; see also 46:192TC to DD, 7 April 1870.

Derby, Edward Henry Stanley (1826–93; ODNB), 15th earl of; politician and diarist; m., 1870, Mary Catherine, b. Sackville-West (1824–1900; ODNB), dowager marchioness of Salisbury, widow of James Gascoyne-Cecil (1791–1868), 2d marquess of Salisbury.

Dickens, Charles (1812–70; ODNB), novelist; friend of the Carlyles since the early 1840s; m., 1836, Catherine Thomson, b. Hogarth (1816–79), separated from her in 1858; see 33:233TC to RWE, 2 June 1858. Catherine’s sister Georgina Hogarth (1827–1917; ODNB), became Dickens’s close friend and companion.
Disraeli, Benjamin (1804–81; ODNB), politician and author; prime minister 1868 and 1874–80.

Duffy, Charles Gavan (1816–1903; ODNB), Irish nationalist, lawyer, and politician,
friend of TC’s since 1845. He m., 1847, Susan, b. Hughes (1826–78); they immigrated to Australia 1855.
Durival; see Otthenin.
Elwin, Whitwell (1816–1900; ODNB), clergyman and editor; rector of Booton, Norfolk, 1849–1900, and ed. of the Quarterly Review, 1853–60. He was an old friend of John Forster’s.

Emerson, Ralph Waldo (1803–82; see 6:425TC to JAC, 27 Aug. 1833), philosopher, essayist, poet, and transcendentalist. He first met TC in Aug. 1833; in spite of their differences they had close ties; he introduced many Americans to TC and played a leading part in arranging the publication of TC’s works in the U.S. Emerson m., 1835, as his second wife, Lydian, b. Jackson (1802–92); their children were Waldo (1836–42), Ellen Tucker (1839–1909), Edith (see Forbes), and Edward Waldo (1844–1930), m., 1874, Annie Shephard Keyes (1847–1928).

Erskine, Thomas (1788–1870; ODNB; see 10:18TC to JAC, 1 Feb. 1838), theologian and retired advocate, living at Linlathen, Dundee; known to the Carlyles since the mid-1830s. He had had two widowed sisters: Christian Stirling (1789–1866), m., 1817, Charles Stirling (d. 1830); she had lived with Erskine, during the winter they had usually lived in Edinburgh; and David Paterson (1791–1867), m., 1821, Capt. James Paterson (1795–1856); she had lived with her son, James Erskine Paterson (1826–88) and his family at 8 Newbattle Terr., Morningside; he took “Erskine” as his surname on inheriting from Thomas Erskine (see 47:181TC to JAC, 25 March 1871), but may not have done so formally; his death certificate was in the name of Paterson.
FitzGerald, Edward (1809–83; ODNB), writer and translator, TC’s friend since 1842.

Forbes, Edith, b. Emerson (1841–1929), da. of Ralph Waldo Emerson, m., 1865, William Hathaway Forbes (1840–97), businessman; they were to have eight children, including Ralph Emerson (1866–1937), Edith (1867–1926), William Cameron (1870–1959), and John (1871–88).

Forster, John (“Fuz”) (1812–76; ODNB; see 6:118TC to GE, 15 Feb. 1832, and 11:7TC to JF, [25 Jan. 1839]), historian, journalist, and biographer; ed. of the Examiner 1847–55; sec., 1855–61, and commissioner, 1861–72, of the Lunacy Commission; friend of the Carlyles since the late 1830s and TC’s literary adviser. He m., 1856, Eliza Ann, b. Crosbie (ca. 1819–94), widow of the publisher Henry Colburn (ca. 1784–1855; ODNB); from late 1863 they lived at Palace Gate House, Kensington.
Frankau; see Neuberg.

Froude, James Anthony (1818–94; ODNB), journalist and historian, ed. of Fraser’s Magazine 1860–74; he m., first, 1849, Charlotte Maria, b. Grenfell (1812–60); they had two das., Georgina Margaret (1850–1935) and Rose Mary (1852–75), and a son, Pascall Grenfell (1854–79). He m.,
second, 1861, Henrietta Elizabeth, b. Warre (1824–74); they had a son, Ashley Anthony (1863–1949), and a da., May (1867–1906). They lived at 5 Onslow Gdns., Fulham Rd.
Gladstone, William Ewart (1809–98; ODNB), politician; leader of the liberal party 1867–94, prime minister 1868–74, 1880–85, 1886, 1892–94. He m., 1839, Catherine, b. Glynne (1812–1900; ODNB).
Gordon, John (1797–1882; see 43:44TC to JAC, 22 Nov. 1865), inspector of schools, old friend of both TC and John A. Carlyle.

Hanning, Janet Carlyle (1813–97), TC’s sister; m., 1836, Robert Hanning (1796–1878), who had immigrated to Canada in mysterious disgrace in 1841; she joined him in Hamilton, Ontario, Aug. 1851, with their two das., Margaret (b. 1838), and Mary (b. 1840), who m., 1864, Charles Coates Holden (b. 1836) and they had at least two das., Jenny (d. Dec. 1870 [JH to JAC, 5 Jan. 1871; MS: NLS 1775E.7]) and Jane. Janet and Robert had two more das., b. in Canada: Catherine (b. ca. 1852), school teacher, and Jane.
Harding, Robert Palmer (1821–93; ODNB), head of a London accounting firm. See also Chapman.
Hayward, Abraham (1801–84; ODNB), essayist and journalist.
Hogarth; see Dickens.

Hosmer, Harriet (1830–1908), American sculptor. Lady Ashburton had first met her in Rome in 1867 (see Surtees, Ludovisi 130–31) and they became close friends. TC also met her in 1867; see 45:58TC to FC, 31 Oct. 1867; for his view of her then, see 45:63TC to SWA, 8 Nov [1867].

Houghton, Richard Monckton Milnes (1809–85; ODNB), 1st Baron, author and politician; friend of the Carlyles since the late 1830s; m., 1851, Annabella, b. Hungerford Crewe (1814–74), they had two das. and a son; see 37:27037:biographical notes.
Howard; see Stanley.
Huxley, Thomas Henry (1825–95; ODNB), biologist and educational theorist.
Irving, Edward (1792–1834; ODNB; see 1:92TC to RM, 2 Feb. 1817, later vols., and Carlyle, Reminiscences), the Carlyles’ great friend; religious leader and preacher.

Jewsbury, Geraldine Endsor (1812–80; ODNB; see 12:103–4TC to GEJ, 12 April 1840), novelist, reviewer, and misc. writer; friend of the Carlyles, particularly of JWC’s, since 1841. She lived at 41 Markham Sq., Chelsea.

Laing, David (1793–1878; ODNB), antiquary; librarian of the Signet Lib., Edinburgh, 1837–78. When TC became rector of Edinburgh University, 1866, he chose Laing as his assessor on the Senatus Academicus. Laing’s youngest sister, Euphemia (1808–96), lived with him as his housekeeper after the death of their mother, Helen, b. Kirk (1767–1837); since 1845 they had lived in East Villa, 12 James St., Portobello (see 43:122TC to JRU, 14 Feb. 1866).

Lecky, William Edward Hartpole (1838–1903; ODNB; see 44:97TC to JAC, 28 Nov. 1866), historian, m., 1871, Catharina Elisabeth Boldewina, b. Baroness van Dedem (1842–1912), writer, historian, and suffragist.

Leighton, Baldwyn (1836–97), 8th bart.; m., 1864, Eleanor Leicester, b. Warren (1841–1914); they had four children: Catherine Barbara (1864–1952), Bryan (1868–1919), Meriel Gundrede (1872–1947), and Cuthbert (1877–1954).

Lothian, Constance Harriet Mahonesa, b. Chetwynd-Talbot (1836–1901), marchioness of, widow of William Schomberg Robert Kerr (1832–70), 8th marquess of Lothian. She lived at Blickling Hall, Norfolk, and Newbattle Abbey, Midlothian. Both had been friends of the Carlyles; see 38:120–21JWC to LLO, 21 [July 1862]. Her sisters were Lady Adelaide Brownlow (see Alford, above) and Lady Gertrude Frances Chetwynd-Talbot (1840–1906); their mother, an invalid who usually lived with one of her das., was Lady Sarah Elizabeth Chetwynd-Talbot, b. Beresford (1807–84), countess of Shrewsbury, widow (m. 1828) of Henry John Chetwynd-Talbot (1803–68), 18th earl of Shrewsbury.

Lytton, Edward George Earle Lytton Bulwer Lytton (1803–18 Jan. 73; ODNB), 1st Baron Lytton, writer and politician, m., 1827, Rosina Anne Doyle, b. Wheeler (1802–82; ODNB); in the marital disputes between Sir Edward and his wife, TC’s and JWC’s sympathy tended to be with Lady Rosina; see 11:87–88TC to JAC, [15] April 1839, and later letters. Their son was Edward Robert Bulwer-Lytton (1831–91; ODNB), 2d Baron, 1st earl of Lytton(1880), diplomat and poet, m., 1864, Edith, b. Villiers (1841–1936; ODNB). The family home was Knebworth House, Hertfordshire.
Marshall, James (1805–81), originally from Ayrshire, secretary to the grand duke and duchess of Weimar; see 30:28130:biographical notes.

Masson, David (1822–1907; ODNB; see 16:312JWC to TC, 24 July 1843), writer and editor, prof. of rhetoric and English lit., Edinburgh Univ., 1865–95. He m., 1853, Emily Rosaline, b. Orme (1835–1915); they had a son, David Orme (1858–1937; ODNB), and three das, Flora (1856–1937), Helen (b. 1864), and Rosaline (1867–1947); they lived at 10 Regent Terr., Edinburgh. He was also ed. of Macmillan’s Magazine 1859–68.
Mazzini, Giuseppe (1805–10 March 72; see 11:225TC to JSM, 6 Dec. 1839), Italian revolutionary, friend of the Carlyles since the late 1830s.

Mill, John Stuart (1806–7 May 73; ODNB), utilitarian philosopher and economist; m., 1851, Harriet Taylor, b. Hardy (1807–58; ODNB), feminist and political radical, who strongly influenced his thinking. Mill met TC in Sept. 1831 (see 5:398TC to JWC, 4 Sep. 1831); they remained on friendly terms even after the MS of vol. 1 of The French Revolution was burned while in Mill’s keeping (see 8:66–68TC to JFR, 7 March 1835), but later became estranged because of many differences in temperament and attitudes to social questions; Mill also believed that TC and other friends disapproved of his marriage. Liberal M.P. for Westminster 1865–68. His sister was Harriet Isabella Mill (1812–97).
Milnes; see Houghton.

Neuberg, Joseph (1806–67; see 11:231TC to JFR, [18 Dec. 1839]), a German Jewish businessman, naturalized British 1845, and retired 1849; m., 1841, Marian (d. 1848; see 23:77JWC to JN, 22 July 1848). He was introduced to TC, whom he had long admired, by Emerson, 1848; helped TC as an unpaid sec., translated his work into German, and twice accompanied him on visits to Germany (1852 and 1858). He lived at Roslyn Park, Hampstead, with his widowed sister, Rosetta (or Rosette) Frankau (ca. 1816–98), and her children; see 45:227–2845:biographical notes.

Norton, Charles Eliot (1827–1908), author, journalist, and Harvard Coll. prof. of Art 1875–98. He m., 1862, Susan Ridley, b. Sedgwick (1838–17 Feb. 72), they had six children: Eliot (1863–1932), Sarah (Sally) (1864–1922), Elizabeth Lily (b. 1866), Rupert (1867–1914), Margaret (1870–1947), and Richard (1872–1918). Norton’s mother was Catherine, b. Eliot (1793–1879), and his sisters were Louisa (b. 1823) (married by 1872), Catherine Jane (1824–79), and Grace (1834–1926). He and his family spent 1868–73 in Europe, mostly in London, staying at 33 Cleveland Square, where he became friendly with TC.

Oliphant, Margaret Oliphant, b. Wilson (1828–97; ODNB), prolific novelist, biographer, reviewer, and misc. writer; friend of JWC’s since 1860; see 37:62JWC to MO, ; she lived at 6 Clarence Cres., Windsor. She had two surviving children, Cyril Francis (Tids) (1856–90), and Francis Romano (Cecco) (1859–94).

Otthenin, Jean, b. Johnston (ca. 1800–1870; see 42:23642:biographical notes), old school friend of TC, who had lived for several years with her das., Margaret and Irma (1838–97), at 33 Northumberland St., Edinburgh. Irma m., 1867, Jean Charles Louis Eugène Durival (1811–92), and lived in Vassy, Haute Marne, France, where her mother and sister joined her.
Paterson; see Erskine.
Quain, Richard (1816–98; ODNB), physician; see 45:101TC to JF, [2 March 1868]. He had attended both Lord Ashburton and JWC.

Reichenbach, Oskar von (1815–93), Silesian landowner, liberal deputy to the Frankfurt parliament 1848–49, exiled to London in 1850. His wife was Friederike, b. Plattnauer (b. 1817), sister of Richard Eduard Plattnauer (b. 1814; see 41:23441:biographical notes), political refugee from Prussia (see 22:10JWC to HW, 5 July 1847), who suffered periods of insanity; old friends of the Carlyles. Their children were Elizabeth (b. 1843), Hedwig (Hetty) (1844–92), and Oskar (b. 1845). They had immigrated to the U.S. in 1853 and had moved back to London sometime after 1865; they lived at 5 Carlisle Ter., Kensington.

Robson, Charles (1805–76), TC’s printer since 1837; initially of Robson, Levey, & Franklyn, printers, 23 Gt. New St., Fetter Lane, which went bankrupt early 1864. He then went into partnership with one or both sons, John (b. ca. 1837) and Christopher (b. 1843), forming Robson & Son, Great Northern Printing Works, St. Pancras Rd.

Ruskin, John (1819–1900; ODNB), author, artist, and social reformer; m., 1848, Euphemia Chalmers, b. Gray (1828–97); marriage annulled 1854 (she then m., 1855, John Everett Millais [1829–96; ODNB], artist). Ruskin lived in the family home at 163 Denmark Hill, S London, with his mother, Margaret, b. Cock (1781–5 Dec. 1871). After her death he moved to Brantwood, Coniston, Cumberland, in 1872. His father, John James Ruskin (1785–1864), was a wine merchant. His cousin Joan, b. Agnew (1846–1924), m., 20 April 1871, the artist Arthur Severn (1842–1931).

Russell, Mary, b. Dobbie (1802–75; see 6:145TC to MN, 8 April 1832), close friend of JWC and her mother. She m., 1829, Dr. James Russell (ca. 1796–1878); they had moved to Holmhill, nr. Thornhill, by Oct. 1859.

Scott, Janet (Jenny), b. Carlyle (1843–74), youngest child of James and Isabella Carlyle; m., 1864, William Scott (b. ca. 1829), draper; they lived at 27 Bradford St., Birmingham; they had a son, John James Carlyle (b. 1865), and two das., Isabella (b. late 1860s) and Jessie Beattie (b. May/June 1870).
Severn; see Ruskin.

Spedding, Thomas Story (1800–1870; see 10:32TC to TSS, 17 Feb. 1838), m., 1839, Frances Elizabeth (previously called Emily in error), b. Headlam (1811–96); their children were Margaret Emily (1842–73), Frances Ellen (1843–1900), Maria Isabella (d. in infancy 1845), Henry Anthony (1846–87), and Mildred Eyre (1848–1918). They lived at Mirehouse, nr. Keswick, Cumberland. A lawyer, he devoted his life to local interests in Cumberland. He and his brother James Spedding (1808–81; ODNB; see 8:196JWC to JCA, [Aug. 1835], and 19:205JWC to TC, 20 Sep. 1845), literary editor and biographer, known as “Lord Bacon,” had been friends of TC’s since the late 1830s. James lived in Westbourne Grove, London.

Stanley, Henrietta Maria, b. Dillon (1807–95; ODNB), m., 1826, Edward John (1802–1869; ODNB; see 12:59TC to JAC, 27 Feb. 1840), 2d Baron Stanley of Alderley, Whig politician; they lived at Alderley Park, Cheshire, and 40 Dover St., London. Both were friends of the Carlyles. They had nine surviving children including Henrietta Blanche (1829–1921), 5th countess of Airlie; Maude (1833–1915; ODNB), women’s welfare activist; John Constantine (1837–78), soldier, m., 15 Aug. 1871, Susan Mary Elizabeth Stewart-Mackenzie (d. 1931), niece of Lady Ashburton; Edward Lyulph (1839–1925; ODNB), educational theorist, m., 6 Feb. 1873, Mary Katherine, b. Bell (d. 1929), their first child was Henrietta (1874–1956); Katharine Louisa (1842–74; ODNB), Viscountess, radical and suffragist, m., 1864, John Russell (1842–76; ODNB), Viscount Amberley; and Rosalind Frances (1845–1921; ODNB), women’s rights and temperance activist, m., 1864, George James Howard (1843–1911; ODNB), artist and politician. See also 45:222 and 229–30.

Stephen, James Fitzjames (1829–94; ODNB; see 41:24JWC to TC, [14 Sep. 1864]), judge and writer, m., 1855, Mary Richenda, b. Cunningham (1829–1912); they had eight children: Katharine (1856–1924), Herbert (1857–1932), James Kenneth (1859–92), Harry Lushington (1860–1945), Helen (1862–1908), Margaret Emily (b. ca. 1862), Rosamond (1868–1951), and Dorothea (1872–1865). Their London home was at 4 Cornwall Gds., Queen’s Gate.

Sterling, Sir Anthony Coningham (1805–1 March 71; ODNB; see 9:103TC to JAC, 2 Dec. 1836, and later vols.), soldier; m., 1829, Charlotte, b. Baird (d. 1863), who suffered attacks of insanity and was jealous of JWC (see 18:266–67JWC to HW, [12 Nov. 1844], and 19:9JWC to HW, [9 Jan. 1845]); he lived at 3 South Pl., Knightsbridge. His brother John (1806–44; ODNB), writer, had been a particular friend of TC’s; see CL vols. 8–18 and Carlyle’s Life of Sterling (1851); his surviving children were Edward Coningham (1831–77); Julia Maria (1836–1910); John Barton (1840–1926), m., 1863, Caroline Matilda, b. Salusbury-Trelawny (1842–1917); and Hester Isabella (1843–1908).

Stewart, Margaret, b. Austin (1831–74), da. of Mary and James Austin, m., 1859, Thomas Stewart (1832–69), farmer from Hollybush, now living at Ernhirst (Ironhirst), about 5½ mi. (9 km.) SW of Dumfries; see 38:19TC to JAC, 1 Dec. 1861; they had a da., Mary (b. ca. 1861), and four sons, William (b. 1863), James (b. 1864), Hugh (b. 1866, dead by April 1868), and Thomas (b. 1869). Thomas Stewart’s brothers were Hugh (b. ca. 1826), James (b. ca. 1831), and John (b. ca. 1839).
Stirling, Christian; see Erskine.
Stirling, Susan, b. Hunter (1799–1877; see 8:159–60 JWC to SS, [June or July? 1835]), m., 1837, James Stirling (1802–76), civil engineer, living at 11 Hill St., Edinburgh.

Strachey, Sir John (1823–1907; ODNB), administrator in India, son of Edward Strachey (1774–1832; ODNB), East India Company diplomat and judge, and his wife, m. 1808, Julia Woodburn, b. Kirkpatrick (1790–1846); the family had been friends of TC’s since the 1820s; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 283–84.

Tait, Robert Scott (1816–97), portrait painter and pioneer photographer; friend of the Carlyles since 1853, he painted TC (see 31:84TC to AGI, 6 May 1856), and A Chelsea Interior (see 33:197JWC to MR, 29 March [1858]), as well as taking photographs of both Carlyles.

Taylor, Clementia, b. Doughty (1810–1908; ODNB), women’s activist, m., 1842, Peter Alfred Taylor (1819–91; ODNB), politician and radical, M.P. for Leicester 1862–84. They had been close friends of Mazzini, and were involved in many radical causes from anti-slavery to women’s suffrage. The Taylors’ home at Aubrey House, Kensington, became a center for radical movements, and in 1869 they opened the Aubrey Institute, to give young men and women the opportunity of rectifying a deficient education. In 1873 they moved to Brighton because of Peter Taylor’s ill health.
Tennyson, Alfred (1809–92; ODNB), poet; poet laureate 1850–92; m., 1850, Emily Sarah, b. Sellwood (1813–96); friends of the Carlyles since the early 1840s.
Turgenev, Ivan (1818–83), Russian novelist and dramatist, whom TC first met in 1857; see 32:157TC to HT, 4 June 1857.
Twisleton, Edward Turner Boyd (1809–74; ODNB), civil servant, longtime friend of the Carlyles; see 43:27843:biographical notes.

Tyndall, John (1820–93; ODNB), physicist, prof. of natural philosophy at the Royal Institution, Albemarle St., London, from 1853; TC’s admirer and friend from the mid-1850s; see 31:1–2TC to JF, 2 Jan. 1856.

Venturi, Emilie (ca. 1819–93; ODNB), da. of William Henry Ashurst (ca. 1791–1855; ODNB; portrait painter), supporter of Italian independence and campaigner for womens rights; unhappily m. to Sydney Hawkes, whom she divorced 1861; see 30:199JWC’s Journal, 21 Oct. 1855, and 23527 March 1856. She m., 1861, Carlo Venturi (ca. 1830–66). A strong supporter of Giuseppe Mazzini, and the Young Italy movement, she published various English editions of his writings and Joseph Mazzini: A Memoir (1875).
Victoria (1819–1901; ODNB), queen of Great Britain and Ireland 1837–1901; m., 1840, Albert (1819–61; ODNB), prince consort.
Ward, Charles Augustus (1828–1914), vintner, author, antiquarian, and bookseller; see 45:230–3145:biographical notes.

Warren, Sarah (b. ca. 1812 in Norfolk), a widow with adult children (see 41:96JWC to MR, [17 Nov. 1864]), cook and housekeeper at Cheyne Row from Nov. 1864 until at least 1875. Mrs. Warren was previously wrongly identified as Eliza Warren (ca. 1816–1905) in vols. 41 and 42.
Watt; see John A. Carlyle.

Wellmer, Meta (1826–89; see 43:21TC to MEW, 24 Oct. 1865, and 45:207MAI to MEW, 3 Dec. 1868), German writer, teacher, feminist, vegetarian, and spiritualist. Her publications included Deutsche Erzieherinnen und deren Wirkungskreis [German Educators and their Sphere of Influence] (Leipzig, 1877).

Welsh, Alexander (Alick) (b. 1816), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John; m., ca. 1849, Sophy, b. Martin (b. ca. 1824). Their children were John (Jackie) (ca. 1853–64), Isabella Helen (b. 1856; see 31:201JWC to TC, [29 Aug. 1856), Margaret (b. 1858), and Jean (b. 1860); they lived at Sandown Park, Wavertree, Liverpool.

Welsh, Ann (1799–1877), Elizabeth (1792–1877), and Grace (1801–67), JWC’s paternal aunts (see 14:67TC to JWC, 11 March 1842, and 16:219JWC to JW, 26 June 1843), living at Craigen Villa, Morningside, Edinburgh.
Welsh, Grace, b. Welsh (1782–1842), JWC’s mother; m., 1800, John Welsh (1776–1819; see 1:202–3JBW to EWE, 5 Oct. 1819), JWC’s father, doctor in Haddington.

Welsh, John (1785–1853; see 28:286–87JWC to HW, [12 Oct. 1853), JWC’s maternal uncle, brass and copper founder, who had lived at 20 Maryland St., Liverpool; m., 1808, Mary, b. Colliver (d. 1838; see 10:200TC to AC, 15 Oct. 1883 ); their children were Helen
(ca. 1813–53); Walter; Alexander; Jeannie (Babbie) (1818–95), m., 1853, Andrew Chrystal (ca. 1811–83), wine merchant from Glasgow, they had a da., Mary (1857–1937; see 40:226–2740:biographical notes); John (1820–60); Margaret; and Mary.

Welsh, Margaret (Maggie) (1821–75), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; lived in Auchtertool with her brother Walter; was JWC’s nurse, Dec. 1863–May 1864; she came to Chelsea to look after TC after JWC’s death, late April–mid- Aug. 1866, and June–Oct. 1867.

Welsh, Mary (1823–79), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; usually lived in Auchtertool with her brother Walter, but had been living in the Perth Asylum since 1869 to try to recover from her opium addiction.

Welsh, Rev. Walter (1815–1879; see 16:12JWC to JW, [8 Jan. 1843]), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John; minister at Auchtertool, Fife, since 1842. His sisters Margaret (Maggie) and Mary usually lived with him.

Wilson, Thomas (b. 1811; see 22:xiii22:introduction, and 26:304), scholar, old friend of TC’s, now teaching in Weimar; see 40:23540:biographical notes, and 47:73–74TC to JTY, 28 Sep. 1870. He m., 1861, a German wife, unidentified further.

Woolner, Thomas (1825–92; ODNB; see 26:37TC to TWO, [21 Feb. 1851], and 29:176–77TC to LA, 20 Oct. 1854), sculptor and poet; he lived at 29 Welbeck St., London. He m., 1864, Alice Gertrude, b. Waugh (b. 1845); they had six children, including Amy (b. 1865), Hugh (1866–1925), and Geoffrey (1867–82).
